Title: Marx's theory of revolution.
Abstract: The present thesis is a study of the origins and development of Marx's theory of revolution, setting it in its historical context and relating it to Marx's practical activity as editor, revolutionary and spokesman for the general European working-class and socialist movement in the 19th century. From a detailed examination of Marx's writings it will be seen that proceeding from the standpoint of Young Hegelian Idealism, Marx came partly from his reading but more importantly from his involvement with `lq material interests (I), begun as editor of the Rheinische Zeitung of 1842-3, to an analysis of the modern individualistic and competitive system of industrial capitalism, and further from his experience of the Parisian working-class and the revolt of the Silesian weavers in 1844 to the conclusion that the industrial proletariat had the potential to overthrow this system and replace it with a harmonious, co-operative society with neither private property, social classes nor state. In examining too, the ideas and strategies of other revolutionary thinkers the specific features of Marx's revolutionary concept will be brought into sharper focus- in particular its fundamentally democratic character. In this respect it will be seen that the crucial watch-word formulated by Marx for The International Working Men's Association in 1871 that `lq the emancipation of the working classes must be conquered by the working classes themselves (2) can well serve as the leit-motiv of Marx's entire revolutionary career, and that this watch-word is directly linked to the theoretical conclusions of both The German Ideology and The Theses on Feuerbach in 1845-6, that equal weight must be given to `lq men and `lq circumstances in the making of history and that `lq the coincidence of the changing of circumstances and of human activity can be conceived and rationally understood only as revolutionising practice . (3)(1) Preface to a Contribution to the Critique of Political Economy, Lawrence and Wishart, London, 1971, p. 19.(2) Preamble to the General Rules of The International Working Men's Association, Selected Works, Vol II, Progress Publishers, Moscow, 1973, p. 19.(3) The German Ideology, Vol I, Feuerbach, Progress Publishers, Moscow, 1965, p. 51; Theses on Feuerbach (Thesis III), ibid. Addenda, p. 66.

Title: Friendly patriotism: british quakerism and the imperial nation, 1890-1910
Abstract: In the arc of the years 1890 to 1910, British Quakers wrestled almost continually and inconclusively over the question of the Society of Friends' right relationship to the State, to the Empire, to politics, and to government. Conflicting pressures toward respectability and radicalism repeatedly tested the Society's loyalties to the Imperial nation and to its heritage of Dissent. It is in this period of what came to be known as the 'Quaker Renaissance' that I have located the emergence of what I call 'Friendly patriotism' - a complex set of attitudes by which public - spirited Quakers attempted to straddle multiple identities. Radical Dissenter and Evangelical Nonconformist; Christian Prophet and Subject of Empire - the 'Friendly patriot' of the period struggled to be true to sometimes wildly divergent traditions and impulses in his desire to embody an ideal of 'Christian citizenship'. No longer a 'Peculiar People', no longer relegated to a social or economic periphery, Quakers had been self-consciously integrating themselves into the mainstream of British life with enviable speed and success. At the close of the nineteenth century, the Society of Friends developed an acute sense of a special Quaker mission to improve the public culture of the day. What were perceived as the Society's unique spiritual and ethical testimonies were to become the essential ingredients of a national and international regeneration. The health of the Emprie rested, in part, with the capacity of civic-minded Friends to commit themselves to its care. Quakerism began to view itself not simply as being integrated into British public life, but integral to its further development. The welfare of the State became intimately linked to the effectiveness of Quaker participation in its political institutions. In this thesis, I have chosen to focus upon three of the most vivid expressions of the social and poltiical feeling within the Society of Friends which I have called 'Friendly patriotism'. The Quaker response to the Nonconformist campaign against the 1902 Education Act, the Quaker approach to international relations within the late nineteenth- and early twentieth-century European peace movement, and the Quaker crusade on behalf of Anglo-German friendship before the First World War revealed the Society's eagerness to interpret and re-interpret its extraordinary heritage of pacificsm and social responsibility in the light of the requirements of the new century. The outward turning of the Evangelical spirit, the firm conviction of Quakerism's unique message for both the churches and the governments of the world, and the profund belief in the Society of Friends' responsibility for the spiritual well-being of the Empire are reflected in each of these dimensions of the Society's life during the period. This work attempts to lift Quaker historiography out of the inevitable parochialism of 'in-house' denominational scholarship in which it has long been mired, and place a critical moment in the history of the Society of Friends within the context of a broader intellectual and cultural framework.

Title: History of the Panamanian novel
Abstract: Despite the ever-increasing attention given to the Spanish American novel, the novelistic traditions of some Spanish-speaking countries remain undocumented. One nation whose writers have been ignored by the international critical community is the Republic of Panama. Although Panama has produced many excellent novelists, isthmian authors continue to be relegated to marginal status. The reasons for this have less to do with the question of intrinsic worth than with other factors, such as limited access to mass audiences and the absence of a viable publishing industry. This dissertation presents a comprehensive historical survey of the Panamanian novel, and demonstrates that isthmian writers merit more consideration than they have heretofore received. The study begins with an overview of Panamanian history, in order to show the economic, social and political forces that have shaped isthmian culture. Then, the beginnings of the Spanish American novel are outlined in order to establish the context that gave rise to the first novelistic efforts--from 1849 to 1903--by Panamanian writers. From the 1920's onward, the Panamanian novelistic tradition began to gain momentum, initially serving as an expression of Modernism, but soon evolving (in the 1930's) into a vehicle for Criollist-oriented works predominantly imbued with Realist and Neo-Romantic elements. It will be demonstrated that Panama's regionalist movement, which maintained its vitality until the 1960's, possesses a rich thematic diversity, and is worthy of study not only for aesthetic reasons, but for its insights about the isthmus and its people. Panamanian Criollism explores rural and urban themes from a wide variety of perspectives, features historical novels depicting significant events in the country's past, and examines the impact of the Panama Canal on the nation via the "novela canalera." In the last several decades Panamanian novelists, while continuing to portray isthmian reality, have also embraced the cosmopolitan outlook and stylistic innovations associated with the more renowned exponents of contemporary Spanish American fiction. It will be shown that, like the Modernist and Criollist writers of previous generations, current Panamanian authors have also been denied the recognition due them, for their contributions have been substantial.

Title: Visions and revisions of the American landscape: Paintings and photographs of the Stieglitz Circle, 1924-1934
Abstract: It is commonplace, in art historical parlance, to cite photographer Alfred Stieglitz' New York gallery, "291", as the channel through which the most innovative European modes of representation were received in the United States in the years of the gallery's existence: 1905-1917. Emphasis has been placed on Stieglitz' role as the American importer and promoter of significant modern European masters. But Stieglitz played another, equally important, role during the "291" years, and even more prominently through his engagement with the Intimate Gallery (1925-29) and An American Place (1929-46), two later galleries which are the focus of this dissertation. It was these later "salons" that saw his most avid promotion of the American artists: Demuth, Dove, Hartley, Marin, O'Keefe and Strand, who became known as the "Stieglitz Circle". In fact, after the closing down of "291" in 1917, Stieglitz chose to exhibit, exclusively, the work of American artists. In addition to revising the misleading identification of Alfred Stieglitz exclusively with "291" ideals and accomplishments, this paper also seeks to correct the familiar assumption that it was not until the forties that a native art, international in ambitions, was created in America. Rather, in the decades following the First World War, the painters and photographers of the Stieglitz group invented unique idioms of pictorial representation which would eloquently and effectively express to a receptive, international public a specifically American aesthetic and social philosophy. The modes of representation they coined were propagated and legitimized by an on-going series of gallery exhibitions orchestrated by Stieglitz and supported by the coterie of artistic and cultural critics who comprised the inner circle. Indeed, during the post-war period, artists of the Stieglitz group introduced into the arena of image-making innovative landscape modes--as ambitious as those of any contemporary American or European movement--with which they both defined and celebrated their native land. Depictions of the American land became their forte, indeed their obsession. The specific nature and complex meanings of their urban and rural landscape images are analyzed in my paper.

Title: Women's campaigns against West German rearmament, 1949-1955
Abstract: This dissertation addresses the issue of West German rearmament and the widespread opposition to it between 1949 and 1955. The study examines women's involvements in the campaign against German remilitarization in particular since the percentage of women opposed to rearmament was considerably higher than that of men. Specifically, the dissertation focuses on two women's peace organizations during the Adenauer era: the German Section of the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom (WILPF), officially reestablished in 1949, and the West German Women's Peace Movement (WFFB), founded in 1952. The case-studies of the two women's organizations describe the difficulties and problems of non-parliamentary opposition groups in general and women's groups in particular. Problems addressed will include the women's motives for their involvement, their self-awareness, political activities, channels of communication, as well as their reaction to governmental accusations of being Communists. The study concludes with an analysis of the achievements and the set-backs of the women activists. In addition to examining internal reasons for the women's successes and failures, the study deals with the socio-political and economic conditions which prevailed during the period under consideration. In illuminating the responses of the Adenauer government toward the peace protesters, the study goes beyond being a description of women's peace activities. Rather, it analyzes the women's motives, goals, and programs in the context of postwar German social and political realities. Though the women failed to achieve their major goal of keeping the Federal Republic of Germany disarmed, they succeeded in setting examples and living lives which conformed to their political beliefs. The active women proved that powerful personal war and postwar experiences could help to overcome political apathy and transform many past fears of political action into energy for political action. In "daring more democracy" themselves, the activists contributed to a broader participation in the democratic process. Thus, these activists and their successors became a force in society.

Title: Jewish emigres and popular images of Jews in Japan
Abstract: This study explores the movement of people and ideas across national borders. Analysis, based upon interviews and examination of popular texts, focuses on individuals whose relocation is a result of dislocation, and on stereotypes fashioned in one culture and exploited and transformed in another. Interviews were conducted 1984-86 in Tokyo, Yokohama and Kobe with Jewish emigres whose presence in Japan is related to political events dating from the 1920's that blocked their lands of origin as places of residence or points of return. Representations of Jews in Japanese popular texts were culled from sources, including magazines, newspapers, novels and bestsellers, school textbooks, drama, television and comics, that span the period from the introduction of Western literature in Japan in the late 19th century to the 1980's. The Jew of popular Japanese literature is highly articulated, endowed with qualities that reveal ample evidence of a variety of absorbed Western ideas on Jews and a full palette of anti-Semitic stereotypes inspired by "The Merchant of Venice" and The Protocols of the Elders of Zion, as well as sympathetic renderings of Jewish diaspora and the Holocaust. It remains a mental universe, however, virtually unknown to most of the Jewish emigres in Japan, much less thought to be a matter of concern capable of affecting their action in Japan where Jewish cultural markers remain non-salient and operationally invisible. The Jewish emigres exist in Japan as Western foreigners who have occupied a rather privileged but politically powerless position, substantially different from that of Asians and minorities in Japan. The Japanese portrayal of Jews represents a metaphor of the West, and is deeply embedded in a search to define Japanese national identity and Japan's place in the world. The dissertation address the issue of statelessness, the idea of incorporation in a social arena that stresses homogeneity, and the problem of identity formation. It is argued that both the Jewish emigre in Japan and the Japanese construct of a Jewish stereotype are to be understood in the context of global historical, political and economic forces that determined their entry and operation in Japan.

Title: Such a contracted sphere: Some aspects of the writing of Australian history prior to 1900
Abstract: Students of Australians historiography generally fail to connect what has been written in the Twentieth Century with what came before. This thesis attempts to fill some part of this gap in Australian historiography by looking at the way in which some claimants to the name 'Australian' reconstructed the past during the Nineteenth Century. In particular, it demonstrates the development of traditions in, of influences on, and versions of, the interpretation of Australian history in the works of four Australian 'historians': William Charles Wentworth, John Dunmore Lang, John West, and George William Rusden. Wentworth's A Statistical, Historical and Political Description of the Colony of New South Wales..., is shown to arise out of the classical, legal and political sources of the time, and to affect future writing on the past by the establishment of a model of historiography. West's History of Tasmania is the first full-blown work of history on the colonial scene. As such, his history can be seen as one of the first links in the Liberal historiographical section which was to develop so strongly in the Twentieth Century, and is linked to some of the social movements that formed the 'liberal' politics of mid-Nineteenth Century Australia. In contrast, G. W. Rusden's History of Australia demonstrates both terminating and continuing strands in Australian historiography. His imperialist, romantic and commemorative historiography was part of the scene that the increasingly professionalised craft in Australia rejected, and yet, as the standard library work of the day, he was an important transmitter of developing historiographical mythologies still traceable today in the works of historians. The argument of this thesis is that there was a colonial historiography in Australia identifiable by its political usages and liberal-conservative preconceptions, that this historiography developed from and in competition with other literary forms and under the impact of international models, and that it laid the basis for the twentieth century studies in Australian history.

Title: Local knowledge and the politics of world order: Interpretation and international relations
Abstract: This dissertation is an exploration of the manner in which western cultures, and especially liberal American world order studies, has constituted normative discussions of world politics. By beginning with the assumption that all such discussions imply rather broad cultural interpretations, the object of the study is initially to reveal the implicit cultural biases in past western efforts to construct a normative vision of world politics. Beginning with the emergence of the law of nations in Grotius, Pufendorf and Wolff, through the enlightenment search for peace through international organization that found its clearest spokesperson in Kant and into the contemporary intellectual world order movement that includes Falk, Galtung and a host of others, it is the western conceived notion of the social contract with underlies all western thought on world politics and, in the opinion of this dissertation, leads it astray from being able to accomplish the normative goals espoused. To work toward correcting this situation ideas are then presented which might lead toward the purposeful inclusion of cultural interpretations into the study of world politics. This would make world order studies a near relative of contemporary interpretive anthropology especially in the re-evaluation of the importance of local knowledges. This reconstructive effort includes both an exploration of the times and types of historical re-interpretation of politically significant events/periods that will be required to create an interpretive world politics and a tentative exploration of the manner in which future world politics can be discussed from within the western cultures. The emphasis here is placed on an "ethic of toleration." It is the ultimate position of this dissertation that a continued place in world politics for western cultures can only come through such an ethic.

Title: Re-interpreting the Taiwan experience: State planning and the emergence of bureaucratic-authoritarian pluralism
Abstract: This is a study on the role of the KMT party-state in the post-war development of Taiwan. Specifically, it seeks to monitor the evolution of the state's role in socioeconomic management by examining the changes in the overall state-society relations. Two specific issues--the consumer protection movement and the breakthrough in trade opportunity with the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe--are analyzed in detail. They are intended to illustrate how an increasingly assertive, self-confident private sector has demanded greater participation in policy-making and, thus, more control of their own destiny. Despite a more aggressive private sector and recent measures to relax the once authoritarian control of the government, prospects for multi-party, pluralist democracy in Taiwan remain distant. Primarily because of (1) the Confucian cultural traditions, (2) Taiwan's peculiar international status, and (3) Taiwan's delicate relations with the PRC government on the mainland, a political system characterized by open confrontation and multi-party competition seems highly uninviting. It is in this respect that Bureaucratic-Authoritarian Pluralism (BAP), not pluralist democracy, will likely characterize the new type of state-society relations. Following martial law, civil liberty in Taiwan has been expanded appreciably. In spite of the relaxation of control, there are specific boundaries, as manifested in the newly-enacted National Security Law, which no one should violate. Therefore, in this "restricted" type of pluralism, dissenting views are permitted but not conciliated; and "deviated" behaviors are tolerated but not placated. The government still retains extensive control of social groups' behaviors and activities, particularly on some politically "sensitive" matters; and it reserves the right to discipline, or outright disband, groups that violate stipulated rules and regulations. In all, martial law might have been lifted, but the age of socio-political control continues in Taiwan by merely assuming a different form--where the style of leadership has changed from exclusionary to inclusive, the method of governing from domination to coordination, and the pattern of management from coercive to manipulative.

Title: The internal and external dimensions of the Portuguese revolution. (Volumes I and II)
Abstract: The internal and external dimensions of the Portuguese revolution provide a case study of the dynamics of regime transformation. Portugal, the oldest authoritarian regime in Europe, was transformed via a coup by junior military officers, whose role had previously been to maintain the regime. The Portuguese military is an interesting case study in regime transformation. It was the military that transformed the First Republic into the Estado Novo and that transformed the authoritarian regime into a democracy. The Portuguese transformation from authoritarianism to democracy was linked to the increasing alienation within the armed forces due to the colonial wars. The young officers of the Movement of the Armed Forces initiated the transformation with few, but specific, goals: decolonization, the dismantling of the authoritarian regime via a political and social revolution, and economic development. The pursuit of these goals unleashed a host of previously excluded forces. Political parties of every ideological configuration emerged from underground while others sprang anew in the postcoup chaos. Spontaneous demonstrations erupted all over Portugal. Previously excluded from participation, these elements vied for power in the postcoup settlement. The dynamics of this internal and external transformation affected the character and consequences of the new democratic regime. With the eruption of popular participation came the struggles for power among the political parties, particularly, the older, more organized parties of the traditional opposition: the Portuguese Communist party and the Socialist party. These parties vied for power and support internally from the flood of new participants, and externally from allies in their respective party organizations. By exploring the antecedents to this transformation, the authoritarian regime's policies, and the dynamics of the transformation process, it is possible to evaluate the causes and consequences of that transformation. The following thesis emerges: Portugal's transformation from an authoritarian regime is inextricably related to the shortcomings of the Estado Novo (New State), particularly the colonial and economic policies; the affront to the military's self-interest; and the costs and hardships of the unwinnable colonial wars. The second thesis emerges: this transformation unleashed a dynamic flood of popular participation in Portuguese politics at a critical time in superpower relations, which thrust the transformation from authoritarianism to democracy in Portugal into the much greater global transformation of East-West detente.

Title: Jean Henri Merle d'Aubigne: Historian of Christianity in an age of revolution
Abstract: This is the first critical study in English of the works of Jean Henri Merle d'Aubigne (1794-1872), a Genevan Reformed historian of Christianity. Its primary focus is Merle d'Aubigne's historiography, examining his development as a historian, his conception of history, his understanding of divine and human agency in history, and his historical writings, mainly on the Reformation. Merle d'Aubigne's writings appeared at a time when Protestant nations, in their search for stability after the French Revolution, were looking back to the sixteenth century as the foundation of modern society, and his interpretation of the Reformation proposed principles for a new relationship between church and state in the nineteenth century. Merle d'Aubigne's impact as a historian of Christianity was very extensive in his own day, especially on the English-speaking Evangelical movement. In all, he published over 85 works: historical narratives, discourses, articles, letters, and sermons. His most important work is Histoire de la Reformation du siezieme siecle, 5 vols. (Paris-Geneva, 1835-1853), but it was the English edition of this, entitled History of the Reformation in the Sixteenth Century, (Edinburgh, 1846-1853), that made him famous. The extent of Merle's influence can also be seen in his seminal role in the establishment of ecumenical societies, such as the Evangelical Alliance, and social welfare institutions, such as the international YMCA and Red Cross. As a historian Merle d'Aubigne incorporated the new scientific methods into his narratives, and his historical consciousness was refined by August Neander, under whom he studied at the University of Berlin. Since the Enlightenment, however, "sacred history" had been separated from "secular history," and orthodox Christian interpretations of history came into sharp conflict with modern science. Merle's greatest achievement was a detailed study of the Reformation that searched for the uniquely religious elements, the personal and emotional life of individuals, and the manifestations of divine providence. Through a Romantic style of writing he became immensely popular. He may be considered a transitional figure in Church historical writing because he promulgated a traditional orthodox interpretation of history clothed in new scientific garments.

Title: Resistance to state authority. A study in social ethics with special regard to radical criticism of the state in United States Catholicism after the Second Vatican Council
Abstract: Human well-being and Christian salvation are interrelated. Therefore the struggle for justice and peace is an essential part of the proclamation of the Christian faith. This 'political' duty leads to the question of how Christians should react to state authority. The New Testament and Catholic social teaching generally respect the institution of the state, consists in furthering the common good, which can only be done by universal cooperation. Obedience to state authority, even in democracies, must never be blind or 'deaf'. As history shows, democratic authorities can do and command immoral things, can commit crimes. Therefore resistance (in the extensive sense of the word) may be necessary in democracies. One form of such resistance that has a long tradition in the United States (Henry David Thoreau, Martin Luther King) and that is sometimes adequate and morally right is civil disobedience. During the Vietnam War a movement of predominantly Catholic peace activists, the so-called 'US Catholic Left', were the brothers Daniel and Philip Berrigan. After the end of the Vietnam War they have concentrated on resistance to nuclear weapons. The critics of the Berrigans are right in several aspects. Yet as 'prophetic shock minorities' (J. Maritain) the Berrigans point towards a central truth: If we do not turn around the arms race, we might commit global suicide.

Title: For a future that works: new movements for social and economic change.
Abstract: The thesis starts by identifying a global problematique, increasingly threatening human survival, which is composed of four great, interlinked problem areas: war, insecurity and militarism; the persistence of poverty; the denial of human rights; and environmental destruction. The conventional approaches to this four-fold crisis are analysed by a comparative discussion of the work of the three United Nations Commissions which were set up to deal with one aspect of it: the Brandt, Palme and Brundtland Commissions, with a focus on economic development, peace and security, and environment and development respectively. The thesis finds these Commissions' analyses partial and flawed and proceeds to discussion of the issues by examining the lives and work of individuals who and organisations which have been involved at the grassroots level, mobilising people and lobbying decision-makers, or devising and implementing concrete strategies of change. The thesis ranges widely over the issues concerned with chapters on peace and security, human rights, economic development, the environment, and human development. The conclusion of the thesis identifies the root causes of the crisis as Western scientism- and developmentalism, and the unfettered, inappropriate and irresponsible power of the nation-state. In specifically addressing each of these causes, the new movements for social and economic change are engaged in a process of democratisation, the success of which is by no means guaranteed but which is a prerequisite for long-term peace, human dignity and ecological sustainability.

Title: German socialism in british exile, 1840-1859
Abstract: Between 1840 and 1860 much of the development of early German socialism and social democracy occurred in emigrants' communities abroad, the most important of which was in London. This thesis examines the political activities, organisations and debates in this colony, which for many years also formed the social and intellectual context of Marx's ideas. The organisational centre for socialist exiles was the German Workers' Educational Association. Within German artisanal socialism, it became the single most important centre of ideological debate of the `utopian' Weitling's doctrines, of Marx's views, and of early socialist internationalism. After the failure of the 1848 revolution, the returning refugees fragmented into mutually hostile groups of socialists and non-socialist democrats. Many socialists, however, were also attracted by the uncompromising revolutionarism of the Blanquists, and when this began to clash with Marx's economic analysis, the main organisation of the socialists, the Communist League, split. The public image of exile politics, however, was dominated by the much larger factions of exiled democrats (around Gottfried Kinkel and Arnold Ruge), who are analysed here with respect to their attitude to socialist demands. In particular the larger section of the Communist League under August Willich co-operated closely with non-socialist democrats in order to promote a revolutionary revival at home, as well as dominating the Germans' relations to both Chartists and French exiles. On the whole, thus, the socialist movement was much broader and more tolerant of other groups than the previous scholarly concentration on Marx's politics alone would suggest. The mid-fifties have long been regarded as a period of decline in socialist development, but in London the Germans continued to be involved in propaganda and organisation. A new international association represented a wide variety of exiled socialists, ranging from Weitlingian communists to those straddling socialism and liberal democracy. The dissertation concludes with the renewed conflict between the socialists and democrats in the late 1850s, which was focussed intensively for the first time on the issue of national unification.

Title: Law and order in colonial Puerto Rico: a critical assessment of the criminal justice system, 1974 to 1984.
Abstract: The Law and Order project emerged in a particular period (1974-84) of the history of colonial Puerto Rico, when capital was re-structuring its production relations in the island, shifting from labour intensive to capital intensive production. This process resulted from the international crisis of capital accumulation during the early 1970s. This economic evolution had an impact over the economic model of development in Puerto Rico (the so-called "Bootstrap" model) which, due to capital restructuring, lost its most important feature: the modernizing element of the society which had provided a certain degree of wealth distribution and the basic needs of the working class and popular sectors. However, the effects on the population of this economic process were devastating, prompting many sectors of the labour movement to demonstrate against the economic situation. Since this period, the state has dealt with an increasing surplus population for whom the foreign capital investing in the island does not produce sufficient jobs. Unemployment has been on the increase ever since 1974 in Puerto Rico. Nonetheless, the impact of the crisis in the working class and popular sectors has been ameliorated by the boosting of financial funds from the metropolitan state. This thesis conducts a critical analysis of the law and order project initiated since 1974 by the colonial power bloc, constituted by the metropolitan bourgeoisie and a colonial bourgeoisie which is divided into two main fractions: a pro-annexation bourgeoisie, the Nuevo Progresistas and a pro-commonwealth bourgeoisie, the Populares, For the colonial bourgeoisie the law and order project has been sheltered under the cover of the "war on crime". Official statistics have been used ever since the economic crisis of 1974 to justify an increasing tendency of the state to strengthen the repressive mechanism. However, as I examine carefully, behind this policy against crime, the colonial state has been pursuing a more repressive attitude towards the surplus population that is increasing and becoming marginal to the productive process. Although both fractions of the colonial bourgeoisie have coincided with the particular agenda of law and order for the new times, they have also included the particular interests of their class project. In this sense during the political administration of the Nuevo Progresistas their law and order was expanded to the repression of political dissidents. This pattern, as I analyse, created the foundations of a crisis of authority for the power bloc. The repression of this fraction of the dominant bloc was extended to different social sectors in the colonial society. The hegemony of the dominant class was put into question in colonial Puerto Rico. Thus, it was necessary for the metropolitan state to intervene in the colonial society at the beginning of the 1980s. The U.S., in alliance with the Populares, redefined the law and order project, and tackled non-traditional areas of illegal behaviour such as corruption and police abuses of power. The importance of the intervention of the metropolitan power was that it defined the limits of the colonial bourgeoisie by altering the colonial order. Two theoretical frameworks have been used. First, historical materialism will provide the adequate instruments to explore the impact of the capital re-structuring in the island production relations and the effects this process had on the form adopted by the Commonwealth state and on the definition of law and order. Second, critical criminology, from the so-called political economy of crime, will complement the analysis when exploring the development of the criminal justice system of this Caribbean island. (DX79218)

Title: Tourism and its potential in Iran
Abstract: In Chapter II the significance of modern day tourism was considered both economically and socially. The tourist phenomenon plays a great part in the international movement of people and as I discussed in Chapter II now it almost comprises five per cent of the total world consumer expenditure. At a national level, tourism in many countries has been, if not the main, then one of the major activities and is playing a vital role in the earning of foreign currency and contributes greatly to many countries' Balance of Payments. Tourism can also be vital as a source of employment and helps to improve the country's infrastructure and facilities and can bring an injection of money into an area. It was also discussed in Chapter II that the more advanced and self sufficient the country then the less the need for imported goods and sevices; this makes the multiplier effect higher. The inflationary impact of tourism though is high and although in many countries it is a capital intensive industry it often has a low capital return which can induce governments, especially from the Third World, to seek outside investment, thereby making the industry less profitable to the country. One of the faults of many governmental agencies is that they tend to deal with tourism as if it were purely a sales product and perhaps ignore the social consequences that it may have upon the local population. These undesirable consequences may be: tourist saturation, under-use or over-use of facilities and the infrastructure, and the loss of national indentity, among many others. It was argued that the characteristics of the tourists, i.e. the number of tourists, the tourists' length of stay and racial characteristics etc. can determine the rate of social impact between them and the locals. There are also many variables connected with the destination area which determine the rate of social impact in the area; these are mainly: the economic development of the area, the degree of local involvement in tourism, and local culture etc. In Chapter III my main consideration was tourism planning and development and it was argued that because of misconceptions about the nature of tourism and its organisation many adverse socio-economic consequences were to be seen in many countries created by the development of the tourist industry. It was proposed that all tourism planning should be based on two classes of preliminary survey: a) detailed surveys of the characteristics of the area and its tourist resources. b) studies of future customers and market potential. With a formal and advanced planning programme tourism can bring substantial economic growth to the area with economic revitalisation, a higher standard of living, and preservation of the environment. In formulating a tourism planning programme in order to achieve the benefits mentioned above, concentration must be on how much foreign exchange is to be gained, what part tourism is to have in the national economy and how much the country is prepared to invest in tourism, and in what areas. It was also discussed that when drawing up a tourism planning programme consideration should be given to both the existing and the planned facilities, the capacity to serve a particular development and the range and nature of facilities to be provided. In order that the reader may have the background information in order to identify with one of my main areas of study in this paper, Iran, I gave, early in Chapter IV, a general analysis of tourism in the Third World and Islamic countries, this of course being vastly different from the tourism to be found in the West. Later, a general background was given on the culture of Iran and the Iranian economy, its agriculture and industry. This was done in order to give the reader a clear view of the country itself before talking of the tourism and lifestyle to be found there pre-revolution. In Chapter V it was argued that despite the low spending power of

Title: Imagining the "information society": The case of Taiwan
Abstract: Centring on information technology (IT), this thesis examines two broad but related areas of interests: ideological formations and material movements. Starting from a historical survey it contrasts two visions of 'information society' (IS), and then goes on to depict the social background from which these visions arise. It is found that since the 1960s the capitalist world system has been undergoing crisis, and it becomes especially obvious in the 1980s that IT has been playing a crucial role in restructuring capitalism. As such, the concept of IS and practical functions subsumed by IT have important implications for (semi-)peripheral countries . As one of the widely claimed economic 'miracles' Taiwan's recent developmental trajectory is particularly useful for realising how IT functions and how dominant ideas about 'IS' disseminate. Benefiting from selling IT, Taiwan's experience cannot be said to have constituted a successful story supporting the modernisation theory. Rather, the developmental process she has so far gone through fits the arguments of the world-system approach. Taiwan's quick rise to seize IT for expanding her economic base tells a very good example as how the international capital, the state, and the national capital cooperate and clash. In contrast, Taiwan's records of using IT for production, transmission or consumption are rather poor. This reflects her position in the world system in general, however, it is a necessary result considering that her economic structure is based on small business. On the side of ideological representations, this study confirms the dominant pattern of IT coverage in the popular media (newspapers). Though the newspapers have not yet produced a coherent articulation of different elements of the idea of 'IS', it relays uncritically the established (the government and the business) perspectives on IT and 'IS'. The protesting or suspicious opinions about them are therefore contained in marginal places like the environmental movements or expressed in science fictions.

Title: Los Garcia: Family strategies for migration in Mexico and the United States
Abstract: This dissertation examines the migration strategies used by the members of an extended Mexican family as they moved from the Sinaloa countryside to the California industrial labor market. The family used the step-migration pattern that took them from the rancho El Porvenir to the border town of Tecate, Baja California, and then to Santa Ana, California. A major theoretical position presented in this research is that migration, at least in the modern Mexican case, is undertaken by families rather than individuals. Decisions to migrate are made by the family as a corporate group. In this study, each adult member consulted with, and acted on behalf of, the other family members with regard to the social and economic consequences of migration. Family members remained in contact with each other throughout the total migration period which in this research covered a period of 45 years. The family first experienced migration when they moved from the Sinaloa highlands to work in the cash crop development in the Sinaloa coastal plain. Following an initial family member's move to the agricultural zone of which Tecate was the center, other members migrated to join the industrial labor force growing up around the town's newly organized maquiladora system. By participating in this system, they acquired new skills mostly in the electronic industry and became part of the dynamics of the border economy. Involvement in the maquiladoras resulted in opportunities for entering the international work force in California. Through all the several migration steps, the core family members and the new affinals who joined them continued to act as a unit. At the end of the migration process, they established a pattern of movement which found family members moving back and forth between the original plot in Sinaloa and the new households in Tecate and Santa Ana, with a tendency toward permanent residence in their destination places. Some members preferred to maintain their nuclear families in Sinaloa, and plan to return and live there permanently. The examination of these preferences suggests that this migratory pattern is a significant aspect of Mexican family coherence.

Title: The ascent of Boston's Jews, 1630-1918
Abstract: In January 1909, Jacob De Haas, the editor of the Boston Advocate, invited readers to respond to the question "What methods would tend most to unite the Jews?" He was undoubtedly discouraged by the answers. In Boston, commented one rabbi, "we may notice the distinct constituent elements of Jewry, different religions, different races, classes hopelessly out of social sympathy with one another, and far differing ideals of the necessary and the desirable." Other respondents were equally cynical about the chances for a group rapprochement. By the end of the First World War, however, Boston's Jews had reached common ground. A new spirit of cooperation was evident not only in the pages of the weekly Jewish newspaper, but also in the efforts of the community to aid European war victims, to work together for a Jewish state in Palestine, and to oppose the immigration restriction movement. This dissertation explains how the Jews of Boston overcame the obstacles they faced in becoming a self-assertive, and articulate ethnic community. Chapter one discusses the Puritans' attitude toward Jews, and the history of the Jews who lived in Boston during the colonial and early national periods. The second chapter analyzes the reasons why Jews abandoned their native lands, and where they settled in the city. The third chapter describes their economic ascent. The fourth chapter discusses Boston's autonomous Jewish charities, as well as the history of local branches of national and international Jewish philanthropic organizations. Chapter five analyzes the evolving religious practices in Boston's synagogues through a case study of Rabbi Solomon Schindler. Chapter six explains how Boston Jewry resolved the conflict between the duties of American citizenship and the demands of ethnic solidarity. An appendix with sixty-nine tables analyzes their voting behavior. In their arguments over Zionism, and in their gradual recognition that they formed a community with distinct political interests, Boston's Jews helped redefine the meaning of American ethnicity. By 1918, they had become "American Jews," who took equal pride in their ancient heritage and in their new citizenship.

Title: The politics of transition to socialism in Cuba and North Korea
Abstract: Both critics and defenders of socialism often regard socialism as the full negation of all capitalist social structures. However, a careful analysis of socialist practices in the Third World reveals that the construction of socialism depends not only on the pre-revolutionary structure, but also on the specific dynamics of the domestic and international opposition. A realistic understanding of socialism requires an examination of the interactions between domestic and international political forces and the socio-economic factors constraining this relationship. This comparative analysis of the transitionary processes in Cuba and north Korea during the period of 1959 to 1970 and 1945 to 1961, respectively, confirms the importance of these interactions in shaping socialist societies. Among the conditions favorable to the socialist transformations of both Cuba and north Korea were the large number of wage workers and landless peasants, the discrediting of the bourgeoisie for their collaboration with neo-colonial or colonial forces, the strong leftist sentiment among the masses, and the decision by anti-socialist forces to flee their country rather than remaining to fight. These factors enabled both regimes to avoid the repressive use of force and to develop a more humane socialism, despite the severe technical and financial losses inflicted by the exodus of the bourgeoisie. The legitimacy of the north Korean and Cuban regimes is based upon the role of Kim Il-Sung and Fidel Castro, respectively, in each revolutionary struggle. Their background in guerrilla movements contributed to the widening of their perspectives beyond narrow class-biased communism. In each country, power was then centralized to maintain unity against "imperialist" aggressions and to secure the power of the hegemonic leader and group. Both Cuba and north Korea experienced U.S. intervention, blockades, and a sudden isolation from the world capitalist system during their transitionary period. Although aid from socialist allies was received, Cuba was forced to reduce its revolutionary internationalism to secure Soviet aid, whereas north Korea succeeded in resisting Soviet interference through successful industrialization. Thus, a fair understanding of Third World socialism requires much more than a static conception of socialism. Instead, a study of the effect of historical constraints on the evolving vision of socialism is necessary in any study of Third World socialism.

Title: The dynamics of the settler state: A comparative study of Israel and South Africa
Abstract: This study compares Israel and South Africa in the context of their common origins as settler states. It seeks to avoid polemical treatment of the two nations and their relations. To this end a theoretical framework is established for the analysis of settler systems. A critical consideration is made of existing approaches--among them "fragmentation" theory, frontier theory, pluralism, and internal colonialism. The strengths of these are incorporated into a model which combines the concept of the articulation of modes of production with current theory on the peripheral capitalist state. The two cases are examined at three historical stages (early settlement, state consolidation, and the modern system) as well as from three analytical emphases (domestic political-economy, ideology, and global system influences). This approach allows the study to distinguish among the various impacts of the settlement process, e.g., the impact of the Afrikaner farmers on the "hunter-gatherer" Khoisan was distinctly different than that of British colonialism at the advent of the mining industry upon the "pastoral" Zulu kingdom. The emphasis on the articulation of the modes of production also takes into account the differing natures of the indigenous social systems. Another area of contrast which serves the analysis is between the exploitation of labor in South Africa and the desire of the dominant stream of Zionist movement in Palestine to pursue the policy of "Jewish labor." The study suggests that factors inherent in the settlement process led to the eclipse of the latter. More broadly this dissertation concludes that settlement processes may be richly explored for what they reveal about the nature of modern states.

Title: The urban informal economy and the state in Tanzania
Abstract: Most explanations for economic restructuring in Africa are concerned primarily with how such changes are the product of external pressures from the world economy and from international lending institutions like the International Monetary Fund and World Bank. This study focuses on the role of the informal economy in explaining some of the internal circumstances that allowed Tanzania to embark on a program of economic reform and austerity at a time when urban dwellers, in particular, were suffering enormous hardships. Their disengagement from the state and reliance on their own solutions helps explain why they did not always feel the full force of cutbacks in government expenditure. At the same time, people continued to resist policies that infringed on their ability to carry out informal income-generating activities through strategies of non-compliance. The Tanzanian state thus found itself attempting to mediate between conflicting internal and external pressures. In the late 1970s and 1980s the informal economy grew in Tanzania, as in other African countries, in response to deepening economic crisis. This growth resulted in major reversals in the direction of resource flows: away from the state towards private solutions to problems of income, security and social welfare; away from reliance on wage labor to reliance on informal incomes and farming; and a gradual shifting of migration patterns with increasing movement out of the city into the rural areas. Similarly, relations of obligation in the household were being transformed with new resource dependencies on women, children and the elderly, while only a decade earlier, most urban women had relied on men for income, children on their parents and the elderly on their adult children. This study adopts a societal-oriented approach in contrast to the prevalent state-centric emphasis of the study of African politics. Based on fieldwork carried out between 1987 and 1988, the research combined both quantitative and qualitative methods, involving informal interviews and formal surveys of workers and small-scale entrepreneurs in addition to discussions with Party and Government leaders at all levels.

Title: Dynamic simulation model of groundwater movement in the vadose zone using the percolation process
Abstract: This thesis is an investigation of the use of the percolation process in simulating groundwater movement in unsaturated soil conditions. It is felt that the resulting product will be a useful tool in the design process of landscape architecture. The product of this thesis is the result of a collaboration among people of different disciplines. The underlying theme lies in the belief that the development of new technology may help to resolve some of the problems created in the past. This technology however, must be accompanied by a full understanding of the social, political and economic consequences. The work has been divided into three chapters, the first is an overview of global concerns. It is meant to establish the contextual position of the research, and offer a philosophical base. The second deals strictly with the groundwater system as object of study. The third chapter reveals the proposed model and outcome of the study. Future additional studies are suggested for the elaboration of the model. The illustrations are intended as a visual introduction to the main arguments confronted in the thesis. They were not created to be subservient to the text but to stand on their own terms. (Abstract shortened by UMI.)

Title: The 'Anschluss'-policy of Otto Bauer, 1918-1919: Paradigm of a conflict of theory and practice
Abstract: The dissertation explores the annexation policy of Otto Bauer in 1918-19 in theory and practice. The first three chapters are a description of Bauer's nationalism theory concerning the dissolution of the multinational Habsburg empire, mainly from emphasising its German nationalistic contents and the later formulation of an 'annexation theory' in 1917-18. Chapter IV discusses the enforcement of the 'annexation theory' in the Social Democratic Party's program by Bauer in autumn 1918 and the inclusion in the program of the governments of the young Republic of Austria, the development of a concept to transform it into political reality (i.e. negotiations, participation on the German constitutional assembly of Weimar, Ludo Moritz Hartmann's activities, propaganda, etc.) and the position of the German government in connection with the initiatives of Austria (i.e. invasion in November 1918 in Tyrol and Salzburg, Solf's understanding of German foreign policy, the long term perspective of 'Anschlusz' in Berlin's view, etc.). Chapter V deals with the requirement, the preparation and the realisation of Berlin's negotiations in February and March 1919. The subjects, the commissions of Otto Bauer and Ulrich Brockdorff-Rantzau are discussed. The final chapter describes the international connection of Bauer's 'annexation policy' in 1919, the reaction of Entente governments to the initiative of the Austrian Secretary of State, its consequences for the peace negotiations in Paris and, at last, the failure of this early 'annexation movement'.

Title: TCO and the women, 1944-1974. A study of the labour market policy of the Central Organization of Salaried Employees (TCO) and the Swedish Union of Clerical and Technical Employees in Industry (SIF) and their treatment of the principle of equal wages for equal work
Abstract: The central point of this study concerns the question to what degree the principle of equal wages for women and men met with sympathy in the salaried employees movement. This question has also been reflected in parliamentary debates and through the Swedish government's contacts with the International Labour Organization (ILO) in Geneva. Some of the TCO's board members were members of the parliament as well and participated in wage policy debates. TCO was, in addition, a referral authority on various questions that were treated on the political level. The question of equal wages has been treated from a perspective of conflict. One of the working hypotheses has been that women not only meet resistance from employers, but also from men in the labour market. There is a conflict between the sexes when salaries and careers are concerned, and this opposition is expressed in the union representatives' actions or lack of actions. In the trade union debate it is clear that equal wages for equal work was considered to be established in limited areas during the period 1944-1974. Teachers within the state area were perhaps the group that most nearly approached this vision. In the debate that went on within SIF no examples that the principle was implemented have been given, but the women's relative share of the men's wages increased. The general hiring policies within the public sector were less discriminating than those within the private area. Neither within the public nor the private sector did women succeed in reaching equality with men in regard to the possibility of entering various posts and, especially, qualified ones. Some of the explanations for this discrimination might be that women were not treated equally with men in the wage agreements and that the inequality was institutionalized in the negotiation system. On the political level the "Swedish Model" was used as an excuse for not acting. Discrimination was sometimes openly expressed in the trade union representatives' speeches and in their referrals to the government on questions of social policy. Another sub-explanation is the women's weak representation in the white-collar trade union boards on different levels. In this regard the present study is a contribution to earlier institutional research showing that women can be more strongly represented in the beginning of an organization's life. (Abstract shortened by UMI.)

Title: The inner reform of Seville between 1940 and 1959
Abstract: The inner reform of Seville in the decade following the Spanish Civil War is the main subject of this doctoral thesis. The forties and fifties in Spain, even though they are frequently considered entirely as an age of economic and social post-civil-war crisis and lack of interest in urban changes, show, at least, two well-differentiated moments: the forties and the beginning of the fifties, the first stage, represent all the negative aspects of a society subdued by the hard conditions involved in the Civil War; the late fifties, on the other hand, meant a slow but determined tendency toward change, in which economic recovery occurred along with an increasing international acceptance of the Spanish dictatorship's political establishment. Regarding urban planning activity, all the previous issues result in two completely different movements: a big in-migration in the first of the above explained periods, when all urban problems became more and more difficult, and the beginning of growth in the large Spanish cities, in the the second one. Seville also shows some unique aspects that imply a more critical situation than other Spanish cities: a fast demographic increase, especially due to in-migration of rural origin and difficult conditions inherited from the municipal bankruptcy in the year 1934, after the 1929 Iberoamerican Exhibition. Anyway, this age cannot be considered as a period without interest in Seville. The forties are frustrating years for the municipal urban planning policy, although not lacking, because of it, expansion and improvement proposals, in fact, the first general planning in town appears in 1946; the great affluence of in-migrants implies a continuous renovation in the town houses to accommodate the increasing numbers of in-migrating people. All of the points mentioned above mean a large number of reforms: new divisions of the inner space of houses to increase their lodging capacity, adding new floors to the buildings and other similar operations. The fifties, above all in the second part, show signs of change: although inner reform projects are rarely completed, they are performed in great part. This doctoral thesis not only analyses and organises the available information about the inner transformation of Seville in order to understand it correctly, but also shows the social context in which those changes are made and the way the inner reform influenced all the urban protagonists: the Town Council, other public institutions, building companies, building owners and tenants.

Title: The disarmament-development linkage
Abstract: The purpose of this study is to explore the linkage of disarmament and development. The linkage has progressively evolved through resolutions at the United Nations since its founding in 1945. It has become a major variable in the establishment of the New International Economic Order (NIEO). The philosophy behind the link is one of redistribution of wealth and power. The movement toward general and complete disarmament, as proposed by the United Nations, should accordingly result in freeing of money which should then be rerouted to development of the Third World. The proposed result is seen to promote social and economic equality, and help eliminate the gap between the North and the South. The accomplishment of general and complete disarmament would end the arms race and dissolve East-West tensions. Thus, this link would create world peace. Critical observations are needed for a closer examination of the disarmament - development linkage. Also, an understanding of the underlying philosophy of the link is looked at from a Christian worldview.

Title: Barefoot research and tribune of reason: An analysis of the textual corpus of peace research in Scandinavia, 1959-1986
Abstract: As a field of research with its own institutional basis, peace research is largely an outgrowth of the post-World War II era. In Scandinavia it started up during the Cold War years, but developed primarily in the controversial atmosphere created by the Vietnam war, the process of decolonialization and the growing awareness about underdevelopment and international dependencies. With a point of departure in philosophical hermeneutics, the study gives an account of the three decades of peace research in Scandinavia by inquiring about the research tradition through which this corpus of research is connected with the more general movement of social science. Peace research in Scandinavia, mediated as text, is reconstructed in the thematic unity of semantic paradigms in the text, and, as another methodical level in the study, brought up in its structure of methodological tradition. The textual corpus of peace research in Scandinavia which outlines the scope of the study consists of approximately seven hundred publications, written by thirty-one scholars.

Title: Renewal in triad. Investigations into the liturgical developments in Denmark (ca. 1800 until ca. 1950)
Abstract: Research on the developments within the liturgy of the Lutheran 'Folkekirke' (folk church) in Denmark during the Enlightenment and Romantic Era and the period following until ca. 1950 is obstructed when the scope of research is limited to the form of service and its theological background. Three complementary liturgical components are therefore included: texts of the Ordinary and Propers of the Mass and of other religious rites (part I), hymn text books (part II), and hymn singing (part III). In this manner, renewal is presented in the triad of ritual, poetry and music, known as liturgy. Just as form and content are inseparably bound, theologia and artes form a dynamic powerplay in people's attempts to attune the liturgical life in its broadest sense to life and society in general. In considering the so-called Liturgical Movement as an international and interconfessional phenomenon, Denmark plays a unique role, especially where the renewing power of hymn texts and hymn singing are concerned. In the area where the work of the poet, historian, pedagogue, politician and clergyman, N. F. S. Grundtvig (1783-1872), brought about liturgical and social renewal affecting the vast majority of the people, the power play differed essentially in comparison to the liturigical developments in the Danish overseas possessions (Iceland, the Faroe Islands and Greenland) and those in Norway, Sweden and Finland. These differences are handled in part IV.

Title: Contribution to the early history of the Botanical Garden of Madrid (1755-1820)
Abstract: In the first part of this work the initial workings of the Botanical Garden of Migas Calientes (seed greenhouse, hothouse, library, Botanical School, botanical classes, herb garden, inventory of plants and tools and expenses occasioned by the garden); personalities connected with the Botanical Garden; the Botanical Garden of Migas Calientes and the Royal Academy of Medicine in Madrid; and the scientific expeditions of the Botanical Garden of Migas Calientes, are analysed. Around 1780 the idea of moving the garden to a better site was being considered. The Botanical Garden was steadily going from bad to worse. The insufficient amount given to pay the expenses was the reason why advised repairs were not carried out. Furthermore, the distance would also have been an influential factor as well as the fact that the Garden was getting too small to hold the constantly growing number of plants. In 1781 the Botanical Garden was inaugurated. This inauguration could have gone down in history as just another of the many social reunions which formed a part of the palatial intellectual life in Madrid at that time, but this particular reunion had other ends, not only the collecting and cultivating of rare or medicinal plants, but also the search for a way of incorporating into the country the philosophy of an intellectual movement, one of whose basic principles was the understanding of nature. In the second part of the work presented the initial working of the Botanical Garden is analysed; the aims of the garden, the first rules which regulated the work, the herb rooms, the library, the teaching and other activities (the creation of a perfume factory and a school of plant imitation), the scientific relationship of the Botanical Garden (national and international), the seed house, the pharmacological studies of the Botanical Garden, the Botanical Garden and the botanic expeditions (the botanic expedition to New Spain, the Pacific expeditions and others), the Botanical Garden and the Royal Academy of Medicine in Madrid, the initial working of the professorship of Agriculture of the Botanical Garden, the publications of the Botanical Garden and the existing positions and posts in the Botanical Garden. The work ends with a brief outline of the personalities who were linked to the Botanical Garden of Prado. The research focuses on the period from 1755 to 1820.

Title: Possibilities for a pedagogy of peace and hope in a world of transformation
Abstract: The dissertation explores the meaning of a pedagogy for peace and hope in a community school in Kaskitayo, Alberta. The political, pedagogical, and autobiographical contexts informing the research are discussed in chapter I. Research questions are grouped under three themes: peace, pedagogy, and culture. In chapter II, the issues of peace and hope are dealt with historically through a literature review on the peace concept and the peace education movement. The comprehensiveness of the review is intended to bring about a holistic notion of what peace education has meant in the past and what newer understanding can emerge in the future. Chapter III deals with the issues of peace and hope methodologically. The chapter describes the search for a non-violent research methodology which implies semiological analysis and ethnographic inquiry. Practical application of a peaceful research model consists of semiotic consciousness, dialogic conversation, ethnographic observation, democratic participation, and the art of hermeneutics. The attempt to concretize the themes of peace and hope as process of human actions and praxis of ethics is examined. Chapter IV is the semiological study of four sets of video materials featuring Jubilee Public School as blueprints for peace education or good pedagogy. Research focus is put on how the media captures important spirits of Jubilee Public School as well as on how television freezes public understanding of what has been happening in the school. The semiological study attempts to present a radical questioning of the logic of modern epistemology, which in turn would suggest new ways to look at peace, pedagogy, and culture. Chapter V is an ethnography of Jubilee Public School. The life stories of the Jubilee community, the principal, custodian, teachers, volunteers, parents, and students are presented with the guiding question of "how school participants are brought more fully into life in Jubilee Public School?" I hope that the lived curriculum of the school participants sheds light on our understanding of some important pedagogical issues which include; personal peace, human rights, ethnicities and identities, multiculturalism, citizenship education, conflict resolution, structural violence, co-operative learning, social injustice, and education for global responsibility. The chapter highlights the possibilities and difficulties in implementing peace education in Canadian school systems. Chapter VI is reflection on the multiple meanings in undertaking the research. As a postscript, I return to the pattern of human life of some participants and contextualize their struggles of peace and hope as legitimate concerns in modern pedagogy and philosophy.

Title: Brazil built: modern architecture 1936-1942.
Abstract: In the 1940s and 1950s, architecture in Brazil gained unprecedented prestige in the world of Modern Architecture. This new architecture was praised by architects all over the world, who looked to Brazil as the country which had inherited the Modernism of the pre-war period in Europe, and which was initiating a new phase of the assimilation of cultural and climatic considerations into it. In 1930 a new Government, with Getúio Vargas as President, had taken power in Brazil. It had the dual aim of completely changing the economic and social structures of the country while retaining a Brazilian cultural identity. The `Brazilianization' of all things European was actively and officially encouraged in all branches of the Arts; for the young generation of architects, the architecture of the Modern Movement was seen as the corollary to the modernization of society. Within a few years they had completed a series of buildings in what came to be recognized as the `Brazilian Style'. There were three inter-related reasons which made this feat possible: firstly, the programmes of industrialization and modernization of the Vargas Government; secondly, a unquestioning belief in the aesthetic principles of Le Corbusier; and, thirdly, the advanced state of engineering in reinforced concrete in Brazil. This architecture remained virtually unrecognized both in Brazil and abroad until its discovery and proclamation by the Museum of Modern Art, New York, in 1943. The exhibition `Brazil Builds' was part of the Museum's policy of promoting European Modernism in the Arts. It was facilitated by the mixture of politics and artistic interests carried out by the Museum, firstly, under the New Deal, and later, with the approach of the World War II, under the Good Neighbour policies of the United States Government. The subsequent publication of the book Brazil Builds , beautifully produced and lavishly illustrated, brought immediate acclaim, both popular and professional, to Brazilian Modern architecture. In the United States and Britain, and after the war, in France and Italy, Brazilian Modernism was regarded as having successfully reconciled the abstract notions of International Modernism to regional requirements and cultural conditions. The major buildings - the Ministry of Education, the Brazilian Pavilion at the New York Worlds Fair 1939, the Brazilian Press Association, Santos Dumont Airport, the Pampulha complex - became widely known and highly influential. During the 1950s the `Brazilian Style' declined in creative energy until its swansong, Brasíia. It was rejected in Brazil, on the one hand, by the new military government of 1964 as being part of the liberal political inheritance of Vargas; and, on the other hand, ironically, by a new generation of architects as being a product of North American propaganda. It came to be reviled outside Brazil for its allegiance to the principles of Modernism, by then eclipsed by later developments. The contemporary re-evaluation of Modernism, and the restoration of democracy in Brazil, provide timely reasons to examine how the buildings came into being and around what concepts, how they came to be so highly regarded, and the changing reactions to them in Brazil and abroad. (DX98341)

Title: The caribbean-britain migration cycle: migrant goals, social networks and socio-economic structure
Abstract: This study of the post-war migration from the Caribbean island of Nevis to Britain argues that an appropriate framework for the analysis of labour migration would entail a two-tier system of macro-structural factors and micro-scale forces emphasising the way in which these political-economic forces interact to enable the migration process to occur. Social networks are the focus of a large part of the study and are seen to be a very important mechanism in this case of unrecruited labour migration. They operate on an entirely different scale to the powerful forces of global capitalism which makes use of the migrant labour, but play a vital role in organising the movement and sustaining the new arrivals in the destination. Essential requirements such as housing and employment information are obtained from this source. The research goes on to show that over time the migrants' reliance on this informal, small-scale structure decreases in favour of state and private institutional services. Throughout the study, the emphasis is on the continuous interaction between migrant agency and structure emphasising the variety of ways in which structure is incorporated into behaviour. The context of this research is threefold: the organisation of the migration in the Caribbean, the experience of labour migrants in urban Britain with a case study of Leicester, and the return movement to Nevis. It concludes that the micro-scale social networks played a vital role in the migration process, assisting with the provision of a smooth supply of labour to the core economies. They also sustained the sending communities which supplied the migrant labour force.

Title: Labourism and the disintegration of the postwar consensus: disunited trade union economic policy responses to public expenditure cuts, 1974-1979.
Abstract: The `fiscal crisis' of the mid-1970s was a crucial episode in the disintegration of the postwar consensus in British politics. This thesis considers the response of British trade unions to the Labour governments' public expenditure cuts during the period 1974-1979. The working hypothesis was that there was serious division within the TUC over cuts which had disarmed those attempting to defend the public services associated with the postwar consensus, and that this division corresponded not to established left-right positions, but to the sectoral location of unions' memberships. It was suggested that this division, which has received relatively little attention compared to divisions over wages policy, had nevertheless contributed significantly to the collapse of the Social Contract and to an important realignment within the Labour movement. Having surveyed existing literature on trade union debates on spending cuts, and the impact of spending cuts on the coherence of the Social Contract, central elements of the framework within which trade union policy responses developed are considered. The theoretical and political challenges to the postwar consensus on the social and economic role of the public sector, the constraints imposed on domstic policy-making by international political and economic forces, the chronology and content of government fiscal policy, and the historical development of TUC economic and political strategies, are all discussed. On the basis of conclusions drawn from these studies an analysis is made of the relevant policy statements and debates of both the TUC and of eight individual trade unions selected according to sectoral location. Conclusions are drawn about the nature of the division among TUC affiliates over spending cuts, the political complexion of the TUC economic thought, and the impact of the division on the Social Contract and trade union political affiliations.

Title: A comparative study of urban land use planning systems in Scotland and China - with case studies in Edinburgh and Xian.
Abstract: This research is an empirical comparison of Scottish and Chinese urban land use planning systems. It tests the proposition put by Cherry (1984) that Planning is an international movement with a common language in concepts and methods. The shared ideas are readily observable: the objective of spatial order, the pursuit of amenity, the search for convenience in city form and structure ; and it explores the strengths and weakness of two major arguments of cross-national comparison of planning: a stage/evolutionary explanation proposed by Van den Berg et al (1982) and a stress on particular political structures and the disposition of power within the society. Major themes such as the historical development of urban planning, the ideological and theoretical concepts of planning, the institutions of governments and other agencies with planning responsibilities, the different statutory basis of the planning systems; and the practice of the two systems are examined and compared. Particular attention is given to the comparison of planning practice in the two case study cities - Edinburgh and Xian. The intention of this research is to seek the possibility to transfer ideas, experiences and policies between them and to improve the practice of the Chinese system. Although the findings support Cherry's proposition this research concludes that particular attention should be given to the different national cultural, historic, social-economic and political context of different societies. The research recognized that past transfer of planning skills from the west to China was confined to technical and physical design aspects without relevant institutional changes. Major recommendations are made toward covering this gap - to reform planning institutions, to improve planning legislation and practice.
