Title: Victor Serge: political, social and literary critic of the USSR, 1919-1947; the reflections and activities of a Belgo-Russian revolutionary caught in the orbit of Soviet political history.
Abstract: Victor Serge is known primarily as a revolutionary novelist, yet his work has received little scholarly literary attention. Two doctoral dissertations have explored Serge's literary expression in the last twenty-five years. This study is the first examination of Serge's historical and political-economic writings on the Soviet Union, based on his published and unpublished writings. Victor Serge is a unique political figure who utilized various literary forms to express his view of the nature of the social-political-economic system established during Stalin's rule. Pamphleteer, historian, poet, novelist, biographer, memoirist and journalist, Serge was at once Russian, Belgian, French and Spanish; he was anarchist, syndicalist, Bolshevik, Left Oppositionist, prisoner and refugee. Serge's experiences in the Soviet Union and international communist movement form the basis of his political and literary writings. Serge was a committed writer with a novelist's eye for detail and penetrating description. The dissertation begins with Serge's arrival in his never seen homeland. Born Victor Lvovich Kibalchich in Belgian exile to Russian narodniki parents, Serge was drawn to the land of the first socialist revolution, the country of his roots and his language. He arrived as an anarcho-bolshevik with two prison terms and a failed insurrection behind him. In the next twenty years, Serge participated in the Bolshevik party, the Comintern, and the Left Opposition. He was sent to Germany on Comintern assignment, where he participated in the aborted revolution of October 1923, and edited the French language edition of Inprecor . He was a rank-and-file militant of the Leningrad Left opposition, though on intimate terms with its leaders. Like most of the `revolutionary generation of Bolsheviks', he endured imprisonment and deportation. Unlike them, Serge was saved from certain death through an international campaign of pressure for his release. Though Serge was expelled from the USSR in 1936, he did not end his association with it: he spent the remainder of his life contemplating and acting upon his experience in the disfigured revolution. This thesis investigates Serge's critique of the Soviet Union through his life and works. We follow his political associations and relations, record his analysis and draw out his insights. Serge's mature reflections on the Soviet Union and the world are seen through a comprehensive study of his experiences and writings from the twenties and thirties in the Soviet Union and in European exile. The aim of this work is to establish Victor Serge as a contemporary thinker, a man whose life spans the tumultous struggles of the first half of the twentieth century, while his ideas speak to the problems humanity faces on the eve of the twenty-first. His largely unpublished or out of print work addresses the key theoretical problems of Soviet society as well as the impact that society has had on the world struggle for socialism. Victor Serge considered the Soviet system under Stalin an anti-human, totalitarian bureaucratic society with collectivist tendencies, that was neither socialist nor capitalist. It could only establish itself through a bloody counter-revolution which killed millions while retaining the language of socialism. The new system was inherently unstable and in permanent conflict with its own people. It is this legacy that the Soviet Union today is attempting to reform. Serge's analysis is at times uneven, though his thinking is fresh, and scrupulously honest. Serge is seen as the historian of the Left Opposition, an instinctive, unorthodox and non-sectarian Marxist who retained his dignity and optimism for a socialist future, through the darkest decades of defeats.

Title: Progress and apocalypse: Science and the end of the modern world. (Volumes I and II)
Abstract: Since the 1930s, ecology has helped generate both scientific, religious, and popular prophecies of the collapse of civilization and the extinction of humanity. After World War II, scientists such as William Vogt, Rachel Carson, Barry Commoner, and Paul Ehrlich used the science of ecology to forecast the end of the modern world and the extinction of humanity. I argue that these apocalyptic ecologists are part of a larger social movement that is challenging the social and political structure of the modern world. Ecological apocalyptic scientists are struggling to replace the authority of progress and economic growth with the authority of ecology. Their apocalypticism grew out of the contradiction between technological and industrial progress and modern science's biological understanding of the Earth. These scientist-writers use a shared apocalyptic rhetoric and ecological world view to call for a popular crusade to save nature and humanity. This scientific apocalypticism helped undermine faith in progress and the modern world. By developing a biological history that challenged the human-centered history of the modern world, their writings ignited public opposition to progress. Apocalyptic ecologists helped form a post-war environmental coalition between conservationists, scientists, and an informed public. Using the authority of science and ecology and the threat of the end of the modern world, environmentalists developed a scientific and political critique of modern industrial society. They believed that unless global industrial civilization transformed its understanding and use of the natural world, it would collapse and humanity would be threatened with extinction. Ecological apocalyptics made ecology both a science and politics of human survival.

Title: Artists respond to the Great Depression and the threat of Fascism: The New York Artists' Union and its magazine "Art Front" (1934-1937)
Abstract: Art and politics could not avoid each other during the Great Depression and the rise of fascism, in the 1930s. Social realism, which had been limited to drawings in radical magazines or the graphic arts, became important in painting and sculpture. Artists in the John Reed Club, the Artists' Union, the Harlem Artists' Guild, and the American Artists' Congress Against War and Fascism drew a wide range of supporters and acted as pressure groups, influencing society. The New Deal's Federal Art Project of the Works Progress Administration, which employed a total of 5,300 artists over a period of eight years and had a profound impact on American art, was started largely and continued by the pressure of artists and artists organizations. The Artists' Union, the official bargaining agent between government and the artist, negotiated wages, hours, and working conditions, and kept artists employed as artists, amid threats of closure, "quality control," favoritism, racism, censorship, and selected layoffs. Between 1933-1938, at least three factors favored the artists: in a near crisis situation, the government was impelled to act on artists' solutions to solve their unemployment; the labor movement, aided by New Deal legislation, became insurgent, and provided a role model and support for artists; and all shades of the cultural liberal and left-wing--who would be totally disaffected from each other in the near future--worked together on common goals. Commonality was influenced by radical politics and an idealistic view of working-class--its solidarity, collectivity, and readiness to take action. Engage artists viewed the solving of artists problems in global terms, and with Popular Front ideas, worked with fraternal artists' organizations in Europe and Mexico. A window to this radical shift in artists' subject matter, patronage, and position in American society, is the unique art magazine Art Front. Challenging entrenched hierarchies in analytical writings, indignant drawings, and documentary photographs, it was vital and provocative, stemming from the realistic character of the Artists' Union, which sponsored it.

Title: Information cultures and the transformation of communist societies: The case of the Soviet Union
Abstract: This dissertation is motivated by the belief that the creation of an information culture will be fundamental to the quality of the economic future of the Soviet Union, and its ability to compete internationally in the economic marketplace, regardless of its future configuration. Two major influences have acted as catalysts for the systemic transformations that have occurred since 1985. First, the global information revolution has been an important influence in the determination of new goals for the Soviet system. Second, a "perceptual revolution" preceded this era of change, instigated by the Soviet academic intelligentsia, which has made political, social, and economic change not only possible in the Soviet context, but inevitable. To varying degrees, the three prerequisites necessary for the creation of a Soviet information culture already exist. First, a civil society is emerging to take the place of a failed official ideology, manifest in the movement towards democratization and individuation, and the revival of ethnic cleavages. The demand for political accountability by these three major forces of change contributed significantly to the destruction of the traditional communist ideology. Second, a sound economic infrastructure is essential to informationalization. Presently, the Soviet economic infrastructure is strong, but continues to rely too heavily on industrial production, and economic performance is constrained by poor levels of worker productivity. And third, human and technical capabilities are necessary to achieve the new goals of the system. Unsuccessful Soviet educational reform, and inadequate computerization of the economy continue to slow the reform process. Based upon an analysis of these three prerequisites vital to the formation of a Soviet information culture, the following conclusions can be made: (1) before any future steps can be taken, a stable political leadership, accountable to the people, must emerge; (2) general societal attitudes toward informationalization beneficial to the creation of an information culture must be encouraged; (3) a risk-oriented culture must take the place of the traditionally risk-averse Soviet political culture; and (4) the intelligentsia will continue to play an important role as major contributors to future plans for reform and informationalization.

Title: Union justice: A longitudinal case study of labor litigation
Abstract: The dissertation offers a fifty year longitudinal study of litigation encountered and promoted by the International Woodworkers of America with some comparative studies of litigation by its major rival. This study is designed to create a picture of everyday legal practices from which to assess the strategic consequences of labor regulation for labor organizations, and to speculate on the importance of litigation activity for the growth of the labor law. Major findings indicate a strong and growing reliance on litigation by the union leadership but with a changing historical focus from more short term to longer term strategic considerations. These changing forms of practice are understood as dependent on the nature of inter-union competition and the relative ability of organized labor to elicit working class identification with the institutional forms of the labor movement. The dissertation argues against theories which understand the importance of labor law to organizational and working class strength to lie either with the ideological subversion of labor union leadership or the economic inefficiency of labor regulation. The case study is presented from the context of social jurisprudence which is reviewed in Chapter Two. Chapter Three reviews theories of labor's institutional and organizational development. Chapters Four and Five present the historical analysis of the unions' litigation activity. Chapter Six offers a conclusion which assesses the findings in light of organizational theory, labor decline, and labor law reform.

Title: Facing freedom: The transition from slavery to free labor in Guayama, Puerto Rico, 1860-1898
Abstract: This study examines how planters and ex-slaves tried to define their new relationships after the abolition of slavery in Puerto Rico in 1873. It focuses on the southeastern coastal municipio of Guayama, the island's third leading sugar-and-slavery district in the nineteenth century. The study analyzes Guayaman society at the end of slavery, and emphasizes the heavily Afro-Puerto Rican character of its popular classes, and the European character of its elite. Thus, the work raises new questions on traditional conceptualizations of the racial configuration of nineteenth-century Puerto Rican society. The economic decline of the region's sugar industry is analyzed, but I stress an examination of the ex-slaves' efforts to define their freedom, and the planters' only partially successful efforts to determine the character of the transition to free labor. A detailed study of the dismal record of ex-slaves' (libertos) attempts to become peasants is presented. Local geographic conditions, the scarcity of arable land, and the structural weakness of free peasants and pre-emancipation proto-peasant slave experiences help to explain the libertos' failure to become peasants after emancipation. Guayama's libertos, however, put a premium on their freedom of movement. Mobility within and beyond municipio borders, to the urban township, and to different plantations is examined as planters tried to restrict this central aspect of emancipation. The study also explores elite attempts to maintain social hierarchies and cultural restrictions from the days of slavery. It concludes with a brief examination of forms of conflict and solidarity by looking at the rash of plantation fires registered after emancipation, especially in the 1880s. In short, this dissertation attempts to show that structural analyses of the transition that focus primarily on factors such as land/labor ratios, larger international economic imperatives, colonial labor legislation, or alleged capitalist planter objectives fail to grasp the complexities of emancipation. That a peasantization process failed, or that libertos did not withdraw from plantation work on a large scale, does not necessarily imply ex-slave acquiescence to planter ambitions, nor the absence of diverse efforts by the libertos to define emancipation on their own terms.

Title: REMNANTS OF AN UNWELCOME PAST: THE EXISTENCE OF NEO-NATIONAL SOCIALISM IN THE FEDERAL REPUBLIC OF GERMANY
Abstract: The thesis developed directly from an interest in the issue of terrorism and political violence, as studied for my MA degree. In the case of the Federal Republic of Germany politically motivated violence has seemed almost exclusively, judging from published material, to have left-wing origins, as in the case of the Rote Armee Fraktion (Red Army Faction) and the Revolutionare Zellen (Revolutionary Cells). This thesis sets out, however, to examine the existence of terrorism from the right and to assess its significance. The thesis has been divided into eight chapters. It begins by looking at the existence of right-wing extremism. Chapter one examines the potential sympathy amongst the West German electorate for right-wing extremist sentiment. Chapter two traces the development and history of organised right-wing extremism from 1945 to 1990 and shows that the rise of the Republikaner in 1989 marked the third ascent of right-wing extremism in the FRG. Subsequent chapters focus on the adherents of neo-National Socialism as it is from this area, for the most part, the right-wing acts of violence emanate. Chapter three investigates the rise of neo-Nazism at the end of the 1970s and traces its development, its leaders, membership and international connections. The fourth chapter illustrates the objectives of the neo-Nazis by examining the ideology behind it. Chapter five focuses on the issue of right-wing terrorism and argues that the violence from the right represents a more serious threat to public order than is imagined. Chapter six seeks to explain the appeal of neo-Nazism and provides an account of the social composition of neo-Nazism while the seventh chapter examines the political and judicial reaction to the existence of the neo-Nazi movement. Finally, the last chapter pulls all the above strands together to present a picture of neo-Nazism at the beginning of the 1990s and assesses its position in the newly united Germany.

Title: NATURE CONSERVATION IN SPAIN: THE INFLUENCE OF PRESSURE GROUPS AND VESTED INTERESTS IN THE ESTADO DE AUTONOMIAS, WITH SPECIAL REFERENCE TO EXTREMADURA. (VOLUMES I AND II)
Abstract: Conservation of nature in Spain began with measures to protect hunting and timber. Liberal interludes of the last century concentrated land into fewer hands, destroying much of the country's forest. A corps of forestry technocrats--the ingenieros de montes--grew up, with a first interest in production with an emphasis in this century on reafforestation with rapid-growth, introduced species, serving to exacerbate rather than check erosion, along with other deleterious social and environmental effects. ICONA has, since its creation in 1971 been dominated by the technocrats. Awareness of conservation issues on the part of the general public was heightened by the growth of the conservation movement, in spite of its failure to become organised on a national scale. Devolution has led to some successes in conservation of habitats, after learning the lessons from extensive campaigns such as that which saved Monfrague, one of the world's great natural areas. However, the process of devolution had not been fully implemented as Spain prepared for EEC entry, with far-reaching effects, mostly because of the impact of the Common Agricultural Policy and other structural funds. Paradoxically, whilst the CAP is posing some of the major threats to Spain's natural environment, European legislation and other initiatives may be beginning to provide the means of protection in the face of increased pressures. To ensure an adequate protection for Spain's fragile ecosystems the conservation movement must develop a national structure to compensate for regional fragmentation and to face up to a new European dimension. Pressure must be maintained to ensure integrated regional planning policies, to be coordinated on a European level, so that the CAP and other measures might be adapted to the special nature of Spain's wildlife. Failure to do this will mean desertification and international recriminations, because of the Peninsula's importance for migrating wildlife. Such an integrated policy must ensure the harmony of regional populations with agricultural systems to ensure correct and rational use of natural resources. The work concentrates on the area of Extremadura, arguably one on Europe's richest wildlife areas. It is a region outstanding for the harmonisation of agricultural practices with wildlife protection, and the vast areas of oak groves, supporting an agro-sylvo-pastoral system of agricultural exploitation, in conjunction with virtually Mediterranean climax forest, makes it unique, and increases the need to ensure its protection from a variety of threats and pressures.

Title: The impact of the french revolution in the ideas and policies of william pitt, 1789-1795
Abstract: This work addresses the Younger Pitt's response to the French Revolution from 1789-1795. Government records, the personal papers of Pitt and his contemporaries and the proceedings of Parliament have been examined to trace the development of Pitt's thought and its expression in Britain's foreign and domestic policy. In contrast to many members of the British social elite, Pitt saw events in France during the laste 1780 and early 1790s in conventional terms; the following years of Revolutionary War consequently witnessed no intellectual or practical discontinuity in comparison to the previous decade.Pitt entered office in 1784 with no experience in the field of international relations. By the late 1780s, his thoughts had been formed in a practical context and predisposed him to regard overseas developments in a pragmatic light. The complacence he had derived from the decline of French power throughout the late 1780s gave him the confidence to launch a series of global military offensives that failed through a fundamental misunderstanding of allied objectives and of the Revolution itself. Pitt never saw France in strictly ideological terms, which made him relatively flexible about its post-war political settlement but traditional war aims respecting the Continent and colonies made him uncompromising about the condition for peace. Populare political activism was regarded as a threat to social or political order only at certain critical moments. The popularisation of politics was, to Pitt, directed from Paris at specific diplomatic goals which, in 1792, comprised neutrality and, from 1793 to 1795, constituted withdrawal from the war. His gradual implementation of repressive measures was ultimately determined by the seeming strength of popular unrest but Pitt realised that the official condemnation of the popular political movement carried executive action into unconstitutional realms. His adherence to the `liberal' political creed of Augustan England places him within the tradition of eighteenth century Whiggism, if not it Pantheon.

Title: The Farmer - Dominant Study Group: a practical paradigm in international extension strategy.
Abstract: The Farmer-Dominant Study Group (FDSG) paradigm is tested against the hypothesis that it offers a practical means of achieving technical agricultural progress, delivering cost-effective and socio-psychologically sound extension, and contributing constructively to the social cohesion between working family farmers for the benefit of rural communities. FDSG allows for a logical linkage between farmers, researchers and extensionists for Farming Systems Development (FSD). The FDSG MODEL is distinguished as beginning with farmer dominance, served by appropriate catalyst/lubricant extensionist involvement. Its focus is on study together using methodical monitoring management (MMM) whereby physical and financial parameters are compared on normal farm crops, with some on-farm research (OFR) and subsequent Farming Systems Development. Beneficial group characteristics result from such study, producing strong mutuality. This leads on to the full realisation of farmer-dominance, expressed through the integrated realism characteristic of farmers worldwide. The FDSG model is found to be transferrable, with adjustment, to other agroecological contexts. Evidence is drawn from:- i) the UK case of the Cirencester Cereal Study Group (CCSG) and its linkages, particularly to the Arable Research Centres (ARC), using participant-observer research with a devised group assessment procedure involving 55 farmers, a farmers' own evaluation involving 27 farmers, and a comparative survey of 173 farmer-members of ARC, ii) the comparative case of the Africa Cooperative Action Trust (ACAT) Club movement in Transkei, Ciskei, Kwazulu and Swaziland, by questioning:- 26 Southern African farmers, 71 ACAT Clubs (FDSG) and 40 ACAT extensionists; plus support from a survey of 145 Nigerian farmers, ii) preliminary work among farmers and extensionists in India, iv) the international literature. Assigned CCSG members' mutuality ratings agreed significantly with their own evaluations of FDSG membership. Educational output, linkages and the beneficial association between membership and intensity of arable interest plus farm practice, all strongly support the hypothesis.

Title: The career of F.B. Meyer (1847-1929).
Abstract: F.B. Meyer (1847-1929) was one of the most prominent Free Church ministers of his period. He had a number of successful ministries, in which he gave priority to work as an evangelist rather than a pastor, an emphasis which owed much to the decisive influence of the American revivalist D.L. Moody. Meyer's theology was essentially devotional, and he was able to relate to different doctrinal perspectives within Evangelicalism. In ecclesiology he was transdenominational, although he was also a notable Baptist figure and was committed to the Baptist doctrine of believer's baptism. His pietistic sympathies and his undenominationalism found expression in the holiness movement associated with the Keswick convention, of which he became the foremost international spokesman. He was also the leading Nonconformist in his movement, which was predominantly Anglican. Meyer's ability to combine other-worldly forms of spirituality with an equal dedication to local and national socio-political activity - in such areas as temperance, social purity, education and the rights of pacifists - enabled him to function as the leader who most effectively bridged the diverse elements in British Evangelicalism from the 1880s to the First World War. By the 1920s Meyer's expansive vision for the Free Churches was receding and the focus of his energy moved to the advocacy of premillennialism. In this period he associated more closely with those on the Fundamentalist wing of Evangelicalism and the fact that Britain did not experience the kind of Fundamentalist schism which took place in America was due in part to Meyer's reconciling influence. Comparatively little scholarly work has been done on the signifiance of Meyer. This study of his career should give an insight into crucial developments which took place, from the 1870s to the 1920s, in British Evangelicalism.

Title: The origins and development of English language teaching in China
Abstract: Since China's open-door policy and reform movement began in 1979, English language teaching (ELT) has developed tremendously to meet the needs of China's international interactions with the world. English is becoming so popular that China is now the host of the largest English as a foreign language (EFL) classroom in the world, largest meaning that among the countries where English is not the native or official language, China has the largest number of EFL students. However, little research has been done on issues regarding the development of EFL in China, such as when and how did ELT start? Who sponsored ELT at each stage of its development? Why is English so popular these days? How has it developed to its current status? This dissertation attempts to explain these issues and to account for the forces that have driven ELT into its current being in China. If anything, this writing is, first of all, a historical account of ELT development in China, which is so far the first of its kind written in English. The dissertation falls into five parts. Chapter I functions as an introduction to the writing, and lays out some background information. Chapter II focuses on the early stages of ELT in China (1830-1900), including the missionary activities and the Chinese efforts in ELT. Chapter III takes a look at the ELT activities and development in the newly founded public schools in China in the first half of the century (1900-1950). This was the period in which some master English teachers had been prepared, and foundation laid for later development. Chapter IV describes the ups and downs of English (1950-1978), how it lost to the Russian language and how it was politicalized during the years of the Cultural Revolution. And the last chapter, Chapter V, tries to capture and present some highlights of the English language resurgence to its highest popularity in the 1980s, and attempts an analysis of the social, economic factors that helped push forward the enterprise of ELT. It concludes by looking ahead at the development of ELT in the 1990s.

Title: "The work of democracy": Ralph Bunche, Kenneth B. Clark, Lorraine Hansberry and the cultural politics of racial equality
Abstract: This dissertation uses the public lives of three African-American intellectuals who became postwar "role models" of racial equality--United Nations diplomat Ralph Bunche, social scientist Kenneth B. Clark and playwright Lorraine Hansberry--to explore the cultural understandings and tensions which underlay the American "coming-of-age" on race. By following the rise and decline of the symbolic currency of each of these individuals, I chronicle the evolution of the American discourse on race from the era of Jackie Robinson to the emergence of "Black Power." In the late forties and early fifties, Bunche personified for many Americans the relationship that existed between domestic progress on racial equality and the objectives of Cold War foreign policy abroad. During the height of his celebrity Bunche also symbolized the great popular hope that the U.N. might finally redeem the unrealized promise of Wilsonian internationalism. As the civil rights movement was hitting its stride, Clark became the best known "expert-interpreter" of racial issues to the American public. Clark's close association with Brown v. Board launched him as important advocate of school "integration" while his authorship of Dark Ghetto established him as one of the foremost authorities on the "American Dilemma" as represented by the northern urban ghetto. Hansberry's A Raisin in the Sun was, to its admirers, a final frame in the cultural narrative of the "ethnic arrival" of African-Americans. Through that play, however, Hansberry sought to accomplish something considerably more audacious: to reintroduce the entanglement of race and class as a subject of the American discourse on race. She further argued that "American Negroes" were, in fact, "African-Americans," and that their struggle for "civil rights" was one branch of the global anti-colonial movement. I examine the experiences of these three "participant-symbols" of racial equality to illuminate the way in which the "common meanings" they put forward challenged existing understandings regarding individualism, democracy, and equality. This study attends as well to the ways in which existing cultural patterns impeded the establishment of these new values--what Martin Luther King, Jr., described as the "work of democracy."

Title: Organizing for internationalism: A study of the educational mission of the United Nations Association of the U.S.A.
Abstract: This study is an exploration of the organizational processes through which an innovative ideology may become institutionalized. It focuses on the United Nations Association of the U.S.A. as an ideological organization advocating "internationalism." Participant observation, interviewing, and archival research methods are used to investigate the relationship between ideology and organization in a large chapter and at the national headquarters of UNA-USA. Social science literature often presents ideological organizations as tools for the dissemination of an already coherent ideology or as pluralistic arenas for the pursuit of multiple non-ideological goals. On the basis of this research, I argue for an alternative image of ideological organizations as crucibles for ideological change. The internationalism of UNA-USA is revealed to be an unstable combination of two different sets of beliefs. One, originating in religious reform movements of the late 1800's, is a "universal humanism." The other, represented by a small number of government and corporate leaders, is an "enlightened self-interest" relating the national interest to increased cooperation in international organizations. The commonalties and contradictions of these two internationalisms have been played out in the organizational history of UNA-USA. A new "multilateralism" has recently emerged from the organization, synthesizing the two earlier perspectives. Ideology, organization, and politics are each examined in this study, and linked in an analytical model of institutionalization as a political process of organizational and ideological change. Individuals and groups within the ideological organization are seen engaged in a continuous process of political contest and negotiation regarding both the nature of their beliefs and the organizational requirements for the advocacy of those beliefs. This process of negotiation generates a changing ideological discourse.

Title: Internationalism and its betrayal: From Grotius to Hegel
Abstract: In this thesis, I explore the development of internationalism from the disintegration of the catholic commonwealth to the congress of Vienna. The internal contradictions of internationalism led to its decline, and to the rise of nationalism. Internationalism was developed by the rising middle-class against the catholic respublica's false claim of universality. It expressed the increased self-awareness of a group, the Third Estate, seeking international solidarity against the particularism of Absolutist regimes. Internationalism included new principles of moral, political and economic rights. It was applicable to both individuals within and between states, compatible with the spirit of free enterprise, able to free the realm of knowledge from christian tutelage, and to expand the political and property rights of the Third Estate. The development of internationalism, however, as conceived by the ascending middle-class, engendered contradictions inherent to the pre-capitalist period of the eighteenth century. The French Revolution, the apex of internationalist ideals, raised hopes but did not lead to European unity or the universalization of human rights principles. The history of the nineteenth century illustrates that the principle of social justice, as espoused by internationalism during the French Revolution, could not be reconciled with the new emerging economic order. The idea of internationalism receded or rather was superseded by the development of nationalism. The Napoleonic conquests veiled the interest of the bourgeoisie and incubated the burst of nationalist movements in 1848. The idea of internationalism, as conceptualized by the thinkers of the rising middle class, incorporates particularist forces which manifest themselves as nationalism during critical periods. Thus understood, internationalism remained a futile theoretical abstraction. Given this historical setting, I have selected some major political thinkers, who critically illustrated the historical tension between internationalism and nationalism. They included Vico, Grotius, Rousseau (for the post-Reformation period--part I); Kant, Paine and Robespierre (for French Revolutionary period--part II); Burke, Fichte, and De Maistre (for the rise of romanticism and nationalism--part III); and finally Hegel, whose writings incorporated the ideas of the enlightenment and the germinating ideas of romantic nationalism.

Title: A survey of modern painting in the islamic world and the development of the contemporary calligraphic school
Abstract: The fIrst part of the thesis deals with the development of modem painting in the Islamic world according to Western concepts and styles. It traces the inception of Western aesthetics from the 19th centmy onwards and touches on the political, social and economic determinants that aided their introduction in the following countries: Turkey, Egypt, Lebanon, Iraq, Algeria, Tunisia, Morocco, Iran, Syria, Jordan, Palestine, Sudan, and the Arabian Peninsula. The second part of the thesis analyzes the movements which sought to establish a modem art style in the Islamic world that would confirm a national artistic identity. It follows the different art movements which undertook this quest that eventually led to the development of the contemporary Calligraphic School of Art. It discloses the factors and artists which induced its inception. It establishes the main styles and various branches of the modem Calligraphic School of Art, including in-depth analysis and critique of each style, sub-style and its adherents. The placement of the Calligraphic School within the scope of international art is also mooted. The thesis ends by establishing a continuity between traditional Islamic art and the contemporary calligraphic school of art in the Islamic world.

Title: Word, sound and power: Rastafari and conceptions of musical meaning in roots reggae music
Abstract: Reggae is a popular musical form that originated in Jamaica in the late 1960's and soon came to be closely associated with the oppositional, Afrocentric Rastafarian movement. During the 1970's it achieved global popularity and is now produced in many locations around the world. In Montreal, reggae is produced by and for a cosmopolitan community; however, certain conceptions of the distinctiveness of this music as an effective intervention in social processes, derived from Rastafarian philosophy, are maintained by its performers. This thesis examines reggae song lyrics and elements of discourse about reggae music in relation to Rastafarian cultural practices, showing how the aesthetic conventions of the form involve a certain ritualization of musical activity that allows for the interpretation of aesthetic experience in terms of solidarity, resistance and historical progress.

Title: The dialectrics of urban space
Abstract: This thesis attempts to understand the social construction of place through a study of the dialectics of space . The research starts out from the basic ontological proposition that although material space exists as a `thing', it is nonetheless a complex social process, subject to change and constantly changing. Under capitalism, it is a process which must be comprehended dialectically since it is constituted by conflictual practices which are themselves part of an internally-related global capitalist system. I argue that by laying bare the dialectics of space - theorising the diverse processes involved in its creation and transformation - we can begin to grasp place as constituting the form of one moment of a broader dialectical process. To explore and formulate a framework toward the construction of this `new object' for human geography, the thesis adopts and develops the materialist dialectic to probe and reconstruct the interconnected processes that command space and shape the urban landscape in particular places. By using actual research findings from two concrete case studies of socio-spatial change in the cities of Baltimore, U.S.A, and Liverpool, England, the analysis invokes dialectics as a way of gaining knowledge of capitalist spatiality. This viewpoint challenges the Cartesian foundation of much urban and geographical research and has important implications for developing critical theoretical understandings of contemporary urban change. It also raises vital political questions about local democracy, and of the empowerment of place-bound groups as they struggle against the exclusionary and pulverising tendencies of this particular phase of capitalist urbanisation. I assert that the method of gaining knowledge must be dialectical in character, and that the movement of space under capitalism is itself dialectical. And these two dialectics are one and the same. Hence the thesis aims to illuminate both.

Title: Continuity of Islamic art in the 20th century through the contemporary calligraphic school of art.
Abstract: The thesis starts with an attempt to define traditional Islamic art and aesthetics, from a Muslim's point of view by tracing the conceptual development, characteristics, philosophy and goals of Islamic art and the formation of an Islamic sani' . After discussing Western interpretation and understanding of Islamic art, a brief comparative study is made of Islamic and Western aesthetics which includes differences and similarities between the two perceptions. The art of calligraphy is traced and evaluated and shown to be the only one among the different art forms in Islamic culture which has survived atrophy. The main part of the thesis is concerned with the decline of Islamic art forms in the Ottoman Empire and under the Safavid Dynasty, since the sixteenth century. It analyzes the political, economic and social factors that had caused the decline while simultaneously led to the penetration of Western cultural trends in the Islamic world. The history of development of Western art styles, in each of the Islamic countries in the Middle East and North Africa including Turkey, Lebanon, Syria, Egypt, Tunis, Iraq, Morocco, Jordan, Palestine, the Arabian Peninsula and Iran, is traced after a brief historical and social background. The main artistic trends are analyzed, citing the artists that have brought them about, with illustrations of their works. The last part of the thesis establishes the inception of the contemporary calligraphic school of art in the Arab world and Iran, with mention of Turkey. It cites the factors that have induced it, the first artists who started it and its subject matters. It establishes its three main styles, with their various branches, including in-depth analysis and critique of each main style as well as sub-style, including the artists who propagate it, and giving illustrated examples. The placement of the calligraphic school of art, in painting, sculpture and ceramics, within the international art movement, is also mooted. The thesis ends by setting up a link between traditional Islamic art and the contemporary school of art in the Islamic world, according to the definition of Islamic art reached in the first part of the thesis.

Title: British working class attitudes to war and national defence, 1902-1914.
Abstract: This thesis examines working class attitudes to war and national defence between the Boer War and the First World War. An epilogue considers their reactions during the last months of 1914 and tests whether the outbreak of war caused their opinions to change. Throughout the peace the workers were subjected to propaganda from both the right and the left. This propaganda has been studied before but the difficult problem of establishing how the workers reacted to it remains. It is here that this thesis seeks to make an original contribution. Part One looks at the efforts of the National Service League to persuade the working class to accept universal military training and considers why, although a few workers became enthusiastic supporters, the majority remained hostile. The debate between the League and the organised labour movement is also examined. Part Two studies the propaganda of the socialists and reveals its limited appeal to the working class. It highlights the differences of opinion between Keir Hardie, H.M. Hyndman and Robert Blatchford; charts the progress of the proposal for an international strike against war; examines the record of the anti-military campaigns conducted by the Independent Labour Party; and follows the campaign for a citizen army of the Social Democratic Federation. The favourable attitude of armaments workers and their representatives towards military and naval expenditure is demonstrated. In addition, the question of the food supply in time of war is studied from the working class perspective. Part Three investigates the relationship between the working class and the regular army. It looks at the organisation and activities of the recruiting service and the background and motives of would-be recruits. It examines popular prejudice against the army, soldiers and enlistment and studies the effect on working class attitudes of the use of the military during trades disputes.

Title: Conceptions of politics, morality, and war in the nuclear policy debates
Abstract: During the resurgent nuclear debates from the mid-1970s to the mid-1980s, analysts sharply disagreed about the appropriate means and ends of strategy. Deterrence dominance strategists argued that America required a countervailing capacity to sustain a viable deterrent posture and to contain Soviet adventurism. Proponents of pure deterrence claimed that the risks endemic to mutual vulnerability would suffice to moderate the superpower rivalry. Advocates of denuclearization charged that reliance on nuclear weaponry posed the greatest danger to human well-being and called for diplomatic measures to establish a disarmament regime. While scholars have systemically explored the strategic and technological components of the controversy, few studies have examined the political theoretic dimensions. Through a textual exegesis of the writings of key participants, this work seeks to demonstrate that contending conceptions of politics and morality inform dissension about the viability of coercive power in the nuclear age. Justifications of deterrence dominance proposals generally conflate political and ethical considerations through variants of Hobbesian skepticism or liberal just war interventionism. Such arguments perceive the state as the locus of societal values and sovereignty as sanctioning extensive activities in the global system. Pure deterrence notions posit an irreconcilable tension between politics and morality that corresponds with a tragic vision: war may be a necessary element of sociality, but it seldom has truly creative consequences. From this perspective, the state is a morally ambiguous agent that can preserve and endanger societal well-being. Finally, associated with the denuclearization school is a conviction that progressive social movements can conform politics to essential ethical precepts by minimizing the role of coercive power. In this view, the state and its claim to sovereignty are primary sources of the war system, hence must be radically altered through comprehensive democratization.

Title: Immigrant culture and the politics of identity: Italian-American syndicalists in the United States, 1911-1927
Abstract: This dissertation focuses on the nexus between political and social history in the lives of Italian-American syndicalists in the early twentieth century. My analysis of debates, both within the Italian Socialist Federation, the central vehicle for Italian immigrant radicalism in the years before World War I, and among those leading members who later left the organization--on strategy and ideology, on gender, race, and regional differences, and on the relevance of continuing ties to Italy--sheds light on the process by which political and cultural identities are repeatedly constructed and reconstructed. Methodologically, I examine Italian-American syndicalists and their ideology in a transnational context, exploring their political activism both in the United States and in Italy. Using Italian-language newspapers, essays and correspondence from archives in both countries, I analyze the relationship of these radicals to their homeland on a number of levels: in terms of cultural retention; their reaction to events in their country of origin; their exchanges of philosophical and strategic advice with radicals in Italy; and their physical movement back and forth between countries. The importance of the continuing and complex connections between an ethnic group and its homeland is just beginning to receive attention from immigrant historians. The assumption underpinning much of the current work in this field is that both the culture of origin and the mainstream United States culture were static entities. I show instead that there was an ongoing dynamic interplay between the cultures, and identify how this interplay shaped immigrant identity in continually shifting ways. I also suggest ways in which working-class and radical history in the United States need to be revised. This study complements and extends the work done by scholars on the "new unionism" and on ethnic radicalism in two ways. First, it emphasizes the centrality of Italian-American syndicalists in the prewar labor and radical movements, specifically in the struggles waged by the Industrial Workers of the World. Second, it traces the enduring influence of immigrant syndicalism in mainstream unions like the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America after the end of World War I and the demise of the IWW.

Title: "The weapons of our warfare are not carnal": Civil War pacifism, perfectionism, and roots of post-war radicalism
Abstract: This study concerns pacifism in the northern states during the Civil War era and its connection with post-war radicalism. It focuses on an eclectic group of perfectionist pacifists who opposed the war on the basis of their religious convictions, which stemmed from their views on Christian perfection, the Government of God, and the millennium. Believing God's laws supreme over laws of human origin, the perfectionists refused to support or take part in the Federal government's war effort because God's laws demanded that they reject all violence, even if positive results may result from its use. Having experienced ridicule, accusations of treason, ostracism, and the specter of conscription during the war, the perfectionist pacifists united in its wake to create the Universal Peace Union (UPU). Through the UPU the perfectionists strove to convince the rest of humanity to recognize God's laws as the highest source of authority and to bring their governments into conformity with God's laws. They envisioned a day when all nations subordinated themselves to the Government of God, creating a "universal republic" of nations. Once accomplished, they posited, all evils, including international strife, would cease to exist. The pacifists' quest for a perfect world led them to expand their activities to a wide variety of issues within the United States such as Reconstruction, Native American policy, labor relations, education reform, and equal rights among others. In an era when American society and American reformers grew pessimistic about the possibility of individual and societal perfection, the pacifists perpetuated the tradition of perfectionism that characterized antebellum reform. Through their work the perfectionist pacifists endeavored to alter the political and social fabric of the nation and the world. In the process the organization they created became extremely sectarian and doctrinaire, impeding the UPU's ability to bring about constructive change. As is true with other radical movements, the UPU's rigidity explains its failure.

Title: Pentecostal/Charismatic spirituality: Looking through the lens of ritual
Abstract: This dissertation examines Pentecostal ritual as an expression of and an efficacious dynamic within Pentecostal/Charismatic spirituality. It aims to describe and interpret Pentecostal/Charismatic spirituality by means of a ritual study. Through ethnographic fieldwork including the methods of participant observation and ethnographic interviewing, the study focuses on data collected from the central Pentecostal ritual, the Sunday worship service, in three Northern California congregations over a period of more than two years. The dissertation seeks to understand Pentecostal/Charismatic spirituality by utilizing both indigenous categories and those suggested by ritologists and social scientists, especially Ronald L. Grimes and Victor Turner. In order to better interpret the Pentecostal rites and their attending spirituality the first two chapters provide an introduction and orientation to the study as a whole. Chapter one presents a historical outline of the 20th century Pentecostal/Charismatic Movement and, in particular, an overview of the Assemblies of God, International Church of the Foursquare Gospel, and Vineyard Christian Fellowship. These three denominations function as the parent organizations to the three local congregations studied. Chapter two sketches portraits of the three congregations as expressions of local Pentecostal/Charismatic religion. In chapters three, four, and five the dissertation turns to consider distinctive elements and dynamics of the central Pentecostal. Chapter three discusses six select elements of the Pentecostal/Charismatic ritual field, i.e., ritual time, space, identity/roles, sights, sounds, and kinesthetic dimensions. Chapter four identifies a foundational three part structural/processual dimension of the ritual and explores its component rites. Chapter five presents seven modes of ritual sensibility discovered during our field research. The dissertation maintains that the Pentecostal ritual practices are oriented and animated by these embodied attitudes. In chapter six the dissertation gives attention to some of the communicative and efficacious roles that Pentecostal/Charismatic ritual performance plays within the community and its spirituality. The final chapter, seven, sets forth qualities and characteristics of Pentecostal spirituality within six selected indigenous symbols and then summarizes the chief characteristic qualities under the rubric of experience of God.

Title: The political economy of Thailand: The Thai peripheral state, 1958-1988
Abstract: This dissertation attempts to make a fresh contribution to theories of the state by developing the potential of Marx's and neo-Marxist concepts in order to produce new concepts of the state. Its key objective is to use these concepts as a tool to analyze the development of Thai political economy with a focus on examining the restructuring of the Thai state. Another key objective is to eliminate some illusions about the independent and democratic form of the state. It demonstrates that from 1958 to 1988 the Thai state was essentially peripheral in relations to the U.S. imperial state and the Japanese economic empire. The construction of this peripheral state was responsible for a special kind of capitalist development in Thailand: a strategy of over-exploitation composed of many primitive forms--primitive accumulation, semi-slave production, child labor production, prostitution and absolute surplus value. To operate this over-exploitation, the repressive class-state force was formed justifying itself as necessary for "development" and for the defeat of communism. Its main purpose was to silence all political and economic movements of workers and farmers, suppressing their political and economic rights. The growth of Thai economy was based on impoverishment of farmers and intensive exploitation of labor: farmers were indebted, income plummet as prices declined forcing many into low paid industrial and "service" employment. High profits were based on the intensified exploitations of farmers, prostitutes, and child laborers. The social costs, however, far exceed the worst period of the 19th century revolution in the West. Thailand which was a former center of Buddhism has become the global center of sex-exploitation. Thailand with a rich cultural past has become a country of cultural anomie and moral decay. Today thousands of whore houses, bars, and other "entertainment" centers sell not only sex but everyday death. Estimates are that by the year 2000 between 4 and 6 million Thais will have infected with the HIV virus.

Title: Cherishing as a model of education: A spiritual journey
Abstract: This critique examines the dominant consciousness of contemporary schooling and society while discussing how competition, standardized testing, and the effective schools movement continue to diminish and depersonalize students. This study addresses the issues of students' and teachers' suffering and alienation and focuses on the need for healing, connection, and wholeness in our lives and in our society. A model of schooling, based on the concept of cherishing and grounded in a spirituality of love, justice, mercy and compassion, is proposed based on the personal journey of the researcher and linked to one's basic assumptions about humanity and the universe. Religious and spiritual language are used to gain a new perspective and awareness of education. Reflection, by teachers, on one's basic beliefs and practices in schooling is urged. Selective literature, on caring, interpersonal relationships, global interdependence, the need for social and political reform, and the need for an alternative consciousness, is examined as a foundation for a paradigm of cherishing in schools and society. The writings of Nel Noddings, Alfie Kohn, Martin Buber, Paulo Freire, Rita Brock, David Purpel, and Walter Brueggemann are examined extensively. The researcher envisions a society based on love, justice, and compassion where each individual is valued, cherished, and respected, regardless of ability or achievement. Specific and general classroom and school practices are described which reflect this vision.

Title: Embodying the spirit: The significance of the body in the contemporary Japanese dance movement of Butoh
Abstract: Of the many styles of contemporary dance to evolve in Japan during the 20th century, Butoh is the most recognized and distinctive, and it has helped to establish Japan as a leader in the contemporary dance world. Conceptually and aesthetically, Butoh is based on the traditional Japanese body, which for hundreds of years has been shaped by lifestyle and livelihood. There are several characteristics that shape Butoh, but the use of the body is the one that most clearly sets Butoh apart from other dance genres. The purpose of this study is to gain an understanding of how the body as used in Butoh is a reflection of the body as it is manifested in everyday Japanese life and how the Butoh aesthetic is related to the traditional Japanese aesthetic. To set the context from which Butoh arose, the introduction recalls the artistic, social, and political climate of the times, and establishes the life and work of Hijikata Tatsumi, Butoh's principal founder. The seeds of Butoh were planted in the Post World War II period of the 1950s when Hijikata and co-founder Ohno Kazuo began to question the nature of dance itself and what it meant to them. Butoh was born in the process of reexamining their own culture and tradition, and out of a need to create an indigenous modern genre of dance. The introduction is followed by a portrait of the researcher, a Certified Movement Analyst and dance artist who lived, studied, and performed Butoh in Japan from 1987 to 1989. The main body of research is revealed in the three "body" chapters: the body concrete--the human form and proportion; the body ethereal--the concepts of "spirit" and "self," the use of imagery and energy; and the body adorned--the coatings and coverings. These bodies constitute a holistic concept of the body as a subject of study and they merge in "The Butoh Body Aesthetic" in which pervasive characteristics of Butoh are identified, the life and work of Hijikata being the thread woven throughout. The final chapter addresses how changes within the Japanese culture and physical body as well as the growing number of Butoh inspired works created by non-Japanese artists may affect the aesthetics of Butoh and the dance genre's vitality and continued impact on the international dance community. (Abstract shortened by UMI.)

Title: Musical culture and the origins of the Enlightenment in Hamburg
Abstract: Hamburg's German-language opera company, founded in 1678 and housed in the Theater am Gansemarkt, immediately dominated the city's secular culture and became the institution within and against which the cultural values of Hamburg's early Enlightenment took shape. Hamburg was a hub both of international commerce and of cultural interchange with north German and European princely courts. Its Goosemarket opera, which operated for sixty years under protection of the Rat, with the support of aristocratic patrons, and to paying, popular audiences, became the principal locus for the formation of Hamburg's hybrid bourgeois/aristocratic secular high culture on the eve of the Enlightenment. The individuals who initiated the Enlightenment movement in Hamburg in the 1720s and 1730s belonged to the generation that grew up in the shadow of the Goosemarket opera. This study begins by reconstructing the salient features of Hamburg's high culture in the galant period--the period in which the opera was founded. In the musical and literary treatises published in Hamburg in the decade of the 1700s, the galant appears as a positive ideal of worldly wisdom, practical knowledge, good taste and inner cultivation. This ideal was transformed in the writings of Christian Friedrich Hunold, Johann Mattheson, Barthold Heinrich Brockes, and other early Aufklarer as they passed from youth to adulthood. In the Hamburg Patriot (1724-26), the most important moral weekly of the Fruhaufklarung, the "galant homme" is a negative ideal, the heuristic anti-type to the "good burgher," reflecting the critical distance of the Hamburg Aufklarer from their own galant youth. Yet galant social values were carried forward in the early Enlightenment in the ethos of intellectual cultivation and refinement and the galant aesthetic of simplicity and naturalness was carried forward in the moral cantatas of Reinhard Keiser, harbingers of the proto-classical vocal style of another Hamburg composer, Georg Philipp Telemann. The cantatas of Keiser and Telemann--brief, technically simple music, suitable for amateur performance, and embodying the ethical and didactic impulses of the German Enlightenment--set the standard for eighteenth-century vocal chamber music, replacing the operatic standard--complex, technically difficult music for the stage.

Title: The enduring or disappearing South? Testing regional convergence of church attendance, racial prejudice, and gun ownership
Abstract: Sociologists have long been interested in contemporary social change, and have defined this change by concepts such as massification, secularization, societalization, and urbanization. It is generally assumed that these processes have diminished regional and residential differences. In this study I investigated whether differences in church attendance, racial prejudice, and gun ownership--between the southern and nonsouthern U.S.--had declined over the past 20 years. If regional differences had declined, I was interested in identifying factors which might be related to this decline. I tested the effects of the following upon regional convergence: (1) cohort replacement and the regional convergence of birth cohorts, (2) migration from the Nonsouth to the South, (3) residential mobility, (4) education, and (5) movement from the country to the city. The analysis showed significant regional convergences of church attendance, racial prejudice, and gun ownership over the past two decades. The convergence of birth cohorts had its greatest effect upon the regional convergence of racial prejudice, a lesser effect upon that of gun ownership, and no effect upon the convergence of church attendance. Of the other four explanatory factors, migration to the South generally had the most important effect. Education had an effect upon the convergence of birth cohorts with regard to racial prejudice. This suggests that increasing levels of education among more recent birth cohorts has contributed to a lowering of racial prejudice in the South. The effects of residential mobility and movement to the city were relatively unimportant. What do these trends mean for the future regional distinctiveness of the South? Most likely, further population shifts from the Nonsouth to the South and increasing levels of education in the South will result in a continuing decline of attitudes and values generally associated with the culture of the southern U.S. The South as myth will probably continue to be fostered, however, in contemporary music, literature, and film. There is a need for future analyses of regional differences in other parts of the world, particularly given the increasing importance of regional ethnic and cultural factors in current international conflicts.

Title: Population control and the perseverance of eugenics: A case study of the politics of fertility control, Alvin Ratz Kaufman, 1930-1979
Abstract: Alvin Ratz Kaufman was an Ontario-based industrialist, philanthropist, and eugenicist, active in the field of birth control from the early 1930s until the late 1970s. For almost fifty years, and concurrent with his domestic efforts, Kaufman promoted the delivery of birth control overseas in Korea, India, Malaysia, Bangladesh and St. Vincent in the Caribbean; as he had within Canada, Kaufman favoured first the lay-delivery of "simple" contraceptives and after the war, sterilization, in order to limit the fertility of the social underclass. Kaufman's Canadian fertility control efforts in the 1930s have been relatively well documented; in particular, the 1936-7 trial of one of his home visitation workers for illegally advertising contraceptives has been extensively investigated. But his international and post-World War II efforts have been almost entirely ignored. Consequently, both Kaufman and the larger domestic birth control movement of which he was a member have been misinterpreted as primarily of intra-national importance. Furthermore, the failure to examine the continuation of Kaufman's birth control efforts after the Second World War has resulted in a narrow understanding of his methods. This thesis seeks to correct these oversights. (Abstract shortened by UMI.)

Title: Recommendations regarding themes to develop technological literacy
Abstract: The purpose of this investigation was to compile the recommendations of subject matter experts into a prioritized thematic framework for the development of technological literacy in college and university core courses. Fifteen recurring themes were identified through an extensive review of literature. Themes and clarifying descriptions were presented to technological literacy experts from diverse fields. Respondents were affiliated with either the New Liberal Arts (NLA) group or the Science, Technology & Society (STS) movement. The respondents' opinions were obtained from two telephone interviews. In Phase I, the recommendations of the respondents were combined to produce an updated list of 18 themes. The updated list included four additional themes, one consolidation of two themes, revisions for all of the descriptions, but no deletions. In Phase II, the respondents rated the themes on a 10-point scale. A one-way analysis of variance and a Scheffe comparison were used to test for significant differences among the mean ratings of themes. Only the top-ranked and the lowest-ranked themes were significantly different at the.05 level. Comments from the respondents added a dimension that was not conveyed by the quantitative ratings. The ratings and comments of respondents suggested that a variety of themes are important in the development of technological literacy in postsecondary core courses. Seventeen themes are offered to educators as a framework to guide the development of technological literacy. The prioritized list includes the following themes: change/diffusion; quantitative analysis; economic; political; environmental/ecological; technological; risk assessment; ethical/moral; social/cultural; historical; scientific; humanistic; international and global; military; behavioral; contemporary and futuristic; and human rights and freedom. Clarifying descriptions of each theme are included in the report. The prioritized list is not a recommendation that themes be taught in order; however attention should be devoted to the range of themes and to their prioritization. Although the themes are prioritized in the report, increments between adjacent ratings are far too small to approach statistical significance. It is recommended that a thematic approach be used to develop technological literacy in postsecondary core courses. The systemic change that is envisioned would provide organized and holistic curricular reform.

Title: A strategy for renewal and growth among the Pentecostal Churches of South India through small group ministry
Abstract: This dissertation is written with the intention of providing some helpful guidelines to the Pentecostal Churches of South India for renewal and Church growth. According to tradition Christianity came to South India in A.D. 52 through the apostle Thomas. By the fourth century the Syrian Orthodox Church was established in South India by the Syrian merchants who arrived in the State of Kerala for trade purposes. The Roman Catholics came with the arrival of the Portuguese by the end of the fifteenth century. Till this time there was no special attention given to the evangelization of the country. After the Protestant Reformation the Lutheran missionaries established their mission station in South India. Subsequent to their arrival many more mission organizations arrived. With the British as the rulers and Westerners as missionaries the ministry had very little effect upon the people of India. Evangelization was very slow. Those missionaries generally used the traditional methods of communication of the gospel through schools, hospitals, orphanages and preaching. With a culture that is caste oriented and diverse it was very difficult to effectively communicate the gospel. Today Christianity remains a minority with only about 4% of the population. After the emergence of the Pentecostal Churches from the beginning of this century the mission work became more active and many non-Christians accepted the Christian faith. Within the past several decades the Small Group ministry became very popular all around the world and it became a very effective means of Church growth in many countries. A brief survey of the various International Small Group movements is done to see its effectiveness in those countries. Under the present political and social setting of India the house Church movement and Small Group ministry will be very effective for the renewal and growth of the Pentecostal Churches. Through the Small Group ministry the lay people can be mobilized and many people can participate in the ministry and do very effective evangelism without much advertisement and by making use of spiritual gifts, Bible study and personal evangelism as the methods to reach the masses. Thus the Churches will be renewed and the masses will be reached with the gospel of Jesus Christ.

Title: Josef Frank and the crisis of modern architecture
Abstract: This dissertation is a study of the life and work of the Viennese architect Josef Frank (1885-1967) set against the rise, triumph, and decline of modern architecture. Now largely forgotten, Frank, who belonged to the same generation as Walter Gropius, Le Corbusier, and Ludwig Mies van der Rohe, played a seminal role in the history of modern architecture. After graduating from the Vienna Technische Hochschule in 1910, he established a practice with Oskar Strnad and Oskar Wlach, producing a series of houses in a pared-down, geometrical look that later became characteristic of the International Style. After World War I Frank emerged as one of the leading modernists in Austria. He was invited to participate in the epochal 1927 Weissenhof housing exhibition, and in 1928 he took part in the first meeting of the CIAM (Congres Internationaux d'Architecture Moderne). By the mid-1920s, however, Frank had begun to have growing doubts about the direction of modern architecture. Disturbed by what he viewed as the "machine pathos" and "romanticized" rationalism of the architectural left, he published essays and a book calling for a new, undogmatic approach to modernism, one which would be concerned less with issues of style and form and more with real human needs, both physical and psychological. In 1934 he left Austria and settled in Sweden, where he concentrated his attentions on interior design. His softened, comfortable, humanly-scaled furnishings were widely imitated by Scandinavian designers and helped inspire the Swedish Modern style. Late in life, Frank charted a new direction, this time calling for an architecture based on happenstance, an idea which he termed "Accidentism." Drawing on a wide variety of sources, this study seeks to reconstruct the intellectual, cultural, political, and social context in which Frank moved. It calls into question the notion of a unified modernist movement, arguing instead that modern architecture was continuously being redefined by its adherents and that this debate constituted an ongoing crisis. Frank's career and his critique of the radical modernists are viewed against these architectural debates and the forces that gave rise to postmodernism in the 1960s.

Title: Sendero Luminoso and the Indian problem in contemporary Peru: Conquering the other
Abstract: In the years following World War II, Peru experienced rapid economic and cultural changes, but within the confines of capitalism's uneven and contradictory development. Attempts to resolve these economic and ethnic discrepancies at regional and national levels--the re-opening of an important Andean university, the 1968 "Revolution" carried out by the armed forces--combined with the international political fissures produced by the Sino-Soviet split and the student movement of the late 1960s, to create a conjuncture favourable to the emergence of Sendero Luminoso in 1980. The complex, often ambiguous, ethnic landscape of the Andes, in which Sendero operates with mixed success, although long since penetrated by the destructive forces of capitalism, has proven impervious to Western social scientists and the Peruvian intellectual elite. In response to Sendero and the violence of the war both have resurrected, implicitly or explicitly, the old debate on the "Indian problem." Sendero represents both a case study in the conditions that can lead to revolutionary violence, and an example of the inadequacy of conventional academic wisdom to interpret and situate that violence.

Title: The CNT during the Second Republic in Barcelona: Leaders, activists, and members
Abstract: The CNT during the Second Republic in Barcelona; leaders, activists and members. This research had as its aim to analyze more throughly the functioning of one of the most influential trades-unions of the 1930's, the Confederacion Nacional del Trabajo (National Confederation of Labour), anarcho-syndicalist in tendency. Knowledge of its internal dynamics has allowed both a more detailed perception of the influence of the CNT amongst the workers, and to measure the variety, composition and strength of its activists and the nature of the relations it established with the majority of the working class. The militants of the Confederation appear in the light of this analysis as a large sector, although in a minority with respect to the total number of workers affiliated to the Confederation, that was very active and specialized in specific union tasks that depended on the place in which they developed their activities. The decisive sector consisted of the militants that participated in the organization's general and global discussions, in which not all members participated. It was a wide sector based around the single unions and which normally attended the general assemblies of militants that these unions called. Thus, the Confederation did not show a hierarchical structure like a pyramid, but a structure based on the existence of a diffuse responsibility in which a large collective participated. The militants of the base, however, did not participate in these general debates, and only dealt with tasks and demands of a professional nature. In this context the support of the majority of members affiliated to the Confederation can be explained, not exactly by their active participation in the life of the organization, but by specific nature of the libertarian movement of the time, which went far beyond mere union matters. Street life, the neighbourhoods, culture, leisure and the varied aspects of the social life of the working class were impregnated by libertarian ideals, and shaped the working-class culture of the time, and were the undeniable reference point the working class identified with.

Title: "Dancing At Lughnasa": The carnivalesque in Brian Friel's plays
Abstract: This thesis is an analysis of Brian Friel's play Dancing At Lughnasa, with specific reference to the carnivalesque element as it manifests itself in the play's dramaturgical and thematic composition. The introductory chapter traces the history of the practices of Carnival as they emanated from the seasonal fertility rites of various ancient cultures--all of which were assimilated by Christianity at a later date. It further identifies Mikhail Bakhtin as the twentieth century critic who designated the term "carnivalized literature" which draws on the actual occasions of revelry for its composition, but is also recognized as an entity within itself. Bakhtin's Carnival vocabulary ("crowning/uncrowning", "second life", "transformation downward") is applied firstly to the Irish Literary Renaissance (1898-1926) as the mainspring from which the tradition of Dancing is derived. The terms are subsequently applied to four selected plays of Friel between 1963 and 1987 and the context of Carnival is investigated in each play with respect to a dramaturgy that, as it becomes increasingly more diversified and complex, evolves from the verbal to the preverbal and visual. Dancing At Lughnasa's presentational/representational structure is perceived as one which alternately engages and alienates the audience. The play is viewed as a dramaturgical culmination and a thematic departure with respect to Friel's prior works. A highly evolved, festive, multifaceted dramaturgy (form) explores the nature of ritual and celebration (content). The character of the priest in this play is seen as Friel's resolution to the tension between the official and the unofficial--a continual preoccupation in his former works. Conversely the social, economic and political status of women emerges as an entirely new topic--one which is shown to be intrinsic to the notion of Carnival. The thesis concludes that the play is carnivalesque as to both form and structure but that revolution in the lives of the particular characters (the story) does not emerge from this marriage. Dance/music as a metaphor for the underlying dynamics between/among the Irish characters addresses the other themes of failure, unfulfillment, powerlessness, but in so doing it equally addresses the possibility of community and empowerment. The "international" or "universal" appeal of this particular play is thus ascribed to the vocabulary of the dance (movement) as one which precedes the parameters of any specific culture, Irish, African or whatever. The thesis finally concludes that this ambiguity of interpretation is integral to the notion of Carnival, which by definition concerns itself with the process of replacing, the refusal to concur with any fixed authority, the eternal question, rather than suggesting any definitive answer.
