Title: The establishment of ASI chapters in Tanzania
Abstract: Statement of project . The purposes of this project were first, to study the multifaceted aspects and the importance of ASI (Association of Privately Owned Seventh-day Adventist Services and Industries) in the United States of America, and second, to develop an approach for the establishment of ASI chapters in the Tanzania Union Mission of Seventh-day Adventists. Method . To accomplish the above purposes, primary sources of information were consulted, such as a survey of ASI and other relevant literature including ASI audio and video tapes in order to discover the historical background and cultural setting of ASI. The development of the self-supporting movement of the Seventh-day Adventist church from 1904–1947 and the recent trends from 1947 to the present have been described using the primary sources and supplemented through interviews and discussions with ASI leaders. Furthermore, the contributions of ASI to the Seventh-day Adventist church in the areas of home and mission projects and denominational structure (the means of revival) have been investigated. The second part of this study outlines the national and church conditions that justify the establishment of ASI chapters in Tanzania. Study has been given to the ways ASI chapters in Tanzania could help the Global Mission of the Seventh-day Adventist church. Such areas include health projects, improvement of the Tanzania Seminary and College, creation of scholarship funds by businessmen, improving small farms, nutrition seminars, training of lay people in witnessing techniques, and developing appropriate social centers. Summary, conclusions, and recommendations complete the whole study. Expectations from the project . The foremost expectation of this project was, is, and will be (1) the development of ASI chapters in Tanzania, (2) the involvement of more members in Global Mission projects and activities, giving Adventist lay people a sense of identity outside of their usual business associations and clubs, (3) increasing the public's awareness of the Seventhday Adventist church, and (4) the development of another resource for the furthering of God's work in Tanzania. And last, but not least, this project has helped me to develop and refine my skills, making me a resource person to help with the development of ASI chapters in the Tanzania Union Mission.

Title: Local conflict and ideological struggle: #positive images'and section 28
Abstract: The work focuses on a chain of events that began in the London Borough of Haringey in 1986. The Labour-led local council's adoption of a policy that would promote 'positive images' of homosexuality in local schools erupted into a conflict that led, in part, to Parliament's passage of Section 28 of the 1988 Local Government Act, which prohibits the 'promotion of homosexuality.' The dissertation examines the local conflict, investigating circumstances and actions that led to the creation of the policy, underlying economic, social and political tensions in the borough that were exacerbated by the conflict, and the consequent strategic opposition and support of both formally and informally constituted local political groups. It describes the movement of the conflict from the local to the national stage, analysing the national context in which coalitions opposed, supported, and attempted to ignore the policy in national political circles. It studies the construction of homosexuality as a campaign issue in the 1987 general election, the creation of the 1988 law, and the effects that the law had on the Borough. The work investigates the conflict's oppOSitional and exclusionary discourses on homosexuality embodied by the statements of those who were engaged in opposing the Haringey policy and supporting the Government's law. Five interrelated discourses of order were overwhelmingly present in the debates, are included in the brief text of the Section, and are contemporary interpretations of dominant historical discourses on homosexuality: 1. The promotion of 'positive images' of homosexuality is a form of political propaganda or indoctrination that poses a threat to the nation. 2. Homosexuality can be 'promoted' by homosexual predators who force, recruit and/ or proselytise their way of life on unsuspecting innocents. 3. Homosexuality is a disease that, combined with the more recent spectre of AIDS, creates a powerful threat of homosexuality -- or 'positive images' -- as spreading epidemic. 4. Homosexuality is a 'pretended family relationship' that reinforces a notion of 'real' family that consequently excludes other family forms. 5. 'Positive images' of homosexuality would adversely affect innocent children and troubled adolescents. Taken as a whole, the local and national conflict constituted an ideological struggle in which the meaning and import of homosexuality was severely contested and simultaneously transformed. It identifies and connects both action and discourse as major sites of ideological struggle. It posits the possibility of not 'studying down' nor 'studying up,' but of studying through, and thus offers an anthropological model that enables an integrated investigation of both local and global levels.

Title: The Sephardi community of Shanghai and the question of identity 1844 - 1937.
Abstract: From 1845 Baghdadi Jews settled in Shanghai via India, and over 100 years of existence, their numbers never exceeded 1,000. They were exposed to great changes in their social, economic and political environment. Traditionalists felt that loyalties to the customs of their Baghdadi forebears and occasionally even to Judaism itself were being threatened. The action they took to preserve their Jewish and ethnic identity is observed, and changes in ethnic identity in Shanghai between 1845 - 1937 are analysed. Attention is paid to their choice of the title `Sephardi'; the religious and communal institutions they established in order to preserve their identity; their contribution to the economic development of the International Settlement with particular reference to their investment in real estate; the reasons for their tenacious endeavours to be accepted as British subjects, while remaining loyal to their religion; and their restraint in identifying with the Zionist movement. Conventional methods of historical research have been used. Among a wide range of primary and secondary materials, particular reliance has been placed on the Israel's Messenger , the only newsheet from the community (published from 22 April 1904 to 17 October, 1941 with some interruptions). A number of interviews have also been carried out with erstwhile members of the community. It will be shown that the hopes and ambitions of the founding fathers, as expressed by David Solomon Sassoon that traders who left Baghdad to settle in new countries would remain true to the tenets of the Jewish religion and to the traditional observance of Baghdad, were partially fulfilled. This is an example of the flexibility achieved by so many Jewish communities in the Diaspora, while still remaining faithful to their essential beliefs and values, and which has contributed to their survival. It is hoped this addition to the considerable body of literature which documents the history of Jewish communities in the East will promote an understanding of their economic development and social transformation.

Title: Changing soundscapes: music and identity in Finland.
Abstract: This thesis presents an ethnography of contemporary folk music in an urban and in a rural context in Finland. The focus is on processes of transmission through the implementation of education programmes, performance contexts, the interrelations and divisions between musical genres, and musicians' perceptions of musical continuity and change. One of the principal questions addressed concerns how people express identity through music. The ways in which folk music has drawn on, and incorporated, traditions from diverse sources, including other European folk traditions and 'world' music, are described in conjunction with showing how Finnish identity is continually reconstructed in relation to neighbouring countries, and more generally in the global context. It is argued that music not only reflects, but also shapes, patterns of social identity. In the first part of the thesis (chapters 1-3) the historical, cultural and social contexts in which contemporary folk music may be interpreted are examined. An outline of the historical background is provided, followed by a discussion of folk music research and concepts of folk music within the context of nineteenth century nationalism. An account of the folk revival movement of the 1960s, focusing on trends of folk music research, education programmes, and musicians' performances and recordings, which contributed to the emergence of 'new folk' music in the 1980s, leads to the second part of the thesis. The ethnographic material presented in the second part (chapters 4-6) was collected from an urban (Helsinki) and a rural (Kaustinen) context. The way in which regional identities are stressed when various folk music traditions meet in the urban setting is first examined. The discussion continues with an examination of the fluidity and multiplicity of concepts of identity, and the interrelations between regional, national, and international identities in the rural setting.

Title: Popular participation in Sandinista Nicaragua: A case study of two rural cooperatives
Abstract: This thesis provides a detailed examination of the processes of participation which developed during the years of the Sandinista Government in Nicaragua (1979-90) and is based on extensive fieldwork on two rural cooperatives. Whereas the predominant analysis of the experience of popular participation during the period has emphasised structural level phenomena, here an attempt is made to combine actor-oriented and structural-historical approaches in order to identify the key factors which operated to shape the development of local participation. In such a way the thesis stresses how micro-level factors - life experiences, subjective meanings and group dynamics - interacted with macro-level processes. The thesis starts by identifying the dimensions and theories of popular participation which relate to its objectives, intensities and outcomes, in order to frame the research questions. The period studied is then contextualised with a history of Nicaragua, establishing the authoritarian conditions which marginalised the majority of Nicaraguans from economic development and political processes. Next, the thesis examines Sandinista political theory, the channels of popular participation and the macro-level factors which restricted its development. It also describes how the cooperative movement evolved during the period of Sandinista rule as an expression of the peasant movement in the context of state paternalism. The main analytical body of the thesis starts by providing background details about the two case studies. Then it details and compares the participatory processes underway within the cooperatives, focusing on the assembly, leadership and women; the different intensities of participation; and the social factors influencing it. These processes are evaluated qualitatively and it is demonstrated that despite apparent limitations, participation enhanced the social, political and psychological power of cooperative members although in different, uneven and contradictory ways. The thesis concludes that although the participation of peasants in national level structures was restricted, the objective conditions created by the FSLN contributed to the qualitative empowerment of individuals incorporated into cooperatives. International comparisons, theoretical and policy implications are finally noted.

Title: Women and AIDS in Brazil: The class, cultural, racial, sexual, and gender politics of a modern disease
Abstract: During the last three years, the number of women infected with H.I.V. in Brazil grew steadily, moving the epidemic out of what had been perceived as circumscribed risk groups and into a wider population. AIDS education efforts and accompanying AIDS discourses have been created mainly by elites, such as governmental and non-governmental organizations, religious groups, doctors, academics, and media producers. Simultaneously, AIDS is a major concern of international health organizations that promote specific policies in a variety of cultural settings. These national and international elites contest the meanings of scientific findings and the nature of sexuality. In addition, Brazilian elites struggle to create a broad-based social movement out of AIDS, and try to change sexual behavior through AIDS education. The politics of AIDS provides a unique case study of the politics of the relations between Brazilian elites and the impoverished masses. As AIDS increasingly spreads to impoverished women, the cultural gap between the classes is increasingly apparent. AIDS programs, failing to understand the sexual culture of the lower classes and the specific problems of impoverished women, fare poorly in their attempts to change sexual behavior in this disenfranchised population. My dissertation is a study of the politics of impoverished women's sexuality, how it relates to the spread of AIDS, how it is misunderstood and manipulated by elites, and how it relates to other aspects of class, cultural, racial, sexual, and gender relations in Brazil. Using participant observation and hundreds of interviews with both elite AIDS program workers and the class that serves them as impoverished domestic servants, my research examines the class-based cultural gap, using the AIDS crisis as a lens through which to view the class disjuncture in the discourse of sexuality. Through the juxtaposition and cultural analysis of the interrelated worlds of elite activism and impoverished women, I document how AIDS is constructed in the Brazilian context, particularly during the years 1991 and 1992. My dissertation research tries to enlarge our understanding of the cultural construction of sexuality, race, gender, public/private, AIDS, science, and new social movements in Brazil. Brazilian AIDS discourses are embedded in a complex web of sexual, racial, cultural, class, and gender politics that not only define the parameters of the epidemic, but also question and challenge the nature of public/private, class/culture, and masculine/feminine body politics in Brazil. I draw from a number of theoretical and interpretive frameworks drawn from inter-disciplinary sources to understand how AIDS discourses affect women. Writing the ethnography of AIDS education and political strategies as a sympathetic form of cultural critique could lead to the formulation of alternative strategies by AIDS organizations. Furthermore, providing a detailed account of how poor urban women discuss AIDS in the context of their own sexuality may also lead to a rethinking of AIDS education in the Brazilian cultural context. In addition, my research intends to bridge the gap in research on Brazilian women's sexuality. (Abstract shortened by UMI.)

Title: Philosophies of African American music history
Abstract: African-American music often reflects the political, social, and cultural currents of any given historical period. This dissertation examines the relationship between three currents (nationalism, cultural aesthetics, and musical historicism) and African-American music from the late 19th century to the present. African-American nationalism, based on the belief that African Americans in the United States share a common cultural foundation based on their African heritage and their experiences in the New World, covers a range of viewpoints, from assimilationism to separatism. Cultural aesthetics focus on the efforts of African Americans to develop philosophies of artistic expression that embody the African-American experience. Historians of African-American music, particularly through comprehensive histories, endeavor to create philosophies that depict the correlation between these three currents and music. The relationship of African-American nationalism and cultural aesthetics to music will be examined in four "test cases": (1) the African-American concert spiritual from the 1870s through the 1940s, (2) African-American musical theater from its origins in the 19th century through Joplin's Treemonisha (1911), (3) jazz, with particular attention to the music of Duke Ellington, and (4) rap music from the 1970s through the 1990s. Each of these genres was created by African-American artists primarily for African-American audiences and later modified (by either Euro-American or African-American musicians) in order to appeal to mainstream American audiences. The spiritual began as African-American folk music but became known to national and international audiences through concert arrangements. The ragtime music of Joplin's era had its origins in saloons and bars; nevertheless, Joplin sought to place ragtime within the tradition of European art music with the composition of his opera Treemonisha. The multi-movement compositions of Ellington owe much to both African-American and Euro-American musical traditions. Rap, which originated as African-American dance music in the late 1970s and later became a vehicle for African-American political and social expression, "crossed over" from African-American audiences to mainstream American audiences by the mid-1980s.

Title: Innovators and gravediggers: Capital restructuring and class formation in Ann Arbor, Michigan, 1945-1994
Abstract: This dissertation examines how international economic transformations converged with capital restructuring efforts and local progrowth coalitions to redesign Ann Arbor's physical and cultural landscape. It also studies the effects on working-class communities and the shifting contours of class formation. I begin with the area's largest economic institution, the University of Michigan, and the evolution of federal and corporate spending on scientific research. Consequently, U-M restructured fundraising efforts, research programs, and administrative departments to attract venture capital. Business and political leaders reacted by coordinating campaigns to attract R&D companies to Ann Arbor, the self-proclaimed "Research Center of the Midwest." Yet, subsequent development displaced working-class neighborhoods, particularly the African-American community on the city's Northside. After WWII, these neighborhoods possessed economic institutions and cultural organizations that buttressed a powerful local civil rights movement. While gaining strength from national events, most efforts grew from traditional cultural practices and community networks that had historically empowered fights for dignity and survival in a racist community. The final chapters examine how all of these changes reflect and reinforce transformations in class structures and cultures: a new petite bourgeoisie ushers in a scientific paradigm integrating research and enterprise; peripheral development forces downtown merchants to meet the new tastes of sophisticated and globalized consumption practices; and new disciplinary narratives rationalize postindustrial production and postmodern culture. However, fragments of working-class resistance have drawn on experiences with the new socio-spatial organization of economic and social life to challenge postindustrial policies and ideologies. By drawing on emerging and residual notions of community, groups of homeless activists and public housing tenants have integrated life experiences with political action to struggle against elite progrowth visions of the postindustrial city. This study employs methodologies including archival and oral history work as well as ethnographic and participatory research to investigate the dialectical dynamics of capital accumulation, institutional restructuring and class struggle in a postindustrial city.

Title: Recharting the Caribbean: Land, law and citizenship in the British Virgin Islands
Abstract: Previous anthropological research on the Caribbean has presupposed rather than problematized the region's colonial past and nation-building present. The literature on colonial discourse and nationalism developed for other regions has no counterpart in the Caribbean literature. This dissertation's focus on colonial processes and the modern state is intended as a corrective. Based on a year of fieldwork in the British Virgin Islands, it explores how modern statecraft and law have helped differentiate British Virgin Islanders from other Caribbean peoples with whom they share a colonial past. It investigates contradictions of the current regime as British Virgin Islanders struggle to define a "national" culture while maintaining their colonial relationship with Britain, becoming an important tax haven, and attracting increasing numbers of immigrants from other Caribbean places. This dissertation demonstrates how kinship, nationality, race, place, and land came to be defined as "natural" entities that determine human life, and argues that the liberal state was central to this creation of a determining and determinate nature through its legislative and administrative procedures. The construction of a "nature" that is seen to constrain choices co-occurred with the introduction of democratic institutions. Why would democracy foster the construction of "nature" when under democratic principles people and not forces outside of human control are called upon to shape society? The answer proposed is that this construction resolves the contradiction between the liberal dictum that all persons are equal and the observation that some people seem to be more equal than others. Ideas about a natural order have come to justify a social order in which half the population is deemed "not to belong" and is denied citizenship. This ordering of the world has resulted in the exclusion of people from political participation, the exploitation of labor, and the movement of capital across international borders. At the same time it consolidates "British Virgin Islanders" as more similar to each other than to immigrants and is central to the invention of "national" identity in this late twentieth-century colony. The dissertation points toward similar processes occurring worldwide as "ethnic" and "nativist" attachments become increasingly important to people living in market societies, but argues that these attachments are recent constructions rather than primordial.

Title: The political economy of direct foreign investment: The case of Taiwan
Abstract: Direct foreign investment (DFI) has become a primary vehicle for technology transfer and capital movement from advanced countries to Third World countries. While DFI may not be a necessary condition for economic growth in developing countries, foreign capital and advanced technology certainly facilitate their economic growth one way or another. Taiwan's successful economic development over the past decades has been widely recognized. In the early stages of Taiwan's economic development, foreign investment contributed to capital accumulation and foreign exchange surplus. In the case of Taiwan, even though DFI is not as important as often thought, there is no doubt that it has been quite important in Taiwan's economy, not to mention its political implication. In searching for the factors causing the changes in the trends and features of DFI, current literature only considers demand-side effects (i.e., the host country's political stability, healthy economy, and inexpensive labor force) and economic factors while excluding supply-side effects (i.e., multinational's investment strategy, and its home government's attitude toward overseas investment) and political and social mechanisms. Accordingly, the primary objectives of this study are threefold. The first is to understand the major factors that determine the inflow of DFI in Taiwan. The basic argument that I make in this regard is that both demand and supply-side effects are equally crucial in affecting inward DFI. The second is to search for insights on the differences among foreign investors who have brought capital into Taiwan. Regional differences such as market orientation, ownership structure, the size of investment project, and sectoral difference among these investors, especially American, Japanese, and overseas Chinese, are a major concern in this regard. Finally, this study attempts to understand the momentum for changes in the nature of DFI. It argues that if change in the trends and features of inward DFI is the primary dependent variable we want to explain, the structural factors, which include both domestic and international political and socio-economic mechanisms, are the fundamental independent variables to explain this change.

Title: Pluralism and liberation: A critical-constructive conversation for postmodern Christian theology
Abstract: Contemporary Christian theology is marked by its concern for efficacy in promoting social justice and by its attention to the challenges of the various pluralisms that characterize the postmodern world. To date, however, these two matters have tended to be pursued in separate theological movements. Latin American Liberation theology, the most systematically developed expression of the socio-political dimensions of Christian faith, and the pluralist theology of religions, the most radical theological assessment of the place of Christianity in the religiously diverse world, are here brought together in a critical and comparative study. After a critical survey of traditional approaches to religious pluralism in Christian theology, the pluralist model is exposited and defended through an examination of four "cases" made by contemporary Christian philosophers and theologians for a de-absolutized, non-normative understanding of Christianity. Assessment of the critiques of pluralist theology, however, indicate that as presently articulated, this theology faces serious challenges. Central among these are its epistemological inconsistencies and its relative inability to specify the distinctiveness of Christian identity and norms for Christian practice. The conversation with liberation theology affords insights at these points of vulnerability. The praxis-based method developed by liberation theologians, in which the truths of faith are discovered and verified in the practice of working with and for the oppressed, its soteriocentric interpretation of the normativity of Jesus Christ, and its understanding of the relationality of God all offer to pluralist theology ways of affirming the normative truths of Christian commitment without imposing them on those of other perspectives, or so distorting them, in the name of interreligious harmony, that they cease to resemble that on which Christians have staked their lives. Because the Latin American movement has not itself attended to problems of pluralism and thus has not absorbed many of these insights, this conversation raises reciprocal challenges for liberation theology. Specifically, it will need to re-examine its own normative christological claims in relation to its description of the open-ended engagement of God in liberation struggles. This examination promises to enhance liberation theology's potential for global networking and prompt a deepening of its understanding of the commitment to the priority of orthopraxis over orthodoxy. The confluence of the experientially grounded and politically committed method of liberation theology and the dialogical, anti-absolutist approach of pluralist thought results in a theology that is greater than the sum of its parts. A finial component of this study is an effort to suggest the dimensions of such a theology by presenting a sketch of the liberationist-pluralist theology currently developing among Christian theologians in Asia, where the experiences of religious pluralism and the experiences of poverty and oppression intersect.

Title: Sudanese-New World migration: The social history of Sudanese international migration to the United States and Canada
Abstract: This study concentrates on the social history of Sudanese international migration to the United States and Canada. Previous studies undertaken on Sudanese migratory phenomena were primarily concerned with migration to oil-rich Arab countries (i.e. Kuwait, Saudi Arabia, Iraq, Libya, Qatar, and United Arab Emirates), this study is the first attempt to investigate Sudanese New World migration, and in specific the new waves of Sudanese migration to the US and Canada since the Gulf war of 1991 and the renewal of the civil war in the Sudan in 1989. The basic hypothesis of this research is that an earlier, small temporary migration from the Sudan to the New World, based principally (but not exclusively) on seeking higher education has been replaced by a newer, larger migration stemming from political unrest, economic stringency and a new lack of choice in migration. This latter group, of recent Sudanese arrivals, it is hypothesized, are characterized by diverse socioeconomic histories, more selective demographic differentials, fewer fundamental alternatives, and subsequent different adjustments to New World life, than earlier migrants. The study seeks to provide empirical evidence on Sudanese migration to North America by investigating three major questions: (1) Who are the migrants and from where do they come? (2) What are the reasons prompting their migration to the US and Canada? (3) How are they adapting to living in North America? The research utilized the classical anthropological methods of structured questionnaires, collection of life histories, in-depth interviews of key informants, and the examination of published and unpublished documentary sources. The most significant picture emerging from this research is that, apart from the early Sudanese migratory movement since World War II, and that of Sudanese students from the 1960s the bulk of Sudanese international migrants are very recent arrivals in the New World. Their migration was an outcome of the totality of contextual and structural variables associated with politics, war and religion prompting Sudanese with diverse ethnicity, religious affiliations and migration biographies to leave for the New World. Consequently, Sudanese migrants presently are a less monolithic group than earlier migrants. It is noticeable that not only significant differentiation's exist with respect to their selective characteristics, but also with respect to their status in the New World (i.e. students, refugees, asylees, citizens, permanent residents and diplomats). Previously, most migrants were students (and some are an unique early migrant community in Brooklyn). It follows that today both legal and illegal migrants have dramatically altered the past pattern, character, culture and shape of Sudanese international migration. Moreover, the magnitude of Sudanese migratory movements is dramatically increasing. As a consequence of the variables associated with politics and war, the country has also experienced a pronounced exodus of its most industrious segments of its manpower. These complex and peculiar push factors are analyzed in Sudan, and along with the classical pull factors of the New World migration, are compared with similar data characterizing other migrant communities.

Title: Altruistic bequests and international capital movements
Abstract: This thesis develops two theoretical models of long-run capital movements, in which international capital flows arise from difference in altruistic tastes between two economies. The models are used to explore the implications of the inter-generational assets transfer via altruistic bequests outstanding issues of the long-run capital movements theory, such as the determination of capital flows and the effects of capital market integration on individual/national savings, domestic income/wealth distribution, and individual welfare. The first model contrasts/compares the aggregate savings and overall macro characteristics of no-bequests, life-cycle economy (a la Cass-Yarri) as against a perfectly altruistic, bequest economy (a la Barro-Becker). Given identical technology and time preference rate, the bequest economy will run a current account surplus in the steady-state equilibrium of the integrated world economy with capital mobility. Comparing capital formation under autarky and openness for each economy, capital mobility increases the long-run national wealth of the bequest economy. By contrast, the life-cycle economy may have the greater or smaller steady-state national assets under openness. For both economies, the ranking of stationary individual welfare levels under autarky and openness depends critically upon the efficiency of their respective autarkic steady-state. However, the prospective wealthy groups in the bequest economy, expected to inherit substantially large bequests, would always be better off under openness. In the Gini-coefficient and the coefficient of variation, the capital market integration worsens the stationary intra-family distribution of total wealth (the sum of human and financial wealth) for the bequest economy. Based on social welfare functions (or Lorenze) criterion, however, the ranking of distributions is ambiguous. The second model addresses the same issues as in the first model, but under an extended version of the model which builds on a generalized form of inter-generational taste allowing of imperfect altruism. The first model's extrapolation of the Fisherian economy and bequest economy is lessened, and the two economies therein are now explained as two special cases associated respectively with insufficiently weak altruism or perfect altruism. The open-economy analysis finds that an array of conflicting theoretical results/predictions of the capital movement literature so far can be reconciled into coherent interpretations, all in view of the degrees of intergenerational altruism and the prevalence of the intergenerational assets transfer via bequests.

Title: "An innocent way out": The literature and politics of cultural pluralism, 1880-1925
Abstract: In contemporary debates on multiculturalism, 'pluralism' signifies a number of contradictory and mutually exclusive ideological positions. This dissertation situates these debates by locating the cultural and intellectual antecedents of multiculturalism beyond the social movements of the 1960s, and toward the turn of the century. The first part of the dissertation explores the intellectual genealogy of pluralism within the pragmatic tradition of William James. In 1898, James summarizes the crux of his concept in a syllabus for Philosophy I at Harvard: "The rule is that one victorious should so far as possible keep the vanquished somehow represented. Find some innocent way out." His brand of 'genteel pluralism' illustrates a form of crisis management, which tries to expand the boundaries of cultural inclusion at a time when the nation was undergoing dramatic demographic and economic changes. After the First World War, two of James' students, Horace Kallen and W. E. B. Du Bois, develop a pluralist politics but along different ideological lines. Kallen appropriates Jamesian pluralism for liberal progressivism, while Du Bois inscribes it within a tradition of international socialism. The second half of the dissertation examines the aesthetic manifestations of pluralism in two popular genres of the turn of the century magazine boom: local color sketches and intra-urban walking tours. Both genres chronicle "how the other half lives," either from the perspective of the Howellsian flaneur searching for picturesque ruins in the Lower East Side tenements, or Garland's "native novelist" representing the "vanquished" regions of the nation. Pluralism's elasticity, however, reaches its representational limit with Maria Amparo Ruiz de Burton's use of the term "vanquished" to describe the Mexicans who lost their land in post-1848 California and Mary Church Terrell's 1903 alternative walking narrative of Washington, D.C. The epilogue explores the development of contemporary socialist renditions of multiculturalism. These renditions show a counter-hegemonic genealogy of pluralism, which still continues among certain cultural workers today.

Title: "Rights, not roses": Women, industrial unions, and the law of equality in the United States, 1945-1980
Abstract: This dissertation explores how economic, social, and legal changes influenced the history of gender relations in industrial unions between 1945-80. It considers as well the active part union men and women played in shaping the direction particular unions took regarding "women's issues," protective labor legislation, and equal rights legislation. This project examine how workers constructed these concerns within labor's ranks and why certain contemporary concerns such as comparable worth moved to the forefront of union agendas by the late 1970s. This dissertation presents case studies and overview chapters in a chronological fashion. Early chapters provide historical background to the growing call by many for gender equality in the 1945-63 period in the form of equal pay demands. At the same time, the accelerating trend of automation undercut the rationale for protectionism by eliminating the "heavy" job elements used to justify preventing women from taking "men's" jobs. The growing rhetoric of equality from the civil rights movement gave rank-and-file members a framework with which to demand their rights as women. These women used Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964's ban on sex discrimination in employment to file discrimination charges against their unions and employers. They protested against protectionism and helped usher in the law of equality. The core of this dissertation consists of case studies of two unions: the United Packinghouse Workers and the International Union of Electrical Workers. While the packinghouse union men displayed a "confrontationist" approach to quality demands, the electrical unionists exhibited an "accomodationist" perspective. This is explained by the two organizations' distinct industrial structure, membership composition, institutional structure, and political history.

Title: Reinventing nature: Science narratives as myths for an endangered planet
Abstract: This dissertation is a philosophical and ethical inquiry into the possibilities of a mythological treatment of the modern scientific cosmology in light of global environmental crises. I develop a method for this project by examining science as a philosophical and moral problem following the critiques of empiricism by Hilary Putnam and Thomas Kuhn, and then turning to radical deconstructions of science by Sandra Harding, Cornell West, and others. This discussion sets the stage for a shift to a hermeneutical approach to the sciences which I develop with the help of Paul Ricoeur. The dynamics of interpretation are extended in ways that illuminate the impact of metaphors, models and paradigm shifts on the content and culture of science. This social-biophysical hermeneutics better accounts for the actual phenomena of science, nature, and society, and provides pragmatic and productive possibilities for mythically "reinventing nature" as a way to reinvent human thought and behavior in this moment of evolutionary crisis. I then explore in The Universe Story by Thomas Berry and Brian Swimme as an example of a new mythological approach to modern science. The authors "read" the scientific cosmology as a value-laden natural history which present humans with guidance at a moment of crisis in evolution. The three-fold Cosmogenetic Principle of differentiation, autopoiesis, and communion becomes a description of all phenomena at all moments in the evolutionary epic and a prescription for human adaptation strategies at the end of the Cenozoic era. I then reassess this discussion with the help of Donna Haraway on the basis of a radical postmodern hermeneutics that looks with suspicion on "one-true stories" as counter to emancipatory struggles. Haraway helps to more deeply ground this project within the power-charged dynamics of a hermeneutical conversation between human and nonhuman agents. I conclude with a hermeneutical conversation as a model for human-nature thought and behavior that promotes an environmental ethics and inspires an eco-justice movement of voluntary simplicity. This remythologization of science offers theoretical and motivational models for reinventing nature and ourselves in a mutually enhancing and sustainable manner.

Title: The culture of conquest: The British colonists and Nova Scotia, 1690-1759. (Volumes I and II)
Abstract: The topic of this dissertation, in the broadest terms, is the origin of Manifest Destiny. More narrowly it explores why the British colonists decided to acquire territory in New France, and their debate over how to treat the people who lived there. Before the middle years of the eighteenth century, the English settlers who agitated for expansion advanced specific reasons for their projects and in general pleaded self-defense. The New Englanders, mindful of Old Testament strictures against wars of conquest, never claimed that acquiring territory was a good thing in itself. During the second third of the eighteenth century, growing trans-Atlantic contacts changed the outlook of many New Englanders. Some of them came to see their accomplishments as part of a global movement, the expansion of the British Empire. Others adopted an equally imperialistic religious outlook. With respect to Nova Scotia (the old French colony of Acadia), the policies endorsed by these expansionists constituted a huge social experiment. By resettling the Acadians in nine of the thirteen colonies, they hoped to assimilate them, despite their French background and Catholicism, into British colonial society. The supporters of this policy used force to make the exiled Acadians join Protestant, English-speaking communities. Many of the Acadians fled to Canada and others to Louisiana, but by 1783 those who remained on the seaboard were recognized as citizens of the United States. Contrary to expectations, not all of them had become Protestants, but Catholicism was no longer an insurmountable barrier to entry into Anglo-American society. Expansionism, religious toleration, and racism had become inextricably linked. The Micmacs, the Indian inhabitants of Nova Scotia, were not treated as kindly as the Acadians. Beginning in 1749 the provincial government offered bounties for their scalps. The stated objective of this policy was to make room for white Protestant settlers. In the mid-eighteenth century, for the first time, Anglo-American political leaders argued that conquest was a mark of human progress and that the spread of Anglo-American culture justified exterminating the Indians. They self-consciously put these ideas into practice in Nova Scotia.

Title: On the frontiers of empire: British administration in Kenya's Northern Frontier District, 1905-1935
Abstract: This thesis is a study of British administration in Kenya's Northern Frontier District (NFD) between 1905 and 1935. It examines the colonial policies and institutions which governed the mainly pastoral African societies who inhabited the frontier region. This work argues that the colonial authorities treated the NFD much differently than the rest of Kenya and that, because of the administration's absorption with "law and order," the province's political and economic development was neglected. It is based primarily on British archival sources including the correspondence between Kenya governors and the Colonial Office in London and official records which originated from within the frontier administration. This work surveys developments in northern Kenya during the nineteenth century as well as the political, economic, and social institutions of the peoples who inhabited the region at that time. It examines the extension of colonialism into the north and the emergence of a frontier policy on the part of the British colonial administration. The problems of policing the border region form a major part of this thesis. Accordingly, this study considers brigandage, inter-ethnic raiding, and the movement of peoples across international boundaries in detail. This thesis also analyzes the means and instruments of colonial control in the NFD. The land dispute between the Samburu and European settlers over the Leroghi plateau is discussed. Finally, this work probes issues associated with the imposition of taxation throughout the NFD as well as the impact of colonial policies on the economic development of the region.

Title: International competitiveness and its implications on industrial policy
Abstract: A substantial change has taken place over the last two decades in the trade patterns and distribution of economic and industrial capacity among the United States, Western Europe and Japan. This is increasingly attributed to a movement to the "fifth Kondratiev cycle" from the oil-based old technological regime to what is called the "New Techno-Economic Paradigm" based on microelectronics. In the context of this new paradigm, the question of external trade has been transformed into the question of competitiveness, measured by the ability of a country to develop and produce what are called "new technology goods". For a country to compete successfully in the global markets, inputs that are deficient can be remedied by appropriate policy measures to promote the production of these goods. This study analyzes the question of competitiveness within this new paradigm, taking the case of Malaysia. It is found that Malaysia is competitive in the trade of these new technology goods, defined to be comprised of the Standard International Trade Classifications (SITC) 5, 7 and 8. The behavior of the underlying inputs that are crucial to the production of these goods are analyzed, while simultaneously, the arguments of the new paradigm of the importance of technology in the production process are verified. The translog GNP function is used to analyze the behavior of these inputs and other macroeconomic variables. Imports are treated as variable inputs, while domestic factors as fixed inputs. Since the general results of the model are found to be consistent with previous empirical findings, further disaggregation is subsequently done. Imports of new technology goods and human capital inputs are found to be important for the production in this sector, and they behave as substitutes, reflecting the fact that imported technologies are substitutable to domestic technologies. Physical and human capital are found to be complements, while capital and labor are found to change from substitutes to complements, a new phenomenon in recent empirical findings. The implications of these results on policy are then derived in a more comprehensive method, encompassing the economic, social and institutional aspects of policy-making.

Title: Radio preaching in the World War II era: The cases of Harry Emerson Fosdick and Charles Coughlin on war and peace
Abstract: This dissertation has studied the political use of religious radio in America. Chapter two examined the many changes in America in the period before and including World War Two and how Christian preaching in America responded. Major phenomena examined include global political alliances, the rise of ecumenism, the Great Depression, the New Deal, the fundamentalist-modernist debates, the social gospel movement, and the development of commercial radio and religious broadcasting. Chapter three focused on ecumenical and liberal Christian use of radio. Mainline Protestants interested in using radio joined Jewish and Catholic organizations and received free network airtime through arrangements established by the Federal Council of Churches. Harry Emerson Fosdick's use of radio was examined historically and rhetorically. Aristotelian analysis was applied to four wartime radio sermons that dealt with the topics of war and peace. It was discovered that Fosdick's rhetorical success was due largely to his use of logos and ability to speak directly to relevant concerns of listeners. Chapter four examined the conservative Christian response to radio. The arrangement between the Federal Council of Churches and NBC and CBS created a liberal Protestant monopoly that angered conservative evangelicals. They responded by establishing their own broadcasting facilities and by purchasing time on individual stations and Mutual Broadcasting System. A study of Father Charles Coughlin followed. Coughlin devised his own "network" of stations and used his program for political advantage. A rhetorical analysis of four radio sermons revealed his strengths were related to style, ethos, and pathos, but his use of logos was faulty.

Title: Public opinion, international security policy, and gender: The United States and Great Britain since 1945
Abstract: This study investigates the impact of gender upon attitudes on international security and defense policy. It analyzes a comprehensive collection of public opinion polls and surveys conducted in the United States and Great Britain since 1945. The expectations of sociological, feminist difference, risk perception, and structural political theories are tested against the empirical evidence. This research examines the aggregate gender differences in opinions on the use of conventional military force and on the testing, deployment, and use of nuclear weapons. It finds large, stable, and significant gender gaps on security policy attitudes, which persist from World War II to the Gulf War in both nations. Significantly more men than women supported the use of force in international affairs. Males also had higher levels of knowledge and of self-reported awareness, attention, and interest in foreign and nuclear policy issues. Females perceived greater risks and expected worse consequences from military and defense policies. More women than men thought that the chances of war were high, and they expressed more worry about war also. There is no particular growth or decrease in the size of gender differences over time on most issues. Neither changing social and economic roles of women nor the women's movement has affected the bivariate gender gaps. Multivariate analyses of the 1990-91 American National Election Study (NES) demonstrate significant independent influences of gender upon opinions about US involvement in the Gulf War. Political efficacy, partisanship, and attentiveness also differentially influence the opinions of women and men. Mothering, feminist ideology, education, and age do not have significant, consistent impacts. Socially constructed roles for women and men and structural impediments to the equal political participation of women in security policy-making explain these gender gaps in public attitudes. These causal factors are likely to persist in western societies, so that gender differences on war and peace issues will continue in the future. These attitudinal differences have implications for voting, political participation, activism, elite recruitment, and the democratic politics of foreign policy-making.

Title: Critical intellectuals and the new media: Bernward Vesper, Ulrike Meinhof, the Frankfurt School and the Red Army Faction
Abstract: The Red Army Faction (RAF) originated in the international crisis of the 1960's. The urban guerrilla movement they instigated was modeled on Third World insurrections. It was also determined by the exigencies of the political environment created in Western Europe by the ascendancy of the electronic media. The role of the traditional intellectual, what Foucault called the "universal intellectual," generally a "man of letters," became problematic with the rise of television, the post-war reorganization of the economy, the process of decolonization and the feminist challenge to patriarchal authority. The crisis of the universal intellectual was simultaneously a crisis of writing as a critical institution. Bernward Vesper responded to this crisis by integrating the use of hallucinogenic drugs and mechanical recording devices into the writing process. The result was the creation of a written text, Die Reise, that simulated the effects of LSD. Ulrike Meinhof, who made her name as a critical journalist, attempted to overcome the limitations of her work through forays into radio and television culminating in her teleplay, "Bambule." However, her involvement in the founding of the RAF ultimately overshadowed her experiments in the electronic media. The urban guerrilla transformed her body and the bodies of her comrades into a political medium which made West Germany's political situation visible. These bodies also became political weapons through which a struggle for liberation was waged. This corporal transformation was a reaction against authoritarian aggression and the result of an interaction with critical social thought particularly that of the Frankfurt School. Theory, in order to be revolutionary, had to change bodies; it had to make bodies resistant to hegemonic systems of power and oppression. The RAF attempted both to produce a theory that would have this effect and, through their actions, to demonstrate the appropriate transformations a revolutionary body should undergo. The trace of the group, photographic and otherwise, became the privileged site of their struggle by providing a core for a new, radical identity. The trace also marked the convergence of the RAF's political desire with sexual desire, highlighting the threat of women as militant revolutionary leaders.

Title: Olympic power plays: A social analysis of CTV's production of the 1988 Winter Olympic ice hockey tournament
Abstract: This dissertation is a study of the Canadian Television Network's (CTV) production of the 1988 Winter Olympic ice hockey tournament. A critical cultural studies analysis of the production site, the crew, Olympic and network decision makers is conducted on a number of levels including the political, economic and cultural spheres of broadcasting. On the broadest political-economic level, Olympic broadcasting is analyzed to question how Canada's national private network strategically employed Olympic hockey as a spectacle of accumulation to boost ratings, expand market positioning, strengthen their media monopoly, and attract national sponsors while blocking national broadcast competitors. To study the political-economic level, three methods are utilized including (1) interviews with network and Olympic officials, (2) document analysis of media and Olympic policies, papers, memos and texts, and (3) ethnographic observation of the media officials in the Broadcast Centre and at the SaddleDome hockey venue. Ethnographic observation of the labour process of the CTV hockey crew at the arena, informed by the semiotic insights of critical communication studies, provides the second level of understanding, Olympic broadcasting as a spectacle of legitimation. These observations illustrate how the crew re-make the live sporting event into a series of cultural images to "sell" the national audience. These images are compatible with the commercial and sporting ideologies of the "Olympic family" (including the International Olympic Committee, media rights holders and exclusive sponsors), and broadcasts that are compatible with mythologies of the unofficial Canadian "national game". The ethnographic elements of production appraised in this study include the division of media labour, crew relations, social-aesthetic use of broadcast technology, the conventional employment of sporting codes of commentary and visual codes of television mediation. Despite covering a losing Team Canada, which had been positioned as a medal hopeful by CTV programmers prior to the 1988 Games, this study demonstrates how the television crew laboured to reclaim hockey as "the" Canadian sport in order to reassert a self-proclaimed superiority in producing the television feed for all world broadcasters. The work to create Olympic telecast images of the sporting spectacle is revealed to be a social process that legitimates select systems of meaning, reinforces particular modes of media production and strengthens monopolistic political-economic relationships: the circuit of cultural production constructs a profoundly patriotic and patriarchal version of hockey that momentarily serves the economic and marketing interests of the CTV network and the Olympic movement, while reproducing the cultural-economic power of the National Hockey League as the hockey reference system for broadcasting spectacles of this game.

Title: Interpretive adult education: Language and lifelong learning in university, industry, and community settings in Hawaii and Singapore
Abstract: This study investigates the sociocultural aspects and transformative process of language and lifelong learning programs in Hawaii and Singapore. As Pacific Rim island communities, Hawaii and Singapore were chosen because they are rich in cultural diversity, and they have active adult education programs. The interpretive nature of language and lifelong learning and the implications for adult education are examined through analysis of conversations with seven adult educators in Hawaii and seven in Singapore. Three categories guided the research conversations with the participants: (1) the interpretive nature of language, (2) the role of tradition and culture in learning, and (3) lifelong learning as transformation. Critical hermeneutics was used as the theoretical basis for this research study. The text developed during the conversations with the participants was transcribed and analyzed using the philosophical tenets of Gadamer, Habermas, Heidegger, and Ricoeur. This hermeneutic field-based research methodology was utilized as a process for reaching new understandings and actualizing meaning. The results of this research show: (1) The future for adult education is a movement to interpretive adult education. Adult education is socially and culturally constructed with lifelong learning and language as foundations. (2) Understanding of traditional values is essential for communication in conversation or discourse. (3) The distinction between East and West cultural values is a primary concern for participants. (4) Sociocultural issues encourage educators to focus on understanding how relationship creates an opportunity for student understanding and transformation. Both Hawaii and Singapore would benefit from developing an understanding of core cultural values that represent the people as community, irrespective of race or religion. A shared vision would join the Asian-Pacific region and enhance the meaning and understanding of these core values. A global interdependence that highlights the similarities of the Pacific region and the common economic aspirations can connect people in these geographical areas. This common concern can create a cultural bridge built for the betterment of these geographical and social neighbors. To accomplish a transformation to interpretive adult education, educators can shift from thinking of education as merely information-giving to education that emphasizes relationship, understanding, and lifelong learning.

Title: The life and thought of jacques ellul with special reference to his writings on law, violence, the state, and politics
Abstract: This thesis presents an original interpretation of the life and thought of Jacques Ellul, one of the most important contributors to contemporary Christian social and political thought. Based on the most comprehensive research of the primary source material undertaken to date, it clarifies the context, structure, central content, and coherence of his thought as a whole and also examines in detail certain aspects of his social and political thought. It argues that Ellul is a revolutionary dissenter whose personalist convictions and faith in Jesus Christ made him a radical critic of modernity. His writings analyse the modern world and study Scripture in order to encourage others to understand and revolt against the catastrophic path taken by twentieth century man and to incarnate the word of God in the contemporary world. The thesis has a bipartite structure comprising a "macro-analysis" which offers a global reading of Ellul ( Part One ) and a "micro-analysis" which presents individual case-studies of four subjects central to his social and political thought ( Part Two ). PART ONE offers a detailed biography of Ellul and a brief outline of the origins, structure, and purpose of his corpus ( chapter one ). Ellul's theology and ethics are interpreted by focussing on the relationship between God and the world in terms of communion and rupture ( chapter two ). His sociology is shown to originate in the 1930s personalist movement and to have as its central themes the novelty of modernity, the crisis of civilization, and the dominance of Technique ( chapter three ). A short conclusion discusses the dialectical relationship between his sociology and his theology ( chapter four ). PART TWO examines four important themes in Ellul's work which are also significant in the history of Christian political thought and modern political theology and social ethics: law ( chapter five ), violence ( chapter six ), and the state and politics ( chapter seven ). (D 193, 300).

Title: Complex interactions in social behaviour and ecology
Abstract: Insect social behaviour and population dynamics are studied from the point of view of the Science of Complexity, that is, the analysis of the non-linear dynamical properties that emerge from the interactions of large numbers of elements. In insect social behaviour, the interactions among individuals that communicate and respond to the presence of other individuals within the same colony, generate new global phenomena such as the "group effects" or "social facilitation" where patterns of behaviour different from those observed in individuals arise solely because of the interactions. In this study, this phenomenon has been examined both theoretically and empirically in ants and in termites. Ants show changes in the dynamics of the colony activity as the nest density varies, while termites attain large survival rate as a function of group size. Theory and experiments are discussed. The second part of this thesis is concerned with the study of host-parasitoid models that exhibit complex dynamics such as chaos and spatial self-organization. Chaos via a quasiperiodic route is shown to exist in many well-known host-parasitoid population models. Furthermore, it is shown that this kind of route to chaos is less unaffected than others under the presence of immigration. Host-parasitoid models with explicit spatial dimension are analysed to study the consequences of density dependent parasitoid movement. Finally, the equilibrium stability consequences of dispersal in metapopulation models are explored. (DXN005082)

Title: Social relations and migration: a study of post-war migration with particular reference to migration from bangladesh to britain
Abstract: The objective of this thesis is to study the phenomenon of postwar migration both theoretically and empirically with a view to establishing relationships between social relations and migration. Migration is studied here within a conceptual framework of mode of production, relations of production, hegemony, and cash nexus. The historical aspects of migration are acknowledged throughout. The thesis then studies the theories of migration that are available and traces their developments. In this process, the thesis discovers ideology in many migration theories and literature. It selects three specific problematics of the postwar migration, named as 'zonal imbalance', 'mother country' migration, heavy representation of people who form lower SEGs. By examining these three closely, the thesis reveals many erroneous conception and notions about the postwar migration. In this process, the thesis rejects 'individualistic' and 'voluntary' actions in postwar migration. For the empirical part, Bangalee migration from Bangladesh to Britain has been chosen for its typicality and other reasons. Both quantitative and qualitative research methods have been used. Two control groups, one in Britain, (migrants) and another in Bangladesh (non-migrants, who had had the opportunity to migrate at some point in time, but did not) have been studied in as much depth as possible. The findings of the experience of the respondents are offered in relation to the historical evidence, particularly the relations of production in Bangladesh, and migration history of Bangladesh. Despite the basis of a small universe used in this research, international and historical persepectives have always been borne in mind. The objective remained the study of the totality of migration. Having taken the views of those who did not migrate (non-migrants) at a time when 'everyone was going', this research can claim to be a unique way of exploring a sociological phenomenon by negative investigation. The concluding part is in two chapters. In the first, the thesis has attempted to develop four new categories of migration to end the debate who can or cannot be called a migrant. It then exposes the myths of migration. Having established that socio-cultural transition migration, which is one of the four categories developed in this chapter, is the major concern of most migration studies, the thesis argues that a subtle process of 'branding' exists in the matters of encouraging migration to a country, whether the country is situated in the 'First World' or in the NICs. In fact, since '90s, the trends in the global population movements have changed so rapidly and radically that all older theories fail to explain the new phenomenon. The thesis argues that in order to understand 'migration', one has to study the changes that have occured in the social relations, emanating from changes in their relations of production. Finally, the thesis asserts that the phenomenon of human migration can possibly be explained within the conceptual framework chosen. It concludes that social relations play a major role in migration and offers a definition towards developing a sociological theory of migration.

Title: Sustainable urban development in the kampung improvement programme: a case study of jakarta, indonesia
Abstract: Recently, "sustainable development" has become the key concept in the integration of environmental and economic policy. However, little literature considers the links between sustainable development and urban development. This research focuses on these concepts and attempts to develop the term sustainable urban development through an investigation of the "Kampung Improvement Programme (KIP)", and particularly, a case study of Jakarta - Indonesia. The main objectives of the research are to examine the sustainability of KIPMIlT in Jakarta, specifically to analyse the physical, economic, social and environmental characteristics that positively affect urban systems and should be considered as a component of sustainable urban development as a means of improving quality of life and standards of living. The analysis is based on the data collected from two types of kampung areas: improved kampungs and unimproved kampungs. Moreover, each of these have two types of surveys: the household survey which examines the extent of movement of the people to the urban kampungs and their physical, social and economic living conditions; and the leadership survey which examines the extent to which kampungs settlers have participation, opinions, perception and satisfaction in the KIP. The study concludes that the impact of KIP of the kampung study areas in Jakarta has been to improve not only the physical and environment conditions but also the social and economic conditions of the people as a means of increasing the standards of living and improving the quality of life. In considering the implications of these findings on sustainable urban development in Jakarta, it is shown that the KIP has been concerned with the creation of balanced urban development which does not jeopardise future generations. It is based on social, economic, physical and environment activities, and integrated approach among the government, community participation and international agencies.

Title: Intellectuals, political power and emancipation from Marx to the October Revolution.
Abstract: The introductory chapter of the work sheds light on the philosophical background of the intellectual-question. To this end, the author draws critical arguments from classical works such as Plato's Republic , Aristotle's Politics , Rousseau's On the Social Contract , focusing his attention on the tension arising among intellectual vanguard, on the one hand, political power and emancipation, on the other. Given this philosophical frame of reference, the first part of the study constitutes a critical presentation of Marx's and Engel's commitment to the proletarian movement of the 1840s with special emphasis on their role in the Communist League. According to the author the fact that Marx and Engels finally entered the League represents a decisive turn from the role of the philosopher-interpreter and educator to the role of the philosopher-lawgiver and governor. The second part of this work deals with the participation of Marx, Engels and Bakunin in the First International and, furthermore, with the Marx-Bakunin controversy. The indisputable datum that Marx and Engels were against a Blanquist or a Bakuninist type of elite organisation, the author suggests, does not mean that they were against any kind of intellectual and political vanguard. In fact, the author argues, intellectual leadership and proletarian self-emancipation do not necessarily contradict each other. To support this argument, a direct juxtaposition has been suggested between Marx's and Engel's aristodemocratic version of the intellectual-people relation and Bakunin's apparently ultra-libertarian and actually quasi-dictatorial approach to the same relation. The third part of the study includes a further analysis of the intellectual-question, as this was posed in the framework of the European proletarian movement, and a critical presentation of the Russian Populist and Social Democratic intelligentsia. Moreover, the author takes advantage of the aristodemocracy-concept in order to evaluate particular versions of the intellectual-proletarian relation as appeared in the field of the Russian Populism and Marxism during the end of the nineteenth and the early years of the twentieth century.

Title: The impact of external shocks upon a peripheral economy: war and oil in twentieth century Shetland.
Abstract: This thesis, within the context of the impact of external shocks on a peripheral economy, offers a soci-economic analysis of the effects of both World Wars and North Sea oil upon Shetland. The assumption is, especially amongst commentators of oil, that the impact of external shocks upon a peripheral economy will be disruptive of equilibrium, setting in motion changes which would otherwise not have occurred. By questioning the classic core-periphery debate, and re-assessing the position of Shetland - an island location labelled 'peripheral' because of the traditional nature of its economic base and distance from the main centres of industrial production - it is possible to challenge this supposition. This thesis attempt a comparison of both the economic and social effects of the three major shocks, deploying oral sources as well as more conventional quantitative material. The thesis questions whether Shetland's apparent 'peripherality' has any historical foundations. Greater exposure to the world through trade, seafaring travel and emigration ensured that the three external shocks of this century had less permanent social consequences than may have been anticipated. Both World Wars brought naval and military personnel to Shetland, and saw the movement out of men and women from the isles. War experiences and contact with 'outsiders' had some effects on the attitudes and ideas of Shetlanders. But it is difficult to separate these from more long-term cultural change. In contrast, a great deal of concern was expressed over the social impact of North Sea oil, since the perceived vulnerability of this society, and its supposed unique features captured national and international interest. It was feared that the 'traditional way of life', arguably only devised as a reaction to oil, was under threat. But, as Shetland's history shows, it is not as susceptible to change as many may think, and represents a resilient society when exposed to external shocks.

Title: International cooperation and the rules of change: A neo-institutional approach to the Helsinki process
Abstract: The Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe has been an important agent of international cooperation and change. The present analysis spans from 1975, the year in which the CSCE was established, to 1990, the year in which the CSCE was endowed with a permanent organizational structure. This early CSCE phase is known as "the Helsinki process". The present study looks at the impact of this process upon the end of the Cold War in Europe. The analysis begins with a critique of traditional regime theory and justifies the adoption of a neo-institutional approach to the study of the CSCE. What the author calls a neo-institutional approach (1) puts the evolution of a regime or its historical development at the center of analysis and (2) focuses on the interaction between international institutions and non-governmental organizations--respectively "above" and "below" the level of the state. The author maintains that well grounded institutions are ones which exert a broad societal impact. The main assumption is that the more "informal" an institution, the broader its societal impact. This appreciation of informality stems from the consideration of the "constitutive" and/or transformational nature of institutional rules. To this effect, the author suggests that institutions be seen, first and foremost, as "rule-making" processes. The study is divided into three parts. The first part focuses on the formation of CSCE rules through a linguistic analysis of the main CSCE text: the Helsinki Final Act. The second part looks at the actual impact of CSCE rules, through an analysis of the principal social practices and/or epistemic communities which emerged in the wake of the Final Act. The third part looks at the recent transformation of the CSCE into a "formal" organization (OSCE). Empirical findings confirm the author's main contention that the Helsinki process or institution exerted a broad societal impact. This impact was facilitated by the informality of the process, which stimulated participation "from below"--of peace movements and human rights groups in particular--while triggering a merging of NGO discourses in support of the main Helsinki idea of a linkage between security and human rights. This linkage worked to undermine the Cold War in Europe--or the legitimacy of the political-military status quo--as it was perceived and sustained by society at large as the basis of a new, more humane security "order-to-be" beyond the East-West divide.

Title: Dependency, development, and ethnic mobilization
Abstract: Over the last quarter century many countries in the world have witnessed the reemergence of ethnic mobilization in the political arena. The present study analyzes the impact of external factors, such as dependency on other nations, and internal factors, like modernization and a history of ethnic conflict, on ethnic political mobilization. According to dependency theorists, economic, political, and military dependency affect state policies which perpetuate ethnic inequalities leading to ethnic political mobilization. From the competition perspective, the study investigates whether indicators of development impact state authority and its policies, which in turn provoke ethnic mobilization. The study also assesses the impact of a history of ethnic conflict on contemporary ethnic mobilization. The effects of the history of ethnic conflict, dependency, and development were analyzed in a cross-national model in two sub-populations of fifty and eighty countries. Data for the independent variables were drawn from World Handbook of Political and Social Indicators III: 1948-1977. Ethnic mobilization was conceptualized in terms of types of ethnic organizations and their activities to achieve their goals. A content analysis of the information contained in Revolutionary and Dissident Movements: An International Guide (1988) and World Encyclopedia of Political Systems and Parties Volume 1 and Volume 2: 1983 was conducted to gather information on ethnic mobilization. Multiple regression analysis and path analysis produced assessments of the direct and indirect affects of a history of ethnic conflict, dependency, and development on the endogenous variables of state efficacy, communication resources, ethnic inequality, and ethnic mobilization. The history of ethnic conflict had a direct positive and a significant impact on the mobilization of ethnic political organizations. Import dependency, export dependency, and debt dependency had significant positive effects on ethnic mobilization. Urbanization had positive effect on mobilization of ethnic groups. State efficacy, communication resources, political,and economic discrimination had significant positive effects on ethnic mobilization. Path analysis revealed that the direct effects of the exogenous variables on ethnic mobilization were greater in magnitude compared to their indirect effect in the sub-population of fifty and eighty countries. The implications of the study are very pertinent for understanding contemporary ethnic mobilization and for the theoretical field of sociology.
