Title: The Rockefeller Foundation and modern medical education in China, 1915-1951
Abstract: This study examines the Rockefeller Foundation's medical program in China in the following contexts: (1) missionary education in China since the second half of the 19th century; (2) medical education reform and the professionalization movement in philanthropy in early 20th-century America; (3) the Chinese new intellectuals' modern reform efforts; and (4) the Chinese government's political agenda. Through its medical programs, the Foundation sought to export scientific knowledge and methods in a scientific institution--the American research-based medical school. The Peking Union Medical College (PUMC) serves as a prism to study the diverse spectrum of ideas and approaches, American and Chinese, involved in the development of educational and social reform in modern China; these ideas and approaches are interpreted in their respective historical contexts, with hopes of increasing the understanding of cultural exchange programs in general. There was no single voice in the Rockefeller Foundation's program in China; missionaries and American professionals were the most influential. While the missionaries inspired the Foundation's interest in China, their opinion of medical science often clashed with the Foundation's scientific philanthropy. On the other hand, in the early 20th century, professionals, particularly medical professionals, profoundly influenced the foundations' policy-making. An international version of the Foundation's domestic scientific philanthropy, the PUMC was based on the notion that science along with institutional development was a powerful dynamic for social progress and reform. The Rockefeller Foundation's effort to change China intertwined with reforms promoted by key Chinese leaders. This study analyzes an important aspect of China's modern reform: the development of scientific direction. The Foundation's scientific approach converged with the Chinese new intellectuals' campaign for science and their criticism of the old culture and traditional medicine. The PUMC was the Foundation's response to certain Chinese intellectuals, most with Western educational backgrounds, who favored gradual reform and Western ideas. Through medical programs and other work, the Foundation established a mutually trusting and mutually influential relationship with this elite group. Their support of the PUMC laid a foundation for this intercultural program; however, limited knowledge of China's reality and bias against Chinese rural problems circumscribed the Rockefeller Foundation's perspective of China's reality.

Title: Global change and paradigm crisis: The renovation of left discourse in Cuba and Mexico
Abstract: Through case studies of left intellectuals from Cuba and Mexico, this dissertation explores how major changes in the structures and practices of the world-system have contributed to a paradigm crisis within the left. That crisis has led the left to reformulate its notions of and strategies for the creation of democratic societies and economic alternatives; most notably, the left has been compelled to reconsider the role of the state. The new global circumstances, which constitute the main independent variables, include: the restructuring of the world economy, the demise of liberalism and the ascendancy of neoliberal ideology, and the collapse of the former Soviet bloc. The analysis is informed by theoretical perspectives associated with: (1) the sociology of knowledge, ideology, and intellectuals, and (2) the historical political economy of world-systems theory. It is an empirical account, based primarily on in-depth interviews with seventy-four intellectuals in Cuba and Mexico, a purposive sample selected to reflect the range of relevant political and ideological currents. The interview data is supplemented by an extensive bibliography of current left literature in Latin America. The findings reveal that a chain of world events over the past three decades indeed provoked a great paradigm crisis for the left in Cuba and Mexico, which undid old alignments and produced a new constellation of left discourse. Three "ideal type" perspectives are identified among today's left on the questions of democracy and economic alternatives; liberal, orthodox socialist, and renovative. In Cuba, the renovative tendency is important but somewhat fragile, liberalism exerts its greatest influence over ideas about economic reform, and orthodox notions about democracy still prevail. In Mexico, the renovative current is quite strong, liberalism has been most influential in terms of the left's revaluation of democracy, and orthodox statism still informs much of the thinking about economic alternatives. Nationalism remains strong within all left currents. The renovative perspectives identified have importance beyond the left and beyond Latin America, as they suggest new alternatives to the great social crises of today's world. Our conclusions take into account global structures, national culture, divisions within ruling elites, and the left's relationship to state power and popular movements.

Title: Political foundations of the information society in the European Union: Public space in the information age
Abstract: This study of the political significance of the information society in the European Union (EU), demonstrates that the information society for citizens essentially constitutes a systematic dismantling not only of the European public service paradigm of democratic development, but of the very future of political rights in the information age. The political reality of this historical change is assessed in the context of four specific areas of information society policies and laws: (1) telecommunications infrastructure liberalization; (2) intellectual property rights; (3) audiovisual policy; and(4) the constitutional foundation of communication rights. The policy design of the information age is assessed through the following rival conceptions of European public space: (1) the competitive order of information liberalization as a global social movement derived from liberal political foundations; (2) universal service and public service in the European democratic tradition as developed from non-liberal political foundations; (3) nationalism or culturalism in Europe rooted in expressivist political foundations; and (4) the effect on political rights of participation demonstrated in tensions between public constitutional law derived from the Roman-Germanic legal tradition, and private, contractual law derived from the Anglo-American common law legal tradition. The dissertation illustrates two principal arguments regarding the design of the multimedia age: First, as a theoretical and empirical demonstration of Hegel's (1952) concept of the central role law plays in the social order, the study attempts to develop Hegel's political thought into a theory of law founded on a deliberative paradigm. This approach provides a way of examining the legitimacy of modern policy and law for the information society through the requirements of democratic will-formation and of the principles of public reason and political rights of communication. Second, the dissertation argues that contrary to enhanced freedom of consumer choice the information society is supposed to bring about, the study's finding make it evident the multimedia digital age is far from being designed to function as a demand-led environment. Rather, it is held that the granting of absolute liberty for unlimited economies of scale under information liberalization seriously contradicts the terms and arguments of liberalization's own political profession, viz., that it was supposed to deliver a competitive commercial structure rather than a monopolistic one.

Title: A network of praying women: The formation of religious identity in Women's Aglow Fellowship
Abstract: This thesis examines the lives and narratives of a group of charismatic Christian women and their everyday religious practices, most importantly the practice of prayer, as a way of exploring the construction of religious identities. The group I am examining is Women's Aglow Fellowship International ("Aglow"), an organization that emerged in the 1960s as part of the charismatic renewal movement within American Christianity. Aglow formed in Seattle, Washington, when a small group of pentecostal and charismatic Christian women began meeting together for prayer, worship, and evangelical work. Throughout the 1970s and 80s and into the 1990s, Aglow rapidly expanded, forming hundreds of new chapters across the United States and around the world and establishing a successful publishing industry aimed at "reaching women for Christ." My study examines Aglow in the United States as a case study of a religiously conservative women's prayer group, with the intention of contributing to an understanding of how religious practices such as prayer and testimony work in the formation of religious meanings around Christian womanhood, home and family, intimacy, and healing, all of which are then enacted in public as well as private domains. Often associated with the so-called "religious right"--although not a specifically political organization--Aglow has informal ties to such groups as Pat Robertson's Christian Coalition and Beverly LaHaye's Concerned Women for America, among others. The thesis thus has broader implications for understanding the rise and composition of the new Christian right in recent American history. By analyzing printed and oral narratives, gleaned from literary sources and ethnographic research, the study uses the practice of prayer as a lens through which to view Aglow women's strategic ways of negotiating the circumstances of their daily lives, resisting and even reshaping various cultural and social structures. I argue that prayer itself is a tactical practice, a mode of communication through which the women share stories of suffering as well as one in which they come to feel healed and transformed. Praying together to God for release from pain is a means through which new religious identities are constructed and, they hope, sustained.

Title: Nazi apocalypticism as a response to rapid and radical change
Abstract: Many Nazis perceived Weimar Germany to be a period of chaos, where all political, economic, social and cultural order was turned upside down. This chaos was in turn interpreted as reflecting an imminent apocalypse. They believed that Germany had arrived at a historic turning point, and foresaw the dawn of a New Age--the Third Reich. The Nazis believed themselves to be a chosen elite, led by a God-sent messianic Fuhrer. Their Fuhrer, Adolf Hitler revealed the way to salvation through what I have termed his soteriology of race. It was the divine mission of Aryan humanity to annihilate the "satanic Jew" in an eschatological battle that was to be final and decisive. The "Final Solution" accomplished, the millennial Third Reich could begin. My research in the cross-cultural and interdisciplinary literature of apocalypticism indicates that it is a global phenomenon occurring across cultural and temporal epochs. The common causal factor among these movements is that all occur in cultures undergoing rapid and radical change. The only factor that can explain such a cross-cultural and atemporal phenomenon is the shared genetic foundation of the human brain, which has changed little for millennia. Therefore I have created a psychohistorical model, utilizing the archetypal theories of C. G. Jung. It is the contention of this thesis that the psychological theories of Jung, which posit an objective psyche, in other words, a psyche which contains non-personal elements, may provide researchers with a much needed tool for analyzing collective behavior in historical contexts. What I have termed the apocalypse complex is a common psychological response to stress generated by rapid and radical change. When societies undergo such drastic changes, normal external ordering factors such as family, work, and social and religious institutions are considerably weakened. The apocalypse complex reconstructs order and gives meaning through the production of a standard set of symbols (messiah, New Age and past Golden Age, eternal peace and prosperity, unity, timelessness). These symbols are reflective of the ordering power of the Self, Jung's psychological construct for the internal ordering factor of the psyche.

Title: Migration within cities: A study of socioeconomic processes, intra-city migration and grass-roots politics in Jakarta
Abstract: There is no lack of studies on the contribution of rural-urban migration to the urbanisation process in Southeast Asia. This study goes beyond the common tradition. The huge urban complex of contemporary Jakarta structures the mass migration of the Jakarta's low income groups that takes place within the boundaries of the city. This study thus deals with the basic patterns of intra-city migration and its impact on individual actors, families, and local communities in Jakarta. Based on both secondary and primary data, this study demonstrates that migration within Jakarta is occurring on a massive scale especially if one adds the "shadow migration" to officially registered moves. A large proportion of migrants move more than once, but moves tend to occur mainly over short distances. This finding supports the thesis that there is a large "floating mass" of low-income persons occupied mainly in the informal sector. These informal sector workers live mostly in kampung areas. This study also registers five primary motives for intra-city migration in Jakarta: kampung demolition, important events in the life-cycle, the search for better communities, the intention to move closer to the work-place, and the construction of a new house. These motives suggest two typologies of intra-city migration: voluntary and involuntary intra-city migration. The involuntary intra-city migration is commonly connected to the process of kampung demolition and community politics in Jakarta. However, these kampung-based urban social protests in Jakarta have not developed into massive urban social and political movement for reasons proposed in the dissertation. The overall framework of this study suggests that intra-city migration is linked to the influence of globalization on the urban economy. This economic dynamic provides jobs and income-earning opportunities but on the other hand keeps people on the move. The poor of Jakarta are thus seen as actors and re-actors in the urbanisation process. On one hand mass intra-city migration is produced by the economic and political structures of Jakarta which are being massively affected by wider arenas of the global economy, on the other hand, the city is being made by the moves and related actions of its people.

Title: Domestic reform, structural changes and foreign policy transformation: Structural-institutional contexts of Chinese foreign policy evolution since 1979
Abstract: Based on a dynamic structural analysis which focuses on structural-institutional connections between different issue and policy sectors during a large scale social transitional period, this dissertation explains China's foreign policy transformation at current period in its contexts with domestic reforms and structural overhaul. China's reforms and structural changes in the past 15 years have altered the domestic condition in which Chinese foreign policy is formed and executed. These changes may not be enough to furnish sufficient conditions for an overall foreign policy restructuring. However, they constitute a significant part of the necessary conditions for Chinese foreign policy transition since 1979. Without domestic reforms and corresponding structural changes, a new Chinese foreign policy as witnessed today would be less possible, if not impossible. As well, Chinese foreign policy in the near future will by and large depend on the continuity of its domestic reforms and structural changes. As long as China adheres to its reform and opening-up policy and China's domestic structural transitions undergo along with the present course, China's foreign policy will be maintained complying with the existing principles and following the current track: open, pragmatical, economic and regional concentrated, flexible, and well under-control. To reorient or overturn such a policy may require an entire overriding of existing domestic conditions, which means to redefine China's national interests and priorities; reconcentrate great deal of resources, at the sacrifice of domestic demands, on military establishment and international adventures; and rebuild an over-centralized or authoritarian national leadership. These will be most unlikely, if not impossible, in the foreseeable future. Structural constraints, after all, are enormous and heavy. Though new developments in Chinese politics in some aspects may create chances for challengers toward the current reform policy and movement, an overriding to the major structural transitions China has so far accomplished will be less likely--the price will be unbearable.

Title: The drama of Carl Orff: From "Unerwuenscht" to postmodernity
Abstract: The purpose of this study is to serve as an introduction to Carl Orff the dramatist. As a composer of music, Orff is best known for his staged cantata, Carmina Burana. Although Orff's remaining staged works do not enjoy the international fame of Carmina Burana, they continue to be performed, surviving the test of time. This dissertation treats two aspects of Carl Orff's stage works written during the Third Reich. The first area is Orff's dramatic theories. More specifically, how his dramaturgy was influenced by the "Welttheater" from Baroque Jesuit plays, the epic theater of Bertolt Brecht and the "Gesamtkunstwerk" of Richard Wagner. The second aspect investigates the intriguing role Orff's operas played in the Third Reich. Orff's controversial "Aryan" replacement of what the Nazis viewed as Mendelssohn's "degenerate, Jewish" Ein Sommernactstraum is one such example. Orff also wrote Die Bernauerin during the Third Reich. This drama, based on the life of the 15th-century political martyr Agnes Bernauer, raises questions about Orff's relationship to the Nazi regime and the regime's relationship to the arts. Orff wrote Die Bernauerin in an old Bavarian dialect with the assistance of Professor Kurt Huber from the University of Munich. Huber, a friend and neighbor of Carl Orff, is most famous for his role in the anti-Nazi movement, "The White Rose." Huber was executed in 1943 for his involvement in this underground organization. Despite the association of Huber to Die Bernauerin, the opera was allowed to be performed. Generally, the Nazi leaders afforded Orff quite a lot of freedom. To date, works published that study Orff's operas were overseen or written by Orff personally. These go into no detail on Orff's working relationship with Huber or Brecht, and only superficially into Orff's dramatic theories. Orff wanted such studies to treat his works from a musical standpoint only, illustrating his musical intent Orff's desire to confine studies of his music to these areas is perhaps due to the extreme nature of political and social events of that time.

Title: Women and citizenship: From a critique of liberalism to ecofeminism
Abstract: A large number of women engage in political action, today and historically (West and Blumberg 1990). This fact however is not adequately accounted for in the liberal paradigm, according to feminist theorists who argue that paying attention to women's practices will produce more inclusive theories (Ferguson 1987, Jones 1990, Pateman 1988). Subsequently feminists theorists are constructing an alternative discourse analyzing from the perspective women's experiences offer. My study takes the self described political activism of women and uses its lessons to add to this developing discourse. Specifically, it enlists the feminist theory, ecofeminism to add insights to women's political activism. Ecofeminism has gained national and international recognition in the last twenty years as a progressive and critical social theory. Drawing from a diverse array of grass-roots movements across the globe it maintains close links between theory and political activism. Ecofeminism is multifaced. It sees sexism, racism, classism, speciesm, and naturalism as mutually reinforcing systems of oppression, a perspective which necessitates challenging all oppressions and hierarchal practices in general. For my study of ecofeminism and women's activism I conducted exploratory interviews with women working as grassroots community activists and women working through national political organizations--liberal feminist organizations and a "pro-life" organization. I analyzed the reasons why these women undertook political activism and the meaning of the experience itself. Common patterns emerged among these divergent activists. The most noteworthy pattern was the women were all motivated by a concern for others, a motivation that challenges the liberal tenet, self interest (as feminist theorists argue). Differing patterns also emerged among these groups of activists. I discuss both the common patterns of these women activists and their differing patterns in relation to ecofeminist theory. This study will add to the feminist literature that is beginning to change our concept of the political by incorporating a broader conception of who can and does participate, and for what reasons.

Title: Social discourses of the environment: The absence of consumption and consumerism
Abstract: This thesis examines several contexts for recognition within Canadian society of the biophysical limits to material growth and the related problem of overconsumption. Ecological and 'radical' forms of environmentalism have tended to embrace the tenets of the 'limits to growth,' and are therefore antithetical to the high levels of consumption and consumerism endemic to capitalist countries of the North. In this light, environmental discourses of Canadian news media, government, corporations, and the environmental government itself are examined. An elaboration of the 'limits to growth' and an environmental system of values provide a context for the thesis. Next, a case study of two recent years of environmental news within The Vancouver Sun tested for evidence of news media representation of the consumption problematic. Using key words 'environmental,' 'recycling,' and 'global warming,' and quantitative and qualitative analyses, the consumption problematic was determined to be virtually absent from the newspaper. This tendency is then related to the wider contexts in which news production takes place, especially the economic imperatives of commercial news media and some key professional and cultural dynamics influencing journalists coverage of environmental issues. The character of state environmental administration and 'green' corporations, and the reformist nature of the mainstream environmental movement are also outlined. Like the news media, these institutions generally perpetuate the ideological dominance of economic growth. By variously failing to embody ecological values and means of social change, they too inhibit wider recognition of the need to reduce material consumption. Last, the cultural context in which consumption proceeds space within capitalist countries is sketched. Consumer culture's tendency to privilege material measures of identity and status is analyzed as perhaps the ultimate obstacle to Canadian society's recognition of the ecological consequences of overconsumption. (Abstract shortened by UMI.)

Title: The Bishop Bergosa and the Diocese of Oaxaca (1800-1810)
Abstract: Throughout the enormous personal documentation belonging to Bishop Antonio Bergosa and Jordan, which is in the Archives of Jaca Cathedral (Huesca), we have attempted to analize the Diocese of Oa-xaca during the first decade of the XIXth century. It was a decade full of activity and heavily laden with events, as its closing days meant the point of inflection of a new stage in the mexican and oaxacan life. For such an aim, in a first approach, a general and global study about the Diocese has been done when analizing its different demonstrations and those levels in which the activities of its dwellers developed on: that is, we have essentially analized its economic, social and political structures which are influenced by its geographical setting. We have placed in such a social-economic setting a wide variety of main actors and characters who lived in Oaxaca at that time, such as the Bishop Antonio Bergosa, pragmatic man with enlightened and jansenistic education and behaviour, who will attemp to put into practice the enlightened project of the Crown, becoming eventually both the political and spiritual leader of Oaxaca. Secondly, we have placed the clergy, mainly the rural clergy, who will help him in his tasks, and thirdly, we have the parishioners, that is, the indian natives, representing an 88.4% of the total population of this Diocese. All this means a clash between a native cultural reality and a modern colonial project which Bergosa and his priests identify with and the indian natives rebel against. We put an end to such a study about the Bishopric in Oaxaca with a vision of the Diocese on the eve of the so-named Insurrection, when the echo of the Spanish war of Independence will create the necessary precedents which will shake the colonial american world and consequenthy this Diocese. And finally, we shall also deal slightly with the effect the insurgent movement had on this Diocese, which staggered the foundations and basis of the wealthy, prosperous and solid Oaxaca, as a final note of a decada and age.

Title: Textbook revision in the Soviet Union in the 1980s: "Memory of a Nation"
Abstract: This research essay consists of three major components. The first is a summary of the well documented chronology of historical revisionism during the years of "glasnost" in the Soviet Union (1985-1989). Emphasis is placed on movements within the historical and literary professions which culminated in government and Party reassessments of the Soviet past and the rehabilitations of various personalities who had for decades been cast in the role of traitors to socialism and the Soviet state. The second part of the paper examines the revision of Soviet high school textbooks which occurred primarily as a result of the above reassessment and rehabilitation. The thoroughly revisionist tenth grade history text published in 1989 (History of the U.S.S.R., (1900-1941)) is contrasted with texts which preceded it (published between the years 1957-1987). Two topics are examined in detail: the transition from NEP to mass collectivization (1928-1929), with emphasis placed on the treatment of the so-called 'Bukharin group', and Soviet involvement in the Spanish Civil War. The conclusion is reached that textbook revision was just as much--if not more--a result of the atmosphere of 'political correctness' which had grown up around glasnost and perestroika as it was the product of sincere research and interpretation by the historical community of previously unavailable source materials. The final portion of the research essay is an examination of the portions of the ninth and tenth grade global studies syllabus of New York State that relate to the two topics examined above, and an evaluation of the treatment of these events in textbooks used in New York State social studies classrooms (texts with similar publication dates to their Soviet couterparts). Accompanying this discussion is the author's suggestions as to how both the syllabus and the texts could be best revised to reflect the Soviet revisionism which has given a new perspective to much of Soviet history.

Title: Economic implications of an alternative marketing system for yellow maize on the South African animal feed industry
Abstract: Structural changes are taking place in South African agriculture. Agronomical production shows a decline in production, while animal production shows a positive growth rate. Future growth for the demand of agricultural products for human consumption will be considerably higher for animal products than for grain products. Stockfeed requirements are expected to increase by 57,8% to at least 8,76 million tons for the year 2000. A detailed analysis was done on the production, consumption and price trends of the main protein stockfeed sources (industries supplying them). The marketing thereof were analysed, also taking into account the regional supply and demand of the protein sources for stockfeed. This was done in thirteen regions, identifying regional balances, transport costs and the flow of raw materials. The gross margins of the industries supplying the protein raw materials were analysed as well as the relative profitability. Important policy inconsistencies were identified, of which most can be directly linked to the single channel marketing systems of the products. Since maize is the single most important source of raw material to the stockfeed industry, while the maize marketing system also acts as an "umbrella" for the other industries, detailed recommendations were formulated to deregulate the marketing system. Deregulation is necessary to allow supply and demand factors to interact, especially on a regional basis. The Maize Board should be restructured to render a limited service, while market participants should be allowed to trade freely and performing the necessary marketing functions themselves. The domestic maize price should be linked to international market forces. A sectoral linear programming model was used to evaluate the economic implications of the deregulated yellow maize marketing system on the SA animal feed industry. The result showed clearly that the current maize marketing system "tax" the livestock industry to the benefit of maize producers and white maize users. The social cost of this policy is significantly and the impact on the livestock industry is severe. The result clearly indicates that a movement to a freer marketing system, with regional prices and allowing imports--is the policy where social costs will be minimized.

Title: The survival of privilege: The strategies of political resilience of oligarchies in the Philippines, 1946-1992. (The case of three provinces: Bulacan, Negros Occidental and Bukidnon)
Abstract: This study charts the persistence of oligarchic rule in the Philippines, using the provinces of Bulacan, Negros Occidental and Bukidnon as case studies, through the twentieth century, focusing primarily on the post-war period from 1946 to 1992. Contrary to interpretations of Philippine policies that highlight discontinuities in politcal rulership, this work suggests some fundamental continuities in the composition of the Philippine State's family-based oligarchies, their strategies of rulership, and organisation of ideological, political, economic and military power. This study highlights six main strategies which lead to the persistence of oligarchic rule: (1) the establishment and maintenance of kinship network, especially through intermarraige, and non-kinship ties between and among oligarchic families; (2) diversification into non-agricultural economic interests, e.g. real estate, logging, mining and other industrial enterprises, primarily by establishing family-owned banks, cornering loans and subsidies from government banks and other State institutions and creating tie-ups with foreign and other local capitalists; (3) the control of political parties and State patronage machinery by using their personal wealth and political patronage to non-rival oligarchs, business power brokers and political ward leaders to secure votes, appointments to public office, business franchises and protection and other political favours; (4) the use of political power to obstruct progressive legislation, particularly on land reform and taxation; (5) the exploitation of political symbols or issues (e.g. nationalism, land reform), movements (peasants, cooperatives, non-government organisations and private foundations), and foreign aid from international development agencies for their political objectives; and (6) the astute management of political violence, more conspicuous and vulgar in the case of oligarchs who lack substantial connections to economic capital. As shown in the provincial case studies, the substitution of land-based personal wealth with State patronage machinery as source of political funding in the post-war period moderately altered the social origins and composition of political elites without changing the fundamental oligarchic characteristics of the political system. (Abstract shortened by UMI.)

Title: Avant-garde esthetics and indigenismo in "Boletin Titikaka" (Puno, Peru, 1926--1930)
Abstract: This dissertation provides a thorough analysis of the Boletin Titikaka, the Peruvian journal published in the city of Puno between 1926 and 1930 by the so-called Grupo Orkopata. The outstanding feature of this journal is its fusion of avant-garde esthetics and indigenismo, the cultural movement that redefined national identity in Peru during the 1920's. I thus analyze the emergence of the journal as the expression of an intellectual project which aimed at redefining Latin American esthetics by combining regional and cosmopolitan elements in their practice of indigenismo vanguardista. However, the project went far beyond the artistic and literary milieu to enter an ideological discussion that focused on the struggle for the preeminent role that the Andean indigenous heritage was to have in the national conscience. This was viewed as one of the major "revolutions" that the spirit of vanguardism was to contribute to the Peruvian cultural and ideological sphere. Therefore, my study relates the Boletin Titikaka to the contemporary national debate on indigenismo as part of a general discussion on nationalism and cultural identity within the whole of Latin America. By contextualizing the emergence of the Boletin Titikaka within the major changes in Peruvian society that took place around the 1920's, this study also emphasizes this journal's activities as a vehicle for the expression of the emergent mestizo middle class, the group which promoted indigenismo. This social group was also responsible for the development of a new type of intellectual who was outside the power structure, opposed the status quo and brought claims that attempted to democratize and decentralize the cultual field. Moreover, this Peruvian intelligentsia was connected to its peers throughout Latin America, and by means of intellectual exchange and a shared Americanist ideology, their activities resulted in a general quest for originality and cultural independence. Therefore, my work provides a study of the vital role journals like the Boletin Titikaka played both in the integration of the Latin American cultural and ideological milieus and in the diffusion of transnational artistic and literary productions such as the avant-garde and regional cultural movements such as indigenismo.

Title: The creation of the image of the Indian in 19th-century Peru: The paintings of Francisco Laso (1823-1869)
Abstract: This dissertation studies the first important appearance of the theme of the Indian in modern Peruvian painting, in the works of Francisco Laso (1823-1869). The emergence of this subject matter is examined as part of a wider process of reorganization of social and ethnic identities in post-independence Peru. Inscribed within a dualistic image of the nation, an idealized and abstract "Indian" becomes the cornerstone of Creole nationalist ideology. This manner of representing the nation defines the discourse of modern Indigenism as I define it, and although I do not present Laso himself as an early precursor of this 20th century movement, I argue that his life and work can serve as the basis for a case study in the conditions of the possibility of Indigenist discourse. By examining Indigenism as a discourse, I also analyze its specific rhetorical strategies, in particular that of approximation and simultaneous distancing to a Creole-created "Andean world." My discussion centers mainly on only a few works by Laso (Inhabitant of the Cordilleras, Portrait of Gonzalo Pizarro, The Three Races, and the Pascana series), although a number of other works by the artist are also discussed. I analyze these paintings in the context of contemporary discussions on the Indian population in Peru, but also with regard to the international circuits in which cosmopolitan intellectuals like Laso are increasingly situated. I explain the emergence of the modern image of the Indian as a consequence of both the racial prejudices structuring Peruvian society and the discourse of authenticity defining ethno-linguistic nationalisms.

Title: A history of the "International Encyclopedia of Unified Science"
Abstract: This dissertation examines the International Encyclopedia of Unified Science, founded and edited by Otto Neurath, Rudolf Carnap, and Charles Morris in 1937. Topics treated include the ideal of unified science within the logical positivism of the Vienna Circle of philosophers, the birth of the Unity of Science Movement, the publication of the Encyclopedia by the University of Chicago Press, and the slow demise of the project during and after the 1940's. Neurath's, Carnap's, and Morris's conceptions of unified science and philosophy are examined individually and used to analyze aspects of their collaboration including disagreements over financial management, over topics and authors, and over the nature and role of semantics in philosophy and science. The dispute between Neurath and Carnap about Neurath's monograph "Foundations of the Social Sciences" is examined in detail. These disputes among the editors, and between the editors and some encyclopedists, are used to explain the failure of the Encyclopedia and, less directly, the demise of logical empiricism in the 1950's and 1960's. The ideals and goals driving the Encyclopedia are briefly compared with recent arguments for the disunity of science.

Title: Emergent intellectual challenges to Western cultural hegemony in postcolonial societies
Abstract: The main objective of this project is to trace the various intellectual challenges which have emerged in the post-independence era of former colonial societies of Africa, Asia, Latin America and the Caribbean, as responses to the imposed Western cultural hegemony, the acknowledged legacy of imperialist penetration over the last 500 years. My hypothesis is that the emergent intellectuals or new intellectual formations--incipient and fragmented though they may be in these societies--suggest a fundamental restructuring of world thought which is contributing to the lifting of a "hegemonic hold" (Goonatilake) as a process towards authentic emancipation and a new social order. Although there is considerable evidence of Western cultural hegemony in various domains of these societies, I examine these emergent intellectuals as forums of resistance in three different discourses: educational institutions, especially universities in post-colonial societies; narrative art, with an emphasis on fiction writing; and political praxis, drawn from contemporary post-colonial movements. Each of the three discourses represents aspects of different tendencies in the global process towards the quest for "authentic liberation". To further nuance and delineate these tendencies, I analyze in greater depth the work of three emergent intellectuals reflective of dominant alternative processes corresponding to each of the three discourses selected: first, the work of Susantha Goonatilake, a Sri Lankan engineer and sociologist; secondly, Ngugi wa Thiong'o, a Kenyan writer and former lecturer of English literature; and thirdly, Yoweri Kaguta Museveni, President of Uganda and revolutionary leader of a national political movement in the post-independence period. As a global intellectual study, this work has a broad canvas. The conceptual notions and processes of analysis suggested in the work of Raymond Williams and Antonio Gramsci are used to circumscribe the boundaries of the broad framework. Imperialism resulted in an abrupt cutting off of cultural processes that have led to massive distortions, mutations, and "aborted discoveries" within post-colonial societies. I am asserting as active process a new consciousness that is emerging in contemporary post-colonial societies and I tell that story, as much as possible, from the perspective of the liberating process.

Title: The time and place of sport
Abstract: The aim of these studies from the year 1987 onwards was, by means of conceptual and material analyses, to de- and reconstruct: (a) sport as popular culture, as an expression of the sensuality and spontaneity of the common people, (b) new cultural conditions for sports and corporeality at the threshold of modernity/postmodernity, (c) the specific forms of perception (e.g. the "record", the "landscape") and mentality in physical activity along with the new conceptuality of cultural and microhistory; and finally to develop (d) some fresh models and possibilities for a new body-cultural approach in sport research and physical education. The purpose in the final instance was not to generate a new "grand theory" of sports, but, in accordance with the present ethnography, to deepen and further differentiate the local, minute understanding of the phenomenas in physical activity. The basic approach in these articles was to confront theoretical concepts and phenomenological observation, or to put it in a more philosophical way, "the universal" and "the specific", even "the peculiar", and to dwell deeper into this specificity--various experiences of time and space, an old, censored (?) nude picture, the old feast tradition of the local fire brigade or a certain natural landscape, a mountain--and to specify here, by means of proper concepts, something common and generalizable on a wider scale. Section I deals with the historical background of sport in Finland in the late 19th century, locating the accurate points and minor events where the new, sporting dynamics breaks through the shell of the old, rural mentality and atmosphere. The second section discusses some major cultural sociologists (Th. W. Adorno, Walter Benjamin, Norbert Elias, and Henning Eichberg) of the locality and temporality in everyday life, corporeality and sensuality. In section III, an attempt is made to sketch and estimate some new trends in the physical culture of the late 1980's in Finland, with new games, exercises, bodily movements and expressions. In the last section I try to make some more synthetic conclusions, and apply the method of the study to some local historical and natural examples. A methodological part of the summary ("Ajoituksia ja paikannuksia") has been published in English, see my "On Memory-work in the Theory of Body Culture", International Review for the Sociology of Sport 1/1994, 5-13. An English version of the article 12. ("Laajavuoren maisemaa lukiessa") has been published as "Reading my Landscape", in Strangers in Sport. Reading Classics of Social Thought. Ed. by Soile Veijola, John Bale & Esa Sironen. Department of Social Policy. University of Jyvaskyla, Working Papers No. 91, 1995, 19-32. The article 2.--"The Fastest Man in the Village"--will soon appear in Stadion, in a special number on sports and body culture in Nordic Countries (in print).

Title: Persistence amid transition: The views of Malay students in America on ethnic identity and religious change in the context of Malay history and culture
Abstract: The Malay people of Malaysia have had a Christian witness for centuries, and yet remain resistant to Christian evangelization efforts. This study seeks to understand why this is so, by presenting a profile of the Malays. The thesis is that the Malays have been historically, culturally, and religiously conditioned to be resistant to Christian overtures. This is defended through three prongs: historical investigation, religio-cultural analysis, and an empirical study of modern Malay university students in the United States. The first prong, that of the historical investigation, demonstrates that the successive colonization of Malaya by Western nations that identified themselves as Christian, coupled with the Christian missions' close association with the colonial administrations, their implication in policies seen by the Malays as detrimental to the Malays, and their neglect of the Malay people have led to a Malay antagonism against and fierce resistance to Christianity. The second prong, the religio-cultural study, analyses the relationship between Malay ethnic identity and normative Islam. A strong attachment to Islam coalesces with an exclusivistic Malay ethnic identity to make the Malays see Christianity as foreign to who they are as a people. The fact that Malays get their personal identity from the group militates against individual Malays breaking the social and religious barrier to considering Christianity as a viable option. The third prong of the study entails the findings of interviews of Malay university students in the United States. The information adds to the preceding by giving a firsthand account of what Malays believe about Islam and how they practice it. It also shows their understanding of Islam's relation to the state, and their view of their Malay identity in relation to Islam and other religions, especially Christianity. The interviews also test whether Malay international students display the openness to religious innovation that is typical of many internationals, and whether their exposure to American culture over time causes them to change their views on Christianity. We discover that the Malays in the United States retreat into a Malay ethnic enclave mentality that prohibits free inquiry and causes them to maintain their allegiance to Islam. In some cases, moreover, the relative lack of external, societal pressure to conform to Islam leads them to internalize their faith, and thus become more personally committed to Islam. The study concludes by noting that the rapidly changing Malay society is shattering traditional lifestyles and strong kinship ties, potentially weakening the societal barriers to receptivity to Christianity. In addition, we conclude that Malays overall have never been the object of concerted and thoughtful evangelization efforts, and that Malays do respond favorably to Christian gestures of kindness. Finally, a massive prayer movement is mobilizing to effect the evangelization of Malays. Knowledgeable, selfless, cross-ethnic and cross-cultural witnesses, empowered by God, are needed to bring a clear picture of Jesus Christ to the Malays.

Title: Potato farmers in exile: Power, state, and the mobilization of an interest group
Abstract: This thesis illustrates, through the case study method, how power arises and is exercised by interest groups and the State in resolving economic crises in Canada in the 1990s. This was achieved by examining how a group of potato farmers formed an interest group and challenged the Canadian Government in an effort to defend its interests, and how the latter countered that challenge in a manner that ensured that it retain its position of domination and control. Understanding the nature of that challenge required an examination of the process or “dynamics” of decision making as the two parties interacted with each other, seeking to resolve the situation. The study took place in Prince Edward Island over the course of three years (1990–1993). The crisis arose as a result of a potato virus (PVYn), which was found in the seed potato system. Although it causes no harm to potatoes or humans, it is lethal to the tobacco plant. The potential threat that PVYn posed to the US tobacco industry led the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) to ban the importation of Island seed potatoes and the Canadian Government to subsequently extend the ban to mainland Canada, thus denying the Island's seed potato growers access to their two major markets. As a result, this crucial component of PEI's economy, which represents in excess of $100 million annually, remained at a virtual standstill for over two years. In examining the process by which a resolution was sought, the study assumed a Pluralist position—that power is fragmented or dispersed throughout all strata of society, and that it can arise whenever and wherever people act in concert. A combination of two theories of collective action, New Social Movement and Resource Mobilization, were used to examine the process of mobilization. The methodology incorporated a combination of media releases, correspondence, minutes of the Industry and PVYn Action Committees, official and unofficial documentation, and approximately seventy-five interviews. The study revealed that both the farmers and the Government used primarily traditional methods to defend their interests. The farmers were generally unsuccessful throughout much of the three-year. period of the PVYn situation, because they were unaccustomed to challenging the Government. For the most part, they used strategies that were generally successful in the 1960s and 1970s. Not only does successful challenging the Government today require much greater skill, but challengers must also think and act in what Weber labeled “formal-rational” terms. Also revealed was a phenomenon which may well become more common in economic crisis situations, which is the presence of foreign governments in the role of third parties. Since Canada is closely connected to other countries through various international economic agreements, any resolutions of Canadian economic problems must increasingly require the cooperation or consent of foreign governments. This may well mean that problem solving will increasingly involve multi-partite power arrangements.

Title: The underlying causes of some problematic responses to curriculum evaluation reports within the ethnographic tradition
Abstract: This thesis follows the natural history of the research which gave rise to it. Working as an evaluator on a Social and Environmental Studies curriculum development project in the Republic of Ireland the author was surprised by some of the reactions to his evaluation reports. After consideration he came to the conclusion that these products of his evaluation had of themselves some sort of socio-political role. Moving to Northern Ireland he came into contact with a number of other evaluators, some of international repute, who convinced him that his experiences were not unique but were shared by other evaluators. He was helped to formulate and flesh out an Aggregate Pathology Model of reactions to evaluation products. This model represented a cumulative but not necessarily complete schema of possible negative reactions to evaluation products and included; cooption and collusion between the evaluation and the project, restrictive renegotiation of the evaluator's contract, rhetorical acceptance of the product divorced from political action, rejection of the evaluator or his product, distancing from the evaluation, a counter denunciation in which dossiers of evidence are produced to discredit the evaluation, the use of human sensitivity as an instrument of human control over the evaluation, and a `rival product' developed as an internal counter-thrust to the independent evaluation. Visiting this model with members of the evaluation community the author received qualified approval of its contents as a valid and useful map of many of their own evaluative experiences. In endeavouring to ascertain what might be the cause of the pathological reactions to evaluative products Concomitant Variation Method was used to compare contrasting between-case evaluation outcomes. This enabled the establishment of constants and independent and dependent variables, in evaluation cases where typicality had been established. As a result of its application to evaluation cases three explanations are advanced as causes of pathological reactions to evaluation products. These are (1) that the products are not `practical' in the sense identified by Schwab (2) that the pathology represents reactions to evaluation perceived as a degradation exercise (3) that evaluation products appear at nodes or decisive cusps in project activity where sensitivity is heightened. These explanations are offered as decisive in a final case study of a curriculum evaluation this time conducted in the political and social sensitivities of Northern Ireland. The thesis ends with a methodological appendix and a summary of the conclusions. A review of the literature covers the history of the evaluation problem of the thesis from its beginnings as a substantive critique of the testing movement and as a partial expansion from curriculum development, to the use of ethnography and other metaphors from the sciences and arts in the evaluation of curricula. The problem itself, aspects of which are covered in the literature, is next dealt with and some pertinent explanatory concepts from the social sciences are given. Finally, some published material concerning the principal evaluation cases studied in the thesis are given.

Title: The development of ghanaian pentecostalism: a study in the appropriation of the christian gospel in twentieth century ghana setting with special reference to the christ apostolic church, the church of pentecost, and the international central gospel church
Abstract: The study investigates the origins and development of Pentecostalism in Ghana with special reference to the Christ Apostolic Church, the Church of Pentecost, and the International Central Gospel Church. The theological section explores the continuity and discontinuity between the movement's conception of salvation and the primal concept of salvation. Part A looks at the Akan cosmology, the Akan concept of salvation, and the political, economic and social history of the Gold Coast/Ghana. It also examines some twentieth century Christian renewal movements in Ghana. Part B probes into the historical development of Ghanaian Pentecostalism and the Life and Faith of the movement, using the Christ Apostolic Church, the Church of Pentecost, and the International Central Gospel Church as case studies. Part C examines the Ghanaian Pentecostal soteriology using the Prayer Camps as a case study. The author concludes that the search of the Pentecostals for salvation or abundant life, manifests a continuity with the Akan traditional religious aspirations: a search for Salvation in which health, prosperity, dignity, fertility, security, vitality, and equilibrium within the cosmos are dominant. It also manifests a radical discontinuity in its hostile stand against all traditional forms of supernatural succour. Aspect of the discontinuity between the two religious expressions is Pentecostalism's concern for the paradise beyond. A related interest in this study is the investigation of the influence of socioeconomic factors on the eschatological presuppositions and the evangelistic ethos of the Pentecostal churches. The evidence from the Ghanaian context has led us to the conclusion that the materials presented in this study do not corroborate the thesis that the expectation of the parousia declines in the older Pentecostal denominations as their economic circumstances improve. Our findings indicate that though the neopentecostals believe in the parousia, this has not featured prominently in their kerygma. This, we propose, is due to their avowed concern to address the existential issues facing Ghanaians. The evidence indicates that the Prosperity or Abundant Life Gospel as espoused by the neo-pentecostals, is an attempt to appropriate the biblical message of salvation to suit the contemporary socio-economic and religious experience of Ghanaians.

Title: The construction of Latin identities and salsa music clubs in London: An ethnographic study
Abstract: This thesis is based on ethnographic research carried out between October 1993 and September 1994 and examines the construction and communication of Latin cultural identities across a selection of salsa music clubs in London. Through an engagement with contemporary theories of globalisation, 'power-geometry' and cultural identity the thesis argues for the need to understand music related practices in salsa clubs in relation to wider social, economic and political processes occurring from without the clubs, but which have an impact in the construction and communication of 'Latin' identities at these sites. In this sense, this thesis proposes three analytical distinct but interrelated levels of analysis as a way of studying cultural identities and salsa clubs in London; that of nation and migration, the identity of places and the performing body. In addressing the issue of nation and migration this thesis considers how Britain's immigration regulations affect the movement of Latin Americans across London, having an impact on the visible presence of Latin American cultural practices across London. This is then related to the geographical location of 'Latin' clubs which seek to attract both Latin Americans and non-Latin people. In discussing the identity of places this thesis provides specific details about salsa clubs in London and describes the practices of club owners, promoters and disc jockeys in constructing the identity of the clubs so as to communicate a 'Latin' identity. The thesis also examines how places with different but particular 'Latin' identities are constituted out of participants' movements across salsa clubs in London. The construction and communication of Latin identities is further developed by considering the relationship between body and music as performed by dancers and musicians. This approach to the study of 'Latin' cultural identities and salsa clubs in London has implications for theoretical discussions about the relationship between cultural identities and places: It suggests that the micro movements of the dancing body in a particular event needs to be related to macro attempts to regulate the movement of bodies at an international level. This, in turn, should be considered in relation to broader spatial relationships across the city of London whereby particular places have been given a 'Latin' identity. This thesis elaborates on this discussion and suggests the need for further exploration and explanation of ongoing relations of power between these three overlapping levels of analysis which are at play in the construction and communication of 'Latin' cultural identities in London.

Title: Ezekiel and the ethics of exile
Abstract: Much recent work on the ethics of the Hebrew Bible addresses the theological task of using the Bible as a moral resource for today. By contrast, this thesis examines the moral concerns of the book of Ezekiel as part of a more historical or sociological task: to describes the ethical ideals and practice of the ancient communities which produced the Bible. Ezekiel addressed a community which Nebuchadnezzar had deported from Judah to Babylonia in 597 BC, and as exiles they belonged to two different moral worlds - different realms of moral possibility. The exiles originally came from Judah's ruling elite, and, before their deportation, would have participated in decisions affecting major communal institutions and thus the lives of many others. As Ezekiel predicts the destruction of Jerusalem, the sins he condemns belong largely to the world of these institutions, and his special concerns are international politics and the correct maintenance of the state cult. However, as deportees to Babylonia the exiles experienced a severe loss of status and their communal identity was threatened. Elements in Ezekiel's ethics can be seen as mechanisms for survival, providing significant impetus for social cohesion and the maintenance of a distinctively Jewish community. The rituals of the destroyed temple become the centrepiece of an ethical system which looks back to the homeland for its symbolic coherence. As communal decisions become impossible an increasing "domestication" of sin and virtue moves the focus of ethical interest from the institutions of state to the individual and the family. Furthermore, the book displays a movement from responsibility for judgement to passivity in the face of restoration that reflects the actual social circumstances of the exiles, who have moved from the world of power and influence in Jerusalem to the far more limited moral world of exile in Babylonia.

Title: Sea harvesters, traders and corporations: Local and global dynamics in the world seaweed-carrageenan economy
Abstract: By focussing on the development of a global seaweed-carrageenan economy, this dissertation aims at presenting world-system dynamics in terms of an approach mixing micro- and macro-units of analysis. The anthropological subjects presented in this text are Muslim Filipinos cultivating seaweed in southern Palawan; traders from those communities who transport the commodity to upper knots of commercial mediation; middlemen in Puerto Princesa (the provincial capital); Philippine corporations exporting or processing seaweed, and finally "core" multinationals. All these subjects are presented as agents who can be accounted for only in terms of interrelated processes. As the product of transformations entailing movements and exchanges crossing space a commodity links people following different value systems and embedded in different socio-economic structures. By tracing the activities of different individuals operating at various levels in the world seaweed economy, I hope to show how the modern world system is articulated not only in terms of mechanical connections between abstract structures, but also in terms of the structure-shaping practices of social actors who are pursuing different interests in conditions of inequality. But, I would also like to show how these practices are informed equally by material and cultural/ideological concerns, at each point of the articulation. The tenet that material and symbolic capitals have mutual influence in the reproduction of social life is not new; but it has often been elaborated with reference to isolated microcosms (e.g. Bourdieu). One of my aims is to try to show how the tenet is also valid for intersystemic settings.

Title: A new model of Ecuadorean higher education: Its impact on external efficiency, innovations, and economic growth
Abstract: This study addressed the political, economic and social crisis affecting Ecuadorean higher education. It discussed the reform project "The Mission of the Ecuadorean University for the XXI Century"; the modernization movement in Latin America; and the government regulation models from which higher education systems derive. Models of the current and proposed higher education systems were developed and analyzed based on the constructs of the State Control and State Supervising Models. The study presented that the current model of Ecuadorean higher education was neither compatible with the characteristics of the State Supervising Model nor enabled the adoption of innovations. The study discussed that the State Control Model from which the Ecuadorean higher education system derived since colonial times, preserved the poor external efficiency of higher education given the high dropout rates, low research-teaching ratios, few new grants per year, little investment in library and scientific equipment, lack of scholarships, and high costs per government subsidized degrees (compared to Ecuadorean economic standards). The study also analyzed the centralized nature of the operating governance model as it antagonized the interaction between government agencies, international entities, professional organizations, and the private sector. The lack of linkage with other governmental and non governmental agencies emphasized the strong monopoly of power that the Ecuadorean National Congress had over the higher education system. The new model of Ecuadorean higher education governance developed in this study focused on decentralization and its potential to enable the adoption of innovations. The impact of the new model on the external efficiency of higher education and its relationship with national economic growth was predicted by comparing and correlating the performance of higher education in Ecuador to Chile, Costa Rica, El Salvador and the United States of America. The new model was compatible with the constructs of the State Supervising Model and Theory of Innovations by Hage and Aiken. The new model sought to alleviate the current higher education crisis by considering the recommendations of the project "The Mission of the Ecuadorean University for the XXI Century". The statistical comparison of institutions in Chile, Costa Rica, El Salvador and United States of America under State Supervising and State Control models, as measured by university dropout rates, student-teacher ratios, research-teaching ratios, new grants per year, and cost per degrees, helped to evaluate the possible impact of the new Ecuadorean model on the external efficiency of Ecuadorean higher education. The statistical analysis showed which external efficiency descriptors would and would not change once the Ecuadorean higher education institutions operate under a decentralized model. Correlating the external efficiency of higher education institutions in Ecuador, Chile, Costa Rica, El Salvador, and the United States, to their Gross National Products indicated which higher education external efficiency descriptors had a significant relationship with the country's economic performance. This provided a criteria about which external efficiency descriptors need to be monitored or disregarded in order to assess economic growth.

Title: AIDS, activism and the social imagination in Brazil
Abstract: This dissertation examines how AIDS-related, non-governmental organizations (AIDS/NGOs) have attempted to mobilize Brazilian society in response to the HIV/AIDS epidemic. Through focusing on the prevention/education programs and political action strategies of two such groups--Grupo Pela VIDDA in Rio de Janeiro and GAPA/RS in Porto Alegre--I explore the operation of a global AIDS industry in local settings and the ways in which AIDS activism has affected popular conceptions of HIV/AIDS and behavior at individual and collective levels. The project is based upon qualitative and quantitative data obtained from twenty-six months of fieldwork in Porto Alegre and Rio de Janeiro, including participant observation in the two NGOs, archival research, and a year long study of a low income community in Porto Alegre. The thesis employs a multi-leveled analytical framework to investigate the critical social and cultural spaces that shape and are shaped by Brazilian AIDS activism, including the popular media, the world of AIDS/NGOs, and local practices and attitudes related to HIV/AIDS. The discussion begins by considering ten years of Brazilian media narratives and argues that despite increasing coverage and clarification of the epidemiological realities of the HIV/AIDS epidemic in Brazil, AIDS continues to be viewed primarily as a problem of a gendered "other." Building on this symbolic and discursive analysis, the dissertation's next two chapters provide a historical overview of how Brazilian AIDS activism came to be concentrated within AIDS/NGOs and suggests that the resulting institutionalization and professionalization of these groups, while enabling many effective programs, nonetheless has contributed to their relative isolation from other Brazilian political actors and social movements. The second half of the thesis focuses on case studies of AIDS prevention activities in a low income neighborhood and at a NGO based work group of travesti sex professionals. These experiences indicate that although the success of AIDS-related initiatives is largely dependent on people's willingness to integrate AIDS issues into broader collective concerns and to challenge often deeply ingrained constructions of the erotic that privilege (male) sexual pleasure and transgression over questions of gender/sexual inequality, many Brazilians continue to see AIDS prevention as at best a nuisance to be endured rather than as a pressing political question. In conclusion, I present an emerging wave of cultural production and activism centered on sexuality and race as one possible path through which Brazilian AIDS activism might revitalize itself and partially break the organizational stagnation and public complacency produced by more than ten years of living the HIV/AIDS epidemic in Brasil.

Title: Political economy of institutions and policy change: The case of stabilization policy of 1979, Korea
Abstract: During the second oil crisis of the late 1970s, a dramatic policy reversal occurred in Korea. The character and functioning of this policy shift from "growth by any means" to "stabilization" can only be understood if they are seen collectively as instruments for coping with a political crisis as well as an economic contradiction, even though this change was partly a response to an unfavorable exogenous event like the second oil shock and previous policy failures. The point of this study is to explain the causes, processes and consequences of this policy change with the aid of a comprehensive institutionalist perspective that links economic policy and the policy-making process to the dynamics between the structural constraints implicit in socio-economic organization and the empowerment of agents involved in the struggle for change. Along this line, our analysis also incorporates careful consideration of the forces or actors at various levels, mainly as organized form, formally and conventionally, that shape these policy change processes and outcomes. First, it calls attention to power relationships in the structure and practice of the export-oriented industrialization policy of 18 years that had been led by the coalition of an authoritarian regime and large industrialists (chaebols). It, further, focuses on an underlying socio-economic structure and prodemocracy movement that not only opposed their country's authoritarian politics but was also increasingly able to resist the state's economic policy. In addition, it also examines intellectual innovations which the country's policy community of neo-liberal bureaucrats and technocrats helped produce, move into the power structure, and finally become reality in 1979 as the Comprehensive Stabilization Program. These innovations have persisted well into the 1980s, beyond the historical moment. Our observation shows that if social conditions had a crucial influence on the rate of policy transformation, so too did the elite "sponsorship" at critical junctures. This study emphasizes that the Korean state became socialized not only through structural change within the society and the international system, but also through intersubjective understanding, shared expectation and on-the-job learning, while focusing especially on how political imperatives had a definite impact on the processes and outcome. It says that the most important consequence of this policy change is the erosion of etatism of the Korean state in governing the economy.

Title: Violent democratization and the feeble state: Political violence, breakdown and recomposition in Peru, 1980-1995
Abstract: This is a study of the expansion of political violence in Peru during the 1980s and early 1990s, after Peru made a successful transition from military to civilian, constitutional rule in 1980. This dissertation attempts to explain how a broad, inclusive party system which included a strong partisan left could coexist with a powerful and pervasive violent left, led by Sendero Luminoso ('Shining Path'). It also explains why Peru experienced a rupture in democratic rule on April 5, 1992, the so-called autogolpe (or 'self-coup') instigated by President Alberto Fujimori. It also seeks to understand the factors which enabled the post-coup civil-military regime to consolidate its power. The theoretical framework presented is a state-oriented framework, which examines the interaction of economic, political, social and international factors with state capacity along four dimensions. The argument is that both the 'violent democratization' and autogolpe phenomena can be explained in terms of factors relating to the incapacity of the Peruvian state during the 1980s. State weakness, I argue, contributed to a political and economic opportunity structure (PEOS) which was favorable to the expansion of political violence at precisely the moment at which Peru was moving toward a more inclusive, participatory regime. State weaknesses also generated a political crisis which led to a backlash against traditional parties, and this antiparty backlash in turn paved the way for political independents, notably Alberto Fujimori, to rise to power and subsequently to disband the constitutional regime inaugurated in 1980 in favor of a highly centralized civilian regime with broadly expanded presidential powers and strong military backing, a regime which challenges conventional notions of democracy and authoritarianism and contains elements of both. Utilizing various methods, primarily interviewing, statistical analysis presented in cartographic (map) form, archival research and secondary source research, the analysis reveals political and economic transformations at both the national and regional (departmental) levels of analysis which led to the expansion of violence in conjunction with the expansion of democratic participation, the breakdown of a democratic regime, and the consolidation of the new civil-military regime in the context of a radically restructured state along neoliberal lines. Economic variables are by themselves found to be inaccurate predictors of levels of violence across regions of a society. Meanwhile, the relative presence or absence of political authority, whether state authority or private authority is found to be a major determinant of levels of conflict across regions of a democratizing country. Structures of authority thwart the expansion of political violence, while the relative absence of those structures of authority can encourage the expansion of violence, especially in relatively affluent regions. The analysis also reveals that civil society can also be a major, albeit unwitting contributor to political violence in that sectors of society can be exploited by a guerrilla movement in pursuit of power, contributing to higher levels of violence. Finally, this dissertation demonstrates how the restructuring of the state can contribute to both a decline in violent conflict and the stability of an elected, civilian regime which is widely supported but not 'democratic' in the conventional sense.

Title: Religious education in Turkey: A socio-historical study of the Imam-Hatip schools
Abstract: The question of whether and how religious functionaries such as imams and hatips should be educated has been an extremely controversial issue in Turkey for most of this century. In the midst of sweeping anti-religious reforms to create a new nation with a new identity under the guidance of rationalism and scientism, religious education was eliminated in 1924. After the introduction of the multi-party system in the late 1940s and the early 1950s, religious education re-emerged as a result of grassroots demands and pressures. Since then, the secular governments have taken a great interest in controlling and directing religious education. Despite governmental discouragement, the Imam-Hatip school system gained momentum in the 1960s and particularly in the late 1970s. These schools have shown remarkable vitality, attracting ever-increasing numbers of students. Contrary to the original legislative intent, the Imam-Hatip schools developed from a vocational system for the training of religious personnel into an alternative school system in which students receive both a religious and secular academic education at the secondary level. This study explores the relationships established between the people and the governments of Turkey under the electoral framework of the multi-party system and demonstrates that the public could and did force the government to answer the demand for Imam-Hatip schools. The Imam-Hatip school system from 1924 to the present is studied in relation to major social, political and educational developments in order to determine how socio-political factors shaped the present system of religious education in Turkey. As the case of the Imam-Hatip schools demonstrates, educational reform in Turkey has been motivated by the people's ideas and beliefs rather than imposed from above by the government. Today, a major "post-Kemal self-discovery" is taking place in Turkey. Concerned not only about Islam, this movement is focused on religion's potential for inculcating broad and sophisticated cognitive, emotional and ethical skills for dealing with the chaotic global, social, economic and ideological upheavals that mark the contemporary world.
