Title: Space-time and the city: Glasgow and the literature of the urban peripheries
Abstract: Space, as a dimension through which we experience and understand existential being, has traditionally been subsumed to time. Time, with its inextricable links to history, is seen as the privileged signifier in most social and literary critiques, while space is viewed as the deprivileged signifier. Consequently, time is associated with movement, action, and politics, while space is considered static, limited, and apolitical. To deprivilege space, however, is to fail to recognize its political potential, especially when we are within a particularly spatialized, if not global, epoch. The administrative centre of this spatialized moment is the city. It is similarly at the forefront of the Scottish literary imagination with its emphasis on that quintessentially spatial phenomenon, the "urban". However, Scottish, and particularly Glasgow, urban writers have concentrated on yet another aspect of the urban phenomenon; that is, those peripheralized spaces of the sometimes notorious Glasgow housing-schemes. Not only do these writers address the actual spaces of the periphery, but they simultaneously explore the 'peripheralized subject' and how this subject experiences time and space. Consequently, these literary explorations function to re-assert the active, sometimes volatile, significance of the periphery, and to resuscitate it from a certain type of historical attitude which is ultimately deterministic. In other words, the periphery and its subjects is much more than the outcome of history. To ameliorate a purely historical approach with its peculiarly Scottish impulse towards nostalgia and memory, space as a vital, living component of existential being must be considered. Whereas we make our own history although not always as we please, so too do we make our own geography. Likewise the city of Glasgow itself. As its traditional appellation as industrial, militant, proletarian begins to shift, rupture, and decline, as a new mode(s) of production (as yet not fully defined) insinuates itself, this uneasy transition necessarily has both a spatial and a historical effect. Historically, 'traditional' Glasgow is experienced as lost, or retrospectively apprehended as What Once Was. Spatially, it is experienced as displacement and atomization, if not abandonment, while the impulse towards postmodern classicism in the neo city-centre is a further testimony to that sense of uncertainty. Ultimately, rather than seeing the city and its peripheries through a purely historico-temporal prism, if the discourse is enlarged to incorporate the spatial dynamic, this may consequently lead to a recognition of the political potential invested in space and the agency subjects have within the spatial problematic.

Title: Toward the second revolution: The political thought of Joaquin Maurin, 1915-1936
Abstract: "Toward The Second Revolution, The Political Thought of Joaquin Maurin, 1915-1936," examines the evolution of the political thought of one of the leading revolutionary figures in pre-Civil War Spain. Following a youthful association with a regenerationist radical republicanism, Maurin aspired to forge a movement capable of carrying out a socialist revolution in Spain. This endeavor took him first into the anarcho-syndicalist Confederacion Nacional de Trabajo (CNT), then to the nascent Spanish Communist Party, and finally, to the leadership of the "dissident" communist Bloc Obrero y Campesino (BOC) and Partido Obrero de Unificacion Marxista (POUM). Through his prodigious and penetrating writings, Maurin was, by the early 1930s, recognized as one of the leading intellectual forces on the Spanish Left. The study is divided into seven chapters. The first three chapters focus on Maurin's early political development from 1915 to 1923, during which he evolved from a radical regenerationist republicanism to revolutionary syndicalism. Chapter 3 examines his attempt to reconcile his increasingly bolshevik perspective with the CNT's revolutionary syndicalist tactics. The fourth and fifth chapters concentrate on the period between 1923 and 1931. They examine Maurin's political development during his association with--and estrangement from--the Spanish Communist Party. They also explore his initial attempts to articulate a Marxist analysis of Spanish political, economic, and social conditions. The final two chapters trace Maurin's efforts between 1932 and 1936 to further develop this analysis and to forge an independent communist movement, first in Catalonia, and then throughout Spain. In addition to more completely elucidating the political evolution of Joaquin Maurin, "Toward the Second Revolution" demonstrates: that Maurin's most mature revolutionary perspective can only be understood in light of his earlier republican and revolutionary syndicalist convictions; that his overall intellectual and political development must be approached from a regional (Catalan), national, and international perspective; and finally, that it is these factors that led Maurin to develop the most original and sophisticated Marxist analysis of pre-Civil War Spanish society.

Title: Discourses of reformism: El Salvador, 1944-1960
Abstract: In the period immediately after the 2nd. World War El Salvador modernized its legal and institutional framework to transform the productive structure beyond the traditional agro-export model. The promotion of industrialization led the country to revitalize its links with neighboring countries and eventually to champion regional economic integration. This thesis focuses on the social and political determinations of this process of modernization, by analyzing the characteristics of the political system established after the 1948 military coup. This system, initially proclaimed as democratic, developed into a new form of authoritarianism that persisted up to the onset of the civil war that had just been terminated. In this work local as well as international forces which influenced the establishment of the political system are considered. The nature of the ruling coalition is discussed, as well as its transformation throughout the period. Special attention is given to the articulation of the reformist ideology as expressed in key documents of the time. The analysis emphasizes the modalities of the traditional authoritarian political culture that were recreated in the modernization project, specially (but not only) through the military presence in the ruling coalition. This study uses unpublished materials and interviews to cover events occurring within the Political Society and the State, as well as in the Civil Society, including the labor movement, University students, the Church and organizations of the left.

Title: Constructing unitary reality: An appreciative inquiry
Abstract: Diversity of membership in organizations caused by demographic shifts, changing societal trends, and globalization presents new challenges to organizations. The challenge is to increase the capacity of organization members and structures to include and reflect the varieties of stylistic, gender or cultural differences in the changed composition. The dissertation reports a single case study, conducted over nine months. The lived experience of organization members is explored utilizing combined methodologies of ethnography, appreciative inquiry and narratives. These combine their variety to offer a new perspective for the treatment and understanding of diversity in organizations. Findings from the study suggest that leaders and managers are eminently responsible for the success or failure of organizations to move toward more inclusive environments where diversities of people and interests exist, communicating new images of organizations. A new managerial competency, oration, which combines known competencies of conceptualization, diagnostic use of competencies and oral presentations is identified. Moving beyond the narrow focus of race, gender, age or ethnicity, a grounded theory of unitary reality is introduced. This new approach to the understanding and treatment of diversity in organizations calls for the suspension of the discussion of diversity as the desire for achievement of a permanent future state of harmonious relationship, among varieties of people and interests. Data from the study suggest that a permanent ideal future state is at best only assumed possible, and is yet undefined. What emerges is evidence that episodes of a unitary reality, or temporal sensemaking of collective singularity, contribute to feelings of organizational unity and satisfaction and occur as natural social processes in organizations. Propositions from this study call our attention to organizational processes which lead to a unitary reality These are the social interactions and centering and sensemaking processes commonly ignored as insignificant in rational, organizational processes. Additionally, it is argued that a reordering and re-valuing of processes, informal social interactions, and conversational acts like teaching talk, can not only address the consequential outcomes of fragmentation, myopic vision and statutory dialogue and interaction from previous interventions but may in fact accomplish the work of moving organizations toward a future where varieties and diversities of individuals co-exist in organizational experiences which are more inclusive and satisfying for all. The findings of this study will help to meet the need for practical, useful understanding of contemporary organizations, particularly in the current environment where varieties of people, from a wide range of constituencies are being associated through the movement toward a more global community. This study contributes new wisdom about organizations which will lead to deeper understanding of diversity in organizations and more innovative intervention strategies. The study provides hope as new strategies which more appropriately address the contemporary phenomenon of diversity in organizations are introduced.

Title: Unnegotiated transition...successful outcome: The processes of democratic consolidation in Greece
Abstract: This dissertation analyzes the processes through which a stable, consolidated and fully democratic regime was brought into existence in the 1970s and early 1980s in Greece by systematically and rigorously testing key hypotheses derived from the theoretical literature on democratic consolidation. Little has been written about Greece in political science, and the literature which exists is poorly developed. Despite this, Greece provides a rich opportunity for the testing of theoretical propositions found in the literature on consolidation processes. This is particularly true in light of several unusual features of its transition--its abrupt nature and the unprecedentedly dominant role in the process played by one individual, Konstantine Karamanlis. Several studies suggest that these features should have hindered Greece's prospects for a successful consolidation; yet Greece is today a fully stable and consolidated democracy. Thus, given the lack of prima facie evidence that the Greek transition trajectory fits with the most common models inherent in that literature, the ultimate contribution of this study (aside from contributing to the relatively sparse literature on the Greek case, per se) is the significant refinement in key propositions of the theoretical approaches now dominant in the literature on democratic consolidation. This dissertation focuses primarily on the roles played by political elites during and in the decade after the transition to democracy by systematically examining the four distinct transformations that forged the consensual unity required to establish a stable and consolidated regime in Greece: (1) the modernization of the Right from a questionable commitment to democracy before the 1967 dictatorship to a fully democratic stance in the post-1974 period; (2) the moderation of the Communist Left which went from engaging in anti-democratic oppositional tactics for much of its history to loyalty towards the new democratic regime; (3) the moderation of the Panhellenic Socialist Movement (PASOK) which went from a seemingly semi-loyal stance in the formative years of the transition to one of full loyalty once in government; and (4) the transformation of the military's attitudes and behavior which led it to retreat from political involvement and to submit itself to civilian control. Finally, recognizing that elites do not act within a political vacuum, it also undertakes an analysis of elite interactions paying careful attention to the relevant social, cultural, and international contexts, and to the linkages between elites and their respective social and political groups.

Title: An evaluation system for CUSO: Promoting dialogue across epistemological divides in a learning organization
Abstract: CUSO$\sp1$ is a Canadian-based international non governmental organization (NGO) whose mission is to strengthen partnerships of solidarity among NGOs and social movements pursuing an agenda of social justice. As it faces cutbacks in funding, and meets requirements from its principal donor to improve planning and evaluation functions, CUSO is developing an evaluation system that meets the various needs of programmers, partners, management, the legislative Board, and donors. A basic premise of such a system is that it should be consistent with CUSO's aspirations to being a "learning organization". This thesis contributes to the development of CUSO's evaluation system. It analyses the implications of results-oriented management and evaluation practice which is currently being adopted at the suggestion of the principal donor. It then argues for a system that counterbalances the post positivist assumptions of a results-orientation to program evaluation by proposing participatory and consensus building evaluation approaches based on a constructivist paradigm. The strong associations linking purpose for evaluation, evaluation method, underlying epistemology, and decision-making arrangements in the organization are outlined. The implications of these associations are that participatory approaches based on a constructivist paradigm are consistent with CUSO's mission to develop partnerships of solidarity around responsive programs. For organizational learning, however, conclusions from these evaluations should be juxtaposed with conclusions from organization-wide evaluations based in the post-positivist tradition which examine program performance against CUSO's organizational objectives. The dialogue between these is ideally the site for challenging assumptions, revising the organization's analysis of the development process, and informing policy decisions. The theoretical discussion is based on three short stories conducted over a three-year period. The first is an inquiry into the different organizational needs for evaluation, as expressed by key stakeholders in the organization. The second is a case study of the development of an evaluation guide for CUSO's country program in Papua New Guinea. The third is a theoretical reflection on the application of a consensus-building approach to a regional evaluation of CUSO's programming in the Pacific. ftn $\sp1$Canadian University Service Overseas

Title: Ethnic hinterland: Contested spaces between nations and ethnicities in the lives of Baweanese labor migrants
Abstract: The ethnic hinterland concept is introduced in this thesis to point to the space within which various exchanges which involve the social reproduction of migrant workers such as Orang Bawean take place. International division of labor reconstitutes the labor power of Orang Bawean from that of subsistence farmer to the labor power of a migrant worker. Movements within the labor circuit are closely guarded by nation-states therefore, for physical mobility to be possible, state bureaucracies have to be approached, evaded or manipulated through links with insiders--the various oknums and calur (terms for linkages into bureaucratic offices). Various guards such as pengawal and tai kong assist in crossing boundaries. Many of them have come to play this role by attempting to move out of enclosing spaces themselves, and in the process, acquired the skills to deal with borders, boundaries, categories, documents and policing agents. Their work subverts the state's attempts at documentation because they move in a space that cannot be monitored easily by the formal bureaucracies. These generate overlapping circuits of exchange between workers and the Baweanese diaspora. A new family practice emerged--one divided by national boundaries and perhaps even national identities but unified by a newly found ethnic self, viewed as moral selves, with the help of yet a different kind of protector--spiritual guardians in the form of kiais (religious authorities). Kiais circulate within these circuits to act as linkages between parents and children or to pesantrens that practically raise children under their care. Thus, Bawean is spoken of as Pulau Santri (the island of religious novices) as well as Pulau Putri (the island of women, referring to male migration out to work). Often Baweanese aspire to get their children to become civil servants because in migrating for work, a worker often encounters dehumanizing experiences. The discourse on ethnic self enters into the cultural production of santri Bawean, and--thus, Bawean becomes inseparable with Islam and morality (disciplined or beradap).

Title: Essays in labor migration and economic development
Abstract: This dissertation consists of four essays on the theme of labor migration. The first chapter is an introduction. The second chapter examines a two-country general equilibrium trade model where transnational migrants find employment in the urban informal sector in the most country. We discuss the conditions under which such conventional concepts as "labor exports in underemployed economies improves welfare" do not necessarily hold. The asymmetric pattern of employment across migrants and domestic workers in turn distinguishes the welfare consequences of domestic population growth and foreign labor inflow. The presence of international labor mobility also renders ineffective several traditional corrective policy prescriptions against urban unemployment (such as unemployment tax (benefits) and foreign investment). In the third chapter we present two instances where migration reinforces its own momentum. The first example introduces the notion of cost reducing migrant networks. Through ties of kinship and other social relationships, these networks link veteran with potential migrants and serve to reduce both the physical and psychological costs of migration as the stock of migrants accumulates. The findings suggest the possibility of multiple migration equilibrium and explain the selectivity in terms of migration sources and destinations--neither of which can be accounted for when migration decisions are based on simple cost-benefit calculations. We explore the public good property of migrant networks and the suboptimality of migration flows even when laborers are perfectly mobile across geographically isolated regions. The results also stress the causal relationship between the initial stock of migrants and the migration equilibrium which ensues. The second example presents a model of brain drain which incorporates the role of quality uncertainty of prospective migrant workers. Our analysis emphasizes the impact of scale economies of education and offer an alternative explanation to the cumulative causation of the brain drain phenomenon when the possibility of migration affects education decisions. Free movement of migrants across countries is always suboptimal from the source country's viewpoint and national income maximization calls for both an education as well as an emigration tax. In the fourth chapter, we analyze the relationship between inequality in the distribution of productive assets and the propensity to migrate, in the context of an agriculturally oriented economy. We single out moral hazard on the part of hired laborers and credit market imperfection as key factors determining individual migration propensities. The findings identify the link between income inequality and the differential propensity to migrate between the haves and have nots. Ceteris paribus, a more unequal distribution of wealth implies a higher level of outmigration. The analysis also singles out redistribution of wealth originating from the rural sector itself as an avenue for alleviating the problem of excessive rural-urban migration. The fifth chapter, investigates the evolution of migration pattern when information pertaining to sectoral employment probabilities is imperfect. The chapter focuses on the interplay between belief on employment probabilities across sectors and the pattern of migration. A privately optimal migration rule is characterized and accordingly, the pattern of aggregate migration over time is traced out. We identify the long run pattern of migration under various institutional settings. We find that many common intuitions such as "temporary policies can only have temporary effects on migration flows", "the poorest regions are the most migration prone areas" and "bilateral migration cannot be an equilibrium phenomenon" turn out to be suspect.

Title: The victim as a hero in postwar Japan: The rise of a mythology of war victimhood
Abstract: Progressive activists cultivated Japanese pacifism after World War Two from both remorse over Japan's past as aggressor and a resolve never again to expose Japanese to the hardships of war. Yet in the 1960s a new generation led by Oda Makoto discovered that Japanese pacifism harbored an indulgent "victim's consciousness" (higaisha ishiki) and lacked a critical awareness of ever having inflicted suffering on others in war (kagaisha ishiki). Instead of treating victim consciousness only in the usual context of war responsibility, this dissertation on its evolution from 1945 until the 1960s analyzes war victimhood as a powerful ideological construct contested by conservatives as well as progressives. U.S. Occupation authorities inadvertently set the parameters of this struggle when they established "the people" as the central political entity in the postwar democratic order and encouraged the convenient belief that the militarist state had deceived and manipulated the Showa Emperor and his people into cooperating in the war effort. The victim mythology reached its purest form in the context of atomic victim exceptionalism, Japan's first powerfully unifying postwar myth which privileged the nation with an exclusive claim to leadership in the global ban-the-bomb movement in the middle 1950s. In this cold war context, nuclear victimhood transcended Japan's conventional wartime transgressions. Japanese and foreign critics routinely note that an amnesia about Japanese aggressions against Asians accompanied and abetted victim consciousness, but this study of Occupation reforms, anti-nuclear pacifism, social studies textbooks, novels and films, and victim compensation campaigns reveals that such aggressions were often remembered with clarity. Neglect of Japanese war responsibility characterized the purer, more self-absorbed discourse on victimhood, as in the ban-the-bomb movement; but Asian suffering played an essential role in progressive assertions of a common people's struggle against monopoly capitalism and the state system, and in conservative intimations of a shared Asian desire for independence from Western domination. More generally, Japanese victim mythology expressed progressive fears of a relapse into an aggressive foreign policy and oppressive domestic polity, while conservatives tried to redirect it to support a more traditional, patriotic understanding of postwar society.

Title: The barbarian moment: Southern New Criticism and social change
Abstract: Although Southern New Criticism was still in its infancy in 1942, young New York intellectuals like Lionel Trilling were already expressing the fears of a growing number of scholars that John Crowe Ransom and his disciples were leading American criticism astray, from a "sense of the past" and into the "barbarian moment" of formalist analysis. Ever since Trilling, moreover, the nominally objective approach sponsored by the Southerners and their fellow travellers has been accused of "barbarism" in many forms, whether repressing history, capitulating to the forces of social and political reaction, or even deliberately fostering what some have seen as the academy's entrenched elitism, racism, and sexism. For many poststructuralists, the New Criticism has become, in F. W. Dupee's phrase, an "immortal scapegoat." The irony, however, of the Jewish outsider Lionel Trilling scapegoating the Southerners so easily, can hardly have escaped Ransom, who nevertheless invited Trilling to join the editorial board of Kenyon Review that same year, and six years later to help found the Kenyon School of English. By then, of course, both were institutional insiders, but neither could forget the view from beyond the city's gates. My study examines the complex interrelations between criticism and barbarism by placing Ransom and company into two contexts: first, the "New South" movement, the promoters of industrialism and factory life who dominated academic and public discourse during the 1920s and 30s, and second, the Southern Renascence, the literary response to the unalloyed hubris of wholesale modernization. A concern with material history therefore underpins my analysis of the submerged connections between Southern modernism and the more dominant American tradition associated with such figures as Emerson, Whitman, Dickinson, Santayana, William James, and Wallace Stevens, and to international modernists like Laura Riding, Walter Benjamin, and Julia Kristeva. From this wide-ranging conversation, the portrait that emerges of the Southern New Critics, Ransom, Allen Tate, Cleanth Brooks, Robert Penn Warren, and their successor Marshall McLuhan--all of whose works wrestle with the competing claims of indigenous and non-native cultures, with a pervasive sense of exile at home, and with the utopian temptations of a "new class" of intellectual workers--anticipates many of the theoretical designs of contemporary "postcolonial" criticism.

Title: Shanghai labour: Gender, politics, and traditions in the making of the Chinese working class, 1911-1949
Abstract: Students of Chinese labour diverge widely in their approach to working class formation in China. Chinese historians tend to dismiss workers' pre-modern traditions as "feudal remnants" relegating the skilled craftsmen to the position of a "labour aristocracy" susceptible to political reformism. Working class solidarity and class consciousness tend to be depicted by Chinese scholars as rooted in the Chinese Communist Party (CCP)'s leadership. Many western experts, in contrast, appreciate the key role played by traditional culture in workers' unionization, yet they emphasize the segmentation and differentiation of Chinese workers. Gender, as an analytic category, is understated by most scholars both inside and outside China, although this imbalance is being redressed by recent studies. This thesis explores the character of the making of the Chinese working class, drawing upon insights pioneered by E. P. Thompson, approaching class as a fluent relationship made and remade historically. Concentrating on Shanghai workers' activities in three major arenas--the workplace, the family, and the labour movement--this work examines how gender, pre-modern traditions, and national as well as international politics shaped and defined the experience of female and male workers in the Republican-era (1911-1949). The voices of Shanghai workers assumed distinct tones because of the meanings of region, skill, sex, and gang factionalism. Nevertheless, as this dissertation argues, during this period a new human relation formed that was rooted in the subordination of wage labour to capital. Workers started to express their class identity in daily conflicts with their bosses. Class consciousness manifested itself, and class solidarity superseded divisions and differences during two moments of intensified class warfare--the mid-1920s and late-1940s. Nationalism and the CCP's mobilization contributed considerably to working class formation and reconstitution in Shanghai. The labour upheaval in the late-1940s also indicates a developed working class maturity since women hands, who were usually followers in the 1920s, became central figures in the emerging working class politics of social transformation.

Title: Influence of father absence and satisfaction with parents on selected measures of nurturant fathering
Abstract: This dissertation investigated nurturant fathering as demonstrated by men of differing father-absent backgrounds. Archival data was used from a 1990 survey of 1,515 religious and highly motivated participants in fathering seminars in various regions of the United States. Reasons for father absence included death, divorce, work, and no absence. The influence of type of father absence was examined within the context of (a) participant's age at the time his father became absent, (b) participant's satisfaction with childhood relationship with father, and (c) participant's satisfaction with childhood relationship with mother. The Personal Fathering Profile (PFP) (Canfield, 1990) was used to measure eight aspects of nurturant fathering. The PFP is a 138-item, self-report instrument using 5- and 7-point Likert scales. Data was subjected to several multivariate analysis. Results indicated significant main effects for three measures of family-of-origin relationships (father absence, satisfaction with childhood relationship with father, and satisfaction with childhood relationship with mother). The global direction of these differences indicated a trans-generational movement toward healthy fathering. These differences were consistent with social learning theory and general psychodynamic theory. Participants were found to compensate for their fathers' obvious failures (e.g., amount of time spent with children) and to imitate the more subtle aspects of fathering (e.g., aspects of nurturant fathering). Isolated main effects indicated that childhood relationship with father and childhood relationship with mother made gender specific contributions to the development of instrumental and expressive fathering skills respectively. Relationship with father contributed to (a) commitment, (b) knowing children, and (c) protecting and providing. Relationship with mother contributed to (a) consistency, (b) loving spouse, and (c) active listening. Follow-up analysis indicated that the synergetic union of a father and mother contributed more to their son's development of these six measures of nurturant fathering than did the mere sum of the father's and mother's individual contributions. A father's presence influenced his life expectancy as well as the length of his wife's life. Divorce appeared to shorten life span of fathers and mothers by 10 and 18 years respectively. Work patterns where sons considered the father missing appeared to shorten life span of fathers and mothers by 6 and 12 years respectively.

Title: Quality of life measurement in schizophrenia: A study of the credibility of patients' reports of self-rated quality of life
Abstract: Patients' ability to appraise their quality of life in schizophrenia was studied by examining the reliability and validity of self-rated quality of life estimates. Sixty-three symptomatically stable patients with schizophrenia (DSM-II-R) receiving maintenance treatment were evaluated over a four week period. Quality of life was assessed at weekly intervals by patients of the Sickness Impact Profile, and on the first and fourth weeks by a clinician using the Social Performance Schedule & Global Scale of Adaptive Functioning. A clinical profile was documented using the Positive and Negative Syndromes Scale, Drug Attitude Inventory, Abnormal Involuntary Movements Scale, Hillside Akathasia Scale and a Neurocognitive test battery. The results indicated that patients' self reports were highly consistent over the four weeks (r = 0.80-0.87, p $<$ 0.0001), and their quality of life ratings correlated significantly with the clinician's estimates (r = 0.52-0.54, p $<$ 0.002). Further, the patients' quality of life was significantly influenced by the severity of their symptoms, side effects, cognitive deficits, the dose of their antipsychotic drugs and their attitudes toward treatment, but the reliability of their self-reports was not materially affected by these factors. Since their trustworthiness has been confirmed, it is recommended that increased emphasis be placed on patients' subjective assessments. The expanded use of self-report measures in clinical evaluations and in drug trials in schizophrenia is also recommended.

Title: Christian voluntary service: An appropriate approach to mission in and to a continent in crisis
Abstract: An analysis of the cultural, political, social, economical and ecological crisis in Africa shows that the desire for power and wealth whereby people and groups enrich themselves at the expense of others, is an important reason for the crisis. An integrated people-centred developmental model, which emphasises empowerment through service, is suggested as a solution to address the crisis. The African church has an important role in the implementation of the model by motivating members to address the needs of others. A new understanding of mission, which highlights service, is therefore needed. Jesus came to serve people by providing in their spiritual, emotional, and physical needs. This can be seen in His teaching and deeds which show that the Kingdom of God has entered the earth. Jesus' ministry can therefore be seen as semeiotic or disclosing service. He expects from His followers to continue with this ministry. This unified ministry was divided through the centuries. There is a return in various Christian traditions to the one ministry of Jesus. Mission can therefore be seen as semeiotic service, and the church as a serving community. Every Christian is called to serve others in his family, society, other parts of the world and the environment. It must also be realised out of the family, congregation, local community and international community. Voluntary service represents the apposite of the desire for power and wealth. Mission as semeiotic service is also voluntary service because believers serve others irrespective of compensation. The crisis in Africa can be addressed effectively through this approach. The various forms and categories of voluntary service need to be implemented in the South African situation. "Impact: Community Volunteers Serving South Africa" was established to embody this approach. Especially the institutionalisation of the church hampered the success of the organisation. This problem needs to be addressed if the church wants to play a role in the suggested developmental model. Proposals for a Christian Voluntary Service Movement in Africa and especially South Africa are finally suggested.

Title: Development and resistance: Rural resistance to economic development practices in Western Samoa
Abstract: In this thesis I show that contemporary development practices in Western Samoa are the product of a historical encounter between two social, political, and cultural worlds; the Samoan world characterized by a kin-ordered mode of production and the world of global capitalism. That encounter culminated in the incorporation of the Independent State of Western Samoa created and defined by members of a Samoan political elite in collaboration with members of the New Zealand colonial elite. Since the incorporation of the independent State of Western Samoa, successive government elites in collaboration with aid donors have attempted to implement a state-centered model of and for development directed toward the goals of national self-reliance and a condition of improved economic well-being for all Samoans. Government strategies have focused on the development of relations with patron states that provide aid in the form of grants, loans, technology, and technicians for investment, for the most part, in large state-owned commercial ventures and infrastructural projects. Unfortunately, government strategies have failed to achieve either a movement toward national self-reliance or enhanced economic well-being for the majority of Samoans. The Government development practices have not effectively mobilized and utilized rural resources, specifically, the rural institutions of land and labour, as tools for raising productivity in the rural sector of the economy. Instead the production of export crops has stagnated or declined, and government attempts to utilize land for forestry or infrastructural projects have been met, more of the than not, with resistance from people living in the rural areas. Furthermore, young Samoans continue to migrate out of the rural areas leaving their families short of labour and struggling to produce a surplus in addition to their subsistence requirements.

Title: British ideological movements and irish politics, 1865-1925
Abstract: This thesis is concerned with the movement in British public opinion towards the acceptance of Irish self-government in the years 1865-1925. The thesis is divided into three parts, each of which investigates an ideological grouping (largely represented in the periodical or newspaper press) which contributed significantly to this movement. The first part is concerned with the British followers of Auguste Comte in the late nineteenth century. The Comtean Positivists were the first significant group of educated Britons to endorse Irish independence. Although they derived these unusual convictions from the most visionary features of Comte's system, their advocacy significantly affected the late nineteenth-century debate on Anglo-Irish relations. The second part concerns new Liberalism. It is generally thought that Edwardian Liberal advocates of social reform were apathetic about Ireland; but one tradition within radical Liberalism was persistent and coherent in its support of Irish self-government. This group helped to popularise Home Rule from 1886, until the Anglo-Irish war of 1919-21. The final section concerns Imperialists (or advocates of Imperial "consolidation") in the first quarter of the twentieth century. Unlike the other two groups, these were not Home Rulers by conviction, and they endeavoured to preserve as much constitutional unity as possible in the United Kingdom. But in the second decade of the twentieth century, they came to regard some form of Irish autonomy as inevitable, and, in some cases, assisted the establishment of the Irish Free State in official capacities. This study concludes that changing British perceptions of the Empire and of the international community in these years produced a significantly more favourable attitude in Britain to the idea of Irish self-government. Indeed, it was partly because attitudes were changed by events exogenous to Ireland itself that problems remained after 1925 both with Ireland, and in British perceptions of the country.

Title: Society, politics and economics in mazandaran, persia, 1848-1914
Abstract: This thesis discusses the economic, politics and society of M<IMG WIDTH=7 HEIGHT=9 ALT="a" SRC="/inline/abarabove.gif">zandar<IMG WIDTH=7 HEIGHT=9 ALT="a" SRC="/inline/abarabove.gif">n in the period 1848-1914, with a view to deepening our understanding of provincial history in the Q<IMG WIDTH=7 HEIGHT=9 ALT="a" SRC="/inline/abarabove.gif">j<IMG WIDTH=7 HEIGHT=9 ALT="a" SRC="/inline/abarabove.gif">r period. The first chapter looks at M<IMG WIDTH=7 HEIGHT=9 ALT="a" SRC="/inline/abarabove.gif">zandar<IMG WIDTH=7 HEIGHT=9 ALT="a" SRC="/inline/abarabove.gif">n by 1848, considering in particular its social structure and economic system. In the second chapter it considers the impact of the great powers, especially Russian policies, on both society and local powers in the province. Chapter III looks in detail at economic change, discussing in particular the influence of the international economy on the province. Political movements in rural areas are the subject of Chapter IV where the significance of local factors is emphasized in the analysis of the B<IMG WIDTH=7 HEIGHT=9 ALT="a" SRC="/inline/abarabove.gif">b uprising. Chapter V concentrates on urban politics and draws attention to the rise of new groups especially the local merchants and the intelligentsia and their links with the 'ulam<IMG WIDTH=7 HEIGHT=9 ALT="a" SRC="/inline/abarabove.gif">. The final chapter follows the course of the Constitutional Revolution, demonstrating the inter-action between national and local politics.

Title: Carib to creole: contact and culture exchange in dominica
Abstract: This is an ethnohistorical study of the Carib people who inhabit the Carib Territory (officially called the Carib Reserve), on the northeastern coast of Dominica which is one of the islands of the Lesser Antilles in the eastern Caribbean. It analyses the historical background of the Caribs from the time of their initial contact with Europeans and Africans through the period of colonisation, and considers the effects which the centuries of culture exchange have had on the indigenous societies of Dominica up to the present. This heritage is considered in relation to the cultural revival movement which has developed since the 1980s as part of the hemispheric action being initiated by indigenous peoples of the Americas for greater recognition and rights. Promoting Carib identity in this context has become important to the community on many levels. The thesis assesses the manner in which the Caribs are using their history, material culture, and association with their land to articulate their indigenousness in the face of the centuries of cultural and biological admixture with people of European and African descent known as Creoles. The thesis concludes that although it may be true that these symbols are distorted and exaggerated, they are not entirely invented, for they originate in the history and culture of the Carib people. Even if, in many ways, the Caribs have become as Creole as their fellow countrymen, the social fact is, that in the present circumstances, they see it as important and advantageous to define themselves as Caribs in their engagement with Creole nationalism and the world beyond. By promoting their association with the cultural markers of Caribness, their cultural activists seek to engage with the current international concern and interest in indigenous groups in the hope that it might eventually reap some good for their people.

Title: The personal narrative of edith simcox: an annotated transcription of her autobiography of a shirt maker, and detailed introduction of her life and works
Abstract: This thesis is concerned with the life and works of Edith Jemima Simcox (1844-1910), and offers a detailed introduction to, and annotated transcription of, her holograph journal, Autobiography of a Shirt Maker (1876-1900). The Introduction provides a five-part analysis of Simcox's journal, comprising: i) a biographical outline of Simcox's life, setting her within her social, political, intellectual and cultural milieux; ii) a consideration of the critical responses that the Autobiography has provoked since it was first (partially) transcribed in 1961; iii) the interpretive and methodological issues raised in working on the Autobiography, and detailed examination of such matters as context, form, voice and history/truth. iv) a discussion of the journal as a 'passionate landscape of selfhood' in relation to two main concerns: first, Simcox's political activism in such movements as women's trades unionism, women's suffrage, the women's Co-operative organisation, the 2 nd International, inter alia, and second, her devotion and love for the writer George Eliot; v) a conclusion, evaluating ways in which the Autobiography can be seen as a vital intellectual outlet. The transcription of Simcox's journal is fully annotated, with an accompanying note on the text, details on the editorial apparatus, and full Index of names, places, texts and social, political and cultural organisations.

Title: Worth its weight: gold, women and value in north west india
Abstract: This thesis looks at gold as a highly valued substance in Indian society generally, and, more specifically, as a type of property which is frequently held by women. The first chapter considers the presence of gold in many different social institutions and shows how gold moves in similar ways in each. It is in the movement of gold between persons, and in the changing emphases on the potential of the substance, that the value of gold is to be found. Exchanges of gold give the gold bazaar a unique form. The chapter on markets sees the bazaar as the local articulation of a global commodity. The market is viewed as a social structure within which the primary process is the negotiation of the purity of gold. The chapter dealing with saving, lending and spending shows how, in the Indian context, the possibility of borrowing money against the security of gold means that women view investment in gold as a form of saving. The purchase of gold is simultaneously saving and consumption. As a valuable and potentially economically productive substance, the importance of gold has generally been underestimated in explanations of dowry. By looking at gold as an alternative form of property to land, this chapter seeks to understand the meaning of women's ownership of gold. Gold in India is perceived as embodying the same ambiguous mixture of good and evil as women. The chapter on adornment deals with both the symbolic and the practical uses of gold and other precious things, both worn on the body and consumed in medicine. This thesis uses a single substance as its main focus in an attempt to expand what can be seen as 'economic' within anthropology. To this end feminist critiques of the idea of economy are used.

Title: The role of management control systems in privatisation: a labour process analysis of a Bangladeshi case study.
Abstract: The study is concerned with accounting controls in the social and organisational context of Bangladesh, focusing on recent privatisation issues. The assumption of development economists and policy makers, influenced by neo-classical economics, is that a change in ownership will be associated with superior management performance through improved accounting controls. This study, based on an intensive case study, argues that such assumptions can be over-simplistic and erroneous. The study analyses management controls in the light of the labour process theory paying due attention to intra-organisational conflict, the manufacture of workers' consent and inherent organisational contradictions in the context of wider socio-political factors. Thus, the methodological focus of the research resides in the political economy of work and organisations. In particular, it seeks to extend Burawoy's theorisation of organisation control and consent to accounting in the context of privatisation with a developing country. This theoretical model perceives control as the outcome of interactions of external and internal factors. Accounting is implicated in those interactions. The data for this study was collected from one organisation which had three phases of ownership: public sector, partial privatisation and privatisation. The data covered the historical changes of state policies, trade union movements in Bangladesh and the transformations of internal controls. An examination of the empirics thus collected helps explain the change of controls including accounting in a wider environment. The study argues that internal control processes are conditioned by external issues. For example, during the pre-privatisation periods, PC's control was politicised and bureaucratic due to the influence of state politics and strong trade union movements. Following the changes of external issues, that is, changes in state policies and weaker trade union movements, which are influenced by international aid agencies, control processes in the privatised firm have substantially changed.

Title: Myth, prejudice and vested interest: political and cultural influences on history teaching in British secondary schools, 1945 - 1995.
Abstract: Introduction. The introduction identifies a variety of pressures bearing on secondary school history, analysing their role in producing substantial changes, short-term experiments and reversals of policy over fifty years. Chapter 1. Some Academic Controversies and Antecedents. This chapter traces the transmission of ideas from major historians through universities to school departments, drawing on evidence from the Historical Association, the JMB and a representative sample of school textbooks. Chapter 2. School History and the Politics of Post-War Reconstruction. Chapter 2 examines evidence from two major post-war developments; the improvement of international understanding and the provision of a varied and effective humanities education for senior pupils in the new technical and secondary modern schools. The increasing importance of educational sociology in curriculum theory is also explored. Chapter 3. Integrated Humanities and Social Studies: Challenge or Support to History? The main issue discussed here is the promotion of integrated humanities courses and social studies by the Schools Council and the resultant challenge to history's place on the timetable. The new movement and the traditionalist responses it provoked are considered with reference to the Nuffield Humanities, MACOS and Keele projects, together with some school-based initiatives. Chapter 4. The Defence of History. Chapter 4 reviews early proposals for improvement such as textbook reform, school-based experiments, and the application of Bloom's 'objectives' theory, mainly as interpreted by Coltham and Fines. This section is followed by an analysis of the Schools Council 13-16 History Project (1972) (SCHP) and the controversy surrounding it.

Title: Church and politics in the theology of Jose Miguez-Bonino and Allan Boesak.
Abstract: Since the early 1970s, many Christians have come to the realisation that the churches world-wide have a profound impact on the shaping of a nation's socio-economic and political agenda. Issues and debates within the Church are shaped by the interplay between intra-Church theological and ecclesiastical concerns and national/international ideological and institutional patterns to which churches must adapt. Newly emerging socio-political situations, such as the emergence of democracy in South Africa, complicate the Church's continued search for its prophetic voice: What does it mean to have a concern for social justice, peace, and to maintain a "preferential option for the poor" when the world's political order is continually in transition? This thesis explores the debates that surround the Church's relationship to politics by focusing on the contemporary theological movement known as "liberation theology" and objections that have been raised by its more conservative and liberal opponents. It specifically examines and compares the way Jose Miguez-Bonino from Latin America and Allan Boesak from South Africa, have responded to the theological challenges set by their surrounding social realities and how they have answered the criticisms from Europe and North America. We argue that the theology of these two men offers a more adequate understanding of the relationship between Church, theology, and politics than their critics because of the importance Miguez-Bonino and Boesak give to a praxis that reflects the needs of the poor and oppressed.

Title: Brutal responsibilities and second-class citizens: Women soldiers, martial citizenship, and feminist anti-militarism
Abstract: This dissertation addresses women's incorporation to the United States' armed forces by placing it in political, historical, and social context. From common roots in the women's movements of the 1960s and 1970s, women have been approaching the military from two perspectives: feminist antimilitarists have been criticizing the military for its masculinist culture, while women interested in joining the military have insisted that it is their right to participate, and that the military is the sine qua non of full citizenship. This project explores a series of questions about women soldiers, women's citizenship, feminist antimilitarism, and the culture of patriarchal militarism to untangle some of the interesting and troublesome questions about women and the military. The method of analysis used in the dissertation is interdisciplinary, combining historiography, sociology, ethnography, and political theory in the United States' context to view a series of historical moments in congressional testimony, court cases addressing equality, feminist movements for equality, feminist antimilitarist perspectives on and responses to the military, and histories of martial citizenship, including women's. These materials are investigated for their political importance in shaping public understandings of the military as gendered, for their importance in building a discourse of expanded citizenship claims, and for their contributions to shifting the terrain of citizenship and equality. The dissertation suggests, in view of these materials, that feminist scholars of the military, and of militarism, must account for the changing demographics of the armed forces by examining the contested meanings of citizenship, the effects of technological advances, and the economic imperatives that together comprise the conditions through which women access advancement in the military. Furthermore, the dissertation demonstrates that women's entry to the military is a critical juncture for several reasons: (1) It is a challenge to the structured masculinity of military culture, (2) It informs studies of the international economies in which women become the primary, but low-waged, workers, and (3) It marks a need for feminist antimilitarists to re-evaluate their approach to the topics of soldiering, women, and peace.

Title: Women in transition, health care in translation: Nicaraguan women and the challenge of cervical cancer prevention
Abstract: Nicaragua, a small Central American country, has suffered from centuries of colonial exploitation, social and political unrest, and inconceivable numbers of natural disasters. The health of the population, especially women, reflects the harsh realities of their lives. Extreme poverty, religious conservatism, machismo, and social and interpersonal violence, neglect, and sexual exploitation have left a legacy of high fertility, chronic pelvic pain, and extremely high rates of cervical cancer among women. Despairing of government, religious, or family support, women themselves have organized a vast network of services including new models of health care. Women's clinics, supported by the international women's health movement, have sprung up all over the country since 1990 to provide a wide variety of services for and by women. These clinics are widely perceived as positively affecting the emotional well being of their clients. A key service provided in these clinics is Pap screening for the prevention of cervical cancer. There are indications from around the country that cervical cancer is increasing in incidence. The clinics' effectiveness in preventing significant cervical disease is unknown. This study was undertaken to investigate the impact of these new clinics in reducing the toll of cervical disease on the lives of Nicaraguan women. Using methods from medical anthropology and clinical epidemiology, structured and semi-structured interviews, participant observation, STD testing and Pap smears, the activities of women's clinics and the reproductive tract disease burden of their clients were evaluated from October 1995 through July 1996. Clinical examinations were conducted on a random sample of 248 women that regularly utilized the services of three women's clinics in Esteli, Nicaragua. Results show that a significant portion of women with evidence of cervical disease are missed in the existing programs. I conclude that this difficulty reflects the limited operating funds, lack of education, and quality controls found throughout the Nicaraguan health care system, but more importantly it illustrates the difficulties encountered when technology and health care concepts are transferred from one cultural setting to another. All technology, including the Pap smear, embeds a number of unquestioned cultural assumptions that induce unexpected results in translation.

Title: Female elites, women's formal associations, and political practices in urban Mali (West Africa)
Abstract: This work investigates Malian women's formal associations and their participation in local and national politics from the late 'fifties until the present. Building on both historical and ethnographic data, it details a multiplicity of ways in which Malian women influence political events. It does so by highlighting the often opaque political implications of women's ritual and economic activities. Women's formal organizations may constitute often covert but powerful electoral lobbies. They work as mediators between state institutions and citizens and may be asked by local power holders to enforce administrative changes at the local level. Moreover, women's groups represent a major reference point for local and international aid agencies in search of development partners. This work begins with a critical review of some of the available literature on village politics. It tries to account for the ways that memories of the past have informed people's political practices during the struggle for independence from France. The work continues with discussing a number of institutional transformations that women's formal organizations have gone through from the colonial era to the present. While it describes the diverse historical phases of the women's movement, the main goal remains to further an understanding of the relationship between political practices and local culture. At the center of my discussion I situate the patronage system, since relationships among women within their organizations are far from egalitarian. Building on work by Amselle, Bagayogo and Lambert de Frondeville, I present patron-client relationships as an orienting paradigm within women's political associations. This discussion allows me to focus on the ways in which women's political activism, social distinctions, and Mande social philosophy intertwine in the practices and representations of female group members. I explore the multiple dimensions of the patronage system in Mali by looking at leaders' professional identities, motivations, cultural values, and political practices. I include glimpses detailing how leaders are viewed from the bottom up, and spend some time to describe women's communal activities, especially during feast time. I conclude by drawing some implications of my study for a general understanding of politics in Mali. This work is based on a twenty months of fieldwork in the cities of Bamako and Segu, as well as archival work in Mali, Italy, and the US.

Title: Art world maps: A quantitative sociology of contemporary American art
Abstract: The objective of this research is the automatic style-classification of artists via relationships in the literature between artist-pairs and the graphical depiction of the relationships in a two-dimensional map. This research applies the co-citation methodology, developed and validated for mapping the structure of the science and social science literatures, to the literature of the visual arts. Co-mention, a co-word measure, is substituted for the co-citation unit of analysis. The study derives style structure from the visual arts literature using the multivariate techniques of cluster analysis, factor analysis, and multidimensional scaling applied to co-mention matrices derived from two bibliographical databases, Art Literature International (RILA) and Arts & Humanities Search$\sp\circler$. The co-mention methodology is validated by the comparison of the classification produced by each of the two source databases with the independent qualitative classification of artists synthesized by Diana Crane in her book The Transformation of the Avant-Garde: the New York Art World, 1940-1995, from the major critics and historians of the period. The Rand Index, R$\sb{\rm g}$, provided a metric for comparison of the groupings obtained and produced ratings xindicating very good agreement between each of the database-generated classifications and the qualitative synthesis (3-D RILA and synthesis: R$\sb{\rm g}$ = 0.8873; 3-D AHCI and synthesis: R$\sb{\rm g}$ = 0.8297), as well as between the two quantitative classifications (R$\sb{\rm g}$ = 0.8070). Additional support for the validity of the method can be seen from the consistency of the structures produced by the three different quantitative techniques. The multidimensional scaling produced maps which provide coherent displays of the structures (RILA: 3-D RSQ = 0.799, stress = 0.170; AHCI: 3-D RSQ = 0.758, stress = 0.188). SPSS's INDSCAL scaling model of the ALSCAL procedure was used to compare the two maps and indicated a moderately good fit (3-D RSQ = 0.604, stress = 0.240). Graphical depiction of style groupings appears generally consistent among the maps and Crane classification; deviations from the expected groupings are interpretable, augmenting the understanding of style or movement affiliation.

Title: Prolonging the inevitable: The franc-tireur and the German Army in the Franco-German War of 1870-1871
Abstract: This study examines the nature of the guerrilla war which developed inside France during the Franco-German War of 1870-71. Previous studies of the conflict typically addressed French guerrillas, known as francs-tireurs, in a cursory manner, often portraying them as little more than bandits and outlaws who proved a greater threat to the French population than to the enemy. Drawing upon important German and French primary source material such as diaries, memoirs, military orders, dispatches, and official proclamations, this study demonstrates that the earlier assessments have generally mischaracterized francs-tireurs as a whole and underestimated the degree to which irregulars positively effected their nation's war effort, destroying rail and telegraph lines, ambushing isolated columns and requisitioning patrols, conducting screening operations, providing intelligence, harrying siege perimeters, restricting the movements of major enemy units, and ultimately prolonging the war by two or three months. Francs-tireurs were not a homogeneous group, neither geographically nor ideologically. Demographic information reveals that franc-tireur units consisted overwhelmingly of males of all social classes and geographic regions and several foreign nations. Political philosophies varied among them, but nationalistic sentiments motivated most francs-tireurs to arm themselves and organize or join irregular guerrilla bands. Initially, the Germans perceived them as little more than a nuisance but as the war progressed and franc-tireur operations multiplied, they had to expend substantial manpower and material resources to protect their lines of communications from these formidable and elusive opponents. German counterguerrilla efforts which most often consisted of monetary fines, but also hostage taking, executions, and the burning of villages, ultimately achieved moderate success, convincing many French, just before war's end, to leave the fighting to the military. Never regarding the francs-tireurs as legitimate combatants entitled to the rights accorded soldiers under the laws of war, the Germans maintained vehemently throughout the conflict that warfare was reserved strictly for professional armies and that shielding civilians as much as possible from the horrors of war could be accomplished only if civilians refused to involve themselves in warfare, an argument which led subsequently to international conferences concerning the laws of land warfare to determine among other things the legal definition of combatants.

Title: The centrality of mutuality, Africentric values, and ethnic identity on the socio-emotional functioning of adolescent girls
Abstract: The scholarly study of adolescent development can be fairly characterized as male-centered and Caucasian-centered. Consequently, current theories of adolescent psychological growth and development rarely reflect the socio-cultural realities of African-American girls. The present study was predicated on two theoretical frameworks: relational theory (Jordan, Kaplan, Miller, Stiver, & Surrey, 1991) and NTU theory (Phillips, 1990). This investigation examined the relationship of mutuality, Afrikan values, and ethnic identity to the self-concept and socio-emotional functioning of adolescent girls. It was hypothesized that different categories of perceived mutuality (e.g., relational orientation, unidirectional orientation, and social-isolation orientation) in same-sex peer relationships would be related to self-concept. Subsumed under this hypothesis was the extent to which these categories would be related to socio-emotional behaviors. Mutuality refers to the bidirectional movement of feelings, thoughts, and activity between persons in relationships. Socio-emotional behaviors are defined as indices of school functioning, such as rule compliance, social skills, school interests, anxiety and withdrawal. A second question explored the extent to which Afrikan values are positively related to self-concept and favorable socio-emotional behaviors. The third hypothesis addressed the extent to which ethnic identity would be related to self-concept and socio-emotional behaviors. Finally, it was hypothesized that different categories of perceived mutuality (e.g., relational orientation, unidirectional orientation, and social-isolation orientation) in adolescent-adult relationships would be related to self-concept. Subsumed under this hypothesis was the extent to which these categories would be related to socio-emotional behaviors. Archival data were obtained on ninety-nine African-American girls ages 10–14. The participants, in a group setting, were administered the Mutual Psychological Development Questionnaire, African Value Scale for Children, Multigroup Ethnic Identity Measure, Piers-Harris Self-Concept Scale and the Children's Rating Scale. Correlational and canonical results indicated that the participants strongly endorsed the centrality of mutuality in both relationship types (e.g., same-sex peer and adolescent-adult relationships). However, the categories of mutuality in both relationship types were not significantly associated with self-concept nor socio-emotional functioning. Ethnic identity was a salient predictor of global self-concept as well as several facets of self-concept. The hypothesized significant relationship between ethnic identity and socio-emotional functioning was also confirmed. Additionally, ethnic identity was significantly correlated with specific dimensions of socio-emotional functioning. Afrikan values were statistically significant in relation to one facet of self-concept; although, these values were not significant in understanding socio-emotional functioning. The concept of mutuality for African-American girls is situated within a cultural context. The primary implication of this study is that ethnic identity is an influential component in the lives of African-American adolescent girls. It is also suggested that school-related behaviors are directly related to positive evaluations' of one's ethnic group.

Title: Presentation, modernism, and post-colonialism: Korean Informel and the reception of the West
Abstract: This dissertation discusses Informel, the most significant abstract art movement in recent Korean art history, which flourished from 1957 to 1965. In spite of the fact that modern Western oil painting had been introduced to Korea in 1910, Informel was the fist self-consciously avant-garde movement in the nation's history. As the first major cultural product in postwar Korea, Informel embodies the transformation of the society, in particular a desire for modernization and modernity, formed and led by intellectuals and the young social elite. The discourse of modernization accompanied expanded ideals on Western elements such as democracy, freedom, individualism, and enlightenment. Korean Informel began to emerge in the third Hyundai Artists Association exhibition--the group consisted of young artists who aimed to breach the conventional way of art-making and to challenge a dominant style, the Japanese-mediated French Impressionism. Informel works represent the drip technique, large scale, violent gesture, rough brushwork, strong color and abstract style. Most of the Hyundai artists suggested that behind these formal similarities with those of Western examples lay Korea's frustration with authority and its people's anger after the brutal Korean War. However, from 1960, Korean artists actively developed their own individual style rediscovering Korean traditional art. Hyundai artists branched out and developed diverse abstract styles. The artists including Seo-bo Park, Myung-no Youn, Sang-hwa Chung, and Chang-sup Chung, commanded very dark and rough surfaces built up with mixed media such as plaster and other materials. While Tschang-yeul Kim, Sung-soon Chang, Chang-kwon Kim and other young fellow artists adopted a simpler composition with calligraphic lines. And all of these artists explored traditional Asian visual features with Korean sensibility. For example, techniques of traditional Korean painting, such as using ink of various tones with abstract surface structure and contrasts between positive and negative space with absolute tranquility, were combined in Informel style. Informel was the most successful example of internalizing the Western avant-garde art incorporating the indigenous dialogue of Korea. Informel, diversified and expanded into various media and artists, signified the abstract style in general and caused a further exploration of other Western avant-garde styles. Informel artists actively participated in the international art fairs such as the Paris and Sao Paolo biennales, and this enhanced their status in Korea. The Korean art world turned its focus to abstract style and since then, the recognition and practice of avant-garde became the most significant subject among the artists. Informel was developed intertwined with the social discourse of modernization; intellectuals proclaimed the Western examples of philosophy and their systems of production. In this discourse, the desire to change conflicted with their identity, but as the subject of the change, Koreans took a critical position to both the realms of tradition and the West. As Homi Bhabha discusses, Korean modernization crystallizes the ambiguous stage of identity and an active involvement of mimicry. Informel, symbolizing the imperative to modernize the Korean art world that forebodes the advent of broad reception of the West, represents this ambivalent situation of involvement in the discourse of modernism. (Abstract shortened by UMI.)

Title: Antifascist art of the Popular Front in Paris, 1934-1938
Abstract: This study explores the functions of art of the Popular Front in Paris, a key part of the largest international antifascist alliance during the 1930s. It establishes a corpus of imagery and systematically studies how it relates to the multiple aspects and aspirations of the Popular Front. It underlines the aesthetic as well as the political diversity of the artists who participated in the Popular Front, from Robert Delaunay's abstraction to Boris Taslitzky's French brand of social realism, in order to explore how democratic participation and internal debate contributed to an ongoing effort to define politically engaged art and the role of the artist in the antifascist cause. The dissertation furnishes criteria for defining art of the Popular Front springing from the alliance's structure as a mass movement, an electoral coalition, and an elected government by using its political and cultural organizations and programs as an institutional framework. It takes artists' participation in the organizations' debates and exhibitions and in the alliance's public demonstrations as indicators of Popular Front involvement. Moreover, it identifies and analyzes the primary themes in art appearing in such contexts, including the portrayal of street agitation, key Popular Front events and values, the government social achievements and programs, and the Spanish Civil War. Arranged both chronologically and thematically, the study examines the commemorative function of early street art and imagery of the street in establishing a history of Popular Front events and in tracing a lineage of 18th- and 19th-century revolutionary struggles and cultural traditions. Such early art contained contestatory and affirmative charges which related to the often contradictory alliance propositions of antifascism and peace. These charges informed the Debates on Realism and ultimately became fragmented into distinct functions in affirmative government art and contestatory art of the Spanish Civil War. The study concludes that, among the western democratic powers, the Popular Front in France was the force most able to mobilize a coherent yet diverse artistic response to the totalizing projects of the three dictatorships with which it was faced.

Title: A socio-biography of Shirley Graham-Du Bois: A life in the struggle
Abstract: Many people, when they think of Shirley Graham-Du Bois, tend to locate and situate her political, cultural, and intellectual life and accomplishments during her marriage to W. E. B. Du Bois. On the face of it this may seem to be an accurate representation of Graham's life. This perspective, however, obscures and marginalizes the significance of Graham's life and work before she became Du Bois's wife. This dissertation assesses how Shirley Graham-Du Bois was a leading cultural, political and intellectual figure (beginning in the 1920s and continuing throughout her prolific life). Graham constructed and enacted an intellectual, cultural, and political life which was constantly in tension with the dominant constructions, both within and outside of the black community, of gender, race, and nation. I discuss how Graham beginning with the late 1920s and continuing through the 1930s, 1940s, up to the early 1950s effectively generated, cultural, personal, and political spaces which were oppositional in her lifetime and foreshadowed many contributions to black feminism in particular and woman's studies in general. These areas of concern are investigated by using Socio-biography through qualitative methods. Socio-biography as a method is valuable because it makes visible the interplay between the experience of the individual and social structure. More importantly it highlights how the individual through agency and social structure are shaped by each other. Socio-biography fills the "knowledge gap" by and revealing the informal organizational structure that existed in the Black Colleges of Graham's days, within the formal organizational structure that limited Graham because of her gender in her teaching career. Socio-biography exposes the "production of obscurity": which argues that women's lives tend not to get the same attention and weight that men's lives do. That there has been a practice and system of silencing and marginalizing the lives, work, and activities of women. Through in-depth interviews, biographies, and correspondence I have found and document the breadth and depth of Graham's intellectual, cultural, and political life as a writer of operas and plays in the 1930s and early 1940s, biographer heroic African Americans (male and female) and active member and organizer in the 1940s of the International Peace Movement, and well as a founding member of the Progressive Party in 1948. By exposing Graham's accomplishments while she negotiated politics, career, and motherhood I show how Graham refused to be compartmentalized in any particular role, but was mother, career person, and political person all at once, and because of the complexity of her life I also further expose how Graham's life and work has been left-out of, and marginalized in gender, race, and ethnic studies.

Title: The abundant life prevails: Religious traditions of Saint Helena Island
Abstract: In 1862 two religious traditions collided on Saint Helena Island on the coast of South Carolina. One was an imported faith found primarily at the Penn School where Northern missionaries emphasized citizenship, character development, service, and self-discipline. The other, older religious tradition was that of the newly freed island slaves, representing a mixture of Southern evangelicalism and African traditional religious practice. This study demonstrates how each of these traditions emerged from their own community environment, sought particular goals for the island, influenced each other and eventually merged. Saint Helena Island and the Penn School are historically important because the island was used as a "rehearsal for reconstruction" when the area fell into Union hands in November of 1861. The Penn School was part of the "Port Royal Experiment" which sought to prove to a skeptical America that the former slaves could be good, responsible citizens. By the turn of the century, the Penn School faced various financial and leadership problems and therefore, a new cadre of missionaries arrived to conduct an "experiment" in educational salvation focusing on "character development" among the African-American islanders. Changing circumstances brought new crises to Saint Helena in the 1940s and the island became a center for the Civil Rights Movement during the 1950s and 1960s. The history of the island sheds enormous light on social progressivism and the nation's efforts to solve the "Negro problem." Numerous national progressive figures such as George Peabody, Julius Rosenwald, Reinhold Niebuhr and Martin Luther King, Jr. took an interest in Saint Helena Island. While national and even international attention was focused on Saint Helena, the local people of the island went about their lives, a major component of which was their own style of religion. The churches and pray's houses were the dominant institutions providing a place for community fellowship; for solving legal disputes because the islanders would not carry their cases before white judges on the mainland; and for guiding the people in seeking ecstatic, spiritual visions from God.
