Title: The diplomacy of Late Qing Dynasty and Western Learning
Abstract: Outline: After the Opium War, China became a semi-colonial and semi-feudal society and began the difficult process of modernizing her society. With the development of foreign affairs with the outside world, there appeared a diplomatic group specializing in foreign affairs in the Qing Dynasty authorieties. The personnel in the diplomatic group were the pioneers who contacted the Western society and the rest of the world for the interest of China with a weak diplomacy. Their personal experience in the expansion of western learning in China, and their changes of mind and ideology, are the subjects that deserve investigation and research. For the time being, little research is carried out about these diplomats especially about the diplomatic group, of the late Qing Dynasty. This thesis will do some research in three aspects of the diplomaly of the Late Qing Dynasty.First of all, the formation process on the modern diplomacy as well as its working mechanism. From 1861 to 1875, the Qing Dynasty finally began its construction of modem diplomacy in 1875 after years' preparations and experimentation. At the beginning, the Qing government put an emphasis on the social status and attitudes of diplomats in choosing them for the purpose of avoiding" changing China through foreignness" and only high officials with good academic fame were chosen. But later on, due to the actual demands, a variety of officials were chosen to be sent to other countries. As far as the officials themselves, there were roughly three motivations: 1, to understand the western society by means of being a diplomat in another country, such as Guo Song-tao, Xue Fu-cheng and Zeng Ji-ze; 2, to make a new turn in the officialdom through travelling to other countries, such as Chen Lanbin, Cui Guo-yin; 3,to make it as a shortcut to fame and office, such as Li Feng-bao, 2hang Yin-huang.Secondly, the experience and ideological change of diplomats. In accordance with the notebooks, memoirs, official letters and records of the diplomats, the thesis treats of their knowledge about foreign countries, they had different ways of life in foreign countries because of the varieties of personal experiences and motivations, thus their contacts and attention were quite different as well as their viewpoints to problems. However, they had some common topics as a whole, one was the difference between Chinese and western cultures, the other was the source of the powerfulness of a country. Therefore, there are four changes which deserve our attention: 1, the change from westernization to modernization; 2, less emphasis on the loyalty to the Qing Dynasty; 3, mutiple-viewpoints to treat of the difference between Chinese and werstern cultures; 4, realization of the disadvantageous position on China in the world.Thirdly, the role which the diplomats played in the process of expansion of western learning in China. The thesis points out that they made the main contributions as follows: 1, to restore the state sourveignty through the new knowledge they learned, in this respem the outstanding representatives are Zeng Ji-ze, Xue Fu-ceng, Yang Ru, especially Zeng Ji-ze who made a remarkable success in dealing with Russian authorities by means of international public laws as well as international situation knowledge; 2, to take an active part in the modernization to strengthen the social change of China, especially the direct work by Zhang Yin-huan and Huang Zun-xian in the famous Reformation of 1898;3,to actively advocate the movement to understand the western society and accelerate the exchange between China and the western society, for example, Zeng Ji-ze once led an Imperial Academic travelling activity. In the early expansion of western learning, the diplomats as the native excellent intellectuals, described their personal travelling experiences to persuade the countrymen; in the introduction of western culture, they imported western advance dequippment and technology as well as western academic culture. 4, to push and perfect the construction of modem diplomacy, including the training of the diplomats and the construction of embassy through the efforts of the first generation of diplomats.To conclude, the thesis makes it clear: as the pioneers of leading China to the outside world, the diplomats before the Sino-Japanese War cultivated the active reformation factors in the Qing Dynasty with their special experience to push the process of China's modernization to some degree, especially some excellent intellectuals of them who proved that the Chinese culture itself possessed the reformative and advancing force and power.

Title: World Order:Structures and Mechanisms
Abstract: On the basis of former macroscopically studies on the development of world order, this dissertation tries to further the studies from a microcosmic angle. It takes world order as a special system, and the deve1opment of world order as a self-organized process of the world order system, by which the author will explore the inherent mechanisms and genera1 laws of world order evolution. World order is a Stab1e, peaceful, and well-organized situation that relies on the balance of power. This situation is always streamlined during the process of intercourse among different intemationa1 relations actors under certain rules, norms and regimes. World order, thus, can be regarded as a system with special internal structure that is formed and changed historically by international relations actors' practice. The structure of world order regularly consists of four fundamental elements: actors, objects, aims, and means. The different configurations of those elements constitute various world order models. As the external appearance of world order system, the basic models of world order mainly include balance of power model and hegemony stability model, which are initiated by realists, collective security model and world government. Model, which are developed by liberalizes and idealists. Se1f-organizaton is the intrinsic mechanism of every system's evolution. The development of world order, which is a special social system in the context of the whole human society, is not exceptional either The development of world order is always started by continual stimulation of outside information and driven by inside movements of rise and fall. The process of self-organization and acclimatization can be usually divided into two steps or sub-forms of movement: assimilation self-organization and acclimatization self-organization. The world order system evolves constantly from assimilation to acclimatization, and then from acclimatization to assimilation, by which the world order system begins another process of deve1opment. Simultaneously, the world order system itself undergoes stability and instability circularly. These circulatory movements will never stop. And each new round of circle wil1 bring the new development of world order to a higher level. This is the general law of self-organizational evolution of the world order system. The evolution of the world order, being driven by intrinsic contradictions is the embodiment of the law of the unity of opposites. The evolution of world order from assimilation to acclimatization and then to new assimilation embraces the law of the transition of qualitative change and quantitative change. And the circulatory evolution of world order from stability to instability and to stability again practices the law of double negations. Just as the development law of any other things in the world, the development law of world order is also objective, stable, universal, and recurrent. Subsequently, the evolution of world order should be seen as both the unity of intermittence and continuity and the unity of recurrence and renewa1. In the history the evolution of real world orders followed strictly the general law of the development of world order. Westphalia order, which is accepted as the first true world order with universal implications, Vienna order, Versailles order, and Yalta order represent the most important stable phases in the evolution of the world order system. The period between every two world order phases happens to be the intermission or transition in the development of world order development, during which the whole world experienced the process of instability. As regards to the future new world order facing the 2l century various theories and models have been proposed. However, according to the general law of the development of world order, this dissertation infers that the most possible new world order will be a new multiplier balance of power formed by five major great powers the United States, Europe, Russia, Japan, and China.

Title: Catherine bauer 1928-1935: from modernism and housing to action
Abstract: Housing expert and city planner Catherine Bauer Wurster (1905-64) was, in 1929, introduced to Lewis Mumford. In 1930 Bauer sailed to Europe to study modern architecture. She attended the Die Frankfurter Kurse für Bauen and learned about social, technical, and economic approaches to housing. She came away convinced that an entirely new kind of human environment was not only possible but inevitable. In New York she wrote an article praising social housing in Frankfurt, Germany. In 1932, Bauer travelled to Europe with Mumford, to collect information about housing communities. That summer she decided to write Modern Housing (1934). The dissertation positions the contribution of Modern Housing in the modernist canon while focusing also on the place occupied by Modern Housing in the broader framework of thought about architecture and housing. The dissertation examines the conjunction of aesthetic and social ideas Bauer found in modern architecture. It attributes to her a "moral imagination" to show her thoughts about modernism housing and action. Hitchcock and Johnson's The International Style (1932) is unique in the unchallenged position it has held in the story of modernism coming to America, a text which post-war accounts criticized for having failed to address certain perennial issues definitive to modernism itself. A recent conference challenging the idea of an avant garde in America questioned the " motivations of practitioners of the avant-garde in America and the extent to which they were interested in form rather than in the philosophical, political, and economic underpinnings of the European movement". In this recent rethinking the significance of Modern Housing began to crystallize. To chart the arrival of modernism in America and acknowledge a deeper understanding of The International Style , it must be recognized that Modern Housing was conceived of and designed as a companion text, and that Modern Housing was written from an identifiable position within the 1930s debate.

Title: The cry for justice in Nigeria: A look at MOSOP and the effectiveness of its nonviolent tactics
Abstract: The Ogoni people, a minority ethnic group of Rivers State in the South East of Nigeria are about 500,000 in number. One of their grievances is that despite the fact that the bulk of oil derived from their environment has become Nigeria's main source of revenue, they have been neglected and marginalized. Such economic, political and social deprivations enraged the Ogoni people hence the formation of the Movement for the Survival of Ogoni People (MOSOP) and their uprising in the early 1990s. In its conflict with both the Nigerian government and international oil corporations, MOSOP adopted the following tactics: dialogue, writing of petition letters, direct contacts with the Nigerian government and oil companies, public criticism of government policies and/or actions, massive street protests, civil disobedience, organized seminars, political rallies, meetings, press conferences and campaigns, circulation of posters with the inscription ‘Ogoni Freedom Campaign’, Ogoni songs, television comedies, poems about the Ogoni situation, hunger strike, naming of streets after the executed Ogoni nine and candle light procession. The effectiveness of these ‘repertoire of actions’ in MOSOP's demand for political autonomy and control/fair use of Ogoni economic resources for Ogoni development, constituted the central focus of this study. The concept of political process theory i.e. the dimensions of the political environment that provide incentive(s) for people to mobilize/undertake collective action, was used as the analytical tool. Among others, the political opportunity structure helped in understanding the division among and within the existing and emerging Nigerian elite as well as the crucial roles played by the influential allies in Ogoni crises.

Title: The origins of the Chinese Communist Party and the role played by Soviet Russia and the Comintern (BL)
Abstract: In making a comprehensive survey of the international background of the foundation of the CCP, the author proposes that the establishment of the CCP was a part of the Bolsheviks' global strategy of world revolution, of the Comintern's efforts to expand Communist forces into the East; it also served Soviet Russia's interest in the Far East. The study reveals the important role that Soviet Russia and the Comintern played in the establishment of the CCP. During the period 1918-1921, Soviet Russia and the Comintern dispatched numerous emissaries to China and recruited many agents there. These people made wide-ranging contacts with Chinese in different organisations and factions regardless of their political beliefs, party affiliation or social strata. They conducted intensive agitation and propaganda by various media and means, including supplying news and publicity to the press free of charge and publishing Communist booklets and journals in Chinese. They had a hand in directing important student and worker organisations which emerged during the May Fourth Movement, and later urged people who had a little knowledge of Marxism and who belonged to anarchist organisations and the Guomindang to organise socialist and communist organisations and parties. The CCP's important founders, Li Dazhao and Chen Duxiu's conversion to Bolshevism and their creation of the CCP only happened after the Bolshevik agents' persuasion and instruction. Therefore, the thesis concludes that the establishment of CCP was not, as official ideologists claim, the outcome of the combination of the dissemination of Marxism-Leninism and the labour movement in China, but actually the result of political direction and financial support by the Bolsheviks. In consequence, the CCP was built along Leninist lines from the very beginning. This research further analyses the internal causes allowing Bolshevism to be transplanted into China and points out that the ideology which the CCP embraced during its founding period still has far-reaching influence upon politics in China today.

Title: Comparing the Basque diaspora: Ethnonationalism, transnationalism and identity maintenance in Argentina, Australia, Belgium, Peru, the United States of America, and Uruguay
Abstract: Through a comparison of Basque diaspora populations in six countries, this thesis describes and analyzes ethnicity maintenance, transnational consciousness, and ethnonational tendencies of self-defining Basques. I argue that despite geographical and generational differences, the core elements of Basque identity are defined in a constant manner, and ethnic institutions have developed according to similar patterns. I categorize these populations as 'diaspora' utilizing Cohen's definition, and give examples of their (1) traumatic dispersal from an original homeland; (2) expansion from the homeland in pursuit of colonial ambitions, trade, or work; (3) shared myth and collective memory of their homeland; (4) idealization of their homeland; (5) return movement; (6) sustained strong ethnic group consciousness; (7) sense of solidarity with co-ethnic members in other countries; and (8) distinctive and enriched lives in tolerant host countries. I suggest chain migration and consistent interaction with the homeland have strengthened transnational ties and diasporic consciousness. Contemporary relations between Basque diaspora communities and the Basque Government have fomented and reinvigorated ethnicity maintenance for many from the thirty-eight Basque associations represented. Tajfel's 'positive social identity' theory aids in partially explaining ethnic identity preservation in Uruguay, Argentina and some areas of the United States, though respondents in Australia, Peru, and Belgium tend to employ primordialist vocabulary to interpret their persistent ethnonationalism. While homeland definitions of "Basqueness" have progressed to a more civic and inclusive nationalism, diaspora definitions tend to follow the traditional conservativism of Sabino Arana and ancestry, language, and religion. A multimethod approach creates original quantitative and qualitative data from 832 written anonymous questionnaires and 348 personal interviews. SPSS empirical data analysis facilitated cross-tabulations and comparisons.

Title: Transnational lives, plurinational subjects: identity, migration and difference among Moroccan women in Italy (BL)
Abstract: This dissertation analyses migration in a context of changing configurations, in both the social sciences and people's lives, of notions of locality, identity, difference and membership. The thesis focuses on Moroccan migrant women's lived experiences of transnationalism between Morocco and Italy. In particular, it explores the ways in which Moroccan women's transnational social, economic and symbolic activities affect identity narratives and cultural renegotiation processes. Scholars of transnationalism are debating the interpretation of this phenomenon. Some conceive of transnationalism as a domain of resistance to economic marginalisation and to nation-states' power, others maintain that migrants' transnationalism is, by and large, reflection and outcome of processes of global economic restructuring on sending and receiving societies. This dissertation argues that, as migration, transnationalism is not a homogeneous process that could be universally defined. The articulation of gender relationships with contextual structural local and national factors and individuals' agencies produce differentiated narratives and strategies of transnationalism. The focus on migrant women highlights a specific type of embeddedness within nation-states' hegemony and a different experience of transnationalism from that of their male counterparts. Women's movements and activities are conditioned by a set of normative and cultural regulations based upon hegemonic interpretations of gender roles which both in Morocco and Italy condition their activities, their identities and their likelihood of either moving across countries or staying put. At the same time, however, as well as embodying dominant constructions and structures, women develop a dialectical relationship with them, producing in some cases counterhegemonic discourses or challenging expected behaviour. Whereas most accounts of transnationalism emphasise the economic and political relations of migrants with their countries of origin, this work investigates the cultural and symbolic significance of women's practices within and between Italy and Morocco. In particular, it explores how notions of "modernity", "tradition" and "authenticity" are articulated with migrant women's construction of cultural and religious identities in a context of movement and increasing interconnections. The third section of the thesis provides a picture of the ways in which migrant women are represented and constructed within the national contexts (especially Italy). The politics of "integration", notably in the form of respect for cultural difference, rights to citizenship and to resource redistribution, constitutes the structural framework that shapes the nature and quality of transnational practices.

Title: The implantation of the Plymouth Brethren in Spain, 1869-1936.
Abstract: The history of modern Protestantism in Spain began in earnest in the seven years following the 1868 'Glorious Revolution'. As political and religious changes unfolded, Protestant missionaries from Europe and the United States descended upon Spain and worked without any significant hindrance until 1875, the year that the Bourbons regained the throne under Alfonso XII. Missionaries came from Baptist, Methodist, Anglican and Reformed Churches. However, the denomination that consistently sent the greatest number of missionaries was the British Plymouth Brethren; Protestantism in Spain has been more influenced by them than by any other confession. From their beginning in the 1820s, the Brethren were shaped theologically by the Dispensationalism of John Nelson Darby (1800-1882) and guided missiologically by Anthony Norris Groves (1795-1853), the first Brethren missionary who served in Asia. Subsequent Brethren leaders such as George Müller (1805-1898) and Robert Chapman (1803-1902) kept the Brethren's focus on missions, and particularly, on Spain. Their influence, as well as cultural and religious debates taking place in the international arena, solidified Spain as a primary field that consistently received more Brethren funds and volunteers than any other country where their missionaries laboured. Centres of operation were established in Madrid, Barcelona, and in Galicia. In spite of their relatively large investment, few conversions of Spaniards were recorded from 1869 to 1936, the year when the Spanish Civil War began and, most Protestant missionaries were forced to flee Spain. Their inability to adapt their message to Spain was hindered by paternalistic approaches to missions and continued resistance to the contextualisation of their theology. With the Bourbons and nationalistic Roman Catholicism re-established in 1875, the Brethren were practically excluded from significant involvement in any public process. However, their missionaries continued to arrive in record numbers and laboured principally through grammar schools, printing presses and literature distribution. Some small-scale social relief was attempted until the outbreak of the Spanish Civil War. Enough converts had embraced Brethrenism so that the movement survived the civil war and subsequent harsh treatment prior to Vatican II.

Title: Nursing and health promotion: an exploration of pre-registration nursing students' perceptions of the concept
Abstract: Considerable conceptual confusion exists regarding the meaning of health promotion, yet nurses are called to be leaders in the movement. Pre-registration nursing curricula have been designed purporting to incorporate health promotion principles. In the United Kingdom this change in nursing education has been called Project 2000. Empirical evidence in the United Kingdom suggests that nurses perceive health promotion from an individualistic biomedical perspective. Chapters 1- 4 explore the philosophical and social origins of the concept. It is argued that this is evolutionary, rooted in health education, derived from ancient Greek philosophy. The development of health promotion theory and application to nursing is examined through the development of nursing theory in the United States. Critical comparisons are made by review of national and international literature relating to the focus of health promotion in nursing. Chapters 5-11 contain the main body of the thesis. Three longitudinal case studies investigate Project 2000 nursing student's perceptions of the concept. Three intentions aim to determine the students' health beliefs and values of health promotion on entry to nursing, to establish if any changes in their perceptions of health promotion could be attributed to the philosophical shift from intervention to prevention in nurse education and healthcare generally, and finally to develop an instrument to be used to measure changes in perception as part of curriculum evaluation. The results of the study are reported and contextualised by the influence of teachers, the curriculum and the climate of change in healthcare at that time. The properties of the instrument and the implications for its purpose are addressed. Weaknesses in the design of the strategy are examined. The thesis concludes with a review of the evidence presented. More recent conceptual development is examined. Final conclusions lead to recommendations for further refinement of the instrument, by development of psychometric properties.

Title: “Red Waters”: Contesting marine space as Indian place in the United States Pacific Northwest
Abstract: This study investigates the social construction of race, marine space, and resource conflict in one U.S. Native American community: the Makah Reservation, Neah Bay, Washington. A combination of archival records, news media coverage, and semistructured interviews is employed in order to expose the historic roots of the Makah Tribe’s recent movement to reclaim control over traditional marine spaces. In particular, this research focuses on the gray whale controversy period between 1995–2000, when, to the consternation of conservation non-governmental organizations (NGOs), Makahs organized to resume a limited, cultural based harvest of the California gray whale in Pacific waters. This paper suggests that extant conflicts which developed between the Makah people, on one hand, and anti-whaling NGOs on another, were as much a struggle over marine space as they were a struggle over gray whale resources. Three central conclusions are drawn from the study. First, it is shown that Pacific marine “space” serves as a distinct, historical territory upon which many of the Makahs’ political, cultural, and economic processes take form. Second, this research argues that NGO efforts to arrest the Makahs’ contemporary whale harvest in offshore Pacific waters have been interpreted by tribal members as a neocolonialist invasion into what was once customarily managed marine space. Third, these results show how, despite the dominance of anti-whaling NGOs, Makahs have effectively mobilized global media technologies in order to empower themselves politically, transcend the territorial boundaries of the reservation, and reclaim control over the marine environment.

Title: Transforming Los Angeles: Black and Japanese American struggles for racial equality in the 20th century
Abstract: Over the course of the 20th century, exponential economic and population growth transformed Los Angeles into a global city with a multi-ethnic population. Racial and ethnic diversity were the product of the capitalist economy's increased reliance on non-white labor and the efforts of communities of color to carve out a space for themselves in the city. Race and class interacted in the construction of a structure of inequality that was produced and reproduced not simply by hierarchichal relations of production but through residential segregation and through a contestation over urban space. Prior to World War II, the Japanese American and African American communities remained predominantly under the leadership of ethnic elites, who subscribed to the philosophy racial uplift. In response to the segregation produced during the suburbanization of the city, middle-class ethnic leaders promoted the idea of housing “improvement” to distinguish themselves from their less fortunate brethren and improve relations with whites. However, white resistance to integration, limited the effectiveness of the “improvement” strategy. Struggles for racial progress through employment generated broader participation. The general rejection of minorities by organized labor pushed Japanese American workers to greater dependence on the ethnic economy, while African Americans were moved to mass political action for public sector and defenese-industry employment. It was only with the dramatic emergence of social movement unionism in the CIO during World War II that the fight for racial equality became integral to organized labor. However, the unity that made the wartime advances possible dissipated under the pressure of Cold War politics. While the social conditions of black and Japanese Americans diverged considerably in the postwar era, community leaders united behind an integrationist agenda. Integrationists achieved success in breaking down discriminatory legal barriers but ultimately failed to dismantle the structural bases of inequality. The pent-up frustration caused by concentrated poverty and segregation exploded in the Watts Rebellion. Japanese Americans came to be identified as a “model minority,” whose acceptance into the middle-class validated mainstream society's claim to being “colorblind” while signifying that the hardship of blacks was self-produced.

Title: “The people like melée”: The Parang Festival of Carriacou, Grenada
Abstract: The Parang Festival is produced annually on the small Caribbean island of Carriacou (Grenada). Spanning the weekend prior to Christmas, the Festival is organized by a local community group—the Mount Royal Progressive Youth Movement—which uses revenues generated by the event to assist Carriacouans in need via charitable giving. While the overall intent of the Parang Festival is to preserve traditional Carriacouan music, song, and dance, the event is itself a study of the changing meaning and significance of these forms as they are recontextualized from community-based folk genres to staged competition performances. Born in an era of political upheaval, the Parang Festival was ideologically linked to the 1979 Grenadian Socialist Revolution and served, in part, as a means of cultural decolonization for Carriacou's population. This dissertation examines the cultural transformation of the population of Carriacou through an analysis of the Parang Festival using four vantage points: (1) the historical (primarily the 1950s through the years surrounding the Socialist Revolution); (2) via ethnographies of the festival's component parts, including string band music, Hosannah bands ( a cappella carol singing), and non-competitive performances of quadrille dance and music; (3) through an examination of the Parang Festival as a vehicle for this small society to articulate social mores and values as well as negotiate issues pertaining to cultural autonomy and regional belonging; and (4) via an analysis of what I term “cultural ambivalence” by Carriacouans towards the contemporary practice of certain creolized genres, particularly quadrille music and dance. This dissertation shows how the performance practice and meaning of the island's traditional expressive culture was affected by the politics of the late 1970s and how it continues to change in response to Carriacou's emergence into the global process of modernization. I analyze how this process is tempered by the economic neglect wrought by Carriacou's years of “double dependency” status, that is, as a dependency of a former colony (Grenada). I show how this historically fragile economy has resulted in the development of a culture of community self-help (as exemplified by the Parang Festival), one based on reciprocity, volunteerism, and cycles of giving.

Title: “To be Quechua is to belong”: Citizenship, identity, and intercultural bilingual education in Cuzco, Peru
Abstract: This dissertation explores the conflict surrounding discussions about indigenous rights, ethnicity, and citizenship in the Southern Peruvian highlands as a way to explore recent changes in the way these concepts are understood and lived in Peru. After almost twenty years of political violence in Peru, a group of activists and intellectuals emerged in the 1990s and—like indigenous leaders throughout Latin America—demanded government recognition of Peruvian indigenous peoples and of Peru as a multicultural, multiethnic nation. In neighboring Andean countries indigenous movements have acquired increasing political prominence, while in Peru, there is still no national indigenous organization in the highlands. Peruvian activists, through the development and implementation of intercultural bilingual education programs in the highlands, are attempting to promote indigenous Quechua identity among highland peoples in an effort to establish a national highland indigenous organization in the country. Drawing on more than a year of ethnographic fieldwork in Cuzco, Peru, this study examines the clash between Peruvian activists and their initiatives at education reform, and the indigenous Quechua peoples for whom they claim to work and represent, who are strongly opposed to the implementation of bilingual education in their children's schools. This project also looks at the relationship between the state, through its involvement in education and language policy changes, and international agents—such as UNESCO and UNICEF—closely linked to the elaboration of alternative education programs aimed at social development among indigenous sectors of the population. Theoretically, this dissertation concentrates on the way ethnicity—particularly indigenous ethnicity—is currently being rethought by activists, state agents, and Quechuas themselves. Moreover, it highlights the mobilization of changing ethnic and cultural identity labels in the region. Ultimately, this work shows that the mobilization of ethnicity in Peru is a first step toward the achievement of indigenous autonomy and the recognition of indigenous Peruvians as full citizens.

Title: Controlling births, policing sexualities: A history of birth control in colonial India, 1877–1946
Abstract: My dissertation examines the history of birth control in colonial India, locating this history at the nexus of a complex web of local, nationalist, and international initiatives. In tracing the intellectual, political and social genealogy of birth control in colonial India, my work allows for a more complex understanding of this issue, providing historical context to the existing scholarship and debates on birth control in India as well as in other parts of the world. Moreover, by analyzing the oppressive and ill-liberal historical trajectory of birth control in colonial India, this study has forced me to rethink and re-evaluate my own underlying liberal feminist assumptions, linking birth control unproblematically with expressions of individualism, progress and development. From the late nineteenth century onwards numerous intellectual traditions influenced the discussions on India's population and its health. The debates on population size and health of the people generated a demand for wider dissemination of contraceptive information. Important intellectual currents that framed the discourse on birth control in colonial India were Malthusianism, eugenics, demography, western bio-medical discourse and sexology. In mapping the trajectory of the birth control movement in India, this work interrogates the influence of these intellectual traditions on the work of Indian advocates. The historical specificities of colonialism, bourgeois nationalism and middle class feminist politics are important political impulses within which these debates are located. Although many advocates of birth control aimed to liberate women from their biological destiny, theoretically, a closer examination of the history of birth control in colonial India demonstrates that the concern with liberating women and ensuring better reproductive health facilities to Indian women were not guiding principles in these early debates on birth control. Politics of gender, class, caste, race, community and nation shaped the discourse of birth control in colonial India. This study investigates how these multiple variables intersected to produce a hegemonic and oppressive politics of birth control.

Title: Between sacrifice and desire: Gender, media and national identity in Vietnam
Abstract: The post Cold-War era has given rise to new forms of nationalism. In Europe, the demise of the Soviet Union has provoked the fissure of nation-states into warring national groups divided by ethnic, religious, linguistic or other identities. In socialist Asia, in contrast, the politically-entrenched Party-states have redirected and recast the discourses of nationalism from the priorities of anti-imperialist class struggle to the often-conflicting goals of global economic inclusion and national cultural strengthening. These projects of modern national re-‘imagining’ carry distinct gender and class consequences, as certain human qualities and social groups are singled out as more authentically ‘national’ and globally ‘fit’ than others. This dissertation examines the gender politics of market transition and national cultural construction in 1990s Vietnam. Throughout Vietnam's embattled modern history, the Vietnamese woman has provided the coding for the complex and contradictory terms of national ‘tradition’ and ‘progress’. In the movement from a war-oriented, socialist command economy to a nascent market system, the focus of state pedagogy has shifted from the inculcation of “progressive” norms of heroic sacrifice and collective production to the cultivation of economically self-sufficient and law-abiding middle class families. These new governmental priorities have entailed a re-traditionalization of the terms of national femininity, as women's domestic roles, talents and traditions have become the key ingredients in the promotion of “happy”, “civilized” and morally sound households. The popular media contributes to the domestic disciplining of women through the marketing of “real life” family stories that problematize women's income earning ambitions and police the normative boundaries of female agency and desire. This study draws on formal and informal interview data to explore the constraints of national discourses of femininity on the identity practices of Vietnamese women in two distinct class settings of urban Hanoi. The re-domestication of national feminine norms has carried the heaviest moral consequences for a generation of women caught between the socialist education of their youth and the economic pressures of the new market era. Women's discursive practices of complaint, contestation and parody are analyzed as complex enactments of their confinement in a field of irreconcilable gender demands.

Title: Five smooth stones: Strategic capacity in the unionization of California agriculture
Abstract: The story of David and Goliath poses a question about which many remain intensely curious: under what conditions can the resourcefulness of an underdog overcome the institutionalized resources of the powerful? One instance that offers insight into that question is the United Farm Workers' victory over the California growers in the labor struggles of the 1960s and 1970s. Despite recurrent opportunities since 1900, repeated attempts to unionize California agriculture had failed. Early in the 1960s, three organizations made another attempt: the AFL-CIO's Agricultural Workers Organizing Committee, the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, and the independent United Farm Workers. In the spring of 1966, however, it was neither the powerful Teamsters nor the AFL-CIO that won the first breakthrough, but the upstart United Farm Workers led by Cesar Chavez. Most explanations of such events argue that the “time for change was right” or attribute success to the intervention of gifted charismatic individuals. Jenkins and Perrow's 1977 social movement classic, Insurgency of the Powerless , attributes the UFW's success to a favorable political opportunity structure, but does not explain why the UFW succeeded while its rivals failed, especially when they had access to far greater resources. The fact the UFW strategy worked does not explain why it alone devised such a strategy. And citing the “charismatic leadership” of Cesar Chavez does not explain how this leadership worked. To explain this outcome—the UFW's success and the failure of its rivals—I compared organizational strategy. To explain differences in strategy I compared leadership teams that devised it, the structure of their organizations, and their pattern of interaction with the environment. Biographical data on leaders reveals systematic differences in their life experience, sociocultural networks, and repertoires of collective action. Organizational analysis reveals systematic differences in deliberative processes, accountability mechanisms, and resource flows. Building on creativity theory, I argue that the likelihood a leadership team will devise effective strategy—its strategic capacity—depends on its motivation, access to salient knowledge, and heuristic processes. The strategic capacity of a leadership team will be greater if it includes insiders and outsiders to salient constituencies, those with strong and weak ties to these constituencies, and those who have learned diverse repertoires of collective action. Leaders will make the most of these attributes if they conduct regular, open, and authoritative deliberations, are accountable to multiple, salient constituencies, and draw their resources from them. In sum, I explain the UFW's success over its rivals by differences in strategy, account for differences in strategy by how it was developed, and explain how it was developed in the interactions of leaders, organizations, and environment. Understanding strategic capacity can help explain how resourcefulness can compensate for lack of resources—or why David can sometimes win.

Title: Towards a theater of the common people: New interactions between classical, folk and modern theater in Koothu -p -Pattarai, Rang Vidushak and Ankanam
Abstract: K-p-p, Rang Vidushak and Ankanam are key players in a project called the Theatre Laboratory Scheme (TLS), initially supported by the Ford Foundation and later by the Indian Foundation for the Arts (IFA), formed of ten regionally diverse theater companies breaking fresh ground in Indian experimental theater, especially through intra-Indian networking. Fifty-three years after gaining her independence from the British, India faces an alarming array of power struggles between different identities and interests—political, ethnic, religious and economic. A complex interplay of factors have contributed to India's contemporary identity crisis—her history, pluralism, paradoxical straining subcultures and movements, modernity, the opening of India as a global market and rising consumerism. Modern Indian theater's artistic crisis, which mirrors her post-colonial crisis as a nation, has undergone many changes in its endeavor to forge a genuinely contemporary Indian theater that reflects India's complex identities, cultures and myriad artistic expressions. Artists in free India rejected the colonial model of theater they had blindly imitated and rediscovered their own rich indigenous artistic traditions. Modern theater practitioners experimented with classical, folk and modern theater forms—these experiments have developed into an array of trends from the “theater of roots” to the theater of the common people , envisioned by K-p-p, Rang Vidushak and Ankanam. A significant contribution of K-p-p, Rang Vidushak and Ankanam is that they have nourished in-depth interactions between traditional and modern theater forms and arts by grasping the principles, lifestyles and cultural context behind each form rather than thoughtless imitation and incorporation of exotic images and techniques. Furthermore, they have successfully harnessed traditional expression with contemporary concerns, facilitated mutually beneficial exchanges between traditional and modern performers, developed region-specific actor training methodologies, created original scripts and styles of performance and elevated the role of the artistic process over the product. Apart from artistic contributions, the TLS and its representative companies have tremendous social and political significance, from modeling an artistic community that synthesizes India's pluralistic identity to addressing critical current issues. At the heart of the problems that plague contemporary India lies the plight of the common people, and in the theater of the TLS companies these problems are examined from the perspective of the common man. In spite of major artistic and social contributions, there remain a few contradictions in the theater of K-p-p, Rang Vidushak and Ankanam, particularly the subordinate status of the actor and the lack of actresses in these, and other TLS companies, and weaknesses in developing actor training methodologies. The central challenge for an inclusive contemporary Indian theater would be to synthesize the maddening diversity of Indian culture with its modern and traditional components; to address the second class position of the actor and the lack of actresses; to question any vestiges of orientalisin that may seep into the directors' attempts to create a genuinely contemporary theater and to transform the hierarchy, management and income-generation of the TLS companies. However, despite contradictions and future challenges, the artistic process of these and other TLS companies has brought the vision of a contemporary Indian theater of the common people closer to its fall realization.

Title: “And the stones shall cry out”¹: Native American identity and self -determination in the United Methodist Church
Abstract: The missionizing of Indians in North America was largely an attempt to assimilate Indians during the first two hundred years in America. Christian evangelism among the Indians was a two-pronged process. To Christianize the Indians meant to Europeanize them as well. For the Indians, social and cultural accommodation meant accepting political, religious and cultural change. Pedagogical applications to teaching and proselytizing the Indians were insensitive and demoralizing. Yet in the nineteenth century, Indians who accepted Methodism re-defined the evangelical mission of the Methodist Church. This study will examine how Native American society and culture reacted to the Methodist institution that they encountered. Indians within the Methodist Church made choices that helped maintain their tribal heritage and culture and incorporated them into Christian worship. At times this created a paradox for Indian Methodists. As they became empowered they also became more acculturated. Yet elements of acculturation were temporary as the long term goal for many Indian Methodists was the regeneration of traditional beliefs into Christian worship and Indian life. It has been a reciprocal process where the sanctity of Native American elements of worship have become a way of life for Native American Christians whose values and ancient beliefs were seldom compromised in their understanding of Christianity. The paper will look closely at Native Americans and spirituality where a one-way process occurred that viewed Indians as victims and missions as failures. Using oral testimonies and written documents, this paper will explore how Indians addressed these issues from the early years of missionizing by the Methodists and demonstrate that a significant shift in the mission relationship between Indians and Methodists occurred as early as the mid-nineteenth century. While Methodist missionaries continued to attempt forced assimilation upon Indian converts, many Native Americans resisted and incorporated indigenous practices and lifestyles which accelerated in the late 1960s through the present. Historians have argued that Native Americans have been assimilated in their encounters with non-Indian peoples. Assimilation can be described as communities experiencing an overall decline of their societies leading to the abandonment of their culture. Although Indian communities did experience periods of decline, I will argue that assimilation did not take place as Native American communities within the church developed over the period discussed in the paper. The Indian community as well as the Methodist Church made accommodations, which were reciprocal in nature with each side benefiting from the relationship. This study will rely greatly on oral history. Oral history is central to the Native American experience and one can not grasp the full meaning of the Native American story if oral history is down played or excluded altogether. Oral history preserves the integrity of the Native American point of view. The history of acculturated Indians and Indians in the twentieth century has not received the attention that it deserves which is why much of this study will look at Indians who had adopted Methodism as a religious practice. The general context of the paper will show how Indians constructed opportunities within the context of Methodism, which allowed them to form barriers against total assimilation, and create opportunities in their changing world. Interviews with members of the Oklahoma Indian Missionary Conference will serve to document the historical movements within the Methodist and United Methodist Church. 1 Luke 19:40, Habakkuk 2:11, The Holy Bible New International Version (Grand Rapids, MI: Zondervan Bible Publishers, 1978).

Title: Technologies of Islamic piety: Cassette-sermons and the ethics of listening
Abstract: This dissertation addresses a range of questions about language and the body through an ethnographic study of cassette-sermons in Egypt. Three dimensions of cassette-sermon practice were central to my project. First, I examined cassette-sermon listening as an ethical exercise aimed at cultivating a modern form of Islamic piety, one rooted in a long tradition of moral self-cultivation. My analysis focuses on contemporary sermon rhetorics and the demands of proper audition which these place on listeners, among them, a familiarity with a variety of classical and modern knowledges, certain forms of concentration and responsiveness, as well as competence in a particular affective-gestural repertoire—the embodied dispositions which undergird well-informed reasoning within contemporary traditions of Islam. Secondly, I locate the new practices of cassette-sermon audition in relation to the historical trajectory of the broader Islamic movement in Egypt since the 19 th century. As a technology of individual piety, these tapes join the individual's task of cultivating Islamic virtues with broader social concerns of the Islamic awakening, including issues of societal transformation, state legal reform, and national and international politics. Thus, my dissertation explores how tapes provide a medium for public discussion of a wide variety of issues relevant to contemporary Egyptian society, a discussion, however, conducted on the basis of the ethical capacities, orientations, and goals toward which the act of sermon audition is geared. Lastly, I argue that the cassette-sermon provides an opportunity to explore the impact of mass media and modern print-oriented literacies on the forms of contemporary piety, and the conditions of religious practice within Egypt more generally. Of particular concern to me here is the question of how the virtues listeners sought to cultivate were mediated, on the one hand, by functional possibilities of cassette technology, such as mobility, replay, and discontinuous listening; and on the other, by the discursive conventions of the modern print and televisual-based public sphere. To this end, my work explores the complicated interplay between the cassette medium and the institutional, cultural, and religious contexts within which it is employed.

Title: A hegemonic analysis of John Howard Lawson and the New Playwrights Theatre
Abstract: The concept of hegemony was first developed by Antonio Gramsci and recorded in his Prison Notebooks while imprisoned under Mussolini's fascist Italian government from 1926 until his death in 1937. Gramsci's ideas concerning hegemony involve positioning the relationship between political society (what Gramsci calls the “State”) and civil, or “private,” society as a hegemonic relationship in which predominance depends upon the ratio between control and the willingness to be controlled. Using hegemony as an analytical strategy, the early theatrical career of John Howard Lawson as a playwright and founding member of the New Playwrights Theatre can be viewed through multiple hegemonic relationships, both personal and professional. In addition to identifying the actual, real-life hegemonic relationships between Lawson and his peers, the fictitious hegemonic relationships developed in the plots of his early plays Roger Bloomer, Processional and Nirvana , as well as the plays of Lawson and his colleagues produced by the New Playwrights Theatre from 1927 through 1929, will be examined. Chapter I of this dissertation places Antonio Gramsci's concept of hegemony into three categories: (1) Hegemony explains social order. It is not just a revolutionary strategy. (2) In Capitalist societies, hegemony encapsulates a “war of position,” not a “war of movement.” (3) Hegemony describes a sequence of subaltern coalitions that can either support or be directed against official (State) socio-cultural hegemony. In Chapter II, hegemonic relationships affecting Lawson's education, military service and experiences in Europe and his early years as a playwright will be examined. In Chapter III, his association with the New Playwrights Theatre will be viewed within similar parameters of hegemonic analysis. The plays of Lawson and the New Playwrights Theatre will then be examined under three hegemonic/counterhegemonic groupings: (1) Religious and Racial Tolerance/Prejudice: Lawson's Nirvana , Em Jo Basshe's Earth and The Centuries , and Michael Gold's Hoboken Blues . (2) Industrialized Management Control/Organized Labor Rebellion: Lawson's Processional , Paul Sifton's The Belt , Upton Sinclair's Singing Jailbirds and John Dos Passos' Airways, Inc. (3) Conservative Socio-Politics/Politico-Social Revolt: Lawson's Roger Bloomer, Loud Speaker and The International .

Title: A study of new directions in Taiwan's education *policy
Abstract: Educational reform is an issue of global importance. Taiwan, like many other countries, has designed educational reform initiatives to support increased educational quality. In 1994, Taiwan developed an approach to deregulate its educational system. Specific reforms in elementary education included setting up a Teachers' Assessment and Evaluation Council (TAEC) in every school, reducing the size of classes and schools, changing the system for the approval of textbooks, and increasing teacher autonomy. Attention was also given to reforming the traditional examination processes. However, educational policies emerge from ideologies of the people who design and promulgate them. The political movements, economic conditions, and social values of the day shape these ideologies. Since 1994, policy implementation has been underway. The purposes of this study were to: (1) describe the national educational policies in Taiwan; and (2) examine the emerging educational programs, issues, and concerns connected to policy implementation. Taiwan's experiences with educational reform were compared to those of Japan, the United Kingdom, and France to help generate a sense of the meaning and relevance of Taiwan's initiatives. Qualitative research strategies, including interviews and document analyses, were used to generate and analyze data. Participants included policy makers, researchers, and educators who had knowledge of the national agendas, familiarity with local and regional issues, and experience with school-based implementation of the educational improvement policies. Based on the data generated through this study, the educational reform agenda was clarified. Taiwan's education policy initiatives include a complex and comprehensive array of activities to reform governance, funding, curriculum, and the examination system. Important issues in policy implementation that are emerging include: (1) the variety of professional dilemmas that accompany school-based control; (2) the demands of instructional and curricular improvement; (3) the need of identify more efficient and equitable funding policies; and (4) the identification of strategies to deal with problems that arise in implementation. Comparison with the experiences of policy makers and educators in Japan, the United Kingdom, and France revealed that, although there are similarities in approaches, strategies for enacting deregulation and increasing local control differ, especially as they related to cultural traditions.

Title: Out of the jungle: Jimmy Hoffa and the remaking of the American working class
Abstract: By examining the career of International Brotherhood of Teamsters leader James R. Hoffa within the changing context of twentieth-century American industrial relations, this dissertation challenges many of the tenets of the so-called “new labor history,” which has largely ignored the Teamsters and other affiliates of the American Federation of Labor in favor of the much smaller Congress of Industrial Organizations. This study reveals Hoffa's mid-century Detroit as a violent underworld in which trucking firms and other small businesses were terrorized into submission to the Teamsters, police and politicians were bought with near impunity, saloons were the locus of social activity, criminals disemployed by the repeal of prohibition provided a wealth of useful services, and unions battled against each other with as much frequency and fury as they did against employers. Yet while relying on the techniques of the new labor history to unearth this culture, this study contradicts the scholarship of the past generation in many important ways. While historians since the 1960s have looked within the labor movement for a purpose other than “delivering the goods,” Hoffa's Teamsters adhered to a strictly economic mission and scorned the attempts by radicals and “labor statesmen” to bring workers into the managerial classes. Similarly, this study presents new labor historians with the troubling fact that much of the rapid growth and prodigious material accomplishments of the Teamsters was caused not by the “industrial democracy” they endorse but by competition both within the IBT and from rival unions. Beginning with the rise of the wartime state in 1941, Hoffa's world of unloosed conflict was continually confronted by government officials and labor leaders seeking to civilize the class struggle. The CIO's campaign to unify labor and share power in a managed economic system merged with efforts by government agencies to normalize industrial relations and to remake militant workers into responsible citizens. However, this study shows that while these intrusions into Hoffa's jungle often benefited Hoffa personally, they produced dubious results for the working class itself.

Title: The Women's Ordination Conference (1975–1994): An introduction to a movement
Abstract: The Women's Ordination Conference (WOC) offers perhaps the most significant example of American Catholic popular theological discussion of the ordination of women in the Catholic Church. This dissertation studies the women's ordination issue in the U.S. from 1975, the year of the First International Women's Ordination Conference, to 1994, the issuance of Ordinatio Sacerdotalis . In particular, the dissertation investigates how WOC and the hierarchy treat three key themes inherent in the debate: Theological anthropology (the nature of humanity as male and female); the roles and status of men and women in church and society; and the general understanding and flourishing of church order and social order. The contribution of the dissertation is two-fold. First, it provides an introduction to central theological dimensions of the debate. After the introduction (Chapter 1), I examine the historical context of the hierarchical Catholic teachings on the ordination of women between 1975 and 1994. I demonstrate and evaluate some arguments in these documents giving specific attention to the following themes: (a) theological anthropology, (b) roles and status of men and women in church and society, (c) understanding of church order and social order (Chapter 2). Second, my cataloging and studying of Marquette University Memorial Library's WOC Archives, which had not been previously investigated, makes these materials more readily and widely accessible for other researchers. After providing a brief historical overview of the WOC conferences, its dialogue with U.S. Bishops, its national leaders, its prominent theological voices, its actions and its key themes (Chapter 3), I analyze the arguments used by WOC in light of the three aforementioned focal themes (Chapter 4). In the concluding chapter, I confirm that a positive interchange between the hierarchy and WOC regarding these three themes is instrumental to explicate this issue in contemporary American Catholicism. I also suggest directions for further research (Chapter 5). Detailed appendices identify WOC archives, articles, leaders and awardees. An extensive timeline lists significant dates in the women's ordination movement. An index to the appendices will benefit the reader.

Title: Environmental regulation and implications for the United States hog and pork industries
Abstract: This study examines the effect of increasing environmental regulation on hog production in the U.S. domestic market and on the competitiveness of U.S. pork in the international market. Agricultural pollution from animal feeding operations (AFOs) is becoming a major environmental consideration in the high hog production regions of the United States as well as in the heavy production areas of Northern Europe. As environmental concerns increase and governmental regulations are imposed to protect the environmental quality in these areas, will there be changes in production signaling an increase in competitiveness for regions with more lax environmental regulatory standards? This is an important question for the U.S. hog and pork industries from both a domestic (interstate) and an international perspective. The first half of this study examines differences in U.S. state water quality regulations and their influence on the location of hog production in the United States. Modeling the profit maximization decision of hog producers allows investigation as to whether or not the current changes in the industry towards larger and more geographically concentrated operations has been influenced by differences in environmental regulation. This analysis is conducted separately on small and large operations in order to allow examination of the differences in the regulatory effect by size of operation. The results of this analysis provide evidence that environmental compliance costs are significant for small hog feeding operations, while hog production on large operations does not seem to be influenced by the level of environmental stringency. Implications for policy making include the fact that the observed movement of large hog operations out of traditional mid-western states is not primarily a consequence of differences in environmental regulation and therefore, current policy proposals calling for harmonized national AFO manure management standards may not be necessary. Also, policy makers concerned with the economic and social implications of decreasing small farm production will want to consider the detrimental effects of increasing environmental regulation on these small producers. The second half of the study examines the effects of increasing U.S. and European Union (EU) environmental regulation on the competitiveness of the U.S. pork exporting industry. An equilibrium displacement model is developed to estimate the magnitude of the effect on U.S. pork export quantities and also to calculate producer welfare changes. A review of information on the environmental regulation imposed on the major pork exporters is provided as background to the current policy environment in each of these countries. Results show that the expected increase in U.S. hog producers' compliance costs lead to only minor losses in competitiveness for the U.S. pork industry and in fact it is the hog producers, not the pork processors, who bear the majority of the economic loss. Changes in EU environmental regulation over the next few years are expected to be more restrictive than those imposed in the United States. Examining these changes in EU regulation shows that over a range of EU regulatory scenarios, U.S. pork becomes more competitive as EU pork prices increase significantly in the face of very stringent environmental regulation. Future trade policy implications of these results include the need of EU countries to negotiate harmonized environmental standards to equate environmental compliance costs across pork producing countries.

Title: Monstrous desires: Psychopathy and subjectivity in Cold War America
Abstract: My dissertation situates a preoccupation for Cold War culture, the figure of the sexual psychopath, within a conceptual history of the monstrous. The monstrous is a cultural space in which definitions of the natural, the normative, and the human are formulated and reinforced by means of aberrations and anomalies. Considered in this light, I argue, the literary, legal, and scientific representations of the psychopath produced in the U.S. during the Cold War constituted the simultaneous emergence and attempted containment of a new form of monstrosity. Legal and scientific accounts of the psychopath tried to theorize and disarm him, even as popular journalism and citizens' crusades emphasized the threat he posed. By examining psychopathy as an instance of monstrosity, my dissertation undertakes an historical and theoretical double-movement in order to revise our understanding of postwar culture. Placing the psychopath within a conceptual genealogy of monstrosity reveals the ways in which this, by definition , marginal figure created a repository both for the exclusions against which so-called normal sexual subjectivity was defined and for the social and political anxieties that informed American culture as the nation emerged as a global superpower. At the same time, the psychopath's particular, historical features—his departures from traditional models of monstrosity—disclose hitherto unrecognized conceptual transformations in our understanding of the monstrous and, consequently, of the human. Literary texts are a privileged, if provisional and by no means exclusive, locus of investigation in the dissertation. If the psychopath was, according to legal and scientific accounts, a reified disruption of natural processes, from the perspective of conceptual and literary history he was a set of stories, narratives generated in various scientific quarters about a new figure on the landscape. And so the fictional accounts of the psychopath translated—with all of the creative and critical modulation that the term implies—these stories from a variety of technical discourses aimed at specialized readerships into narratives for general consumption. In these narratives the parameters of licit desire and ordinary subjectivity were most visibly naturalized, negotiated or contested for the public imagination.

Title: Human rights and the state: Changing roles in a liberal economy
Abstract: The role of the federal state in Canada has always been one of change and adaptation. This is particularly true of the state's role as it pertains to human rights based issues; those aspects of Canadian life which are most influenced by political, social and economic factors. Canada, in a neo-liberal economy, is trying to achieve a balance of power which provides appropriate representation of and protection for its citizens. This paper follows both the state's efforts to regain power at regional, national and international levels and the expectations Canadians have of the federal government. The two concepts meet in a discussion of the potential benefits of a joint partnership between the federal government and the Third Sector. It is the premise of this thesis that such a partnership will, in fact, meet many of the expressed and implied needs for both the state and for Canadians. However, the preliminary nature of the partnership movement leaves many issues unaddressed.

Title: Islamic “fundamentalism” and the West: Issues in *change, peace and conflict resolution
Abstract: Is “Islamic fundamentalism” a political myth, or is it a “challenger civilization,” as Samuel Huntington, the author of “The Clash of Civilizations,” claims? Other Western scholars caution against the aims of the growing Islamic movement for change against neo-colonial institutions and the Western political domination of the Muslim world. The author attempts to examine the phenomenon of change and reformation in the post-colonial Muslim world that continues to live under the “no system” of anarchy and repression. Islam seems to emphasize change as an important precept of human life, but Muslim scholars have ignored its significance in social, economic and political policy. The West has achieved material change, but seems to have sacrificed the spiritual dimension of the human reality, says John Saul (“The Unconscious Civilization”), and this has caused a conflict between man and society, rather than peace and harmony. Muslims and the West both seem to aspire for change in different ways and for different reasons. The author introduces the readers to new insights into the much-neglected role and importance of the originality of Islamic “thinking” as the foundation for human change and relations; and explains that Islamic principles and values may be viewed as contributing factors to human solidarity from Adam to Mohammed, as its message is valid for the whole of mankind. Generally speaking. Islam attempts to foster a natural harmony and understanding among man, society, the state and humanity as a whole, all being part of the organic unity of things in the world. Yet, this factor has been all too absent from the secular intellectual perceptions and the foreign policymaking agendas of the West. The Western industrialized nations put forth varied notions of “civilization”, “self-conflicting freedoms” and overwhelmingly materialistic systems devoid of spirituality. The author notes that the West cannot be blamed for its political indifference and misinformation with regard to Islam, because the Muslim world seems to have lost the capacity to demonstrate a living model of Islam and its past contributions to the unity of mankind. However, the movement for change and societal reformation is deeply rooted in the Muslim world, and the author proposes an innovative framework for reformation, from strategic planning to the revitalization of political institutions, as the essential foundation for peace and security conceived of as a global phenomenon and part of the objective of One World. (Abstract shortened by UMI.)

Title: The limits and potential of civic nationalism: The case of the Scottish National Party
Abstract: Nationalism, justifiably, has been vilified for its chauvinistic, atavistic and exclusionary characteristics. Overlooked by many observers is the potential of national to serve as a foundation for collective action which may then be used for progressive political purposes. This thesis examines the potential of the civic-nationalist discourse of the Scottish National party to serve as a non-ethnic, non-exclusionary social movement for the enhancement of Scottish democracy and sovereignty. Issues of sovereignty, identity and sovereignty are examined through an analysis of the official discourse of the party. The three areas examined are critical features of a nationalist party's discourse. A thorough examination of each yields the evidence on which to draw conclusions about the limits and potential of civic nationalism for providing the foundation for local resistance to neo-liberal globalization. The discussion of sovereignty considers the impact of economic globalization and Scotland's membership in the European Union. The volatility of the global oil market and the mobility of financial capital constitute threats to the objectives of the Scottish National Party's social policy agenda. The European Union also threatens to intrude upon Scottish sovereignty by reducing the scope for independent policy-making by a Scottish government. Identity is examined in order to determine the commitment of the Scottish National party to a non-ethnic, non-exclusive conception of political community. The party has made a determined effort to transcend societal cleavages of gender, race, religion and sexual identity within the limitations of the party's broad commitment to liberal values of equality. Finally, the extent to which the Scottish National Party's civic nationalism can create the conditions for a robust and renewed Scottish democracy is analyzed. The party's commitment to a written constitution, as well as electoral reform contains the promise of remedying the democratic deficit with which Scotland has had to deal with in the United Kingdom.

Title: Suomen valkoinen sotilasarkkitehtuuri, 1926–1939
Abstract: This thesis examines the architects and architecture of the Finnish Defence Forces in the inter-war era. It analyses architecture within the frame of power discourse, i.e. as political architecture. My main point is that the Defence Forces used architecture together with cinema, press photos and literature as a medium of propaganda for the national defence effort. I focus my argument on barracks, military hospitals, airports and the Helsinki Military Academy and interpret architecture from the angle of contemporary social and military aspirations. The thesis also provides an overview of public architecture elsewhere in Europe, including the German, Swedish and Soviet military architecture of the same period. The Finnish Defence Forces were formed in the inter-war period. The air force was then a totally new branch of the armed services. The medical services of the Defence Forces were modernised and large, modern military hospitals were built in Viipuri and Helsinki. The main aim in planning new barracks was to create healthy and hygienic living conditions for all conscripts. For strategic reasons, most of the new garrisons were situated near the eastern border in South Karelia and on Lake Ladoga. All military buildings were planned at the Construction Bureau in the Technical Department of the Ministry of Defence between 1926 and 1939. The Construction Bureau was then one of the largest architectural studios in the country. It is notable, that a number of women architects worked and established their careers there. The international Modern Movement and its planning methods, which emphasised economy and hygiene were adopted by the Finnish Defence Forces in the 1930s. The National Defence used 1930s architecture to propagate the modernity and progressiveness of the young republic. “White military architecture” thus embodied the spirit of the Defence Forces, which was rooted in the values of the White Guard of the Finnish Civil War. This white functionalistic architecture contrasted sharply with the old red-brick barracks, which stood as a testimony of the time when Finland was a Grand Duchy of the Russian Empire.

Title: Negotiating South Africa's economic future: COSATU and strategic unionism
Abstract: This dissertation investigated South Africa's ‘second transition,’ the economic policy negotiations that accompanied the commencement of majority rule. It focused on the efforts of the largest trade union federation, the Congress of South African Trade Unions (COSATU), to shape the economic framework of post-apartheid South Africa. To do this, it analyzed how the federation made use of three national economic and labour policy negotiating forums, the National Economic Forum, the National Manpower Commission and their successor, the National Economic Development and Labour Council. These forums were comprised of representatives of business, labour and government. The dissertation drew upon a number of policy engagements between 1992 and 1997 to assess organized labour's interventions as measured against the goals for economic transformation that the trade union federation had approved. It found that COSATU did not substantially shape core labour and economic policies through its participation in the national policy-making structures. In the realm of macroeconomic policy, COSATU was starkly at odds with the government's approach and pushed for a fundamental revision of the program. In the area of industrial restructuring and trade liberalization, COSATU was marginal to the policy-making process. Only in the sphere of labour rights and standards could the trade union movement point to clear gains and even in this instance they were disappointed by some of the provisions contained in the new legislative framework. The dissertation identified several factors that contributed to COSATU's inability to play a more substantial role in shaping the post-apartheid economic dispensation. Two factors that shaped the context for the South African economic transition worked against the federation's agenda: the importance of South Africa's economic structure (dominated by a small number of very large mining conglomerates) and the nature of the international economic regulatory regime of the 1990s. Actors associated with these two important and interrelated social forces influenced African National Congress economic policies both before and after the first democratic elections while neutralizing many of COSATU's proposals. The dissertation suggested, however, that notable weaknesses in the trade union federation's own interventions further limited its influence. (Abstract shortened by UMI.)
