Title: Outback or at home? *Environment, social change and pastoralism in Central Australia
Abstract: This thesis examines the responses of non-indigenous pastoralists in Central Australian rangelands to two social movements that profoundly challenge their occupancy, use and management of land. Contemporary environmentalism and Aboriginal land rights have both challenged the status of pastoralists as valued primary producers and bearers of a worthy pioneer heritage. Instead, pastoralists have become associated with land degradation, biodiversity loss, and Aboriginal dispossession. Such pressure has intensified in the 1990s in the wake of the Native Title debate, and various conservation campaigns in the arid and semi-arid rangelands. The pressures on pastoralists occur in the context of wider reassessments of the social and economic values of rangelands in which pastoralism is seen as having declined in value compared to ‘post-production’ land uses. Reassessments of rangelands in turn are part of global changes in the status of rural areas, and of the growing flexibility in the very meaning of ‘rural’. Through ethnographic fieldwork among largely non-indigenous pastoralists in Central Australia, this thesis investigates the nature and foundations of pastoralists' responses to these changes and critiques. Through memory, history, labour and experience of land, non-indigenous pastoralists construct a narrative of land, themselves and others in which the presence of pastoralism in Central Australia is naturalised, and Central Australia is narrated as an inherently pastoral landscape. Particular types of environmental knowledge and experience, based in actual environmental events and processes form the foundation for a discourse of pastoral property rights. Pastoralists accommodate environmental concerns, through advocating environmental stewardship. They do this in such a way that Central Australia is maintained as a singularly pastoral landscape, and one in which a European, or ‘white’, frame of reference continues to dominate. In this way the domesticated pastoral landscapes of colonialism and nationalism are reproduced. The thesis also examines Aboriginal pastoralism as a distinctive form of pastoralism, which fulfills distinctly Aboriginal land use and cultural aspirations, and undermines the conventional meaning of ‘pastoralism’ itself. The thesis ends by suggesting that improved dialogue over rangelands futures depends on greater understanding of the details and complexities of local relationships between groups of people, and between people and land.

Title: Violence, profits and power: Globalization, the warfare-welfare state and the rise and demise of the New Deal world order
Abstract: This is an inquiry into the Anglo-American hegemonic transition and rise and demise of the New Deal world order. The thesis is that militarism proved critical in the rise of East Asia and Western Europe, while locking the US into a path dependent process of militarization. Militarism was instrumental in the rise and demise of the New Deal world order, the loss of the peace dividend and globalization. The empirical base of the work is an analysis of high finance, military industrialization and race-ethnic-class formation in the development of the National Security State Corporate Complex (NSSCC)—denoting the fusion of private corporate power and public state bureaucracy—and rise and demise of the New Deal world order. The origins of this NSSCC are traced to the formation of an embryonic military-industrial complex and Anglo-American Establishment during the corporate restructuring, militarized financial expansion, overseas imperialism, and war preparedness movements around the turn of the century. This war collectivism, became the model for US hegemony on the enlarged social foundations of the US warfare-welfare state. The thesis adjudicates the debate between state autonomy, class dominance and world-system theorists as to the primary logic of the modern world. While the contradictions between the pursuit of power and profit are examined, this investigation analyzes the centrality of profit and synthesis of violence, profits and power in entwined processes of politico-military competition, capital accumulation and waves of state-corporate globalization. Due to the internalization of allied protection costs, militarism played a much larger role in US capitalist enterprises and state management of global hegemony than during Britain's hundred years' peace in Europe. Changes in the global/regional geopolitical economy of military spending over the centuries are explored in terms of multiple functions of deflecting class struggle towards overseas expansion while supporting capital accumulation and military power projection capability to defend global state-corporate interests. This account of the changing geopolitical economy of militarism is used to analyze the fiscal crisis of the warfare-welfare state, the right turn of the Anglo-American Establishment, the rise of the New Right and the demise of the New Deal world order.

Title: Educación de la afectividad. Una propuesta educativa desde el pensamiento de Tomás de Aquino
Abstract: The education of effectively in the last instance brings up the problem of the emotional mastery of the human being. Lately, several authors have approached this issue, focusing its importance on education due to the clearness of evidence that good human relationships presuppose the appropriate government of own subjectivity. Although the main pedagogical propositions that emerge from such educational theories conclude in a theoretical mastery of the subject and in more or less critical situations, besides proposing an insane dependency on a “specialist”, these pedagogical propositions do not wholly solve the practical sense of the self-government. Ever since the classical philosophy, Thomas Aquinas teaches that emotions or feelings are interior forces that demand a mild mastery through two cardinal virtues formed in the interior of the subject; these virtues, far from submerging the effectively or controlling it despotically, direct and guide it conveniently in benefit of a good and effective action, collaborating in a meaningful way to the attainment of happiness. In this way, temperance is the virtue that regulates the leading movements that are directed towards the absolute sensitive goodness, among which pleasure, the basic emotion for bodily constitution, outstands. On the other hand, fortitude permits resistance and affirmation of human goodness, against various sensitive and affective obstacles that appear in the individual's actions, such as fear, a mediate emotion that retracts the activity. If in general the effectively directs itself throughout these virtues, in the global approach of the interior growth of mankind—in which education is comprised—both temperance and fortitude constitute the main basis for personal and social growth. The reason for this, is that effectively is the link between the bodily and spiritual growth; its correct disposition depends on the proper use of these human abilities, intelligence and will. For this reason, during childhood, parents try to form a series of habits, in the realm of temperance, in the child's ordinary activities that guide his subjective interior since he has a natural tendency to dispersion. In adolescence, it is a prior issue to form the other habits, in the realm of fortitude, to avoid the own emotional disorder of this evolutive stage, which detracts from the good performance. The development of both virtues demands the direct participation of both parents; but not through a rational lecturing teaching but by means of example and activity; this education will permit the adequate development of the most important cardinal virtues, justice and prudence, whose function is to direct in the most perfect manner for its own sake and the good of other people as well.

Title: The practice of Stalin models in Eastern Europe (1948--1953)
Abstract: After World War II, under the leading of Communist Parties, the People's Democracies were established in Eastern Europe. The People's Democracy was in concordance with internal and international situations. It differed from Soviet Models' Socialist and would develop toward socialism. With the deterioration of relations between the U.S and Soviet, Soviet consolidated its control over East3ern Europe in order to confront with the U.S, and then Soviet exported Stalin Models. The People's Democracies were forced to stop their own roads. Under the pressure of Soviet, the communist parties absorbed the socialist parties, party system transformed from multi--parties to one-party in nature and formed centralism in Eastern Europe. While the political systems were changed, central economical systems were established through the change of ownership in town and in countryside, importation of the Soviet industrialization policy and directive plan method. In order to get rid of obstacles to transplanting Stalin Models, many communist parties' leaders were purged. This movement was with the help of Soviet leaders. It is disastrous to copy Stalin Models. Political, economical and social progress is destroyed by Stalin models. According to systematical study of the processes of the formation of Stalin Models in Eastern Europe, this dissertation concludes that every country has its own specials and thus should develop its own models. Never copy other's models.

Title: Study on the Problem of Urbanization of Shenzhen
Abstract: Urbanization is the inevitable trend of the development of human society and economy, it is also the necessary qualification of realizing industrialization and modernization of China. Excessively low urbanization level of our country has become the important factor, which restricts the sustainable development of economy and society of our country. In brief 20 years, Shenzhen City has become a modern city, which developed from a fishery village. Through the research of Shenzhen, we could probe some basic rules and solve some concrete problems in the process of urbanization of Shenzhen. This is the gist of this paper. The paper concludes several contents as below:Firstly, the paper defines the concept of urbanization. The paper thinks that urbanization is a dynamic process of transforming from traditional rural economy-society-ecology complex system to modern economy-society-ecology complex system which considers the modern cities as its carrier and activity center and considers the harmonious development between human and the nature as its value. Urbanization should be not only rural urbanization, but also re-urbanization of the cities at the same time. Future cities will sustained develop only under the conditions of openness. On the basis of the concept, the standards, the characteristics, the implications, the functions and the roles of urbanization, the paper analyses the inevitability of the urbanization, its problems and its new phenomenon. Then the paper reviews the courses of urbanization of China. The slow process and consequence of lagging urbanization shows that urbanization has become a strategic task of our country.The paper then analyses the process, present situations and development trends of Shenzhen City, to establish the base of further analysis. The paper introduces the process of different stages. On the basis of analysis the index system of measuring the level of urbanization, the paper measures and evaluates the level and effectiveness of urbanization of Shenzhen. Then the paper analyses the characteristics and present problems of the process of urbanization of Shenzhen. Though analyses, the paper considers that the process of urbanization of Shenzhen City has reached the period of gradually smooth, which begins with the speeding-up. In point of quality, the implication of urbanization should be enriched. In future, urbanization of Shenzhen City will present the trend of mixture of the city and rural areas, slowing down of the speed of the enlargement of the city’s scale, the advanced science and technology of the city’s economy, fast transformation of city’s social structure and the trend of counter-urbanization. According to the actual conditions of Shenzhen, the paper proposes the urbanization strategy of Shenzhen. That develop Shenzhen into an international city, which has unique characteristics evenly and step by step on the basis of present conditions of nature and human and economy and the system innovation. The main measures are improving industry structure, coordinating the development of Shenzhen and Hongkong and the whole Zhujiang triangle areas, completely improving the qualities of population and protecting ecology environment.On the basis of above analysis, the paper analyses the motive mechanism of urbanization. The paper analyses the norms of motive mechanism of urbanization and its basic frame. The paper lays emphases on the system arrangement, marketing, the functions of human capital, etc.Urbanization of Shenzhen City has its outstanding characteristics. Bringing the market mechanism and macrocosm adjustment and control are the two big problems in the process of urbanization of Shenzhen. The system arrangement of pushing the growth of market economy efficiently is the dynamic source of the development of urbanization. Bringing the market economy creates the historical turning point of urbanization of Shenzhen. Xiaoping Deng’s inspection tour in the south raised second summit of urbanization of Shenzhen. As for Shenzhen, the factors of external demand, foreign investments and loans, new international division order of labor etc have the decisive effects on the urbanization of Shenzhen. So we could say that the pattern of urbanization of Shenzhen is a kind of urbanization pattern which is caused by external factors.In point of the concert motive mechanism of urbanization, the institution arrangement and its changes is one of the unique motive mechanism of Shenzhen City. Institution barrier hindered the development of urbanization, but after the reform and openness, special favorable policies supplies advantages for the speeding-up urbanization of Shenzhen. Human capital has the important effect to the urbanization of Shenzhen City. Shenzhen is a typical immigration city. The entries of a great deal of labors with good qualities meet the demand of speeding-up urbanization for human capital. In the past, recurring to human capital, all kinds of favorable policies, which were given by nation could be carried out and realized smoothly. Hereafter, Shenzhen should make good use of the accumulated human capital continued, and go all out to accumulate more human capital to ensure the further development of urbanization of Shenzhen. The paper analyses these problems in detail.The process of urbanization has close relationship with the promotion of industry structure. The paper analyses the changing process of industry structure of Shenzhen and considers it is very unique, which represents mainly on the less-developed heavy industry, considering the light processing industry as its principle part, and powerful-developed third industry. This kind of industry structure has active effect on urbanization of Shenzhen on one hand, on the other hand, it has some problems such as slim relation of each industry, shortcomings on high and new science and technology industry’s enterprises’ scale, technology content of its products, and motion institution. Urbanization requires the escalation of industry structure of Shenzhen City inevitably. This sets higher requirement for the macrocosm adjustment and control of the government. The paper considers that Shenzhen should armed industries with high and new technology of high additional value and pushing the escalation of industries with market pulling, speeding up the development of high and new technology industry.Agriculture is the base of urbanization. This cannot be neglected. The demand of the development of modern cities for the agriculture has not only been the economic exploration, but also the common exploration of the functions of ecology, society etc. and their organic integration. We have to establish new concept of modern agriculture, create the “city-earning foreign exchanges-environment-sightseeing” agriculture, change the “cultivated agriculture” into “territory agriculture”, adjust agricultural structure vigorously, protect lands, explore agriculture and ecological technology on food field, speed up the facilities’ structure of metropolis agriculture, develop ecological agriculture and build metropolis information industrialization system.Effective macrocosm adjustment and control are the premises of smooth urbanization. The paper concretely analyses the macrocosm adjustment and control of Shenzhen. The macrocosm adjustment and control’s contents concludes: creating the development strategy of mixing regional social development and urbanization, deepening the reform of institution of registered permanent resident, abolishing the employment policies which sticks to the institution of registered permanent residence, deepening the reform of institutions of rural lands, creating the market-regulated institution of the movement of the usufruct of land，controlling the population, increasing the investment of education, bringing the regional plan, cities and towns’ plan and the adjustment administrative divisions into the orbit of legal institutions, reforming the finance system, the institutions of the investment and raising funds and the administrative management institutions. The institution of investment and raising funds are important problems. Shenzhen city breaks traditional model of centralized management in finance, formulating pluralistic structure of the path of capitals and management institutions, bringing market mechanism into city management and motion, breaking monopoly, encouraging competition, combine systematic coordination with enterprise-style management, improving effectiveness and levels of cities’ infrastructure and public services supply，creating the mechanism of capital-accumulation of city’s construction fit to the rules of operation of socialist market economy. Now, pluralistic principle parts of investment and raising funds and varied channels and structures of raising funds have been formulated. The function of market mechanism has been enhanced in the field of investment and raising funds. The operation of enterprise-style and joint-stock of infrastructure create beneficial conditions for breaking the administrative plan and perfecting trans-regional infrastructure construction.Plan is another important problem of macrocosm adjustment and control in urbanization. The paper analyses the concept, the categories, the importance and the rules of plan of urbanization. Then the paper analyses the previous conditions, characteristics and problems of plan of urbanization of Shenzhen, then analyses the regional town system plan and the arrangement of the plan of urbanization of Shenzhen, the perfection and the management-intensifying of it. The paper considers that two big characters in the plan of Shenzhen are leading role of the government and market-openness. Followed the development of new industries group and new cities’ structure, great changes have taken place on cities’ functions and structures. Shenzhen City should perfect urbanization plan, stick out the innovation of urbanization plan, strengthening its legality, long-term, democracy, perfect static plan with dynamic revise. Especially notice the problems of resources and the environment when carrying out the city plan. In the process of urbanization of Shenzhen, the change of the structure and ways of land use often have important effect on the development of economy and society. The paper analyses these problems.Urbanization is not only a process of economic development, but also a process of social development. After analyzing the problem of urbanization of Shenzhen from the angle of economics, the paper then analyses it in point of view of sociology. The contents conclude population, social ensure system, the change of life style and the improvement of cultural civilization, etc. After analysis the theories of population immigration and the conditions of the transformation of peasants identity to townspeople, the paper then analyses the present conditions of population problems in Shenzhen, then proposes the improvement measures of plan management institution and concrete management institutions. Aiming at heavy pressure of swelling speed of population growth and low-level population qualities to the process of city’s construction and economic construction, the paper analyses the management of population, especially nonnative population. At the same time, the paper analyses the comparatively perfect social ensure system. The paper proposes that Shenzhen should perfect social ensure system, especially bringing flowing population into the social ensure system of Shenzhen City. To a certain degree, population urbanization is the transformation of “peasant” identity to townspeople, the transformation of employment direction to non-agriculture, and the modernization of production and life style. Transformation of peasants’ life style to townspeople’s life style is the symbol of modern civilization. The degree of spirit civilization is the important index of urbanization. The paper analyses the change of peasants’ life style and the conditions of spirit civilization of Shenzhen, and proposes concerned improvement measures.

Title: 'the right to have rights': gender politics, citizenship and the state in uruguay
Abstract: The thesis comprises a historically-grounded analysis of gender politics in Uruguay. It analyses the extent to which women have been able to establish a controlling presence in politics - in terms of entry of institutional arenas and of the representation of their interests in the political agenda and policy-making process - by exploring the interplay between structure, discourse and agency. The first chapter provides a historical perspective, showing how, in the context of the construction of the modern state in Uruguay, the progressive social justice discourse of the hegemonic political sector together with pressure by organised women's groups led to early reforms promoting women's rights. The second chapter examines how the second-wave women's movement emerged, initially as part of the wider civil opposition to the military dictatorship (1973-1984), and then as a political actor in its own right, to press for the inclusion of its gender-specific demands as part of the democratic project. The final four chapters analyse the development of gender politics in different political arenas - the legislature, state and political parties - in the post-dictatorship period (1985-1997). The thesis argues that the continuing obstacles to the representation of women and their interests in politics are partly the result of persistent traditional assumptions about gender roles, but derive principally from the nature of the political system itself and changing conceptualisations of citizenship and state-civil society relations, influenced by the neo-liberal doctrine of individual liberty and minimal state intervention. By constructing unity in diversity as a collective political actor, developing a rights-based discourse and using international legal instruments for lobbying, the women's movement has won some institutional space and achieved the politicisation of certain gender issues, although these gains are far from consolidated.

Title: The development of a southern whale fishery from britain between 1775 and 1815
Abstract: This thesis examines British involvement in the Southern Whale Fishery, which commenced in 1775 and over the next forty years resulted in Britain becoming the world leader in the industry. The main aims of this essentially empirical study are twofold: first, to reconstruct the historical geography of whaling by collecting and analysing primary records in order to fill a gap in our knowledge; and second, to place whaling - as a particular commercial activity carried out in the southern hemisphere from Britain during that period - in its wider social, historical and political context. The theoretical insights and concepts derived from contemporary historical geography that underpin the study and locate it in the discipline of geography are those of globalisation with particular reference to oceanic trade. Documentary analysis and interpretative narrative form are the principal methods used to collect, analyse and present the data. A detailed picture is presented of the networks of people, ships and products associated with whaling from Britain to the southern seas. Some of the geographies of that whaling world have been reconstructed at different spatial scales, both global and local, tracing the movement and flows of different social groups, commodities and capital in the development of the Fishery. The study identifies the significant political influences and key players that impacted on the global oceanic trading activities of the Fishery and how these operated at a local scale. The thesis also discusses the establishment, in 1792, of a whaling town at Milford in south west Wales by Nantucket Quaker families. The study shows how the Southern Whale Fishery, at that time, represented an important element of Britain’s contribution to world trade, a means of supplementing Britain’s naval power, the provision of opportunities for territorial expansion and the identification of new trade routes.

Title: From the margins to the mainstream: Contact improvisation and the commodification of touch
Abstract: My dissertation follows Cynthia Novack's work, who in Sharing the Dance traced the development of contact improvisation from its onset to the late 1980s and revealed the form as a polyvocal and experimental practice arising from the American political and social values of the 1960s counterculture movement. I examine ways contact improvisation remains a subculture practice and has emerged in mainstream frameworks to determine its influences and significance in the 1990s. I argue that contact improvisation sustained as an egalitarian community by preserving its vitality through rhetoric of a “natural body.” At the same time, contact improvisation contributes to new trends in post/modern dance by offering partnering skills, exploring issues of identity, and performing various choreographic representations of touch and weight. I raise issues of gender, sexuality, ability, race, and class to track changes in the sociopolitical climate by investigating contact improvisation as it arises in various choreographic circumstances and is performed by a range of bodies including “hired bodies,” dancers versed in a variety of techniques in order to meet the demands of contemporary choreographers; “contact” or “weighted bodies,” dancers schooled in the principles of contact improvisation; disabled dancers; and classically-trained ballet dancers. As an identifying-ethnography, I utilize embodied research along with choreographic analysis to illuminate contact improvisation as a particular movement language. I apply theories of transgression to illuminate ways that contact improvisation exposes and crosses boundaries of touch. Chapter One locates the current concerns of the community by highlighting the 25th Anniversary Celebration of the form at Oberlin College in 1997. Chapter Two investigates contact improvisation as a choreographic tool by delineating the form as technique, vocabulary, and practice. Chapter Three analyzes contact improvisation in relation to the historical trajectory of American modern dance and the overarching field of “release technique” to explore its “revolutionary” politics. Chapter Four examines contact improvisation in the global sphere where issues of gender, sexuality, universality, and commodification surface in various ways. I argue, as a metaphor, or currency, of corporeal exchange, contact improvisation paradoxically deepens universal ideologies of the body and serves as a model for understanding difference.

Title: Germans, Costa Ricans, or a question of dual nationalist sentiments? The German community in Costa Rica, 1850–1950
Abstract: This dissertation examines the immigration and community formation of German settlers in Costa Rica from the mid-nineteenth through the mid-twentieth centuries and the extent to which they became integrated in their host society. It stipulates that German Costa Ricans established a dichotomous position in Costa Rica, as members of the local economic, social and political elite, yet proud members of a Costa Rican German community. Even the earliest German immigrants to Costa Rica in the mid- to late-nineteenth century established themselves as owners of large commercial firms that helped to expand Costa Rica's international trade. German Costa Ricans also branched out with large commercial agricultural enterprises involved in the production and processing of coffee and sugar, the nation's two most important export products. Participation in these economic enterprises aided German Costa Ricans in forging marriage ties and business partnerships with Costa Ricans that perpetuated their integration into an incipient Costa Rican agricultural elite. German Costa Ricans worked at the same time to establish a local German community. They founded a German Club, School, and Welfare Society, that helped them to maintain their language and culture and perpetuated a strong sense of “Germanness,” which they then passed on to their Costa Rican born children. This powerful foreign community had a significant impact on this history of the Central American nation. I argue that the perpetuation of “Germanness” combined with the connection of influential members of the German community to the Costa Rican government, led directly to the infiltration of Nazi propaganda and influence in Costa Rican in the 1930s. The penetration of Nazism among some members of the German community in turn created the fear of a local “Fifth Column” movement. These fears then forced the Costa Rican government to take action against local Germans after Costa Rica entered World War II on the side of the allies. I further explain that the pre-World War II perpetuation of Deutschtum and the government actions this warranted led Germans to shed their “Germanness,” and to become more fully assimilated into Costa Rican society, after the end of the war.

Title: Self, language, and the body: Literary case studies from Flaubert to Ernaux
Abstract: This project traces representations of medical treatments in French fiction from Flaubert to Ernaux as they evolve in connection with changing notions of self, medicine, and the body. My analyses trace this shift in terms of medical treatments represented and the writing cure. As science develops, treatments reflect the introduction of specializations and technological advances. A division remains between routine practices and more extreme measures. In Gustave Flaubert's Madame Bovary and Émile Zola's Nana , the limits of reason appear in an inability to cure or treat all physical—and psychological—ailments. Growing disappointment, strong during times of personal and collective trauma, carries over into traditional medical practices and the medical profession, in general. What I call the “writing cure” embodies the transition from medical institutions to lay-attempts at cure. Beginning with Emma's dreaming cure and moving to the psychoanalytic talking cure, I argue for a drive among protagonists and narrators to treat themselves after conventional therapies fail. Le Docteur Pascal anticipates the specific alternative of a “writing cure.” Narrators in André Breton's Nadja , Louis-Ferdinand Céline's Voyage au bout de la nuit , and Albert Camus's La Peste are faced with physical and moral contagion on a global scale. These doctors' lives and practices are put into question, revealing the limits of medicine. André Gide's L'Immoraliste , Camus's La Chute , and Jean-Paul Sartre's La Nausée present a further move away from medicine on the part of lay narrators who see writing or talking as a way to confess. Marguerite Duras's Le Ravissement de Lol V. Stein intentionally manipulates aspects of voice as a male doctor writes a case study about a woman, with a female author increasingly present behind his words. In Passion simple , Annie Ernaux's narrator reconstructs conflict in order to work through and move beyond trauma. The movement in fictional representations from physical to more abstract or psychological therapies reflects social and historical changes of medical treatment in nineteenth- and twentieth-century France. The stark realization that medicine, even with its discoveries, still cannot resolve human mortality or cure the innermost sufferings of the soul compels characters to undertake the “writing cure.”

Title: For all our relations: Ecofeminist and indigenous challenges to sustainable development
Abstract: For All Our Relations presents a dual challenge to the field of Christian Ethics and the emerging paradigm of sustainable development. The debate over sustainable development (the international movement to make economic and social development environmentally sustainable) provides a theoretical and practical locus to explore the interactions between environmental sustainability, economic equity, and the rights of disenfranchised peoples. A small number of Christian ethicists have been exploring these questions, seeking to integrate the demands of a viable earth ethics with the requirements for just political economy. The dissertation argues, however, that both Christian ethicists and sustainable development advocates suffer from a serious blind spot. Neither has adequately attended to the marginalized voices of the people most impacted by the complex crises of culture and nature confronting our world. This dissertation focuses on two of these constituencies: indigenous peoples and women. Taking an ecofeminist approach, the thesis brings the voices of ecofeminists, women activists, and indigenous peoples into dialogue with the mainstream paradigm of sustainable development. Through focusing on three policy areas: land rights, preservation of endangered cultures, and biodiversity conservation, the thesis argues that a provisional consensus has emerged among ecofeminists and indigenous peoples which challenges fundamental presuppositions embedded in sustainable development discourse. By egg the challenges posed by ecofeminists and indigenous peoples to sustainable development and Christian ethics, the thesis indicates that a double transformation is required if humanity is to live sustainably and equitably within the broader earth community. First, our globalizing capitalist culture with its religious adherence to the gospel of “free trade” and “property rights” must learn to respect and protect non-Western and indigenous cultures, which value people over profits, the well-being of all over the flourishing of the few, and harmony with the earth rather than dominion over it. Second, the thesis calls for the transformation of Christianity into a genuine “earth faith.” Finally, the dissertation calls for a theo-ethical shift which includes the recovery of the sense of the sacred in the natural world, the recognition of the agency and moral standing of non-human creatures, and respect for diversity as a key moral norm.

Title: Networks of capital and influence: A critical social inquiry into the field of management consulting
Abstract: In 1998, management consulting was approximately a $90 billion industry growing at a rate of over 20% per year with more than 70,000 management consultants in the United States alone and over 140,000 worldwide. Yet, it has been both underresearched and largely undiscussed outside the inner circles of the field itself. Using a critical interpretive approach, this study uses empirical data from informant interviews with consultants and clients, secondary data from a variety of sources, and participant observation and case studies to examine the field of management consulting from historical, descriptive, structural, and cultural perspectives. Exploring the field within the framework of Pierre Bourdieu's theory of practice in combination with social network theory, the research question guiding this inquiry was: What are the properties, dimensions, and dynamics of the various species of capital operating within the field of management consulting; how are these species of capital interrelated and to what effect? The findings were: (a) empirical findings descriptive of how the field is structured, how it operates, and the extent of its reach, scope, and influence in contemporary society—including such factors as practice arrangements, areas of practice and practice structures, consulting firm structures and economic models, recruitment, selection, retention and movement, compensation, orientation and training, the consulting process, tools of the trade, the consulting life, the language of management consulting, educational credentials, and roles and relationships; (b) identification of a “culture of smartness” and its properties and dynamics; and (c) insights into the role networks of capital play in creating and reproducing this culture and diffusing the influence of management consulting throughout society. A historical analysis provides contextual background; structural, cultural, and critical analyses derive from this context and the empirical findings. The conclusion drawn from these levels of analysis is that management consultants occupy elite status in contemporary capitalist society and function as part of the “collective intelligentsia” (Mannheim) of our time. However, this role is played from behind-the-scenes among the elite levels of power and influence in all institutional sectors of society. While having a significant impact on thought, practice, and culture on an increasingly global scale, it is a role played largely outside the public view, consciousness, and discourse, thereby rendering the role and influence of management consulting in contemporary society “invisible” and unchallenged.

Title: Spheres of influence and academic networks: A history of official Australian aid to the University of the South Pacific (USP), 1960–1990
Abstract: This dissertation examined the concept of autonomy and the University of the South Pacific (USP). It explored the significance of USP as a university created by a colonial power, supported by foreign aid, and its development in the South Pacific region. From a historical perspective, the period is significant in that the USP was created during the last days of colonialism and later merged into an international system. The purpose in taking this research back to 1960 was to add an account of the events leading up to the institutionalization of the USP, the particular effects of colonialism in the South Pacific region, and the postcolonial implications of developing higher education there. This dissertation addressed three issues. How significant is the location of the USP in Suva to its role in the region? Is the model of core/periphery being applied behind the mask of intellectual freedom? Does the USP remain a colonial construction or has it developed into an autonomous institution? This research presented a qualitative study using archives and special collections in Australia and Fiji. The change in Australian aid policy over time became evident in the process of reviewing policy documents. Debate was easily traceable in documents from the archives of the USP. Interviews provided synthesis with the archives and policy documents enriching the data from these primary sources. Theoretical analysis added depth to looking at the region from the vantage of spheres of influence and agency. What is crucial in this dissertation is how the USP has been affected by shifting spheres of influence. The theoretical context of shifting spheres of influence focuses on the movement of influence in education through various countries' economic, social, and political power. In this case study, Great Britain, Australia, and Fiji are the focus of these shifts. Through this theoretical lens, it becomes evident that it is not mere incident that Fiji is a developing core, and spheres of influence, particularly in the South Pacific region, are always connected, contested, and infinitely more complex than imagined in an orthodox core-periphery model.

Title: Models of capitalism, complexity and postindustrialism: the case of unified Germany. (BL)
Abstract: This thesis challenges the misconceptions of most contemporary accounts of the German capitalism, and develops a new framework for analysing the German Model in the contemporary period. Between 1989/90 and 1998 debates on the political economy of unified Germany have tended to argue that the German Model of capitalism is no longer viable in the global economy. Alternatively, accounts which defend the German Model fail to recognise the genuine characteristics of unified Germany. Part One of this study criticises the analysis of conventional defences of the German Model in two ways. Conventional accounts are unitary, they focus solely on the autarkic or large firm centred view of German industrialism and ignore the complexity of German capitalism which exists within Germany on account of the different paths taken to industrialism and the post-WWII division and subsequent unification of Germany. Conventional accounts of German capitalism are industrial, they regard the German Model of capitalism not to have been affected by the postindustrial transitions. This study challenges these two misrepresentations of the German Model and, by combining institutionalist theories from political economy with postindustrial theory from sociology a new framework for analysing post-unification Germany is created. The outcome of this synthesis is a four-part model labelled Coexisting Postindustrial Trajectories. It is argued that unified Germany will succeed as an economy in the current phase of capitalism if these trajectories are permitted to coexist on equal terms. Part Two of this thesis identifies the challenge of complexity and postindustrialism on the organisations and institutions of social partnership which characterise the German Model. The appropriateness of trade union responses to these dynamics is assessed through two case studies. The first looks at the response of the trade union movement to the events of 1989. The second analyses the DGB's reformed Grundsatzprogramm (Statement of Basic Principle) of 1996.

Title: Environmentalism emplaced: a sociological exploration of environmentalism in York. (BL: DXN056756)
Abstract: In this thesis, I examine the relationship between environmentalism and place. Studies suggest that this relationship is significant, especially at the local level, where hundreds and thousands of place-based associations have been formed since the Rio Summit in 1992. After drawing attention to the place differences within the wider movement and considering these in the light of globalisation, localisation and relocalisation, I look at four local environmental organisations in York. These have been chosen because they reflect the basic types of environmentalism in general, as well as the scope and diversity of environmentalism in York. I discuss my involvement with the groups, as a participant observer and interviewer. I also attempt to articulate the ways in which their aims and objectives - as well as their achievements - are determined (as in 'decided' or 'completed' as well as 'altered' or 'modified') by the nature of York as a place. I start from the premise that place provides local environmentalists with a 'perspective' and 'experiential centre' (Harvey, 1996). Global environmental discourses and problems are perceived and acted upon through the 'medium' or 'prism' of place, which 'saturates' or 'mediates' local environmentalism (Gieryn, 2000). The influence of the wider movement and its 'associated penumbra' (Purdue et al, 1997), as well as that of other social processes and phenomena such as globalisation and restructuring, is also altered or modified by place. However, because the nature of place is both 'place-specific' and 'case-specific', it is also extremely difficult to generalise about - a dilemma that can only be resolved by conducting further research.

Title: Process analysis of a total literacy campaign in india: a case study of udaipur district, rajasthan
Abstract: The National Literacy Mission (NLM) of the Government of India adopted the Total Literacy Campaign (TLC) model as the main policy instrument for eliminating adult illiteracy in the 1990s. The study is concerned with how the campaign approach approved at the national level is de facto implemented at the grassroot level with local specific variances beyond the model. The TLC of Udaipur district in the state of Rajasthan is selected as a case for a descriptive analysis of the campaign process, with a specific focus on the policy implementation at the village level. The thesis is divided into three sections. In the first, efforts to eradicate adult illiteracy in the global context, and in India in particular, are examined with a view to providing the primary rationale for the current field of study. The origin of the TLC model as it has emerged is reviewed as India's distinctive contribution to the global pool of experience. Particular attention is given to the issue of replicability of the model in different social contexts. The second section is primarily devoted to presenting some contextual background of the case study, including the methodological considerations and logistic realities of conducting the field research. The emergence of TLC in Rajasthan and the achievement of Udaipur district as reported by the NLM are examined in detail. It is argued that the 'quality' of TLC is not properly judged through the current evaluation scheme built into the model. The types of insight into the process of the TLC sought by this researcher may be the natural domain of the interpretive paradigm underlying qualitative strategies. The final section presents the research findings to emerge from the fieldwork, analysing local TLC practices of six sample villages and their responses to the campaign strategies presented by the district authority. It turns out that Udaipur TLC may share in its approach and strategies more with the top-down government programme than with the campaign 'movement', and the gap between policy and practice of each campaign becomes even more apparent at the village level. Considering the multi-faced nature of the TLC, findings are examined from the six operational stages of the campaign implementation, according to which suggestions for future planning are also presented.

Title: Church, state and the aboriginal rights movement in taiwan: a case study of the paiwan
Abstract: This fieldwork was conducted in southern Taiwan, mainly in the village of Piuma, among the aboriginal Paiwan people. The dissertation examines the influence on the Paiwan society of national and international practices and institutions: namely the church, state and Fourth World movements. It details how the Paiwan people actively engage in these social domains that seem to be beyond their control. The globalizing discourses of Presbyterian egalitarianism, state democratic representation and universal human rights, however, do not necessarily diminish local diversity but can sometimes encourage it. These external influences have also helped to create new social and political arenas in which the rhetorics of tradition are adopted and in which local conceptions of what it means to be Paiwanese are re-affirmed and contested, a process that may be seen as 'tradition in the making'. The processes described here follow a pattern recognizable in other parts of the world (e.g., North American and Australia) but are substantially differ in terms of the dynamic tension (or articulation) between local indigenous hierarchy and the egalitarianism of 'external' ideologies. The dissertation proceeds from local through national to transnational politics. The first chapter describes the contexts under which I conducted my fieldwork. In the following two chapters, I use naming practices and a local cultural revival organisation to illustrate Paiwan hierarchy and how it functions in contemporary life. Chapter two examines how the people of Piuma construct relationships through names which are hierarchically ordered, and how names are linked to particularistic loyalties (and hence indigenous political dynamics). Chapter three analyzes the rise and fall of the Cultural Revival Committee in Piuma, and how this new organisation became entangled with the politics of status competition among members of high-ranking houses, who resort to myth and history to legitimise their respective claims. The effort to revive a collective past collapse, due to different perceptions of that past. In the following three chapters, I examine differential dynamical articulations between Paiwan hierarchical and 'outside' egalitarian ideologies.

Title: The practice, power and poetics of direct action
Abstract: The thesis begins with a discussion of the Trident nuclear weapons system, now Britain's only nuclear weapons. It continues by looking at the ways in which the tactics used by police and courts support these nuclear weapons. I suggest that this is often based on a desire to purify space. For police this is largely through surveillance, arrest and detention. In the courts, domination is based on the limitation of acceptable legal discourses to the rational, visual and cognitive. It is impossible to create a perfect regime of control, and this opens up opportunities for resistance in the "gaps in the map". Following Bey (1991), I suggest that Faslane Peace Camp operates as a "Temporary Autonomous Zone". I also discuss fence cutting, graffiti, lock-ons, and the use of political songs, as specific direct action tactics. These tactics often involve the "practical deconstruction" of boundaries. Continuing the discussion of singing, I discuss some of the ways in which singing in police custody can provide a form of personal empowerment. I look beyond purely individual models of resistance and empowerment, and suggest that singing also plays a vital part in the construction, and structuring, of communities. Drawing on my experiences at the St. George's Hill land squat in Surrey, and the use of The world Turned Upside Down, I discuss how these communities many be based on various "ideals", such as the mutual aid of social anarchism. They are, however, always permeated by conflicts and exclusions. Moreover, even these ideals remain problematic. The use of "affinity groups", and consensus decision-making, are further ways in which communities of resistance are structured. Again, there is a conflict between these ideals, and the way in which the communities are actually practiced. I also include a discussion of the ways in which the "international community" has been created as a geopolitical discourse, and the ways in which the anti-nuclear movement has engaged with the concept.

Title: The clandestine struggle for the eastern mediterranean and the middle east: italian subversion, arab nationalism and british counter-intelligence, 1935-1940
Abstract: This study seeks to address the nature of propaganda and subversive activities organised by Fascist Italy in the Mediterranean and the Middle East during the interwar period, and in particular in the last five years preceding Italy's entry into the Second World War in 1940. The approach taken is that of international history, drawing upon the limited and elusive archival materials to establish a chain of causation over time. Where possible this dissertation seeks to reach out beyond the political where the analysis of the Italian propaganda machine and its undertakings can be expanded to permit an examination of the associated social and cultural conditions of the geographical areas targeted by Mussolini's expansionist foreign policy. Several main themes run parallel in this study: the imperial dimension of Britain's foreign policy, and the British determination to preserve and defend the strategic core of the empire; Italian propaganda - here regarded as an instrument employed to further Mussolini's imperialistic ambitions, the challenge brought by Fascist Italy to the precarious equilibrium of political forces within the British empire; finally the rise of an increasingly powerful pan-Arab nationalist movement whose political significance was not always fully appreciated by British observers. Ultimately this study seeks to demonstrate that the demise of British influence in the Mediterranean and the Middle East was not greatly accelerated by the activities of Fascist propagandists, which proved to be short-lived, even though Italian propaganda had been supported by a sophisticated and efficiently co-ordinated structure. Instead, Britain's continued fascination with the old elites - the princes and pashas of the region - and its corresponding inability to adequately interact with new political forces emerging within the empire and the mandatory territories, continued to undermine British influence in a region of great strategic significance.

Title: Immigration in post-communist Europe: Greece and Albanian migratory movement. (BL: DXN050645)
Abstract: This thesis is about Greece and the Albanian migratory movement after 1990. It concentrates on the analysis of three core issues. Firstly, it explores the causes for the rise of the migration flow from Albania. Secondly, it examines the dynamics behind Greece's policy response towards this movement. Thirdly, it investigates how effective this policy response has been. The discussion of these issues is set within the context of a consideration of wider European reactions to new migration flows in the post-Cold-War era. The theoretical framework used in this thesis includes models from the literature on international migration which seek to explain the causes of the phenomenon, as well as concepts derived from the public policy approach of policy failure. The empirical research was based on semi-structured elite interview, while a wide-range of primary and secondary literature was used to provide context for the analysis and to compliment the research findings. In relation to the causality of the Albanian immigration into Greece the research revealed that this has to be appreciated in a multi-dimensional way, given that a number of causes were identified. Similarly, for adequately understanding the country's policy response towards this population movement, a variety of factors have to be taken into account (such as economic, social, foreign affairs, and others). Finally the thesis concludes that overall, Greece's immigration policy response may be defined as largely ineffective, as significant problems were found to characterise its formation, implementation and general performance. The thesis also demonstrated the value of linking analytical tools from different academic disciplines (migration theories from geography; policy failure from politics), in achieving higher levels of explanatory capability.

Title: Outside the Abbey: the Irish national theatres, 1897-1913.
Abstract: This thesis examines debates on Irish national representation in the Abbey Theatre and in a range of alternative theatres set up at the end of the nineteenth and beginning of the twentieth century. It documents in particular the development of a new social role for theatres, signalled by their aspirations to be representative of the Irish nation. In this context the Irish Literary Theatre created its own niche as an 'independent' theatre. It initiated a more extensive debate on the function of a national theatre, and led to the establishment of the Irish National Theatre Society and the Abbey Theatre. The thesis demonstrates that the concept of a national theatre was variously interpreted according to the interests of individual groups: the Gaelic League and Daughters of Erin revived rural performance traditions, the National Players presented drama of a more patriotic cast, and the Players' Club focused on modernist international drama. Moreover, the Ulster Literary Theatre challenged the Abbey Theatre's monolithic concept of a nation, with productions that addressed rather than avoided sectarian issues. The Theatre of Ireland emerged out of disagreements with W.B. Yeat's autocratic policies in the Abbey Theatre and for a while competed successfully for national theatre status. Padraic Pearse's plays displayed a distinctly Catholic identity, the Markieviczs presented middle class urban plays and patriotic Irish drama, and Johanna Redmond's mildly nationalist plays illustrated that in the new political climate of a pending third Home Rule Bill patriotic drama became 'respectable' on the Irish stage. In its examination of the alternative theatre movement, the thesis highlights a fundamental shift in the concept of "national theatre," from a position centred on cultural prestige to one that encompasses the wider concerns of national representation. The movement of the Abbey Theatre along this track was by no means as smooth as suggested by Lady Gregory in Our Irish Theatre (1913). By that time, however, its international reputation and pivotal role in Irish drama meant that Irish audiences unofficially sanctioned its national theatre status.

Title: The aesthetics of cultural modernisation: hindi cinema in the 1950s
Abstract: This thesis questions classic notions of culture as ‘representation of contemporary reality’ and the traditional, linear periodisation of art-historical series. Film criticism, caught (a) in a strictly synchronic notion of the relationship between social relations and cultural forms and (b) in the assumption that author and viewer are fully modern subjects, is unable to cope with cinemas the narrative strategies of which do not correspond to those of Western cinema. By way of a preliminary investigation of the relation between the forms of Indian cinema and their multiple historical reference points, this thesis demonstrates the productivity of an approach based on two hypotheses. The first is that capitalist modernisation, that is to say, the historical constellation that led to the emergence of the cinema’s narrative strategies, is not a linear movement towards a society the socio-economic modalities of which are tacitly understood to be those in place in Western societies, but a field of tension in which the long-term trajectory of a society towards a broadly defined form of capitalism within a global economy is determined by the short-term struggles between the specific forces at work in that society. The second hypothesis is that narration consists, among other things, of orchestrating historically layered forms of enunciation that remain available to each of the temporalities and power blocs constitutive of a given constellation. As a consequence, cultural forms may or may not reflect a dominant economic and/or political configuration at any one time. It is precisely in this struggle between concurring (dominant and non-dominant) forces over the power to fix the meaning of forms, that texts can be seen not to ‘reflect’ or to ‘trigger’, but to ‘stage’ historical conditions and, in the process, to mediate within themselves the struggles that shape the ‘outside’ of textual production. This ‘outside’ context is then to be reconceptualised as the conjunction of positions and preoccupations narrativised according to the resources made available by the short, medium and long term historical currents at work within it. These are the premises that are necessary for the comparative study of cinemas from different cultures and epochs to become visible on the horizon of film theory.

Title: A Catholic Unionist: the life and times of William Monsell, first Baron Emly of Tervoe (1812-1894).
Abstract: This dissertation is the biography of one of the most significant, yet one of the most over-looked, political figures of nineteenth century Ireland. William Monsell first stood for Parliament in 1837. He was returned for County Limerick from 1847 to 1874, and was raised to the Peerage as Lord Emly in the latter year. His political career was of some fifty six years duration. The first chapter introduces William Monsell, and establishes his leading role in the politics of Ireland and Britain in the nineteenth century. Chapter Two describes his family background and youth, Chapter Three describes his political and religious conversions in the 1840s, and Chapter Four outlines his political, religious and social ideology. Chapters Five to Eight are devoted to an account of his career, paying attention to his role as a mediator between Britain and Ireland, between the Catholic Bishops and the British Government, and between his constituency and the authorities. Considerable attention is given to his periods as an office holder, especially in the 1850s at the Board of Ordnance, and between 1868 and 1873, at the Colonial and Post Offices. There is also measured consideration on his international role, his involvement in the Liberal Catholic movement as a European figure, and his concern for political, religious and social equality, for Catholics and the Irish people. Finally, his influence and his achievements are assessed in the concluding chapter, where his ideological stances are measured against the political conditions of his times.

Title: On the animation of the inorganic: “Life in Movement” in the art and architecture of modernism, 1892–1944
Abstract: From film and television to architecture and even to the global market economy, we evolve and dissolve in a computer (re)generated culture which is increasingly possessed by the omnipotent spirit of “animation.” With this dissertation, I want to locate the modern origins of animation as a collective fantasy by inquiring into discourses of simulated life and movement— Lebendigkeit, Beweglichkeit —which evolved from the equally anxious and analogously “animated” psychological landscape of the preceding fin-de-siècle . Originated in the “enslaved” columns of Vitruvius, incorporated in Renaissance doctrines of proportion, echoed in classical theories of physiognomy and caractère and scientifically researched in the formulations of empathy theory in nineteenth-century German aesthetics, discussions of pneumatism, spiritism or animism of forms have proved to be implicitly central in the foundational discourses of art and architectural theory. However, starting with the physiological conception of the sublime in the eighteenth-century, the “body metaphor” mutated from a harmonious exterior morphology into an organic inner pathology affecting the organisms of statues, buildings and modern metropolises. Within this shifting ground, in fin-de-siècle Europe, the artistic drive, Alois Riegl's Kunstwollen , presents an inflection, marking the shift from empathy theory to what Wilhelm Worringer calls “the uncanny pathos for the animation of the inorganic.” My main argument, is that empathy, the ability for identification with the external world, was fundamentally repressed by modern egos, thus, it had to return metamorphically projected and reified into the inorganic form of the animistic artifacts of twentieth-century modernism. The dissertation has two sections. The first deals with animation in turn of the century historiography and the second presents the practice of animation in early twentieth-century avant-garde movements in Germany and France. Moving from mythology to history and from psychoanalysis to social anthropology and natural history, I rehearse the effort of modern discourse to invent new totemic orders between crystals, trees, snakes, houses and human bodies. Bringing together Warburg's nymphs and Léger's nudes, Ovid's Daphne and Mies's skyscrapers, this project ultimately attempts to replicate a Mnemosyne atlas of the inorganic fragments and reanimated fossils of modernism's “living” archaeology.

Title: Placing conflict and collaboration in community forestry
Abstract: This dissertation is about two efforts to propose and enact management arrangements on sections of national forests in California's Northern Sierra region: The Quincy Library Group (QLG), and the Maidu Cultural and Development Group (MCDG). Both of these organizations have been described as “place-based” meaning that their origins, the collaboration between their members, and the bases of their forest management plans are all grounded in relationship to particular locales. This dissertation explores the dynamics of conflict and collaboration associated with these two place-based efforts. I present a way of seeing place in both spatial (local/non-local) and temporal (past/present/future) dimensions. Seeing place in this way allows me to move beyond the typical accounts of the QLG, as merely the conflict between local and national control of national forests, and the MCDG, as merely the conflict between tradition and modernity in forest management and the reconstitution of the Maidu nation. I examine the role of place in the mobilization of the MCDG and the QLG, in their forest management plans and management areas (the Maidu Stewardship Area and the QLG Area), the means of legitimating these plans and areas, and the dynamics of conflict and collaboration that arose in the attempts to put these plans and areas “on the ground.” In telling these two tales, I hope to open up new opportunities for the study of “place-based” natural resource management—how such efforts form and change, how they devise and employ their rhetorical and material tactics, and why they evoke certain relations of conflict and collaboration. Seeing place as a zone of contact between dialectical elements of local and national/global, and tradition and modernity, I hope to support a more dynamic analysis of the community forestry phenomenon in the United States; one that is relevant to both practitioners, and to the theoretical realms of political economy, social movements, cultural politics, and the politics of nature.

Title: Muenzenberg. Rise and fall of a Communist tycoon, 1917--1940
Abstract: “Münzenberg. Rise and Fall of a Communist Tycoon, 1917–1940” chronicles the political career of Willy Münzenberg, one of the leading propagandists of the Communist International (Comintern) in the 1920s and 1930s. Drawing extensively on recently opened archives in Moscow and the former Eastern Bloc, this dissertation sheds new light on Comintern finances, propaganda strategy, and especially on Münzenberg's use of ostensibly independent “front organizations” to infiltrate non-Communist circles in European politics. It also contributes to our understanding of the breakdown of democracy in the Weimar Republic in Germany, in which Münzenberg's shadow propaganda empire played a significant role. The argument runs as follows. Because Münzenberg, as an old friend of Lenin's from wartime Zürich, had easier access to “Moscow gold” than most of his party colleagues, his conversion to the Communist cause after World War I had especially potent repercussions for European, and especially German, politics. Although none of Münzenberg's (ostensibly) “non-Communist” media ventures (newspapers, illustrated periodicals, film distribution companies, book clubs, etc.) made money or came close to breaking even, their very ubiquity was seen as a threat by anti-Communists on both the Left and the Right—most of whom had no doubt that these ventures were, in fact, Communist. Münzenberg, labeled a “Communist Hugenberg” (in reference to a notorious right-wing German media baron of that name), became a potent symbol of the Bolshevik invasion of the European Left, which not only weakened the various Social Democratic parties (whose leaders refused to ally with Moscow) but also lent crucial rhetorical ammunition to aggressively revanchist movements of the Right like Hitler's Nazis. By the last years of the Weimar Republic in the early 1930s, Münzenberg and his fellow Berlin resident and Nazi journalist counterpart, Joseph Goebbels, were firing off (mostly untruthful) propaganda salvoes tit for tat, feeding a destructive spiral of accusations and counter-accusations that poisoned the political atmosphere irrevocably. This was a dangerous political tango, in which the fate of Germany—and after her, all of Europe—was at stake. For the death and destruction that followed the collapse of democracy in central Europe in the 1930s, Münzenberg must share responsibility with the Nazi politicians who defeated him in the race for power. Contrary to the apologias published by many of Münzenberg's collaborators after his death in 1940, this man was no democrat. In the way he responded to his dramatic fall from Moscow's favor after 1937, no less than in his meteoric rise to political fame that preceded it, Willy Münzenberg was a Communist to the core.

Title: The political economy of micro -enterprise promotion policies: Restructuring and income -generating activities in El Alto, Bolivia
Abstract: In countries like Bolivia, development is the tenet to eradicate poverty, and micro-enterprises (MEs) are currently being presented as a mechanism to achieve this goal. This dissertation examines the politics of ME promotion in the city of El Alto, Bolivia and analyzes the practical and theoretical implications on a local and global scale. As the Bolivian government promotes individual entrepreneurial capacities as a means to democratize access to resources and improve the welfare of the poor it also maintains an economic policy that privileges the demands of globalized systems of production and consumption. Using qualitative and quantitative information obtained during field research (1998–1999), I explore points of tension between the local needs and the global demands. I utilize the current politics of ME promotion as a lens to analyze two ongoing processes: (1) the restructuring of economic and political institutions; (2) women's income generating strategies in El Alto. Based on my analysis of the first process, I establish how and why MEs have taken a prominent position in Bolivia's development policy. Based on second processes, I discuss the pitfalls and potentials of the concrete activities in the promotion of MEs in El Alto. To develop this analysis, I focus on concrete points of tension between national government development agendas, the activities of local organizations promoting MEs, and the ways in which women organize individual and collective economic activities in El Alto. The analysis of the primary and secondary data, based on interviews and a small survey, will be couched within the theoretical fields of globalization, gender and development, and social movements. A basic conclusion from this dissertation is that MEs are not inherently negative, but its promotion is currently framed in neo-liberal logic that supports practices that are deepening and reproducing poverty and discrimination. One of the purposes of these policies is to promote a flexible labor force under the guise of entrepreneurship and market competition. Furthermore, these policies have a tendency to transfer responsibility for poverty eradication away from state actions and policies to civil society and individual participation in the market.

Title: Of divine import: The Maryknoll missionaries in Peru, 1943–2000
Abstract: In the post World War II era fear of Communism and peasant-based revolutions which pervaded the western hemisphere contributed to religious and political leaders in Central and South America welcoming a veritable flood of foreign missionaries to their countries. It was believed that spiritual and material aid to the regions' poorest people would buttress a religious foundation, alleviate poverty, and promote modernization, thereby staving off the threat of Communism. My research examines the efforts of one mission organization, Maryknoll, to achieve these goals by transforming the predominantly indigenous people of Puno, Peru into modern Catholics and citizens. I examine the development of the missionaries' proselytization and modernization programs and the impact they had on Peru from 1943 to the present. In doing so, I illustrate how the Maryknoll mission movement and its influence were shaped by a combination of global changes that facilitated Maryknollers' settlement in Latin America, ideological influences stemming from the missionaries' communities of origin in the United States, and the missionaries' adaptation to local expectations about the role Catholic clergy should play in society. There was a reciprocal relationship between the missionaries and the people they proselytized so Maryknollers who sought to transform society in Puno by introducing “orthodox Catholicism” and modernization ultimately were transformed themselves. The Maryknoll missionaries who settled in Peru in 1943 were fierce American nationalists, virulent anti-Communists, and doctrinaire Catholics for whom Faith was evidenced by observance of Sacraments and obedience to hierarchy. The missionaries believed implicitly that by introducing their religious practices and elements of modernization including education, medical care, and credit cooperatives they would transform these backward highland regions into modern, progressive centers. By 1968, however, the Maryknollers' goals and ideals appeared transformed. They became vociferous critics of American policy, advocates of social change, and promoters of inter-cultural Catholic faith. My dissertation provides an analysis of global changes that influenced Maryknoll and the local contexts in which these changes were experienced and shows Maryknoll's impact on political and economic development in Peru.

Title: Labor activism and the promotion of a healthier work environment: The case of ergonomics in Brazil
Abstract: The main focus of this research project was the labor's role in the formulation and implementation of Ergonomic Programs developed by joint committees. Qualitative research methods and a social historic approach were applied in two Brazilian instrumental case studies in the service sector: (1) the Private Banking Industry; and (2) the Cashiers' workplace in Retail Food Stores. In both cases, unions were involved in a policymaking process for the prevention of musculoskeletal disorders—MSDs through the application of ergonomic principles. It was found that the ability of both unions and the inspectorate agency to act effectively for a more protective work environment was limited. The policies formulated were not effectively implemented. Brazilian labor movement activism was constrained by external circumstances. There was a decrease in membership and therefore a tighter budget for union actions. Old labor achievements and workers' rights were threatened demanding an extra effort from the union to be maintained. Changes in production methods, in industry and workforce characteristics generated new union demands and forced the unions to promote fast changes in their agenda and OSH (occupational safety and health) issues were not a priority. Failures in the union actions with OSH concerns were also found. Most of the work on this theme was dependent on personal attitudes of unionists and was reactive. Many union leaders reported that OSH organizing threatens the current union leadership power. In addition, because MSDs primarily affected women, they did not receive support from male health professionals and male union leaders. Although the incidence of MSDs is also a product of ergonomic invisible hazards engendered by global and productive restructuring procedures at the point of production, these hazards remained unrecognized by many health professionals, union leaders and workers. Educational programs were required to promote organizing and raising awareness around at least three major issues: (a) the right to work in a healthier work environment; (b) new ergonomic invisible hazards, and (c) gender issues. Furthermore, a successful implementation of a preventive program required worker empowerment and shared commitment between management, the state, unions, and health professionals.

Title: The evolution of piano education in twentieth -century China with emphasis on Shanghai and Beijing conservatories
Abstract: Many brilliant Chinese pianists distinguished themselves on international concert stages since China opened its door to the West in the late 1970s. Being isolated both politically and culturally from the Western world for decades, how did Chinese musicians succeed in the pursuit of Western music? How were they trained? These questions became the main motivation for the current research. The purpose of the study is to trace the evolution of piano education since 1927, the year China saw the establishment of its first professional music institution—the Shanghai Conservatory of Music. The chapters are organized chronologically. The dissertation starts with a brief account of the introduction of Western music and modern piano into China. As cradles for the musicians, the two principal conservatories are the focal points of this paper. Their establishment and the evolution, incorporated with their system and curriculum, are explored throughout the paper. Political movements and wars that closely affected the development of piano education in China are presented to portray the social environment and living condition of the musicians and the survival of the music institution. During China's isolation from the West, Russians were the major musical influence to the Chinese musicians. Since China resumed its diplomatic and cultural exchanges with the West in 1978, Chinese musicians are exposed to new perspectives and innovative methods of teaching. Foreign influences that are crucial to the evolution of piano education are discussed in different sections of the study. First and second-generation Chinese piano teachers were the main forces in the field of piano education. Biographical information of the major piano pedagogues from each generation and an insight view on their teaching philosophies were obtained through personal interviews and written documents. Cultural exchanges with the West brought about important realizations to the music educational system. Recommendations on the further advancement of piano education in China are offered by leading Chinese pedagogues in the concluding chapter.
