Title: The rise of ethical trade advocacy: NAFTA and the new politics of trade
Abstract: This dissertation focuses on three empirically linked questions: (1) who were the new coalitional actors that gained prominence during NAFTA, and why did they coalesce at this time; (2) how did non-governmental actors in the U.S. transform the trade policy debate during NAFTA and beyond; and (3) why were U.S. environmentalists able to achieve greater gains under NAFTA than other coalitional actors, and in particular more than politically influential U.S. labor activists. Because of systemic changes that integrated northern Mexico into U.S. manufacturing and expanded the scope of trade policy into domestic regulatory law, activists in different social movement sectors prior to NAFTA were increasingly coming to view their interests as threatened by the same trade liberalization agenda. This would create the seeds for “ethical trade advocacy,” or advocacy that promotes efforts to maintain regulatory safeguards as economic activity ratchets up from the national to an international level. These ethical trade advocates included activists that had not previously mobilized on trade issues, and they would find their combined strength and full articulation in the NAFTA fight. The ability of domestic actors to influence international regime negotiations depends in part on their own state's receptivity to mobilization at three political levels: (1) the relevant policy domain; (2) the legislative domain; and (3) the larger political action field. Each political level corresponds to a different dominant type of non-governmental leverage: (1) suasion through the alignment of interests in the policy domain; (2) alliances with decision-makers in legislative bodies; and (3) mass mobilization of constituents or organizational members in the broader political action field. Throughout the three years from the announcement of intent until final passage, U.S. NGOs would negotiate among the political fields in a dynamic process. Those non-state actors with alliances with access to the trade domain would focus most of their efforts on advocacy politics. Coalitional actors without such access would pursue a mixed approach that would combine congressional alliances and populace politics. The Bush administration would be able to use access to the trade domain itself to exploit divisions among environmentalists and split the more pro-growth activists from the rest of the cross-sectoral coalition. President Clinton would also exploit the same divisions to find a compromise that furthered environmental aims. Environmentalists would therefore gain substantively from their ability to add to labor's influence in threatening the agreement, while benefiting from their ability to distance themselves from labor concerns. However, the NAFTA battle also demonstrates the continued importance of the systemic international context in which negotiators find themselves. Even the dominance of the U.S. could not guarantee the inclusion of the strong labor rights protections. Mexican and Canadian negotiators would be influenced by their own domestic political configurations; the zero-sum nature of the supplemental agreements would further limit the negotiating leverage of U.S. trade representatives in their efforts to obtain strong protections. Mexican negotiators would risk the failure of the agreement by declaring that their bottom line was the maintenance of their industrial relations system, and U.S. negotiators would have no substantive concessions to offer in exchange for a softening of that stance. Indeed, the labor side agreements would prove insufficient to ensure passage of NAFTA within the U.S. House. Only through the entrepreneurial efforts of Clinton to provide congressional side payments would the treaty be approved by Congress. (Abstract shortened by UMI.)

Title: Provisional mobilities: Rethinking labour through Asian racialization in literature
Abstract: Literary works by writers who have been racialized as “Asian” in North America constitute discursive sites that materialize the urgent need for redistributing the flow of value from capital towards labour. A focus on cultural labour as a space of potential intervention and partial agency in an ongoing negotiation between fluctuating conceptions of the local and the global can facilitate a generative alignment of cultural production with movements seeking social justice. Critical readings of texts that have been written and published in recent years offer situated efforts to imagine and perhaps prompt enactments of solidarity across fields of labour such as menial, sexual and cultural work. The cumulative effect of bringing together a complex of texts that address these fields—such as Loveruage by Ashok Mathur, China Dog and Other Tales From a Chinese Laundry by Judy Fong Bates, The Excluded Wife by Yuen-Fong Woon, fiction and poetry by Evelyn Lau, T his Place Called Absence by Lydia Kwa, Gold by the Inch by Lawrence Chua, Disappearing Moon Cafe by SKY Lee, Baroque-a-nova by Kevin Chong, Exile and the Heart by Tamai Kobayashi, The Very Inside edited by Sharon Lim-Ring, Premonitions edited by Walter Lew, and more—is to value the performance of cultural production as a site from which alliance construction might begin. A refusal to accept the normalized and institutionalized devaluation of racialized and gendered labour performed by “Asian” bodies can translate into coalitional ways of proceeding which incorporate tactics of reciprocity, affiliation, and conjunction without ignoring or eliding power inequities. Reading menial, sexual, and cultural labour into a rapprochement with anti-imperialist and diasporic modes of consciousness can encourage fluencies and dialogues through situating “Asian” in relation to “Aboriginal” and also through the dispersal and conscientious breakdown of “Asian” in examples of textual coalitions otherwise known as anthologies. In the spirit of proliferation, juxtaposition, and affinities in difference, mobile reading practices can provide a process of producing value and have the potential to meet in synergy with other efforts on the long and necessary trajectory of constructing social justice.

Title: Mysticism and utopia: Towards the sociology of self -knowledge and human architecture (a study in Marx, Gurdjieff, and Mannheim)
Abstract: This dissertation explores in an integrative world-historical framework the underlying paradigmatic causes of failure of past utopistic efforts towards a just global society. The conceptual structures of three western utopian, eastern mystical, and academic approaches represented in Marx, Gurdjieff, and Mannheim are studied using a postdeterminist dialectical methodology. Contributions are: (1) problematizing Marx's dialectic itself as a cause of failures of his doctrine; (2) an independent academic assessment of the teaching of Gurdjieff, the Caucasian mystic, using all his writings; (3) transforming Mannheim's sociology of knowledge into a sociology of self knowledge to help revitalize his intentions while avoiding his self-defeating arguments; (4) developing a conceptual synthesis beyond the three teachings within an alternative "human architecture" paradigm; (5) advancing a nonreductive dialectical method cognizant of the challenge posed by subconsciousness in mediations of mind and matter. A fundamental explanation for human failures in bringing about radical change is found to be the problem of habituation, i.e., the human propensity to become subconsciously attached to sensations, ideas, feelings, things, relations, and processes. The key obstacles are identified as the habituated dualisms of mind/matter, self/society, and theory/practice---responsible for the world-historical splitting of the essentially creative human search for the good life into mutually alienated philosophical utopian, religious mystical, and scientific academic movements corresponding to the transitions from ancient civilizations to classical political, medieval cultural, and modern economic empires. The good life cannot be the gift of a wise few, of supernatural forces beyond, or of an objectively preordained progress. Human de-alienation can only be an artful endeavor by each and all---only creative humanism can overcome the habituated fragmentations of utopistic efforts in favor of the good life. The study posits that all dualisms can be transcended through their re-articulation as manifestations of part-whole dialectics. The habituated definition of society as "multiple" ethno-national or civilizational systems of relations among "individuals" is rejected in favor of its definition as a singular world-historical ensemble of intra-, inter-, and extrapersonal self relations. It is argued that human life can be harmonious only when it is a world-system of self-determining individualities. World-history is viewed as a process of splitting of human life into a habituated east-west civilizational dualism whose transcendence is dependent on creative, conscious, and intentional human effort. The sociology of self-knowledge and human architecture are introduced as the study and practice of spatiotemporal part/whole dialectics between here-and-now self-identities and world-historical social structures. Utopistics cannot advance without utopistic universities.

Title: Documenting dreams: Patient -centered records versus practice -centered records
Abstract: This thesis explores how doctors and nurses use documents to share their knowledge within and across healthcare settings. In addressing this question I draw on a 15-month, multi-sited ethnographic study in several pediatric health care settings, following patients from primary care clinics, to emergency rooms, and in-patient units. The analysis focuses on the practices that go into documenting patients' histories and care, which include recordings on various on-line systems, preprinted forms, and whiteboards. By combining the previously distinct lenses of (1) knowing in practice, (2) time-space analysis of social interaction, and (3) communicative genre and genre systems, I suggest that doctors and nurses employ various types of document genres to manage, not only their distributed knowing about patients' care, but also their own movements across time-space. I outline a perspective on documents and knowing which attempts to highlight the role of human practice in how people use documents to coordinate their activities, share their capabilities, and get things done in complex distributed organizational work. The data suggest that doctors and nurses use medical documents as maps and itineraries to organize their distributed work practices. Doctors and nurses record patients' histories many times in different documents, with each document serving as a map and itinerary for a different constituency of people. Each of these documents is rarely used in isolation from other documents. Doctors and nurses constantly recombine the documents they use, which allows them to both appropriate documents from other settings into their local organization of work and build unique local combinations of documents. I introduce the concept of “re-localizing” to describe how doctors and nurses use documents to share their knowing within and across healthcare settings. Re-localization involves many healthcare professionals' parallel rewriting of a patient's history based on a recombination of each other's maps and itineraries and the patient's own accounts. By integrating the concrete case and the maps and itineraries based on those cases the notion of re-localization overcomes the dichotomy between the abstract and the situated, the local and global. Documents are not seen as mere vessels for abstract representations, but integral parts of distributed knowing within and across settings. (Copies available exclusively from MIT Libraries, Rm. 14-0551, Cambridge, MA 02139-4307. Ph. 617-253-5668; Fax 617-253-1690.)

Title: Just history? An argument for critical cosmopolitan histories of harm
Abstract: This dissertation presents an argument for approaches to history-writing that might re-animate the political and ethical projects of `‘history from below’ in the face of the global realities, political and academic, of the twenty-first century. The argument is premised on the conviction that historiography is suasive, and that it is both political (addressing and intervening in relations of power) and moral (necessarily communicating and shaping judgments of value). While revisions to theoretical understandings and changes in the self-definition, the reach and the vigour of social movements have dramatically altered the context for ‘history from below’ as a project, I argue that inequality and violence require, from all of us, critical judgments based on historical understanding—require, that is, ‘just history’. After a review of some of the aims and the accomplishments of what I call ‘challenger histories’, the dissertation addresses three dimensions of history-writing that need re-consideration: the subjects of history, its boundaries, and its production in the academy. With respect to each of these dimensions, I argue against narrow construals of who ‘deserves’ a history (not just workers, say, or women; not just fellow-citizens; not just fellow-scholars), and argue for a cosmopolitan egalitarianism that would encourage the most inclusive possible recognition of moral obligation. At the same time, I argue for an attention to harm as a practice whose effects our histories should illuminate and whose eradication our political practice should seek to effect. Central to my concerns is the question of ‘just history's’ audience. ‘Challenger histories’ typically imagined their subjects and their audiences to be, in some sense, fellows, be that fellowship one of class, gender or nation. I argue that to reconcile the ethical demands of attending to those most harmed and marginalized with the structural constraints of academic knowledge-production requires that we re-consider both who our audiences are and with which rhetorical strategies we might best address them. While earlier ‘challenger histories’ might be said to have encouraged consciousness-building among the powerless in order to make them less so, I argue that academic ‘just history’ might also address the powerful, to demonstrate, and to encourage critical reflection on, the harms in which they (we) are implicated. My argument, then, is that ‘just history’ will entail critical cosmopolitan histories of harm.

Title: Indigenous federations, NGOs, and the state: *Development and the politics of culture in Ecuador's Amazon
Abstract: This dissertation studies indigenous federations in Amazonian Ecuador, and the historically changing relationships between them and the Ecuadorian state, national and international non-governmental development organizations (NGOs), and multinational oil companies. Their interaction is partially situated within conflicting understandings of development and its objectives, in which development is understood both in economic and cultural terms. State elites and NGO personnel typically view development in terms of economic modernization, and state policies and NGO projects for Amazonian indigenous communities have included agrarian reform, colonization, and the wider participation of indigenous people in the market economy. Elites and NGOs attempt to impose particular visions of economic and cultural behavior on indigenous people as “backwards” and “underdeveloped,” while hoping to transform them into “modern,” “productive” national citizens. Since the 1960s, indigenous leaders have used federations to contest these models of development by negotiating with and/or challenging state and NGO officials, rejecting the perpetuation of culturally-based hierarchies with pseudo-racial undertones which relegate indigenous people to the bottom. Increasingly since the 1980s, and in the context of neoliberal reforms and the rapid growth of NGOs in Ecuador and elsewhere, indigenous leaders, instead of rejecting “development” altogether, have used it as a stake in cultural politics by forging alliances with sustainable development and conservation NGOs. They have proposed alternative visions of development to reconfigure local economies in culturally-sensitive terms, dismantle prevailing “racial” hierarchies, and reconceptualize the Ecuadorian nation as plurinational. The study of indigenous federations helps broaden our understanding of the relationships between social movements and the state in the context of economic, political, and socio-cultural processes shaping them. Ideologies of development, globally conceived by international development organizations and locally implemented through neoliberal reforms, decentralization, and permissive expansion of NGOs, present a multi-dimensional stage on which economic and cultural politics are played out. This has further implications for our understanding of “race,” ethnicity, and the politics of culture, as development ideologies and practices generate prescriptions for the ethnic and cultural (pseudo-racial) composition of local populations. Development becomes intertwined with issues of cultural politics and national identity, as different actors create and contest conflicting representations of each other.

Title: From above and below: The Mormon embrace of revolution, 1840–1940
Abstract: Scholars have traced Mormonism's 19th century revolutionary nationalism, but the leadership's response to the revolutions of other peoples has received little attention. The Mormon hierarchy believed that Christ's return represented the millenarian “revolution from above” that would catapult them to global leadership. Driven west, the Revolutions of 1848 opened another narrative. Revolts “from below” would overthrow the privileged classes and dignify the masses. Revolution weakened traditional loyalties and destroyed the religious, political, and social monopolies that inhibited missionary work. To expresses their millennialism, Mormon leaders integrated the language and symbols pioneered by secular revolutionaries. This dissertation argues that revolution sustained the Mormon view of history. God was omniscient. He projected his power in the medium of time through the agency of man. World events became a source of canon. If revolution was possible, ran the logic, then it was God's will to pursue it. Revolution often endowed Mormon scriptural interpretations with new meaning. Mormon acceptance of revolution shows their millennial theology as a progressive discourse. The dialectical movement of history would produce global conditions imagined in French democratic totalitarianism: universal property, brotherhood, personal fulfillment, and endowments of knowledge and responsibilities that citizenship in the earthly kingdom conveyed. Mormons, like revolutionary utopians, condoned force. The object was to shape society into what it could become. After 1890 assimilation with normative values accelerated, but the Mormon script resisted total Americanization. Anti-capitalist and anti-imperialist undercurrents continued to inform Mormon views of the external world. The Mexican Revolution and political coups in South America in 1930–1931 let Latter-day Saint leaders explore the global implications of their message for 50 years beyond the abandonment of polygamy and the political kingdom of God. The crises of the 1930s collapsed Mormon faith in progress toward a rational world illuminated with spiritual understanding. Furthermore, socioreligious radicalism lost relevance in an institutionalized Church. That leading Mormon leaders ratified efforts in post revolutionary Mexico and the Soviet Union suggests their internal uneasiness with incorporation and their yearning for utopia.

Title: For the pleasures of it: Novel objects and enlightened subjects in eighteenth-century England
Abstract: Eighteenth-century England's transformation into a consumer and global society entangled an “ethics of artifice” with object-oriented markers of subjectivity. Richardson's Clarissa , Burney's Camilla and Evelina and Cleland's Memoirs of a Woman of Pleasure , as well as prose by Fielding, Mandeville, Addison and Steele, and libertine verse, show that as manufactured and exotic commodities crowded eighteenth-century England, its human inhabitants became intensely aware of their power to supplement, as well as ornament the self. Commodity culture worked in productive tension with Enlightenment standards of knowing as evinced in experimental methods and empirical philosophy to animate the mutable and fictive potentials of the modern human subject. Treating the novel as a lively aesthetic site for representing new forms of subjectivity, I argue that its grammar of objects—those bountiful catalogues of “minute particulars”—not only reflects a new public access to exotic goods promising status and beauty, but also, converts the self into “a thing.” Remaining interested in tracing the languages of objects and objectivity in eighteenth-century English novels while dwelling also on the “originality” of their form, my work joins the dialogue started by Ian Watt and Michael McKeon in their respective books Rise of the Novel and Origins of the English Novel . My study diverges from theirs, though, in moving beyond a focus on “the novel” as a privileged aesthetic form that contains, reflects or produces social values in an imaginative fashion, and viewing it as a constitutive element in eighteenth-century culture's more pervasive movements of novelty. Such artifacts of eighteenth-century culture as waxworks, fashion dolls, automata, and scientific and sexual instruments. I show, not only collaborated with the novel by striving to imitate the human subject, but also, by devising new tools for eighteenth-century subjects to fashion identities in a world increasingly dominated by objects.

Title: A life of resistance: Ada Prospero Marchesini Gobetti (1902–1968)
Abstract: For most historians, the word Resistenza or Resistance refers specifically to the fight to liberate Italy from German occupation that took place from September 1943 to April 1945. My analysis of Ada Gobetti's “life of resistance” proposes a broader definition, one that includes not only armed resistance during wartime, but any action that fought against the obstruction of freedom, the limitation of human rights, or the restriction of knowledge imposed by a political power. Ada's resistance activities comprised actions not often considered under the rubric of resistance, such as translating a controversial historical work from English into Italian, which was censored by the Fascists in 1939, and writing an anti-Fascist children's book in 1940. While the Resistenza represented a culmination of more than twenty years of anti-Fascist activity for Ada, it also brought the beginning of an awareness of the specific talents, needs, and rights of Italian women, more than one hundred thousand of whom participated in the Resistenza . This realization led Ada to organize other Italian women into defense and assistance groups and to found an underground women's newspaper. In early 1945, she crossed the Alps on foot and made contact with women in the French Resistance in Grenoble. Ada's “coming of age” during the Resistenza provides us with a fresh view of the Resistenza as a liberator of women's strengths and possibilities. After the war ended, Ada's experience as a resister developed into a constructive political and social activism. As vice mayor of Turin, she fought openly for the rights of women and children in Italian society. She witnessed the birth of the Italian Republic, officially proclaimed on 18 June 1946 after the first election where women could vote, and worked to integrate women into the decision-making process of the country. Ada also became deeply involved in the international women's rights movement, traveling to Paris, Berlin, and China as a representative from Italy. For Ada Gobetti, resistance to tyranny and oppression became a way of life, part of a profound commitment to humanity, justice, and freedom.

Title: New media activism: Alternative media and new technologies from video to the digital age
Abstract: Since the introduction of the Sony Portapak, the first commercially available video camera in the late 1960s, alternative media practitioners in the United States have utilized new and emerging electronic media technologies to support their political and social activism. This dissertation focuses on three major new media forms that have been integral to activism in the United States since the late 1960s: video, satellite broadcasting and the Internet. Specifically, I examine how alternative media collectives have been early adopters of new communication technologies and create their own systems of alternative communication, including the production, exhibition and distribution of progressive, radical and activist media texts. While many analyses of this topic have been conducted in the fields of communication, political science, sociology and journalism, this dissertation approaches the study of activism and new media primarily from the methodologies of cinema and television studies, especially documentary and avant-garde film theories. I analyze several widely circulated activist media texts, including Top Value Television's (TVTV) video Four More Years (1972), Deep Dish Television's television series Gulf Crisis TV Project (1991), and the Independent Media Center's (IMC) video Showdown in Seattle (1999) and web site at www.indymedia.org. Using these representative examples, I argue that alternative media texts frequently blur the boundaries between documentary and avant-garde techniques. Alternative media productions often utilize documentary-style realism combined with avant-garde sensibilities in order to merge media production, politics and everyday life into a transformational political and social praxis. Finally, these grassroots, independent, non-corporate media practices exist in a core-periphery relationship to dominant hegemonic media, and I examine the introduction of each new major technology within and against the political economy of mainstream corporate media. Thus, I situate alternative media production within its industrial, material and historical contexts: the video collectives Videofreex and TVTV during the age of network television broadcasting in the early 1970s; Paper Tiger Television and Deep Dish Television and their creation of a national alternative media network in the age of satellite broadcasting in the 1980s and 1990s; and since 1999, the global IMC movement and their use of emerging digital technologies in the digital age.

Title: Neoliberalism and democracy? The gendered restructuring of work, unions and the Colombian public sphere
Abstract: This dissertation investigates the political and economic outcomes of financial service restructuring in Colombia following the implementation of neoliberal reforms. Through an examination of the impacts of restructuring on the socio-economic and political security of workers, I challenge neoliberal assertions of the causal links between globalization and democracy. This project develops a critical analytical framework for understanding the relationship between economic and political liberalization by looking closely at how labor market restructuring processes affect the everyday lives of workers. Through an in-depth analysis of how the political lives and subjectivities of financial service workers have been affected by workplace reforms, I contribute to wider debates on the relationship between work and citizenship. This multi-scalar analysis traces the mechanisms of neoliberalism from the arenas of international investment down to the lived experiences of workers and unionists. I suggest that restructuring strategies such as downsizing, peripheralization and outsourcing operated through and reinforced unequal gender and class subjectivities of workers and exacerbated economic and political insecurity and marginalization. I explore the response of women workers and banking unionists to the unrealized opportunities promised by both neoliberal and democratic reforms. I track the emergence of new political identities forged through the struggles of women banking unionists to democratize the labor movement and to draw attention to the differing concerns of women and other marginalized workers in the face of neoliberal restructuring. I analyze the ways in which women unionists draw from their experiences of empowerment and inclusion in social movements in attempts to expand the direct participation and decision-making power of women workers and unionists. This research included a pre-dissertation study was conducted in Bogotá in 1997 and fieldwork carried out from 1999–2000. In order to overcome the obstacles of carrying out research in the context of Colombia's ongoing civil war, I developed a feminist, participatory and engaged approach that allowed me to directly address differences of power and vulnerability. This largely qualitative study included in-depth interviews, ethnography, participant observation and the gathering of secondary data. Key methodological techniques included in-depth interviews, ethnography and participant observation.

Title: Capital and punishment: The privatization of prisons in America
Abstract: This dissertation offers an ethically framed deconstruction of the political, economic, social and cultural forces that have informed privatization's recent re-emergence. Chapter 1 presents an historic synopsis of the money/punishment amalgam, traces the experience of key stakeholders, CCA and Wackenhut, and presents a précis of present policy and research issues. Chapter 2 examines the policy in light of the new global economy. It traces the relationship between the diminution of state-based legitimative clout and the privatization of correctional facilities. By repositioning seemingly intractable governance issues within the more fashionable discourse of efficient management, privatization offers the illusion of downsizing while functioning to increase the state's punitive reach. The prison industrial complex has proffered prisons as an economic solution to a range of socio-political problems, including the need for rural development and the question of what to do with economically unproductive populations. Chapter 3 discusses the symbolic and concrete ramifications of public/private divide. It asks whether a greater reliance on the “private” privileges the emotive and the vengeful at the expense of the considered and the just. At the same time, it examines whether the singular, uncompetitive features of the corrections industry are amenable to market place discipline. Chapter 4 traces the relationship between an exaggerated piety, a veneration for business acumen and the privatization movement. It suggests the importance of our Puritan, Social Darwinian legacy. Proffering penal expansion as counterpoint to a fragmented, postmodern polity. Chapter 5 examines the structural etiology and ramifications of an ever more punitive sentencing structure. Chapter 6 concludes that privatization fails to meet a spectrum of ethical tenets. Essentially neutral to normative mandates, beneficent, non-maleficent obligations are extrinsic to privatization's profit-focused objectives. (Abstract shortened by UMI.)

Title: Race and responsible government: Woodrow Wilson and the Philippines
Abstract: Woodrow Wilson never wavered in his belief that “Americanism,” his term for the Americanization of the international mind, constituted the best path to progress at home and abroad. Accepting the myth of American exceptionalism, he believed that America should not become entangled with Europe lest its character become eroded. A new foreign policy, “thoroughly American” in purpose, had to be devised. Wilson sought acceptance of American democratic values by other societies in order to “redeem” them. This would permit American leadership in the world without involving the United States in the Old World's diplomacy and wars. Wilson's faith in American exceptionalism is evident in his ideas about how to regenerate the world through the proliferation of democracy. He translated the experiences of America's democratic growth into principles that were universally applicable throughout the world. Wilson believed that if the twentieth-century world was to be open, safe and free, then it must become more like America. Democracy had to be based on “civic manhood,” the cultural and political requisite of political stability. “Civic manhood,” the quintessential virtue of mature races and the cornerstone of Americanism, involved a demonstrated commitment to Anglo-Saxon culture; an observance of progressive change from above; a faith in free enterprise; and an embrace of Protestant Christianity. Wilson considered the propagation of this blueprint for nation-building to be America's mission in the world. Americanism transcended Anglo-Saxonism, the “White Man's Burden,” and the Social Gospel movement. While its dimensions were complex and often contradictory, the objective of Americanism was simple: the fusion of American and world conceptions of progress, security, and prosperity through the worldwide extension of American-style democracy. Wilson first articulated his view of America's mission in the world in association with the Philippine question. He believed it was critical to keep Philippine policy in line with America's redemptive mission in the world. Failure to do so would yield disastrous consequences for democracy in the Philippines and America's credibility as “redeemer nation.”

Title: Out of hand: Experimental media practices by women
Abstract: Out of Hand: Experimental Media Practices by Women surveys a 30-year history of feminist media production, including film, video, installation, and new media, charting the projects of artists who work tactically, using the term as it is defined by French theorist Michel de Certeau. The study charts shifts in technology, working methods, feminist issues, and the notion of an alternative media practice within the United States, focusing mainly on feminist media projects from 1990 forward. The study also situates these projects in the larger contexts of the history of avant-garde cinema, video art, and the art world, illustrating links to the poststructuralist tactics of appropriation, narrative experimentation, and identity subversion that characterize feminist artwork in general. The study also tackles the ways in which contemporary feminist media artists are continuing to grapple with how to understand and resist the sense of political and social disorientation that in the early 1990s helped reduce what remained of a feminist movement to near non-existence. Another issue asks where, as the entertainment, telecommunication, and international business industries continue to merge, should political resistance occur? Underlying these larger political questions is the ongoing project of rethinking the subject, dramatically questioned in terms of the matrix of race, class, and gender in 1960s experimental film and video and now reconfigured with attention to phenomenological inflections of the world around us, and to technology. A third issue is that of the body, now understood to be thoroughly imbricated in technology such that the boundary separating body and machine has become malleable, with one the supplement to the other. While much attention has been paid in feminist analysis to the political insurgency of the notion of the cyborg, the complex interconnectedness of the body, both physical and psychic, within an increasingly altered conception of space and time, demands more consideration. Finally, the destabilization of the spatial realm and the rethinking of our abilities for cognitive mapping are radically altering how we conceptualize all acts, and therefore the very possibility for resistance.

Title: Globalization, peace and discontent: Israel and Northern Ireland
Abstract: The oscillation of the conflicts in Israel and Northern Ireland in recent years between advances towards peaceful resolution and regressions to new cycles of bloodshed were explained by the inherent difficulties of territorial compromise, security threats, and effective political campaigns drawing on fears. This dissertation proposes an entirely different explanation that involves an analysis at the International level, regarding the process of globalization, at the national level, at globalization's more local effects on the social structures and institutions and a historical study comparing two different periods of globalization. The point of departure of this work is that globalization is a transformation of the world system through a “hegemonic crisis”. Comparing two periods in which hegemonic crises occurred, the decline of the “Pax Britannica” of the late 19 th century and the American “embedded liberalism” of the late 20 th century, this work examines their effect on the dynamics of the conflicts and their resolutions. The first part, which explores the early period of globalization and the related development of the two conflicts, is an historical research based upon secondary materials. The second part, which focuses on the current period of globalization, is based on a combination of primary and secondary materials. Primary materials include archival research, review of media reports and a series of open interviews with leading businessmen involved in the peace process. They were interviewed for the purpose of identifying the perceptions of businessmen of the peace process and globalization, assessing their involvement in the peace process and their impact upon it. The period of early globalization was characterized by growing nationalism and a territorializing drive and influenced the crystallization of the Jewish, Palestinian and Irish national movements. The current period of globalization is characterized by a tension between de-territorializing and re-territorializing developments. While the former created new incentives for the business class and affiliates to support resolution of the conflicts the latter created “spoilers” who perceived negatively the peace process and globalization. The tension between the two explains the impasses the two peace processes face, yet different local circumstances and local-global interactions explain the different outcomes of the processes.

Title: Research On Development of Chinese Private Economy
Abstract: Abstract 1. The Significance of Research. The renascence and rapid-development of private economy has become a prominent phenomenon in China since the reform and opening up. Thus, it is a research work of both practical and theoretical significance to analyze the problems existing in private economy and raise the proper solutions to them. This dissertation centers on the key word DEVELOPMENT, and deals with three problems. Firstly, figuring out the social and economic origins of the renascence of the private economy, depicting its tracks of developments and changes; then, summarizing the traits of the developments of the private economy in China. Secondly, expounding and pining the foundation of the existence of private economy in three main aspects: productive force determinism, mixture ownership and socialism marketing economy determinism. Thirdly, Focusing on analyzing the existing problems of privately-owned enterprise, from the outside surroundings of privately-owned enterprise development, money raising problem and administration mechanism creativeness, then raising saluting tailings and relating tactics. 2. Dissertation composition. The dissertation induces 9 chapters. The first chapter is the introduction. In this chapter, it firstly expounds the motivation and significance of this dissertation, defining the meaning of Private Economy. Then it introduces the undergoing situation in studies on private economy by academia. Finally, it introduces the studying method and composition of this dissertation, focusing on analyzing and defining the meaning of Private Economy. This dissertation dissents from the phenomenon commonly existing in theories circles and enterprises circles that the nongovernmental business taking the place of private economy. It points out that nongovernmental business is an operating pattern. This phenomenon just shows the apprehension, discrimination and prejudice towards private economy in somebody’s mind. In chapter 2, it analyses the social and economic conditions of the regeneration of private economy at the beginning of the reform and its following development. It analyzes three basic terms of the regenerations private economy from a view of production logic: Firstly, the individual must have some capital accumulation, but the primitive capital accumulation of the privately owned enterprises in China depends mainly on diligence, which is different from the capitalism society. Secondly, there must be an opening productive factors and commodity market, providing a broad market conditions for the emergence of private economy. Thirdly, the policies should provide legitimacy for the production. The development of china’s private economy could generally be decide into four phrases: the first phrase (1978-1988) is the period of its germination and preliminary development. The second phrase (1989-1992) is the period of its fluctuation; 1992-2002 is its third phrase, when the private economy came into a period of stable development, and its position rose quickly in national economy. After the opening of the 16th Chinese Community Party at the end of 2002, private economy came into its fourth phrase—a new and vigorous rising period. In chapter 3, the dissertation illustrates the developments of private economy after 1989 by using numbers of statistics data. It expounds from 4 aspects: Firstly, showing general conditions of private enterprises’ development from their numbers, registered capital, employees, value of output, consumer goods entail amount and enterprise scale, then pointing out that it’s the fastest developing economy component after reform and opening and up. Secondly, analyzing the private economy’s importance in National Economy increase by promoting economy increase tax increase labor admission. Export foreign exchange earning and other aspects. Thirdly, by analyzing the distribution conditions, traits and causes of the private economy in the three industries and specific trade, pointing out that it mainly distributes in the processing and manufacturing industry, commerce and accommodation industry currently. There’s on of fen private enterprises in other fields. At last, it analyzes the town and country distribution, area distribution and city clistribation conditions, traits and causes. Pointing out that private economy mainly distributed in the urban, eastern area and economically developed provinces in china. In chapter 4, the dissertation summarizes the traits of private economy in china. Its main characteristics are: 1. Regressive growth in economy system. 2. Its growth expedited a position chime — from supplementing component outside the system to important one inside the system. 3. Private capital increases quickly in value in china, but it’s at its alimentary phrase generally. 4. Many private enterprises are developing under concealment. 5. There are no abundant explanations of the existence and development of private property rights theoretically in china. In chapter 5, the dissertation analyzes and assesses three-motivation theory of the necessary existence and development of the private economy in China. Productive force determinism argues that productive force development decides the existence and development of Private Economy. In this dissertation, it points out that the contradictory movement principle of the productive force and production relationship in Marxism is a right principle forever. But the relation between productive-force and productive material ownership forms is not a simple corresponding one. We can’t simplify Productive Force Determinism to productive force multi-stratification correspondence theory Mixing Ownership theory argues that neither contemporary capitalism nor Chinese Socialism marketing economy is founded on the basis of single ownership form and economy operating system. But both of them are mixing economy—coexistence of public and private ownership, and concurrence of planned economy and marketing economy. Besides affirmation of its mixing trait, the dissertation points out that there are still vast differences between the two in generating mechanism and basically traits. And analyzes the different function positioning in Chinese and western mixing economy emphasizing that socialism marketing economy is a kind of ecological economy. Marketing Economy System Determinism argues that socialism marketing economy system underlies the existence, and development of the Private Economy in China. The present dissertation considers that the private economy is an accentual micro-basic indispensable socialism marketing economy, which demands poly-subjects’ competition, Additionally, it analyses the important role played by the private economy in the development of socialism marketing system, and points out that the private economy and public ownership economy not only compete and confront against each other, but also complement to each other. In chapter 6, the present dissertation analyzes the development trend of the private economy in china. Firstly, it analyzes its position in national economy and its future orientation, and points out that its role has changed from complimentary one to major mainstay of basic economy system at the elementary phrase of socialism, But its position in ownership construction is still a complimentary one, For its orientation, I think it would most probably play a major role, but we can’t make specific vision and depiction, Secondly, it analyzes many favorable conditions for the private economy in the new century as follows: Besides state-owned economies strategic adjustment WTO provides precious developing chance for it. Perfecting socialism marketing economy system creates advantageous system conditions for the further development of private economy, loose policy surroundings and economy environment also push forward it development positively, At last, the essay points out the development trend of production form, management level, industry construction, area distribution and other aspects of the private economy. Chapter 7 analyzes the external factors which restrict the development of private enterprises. It points out four extreme factors that are still restricting the development of the pirate enterprises. The first factor exists in people’s t way of thinking, including their rejection to the “private” and the traditional ideology of “solely economic composition theory” and “paying more attention to the ethic than to profit” and “paying more attention to the public wellbeing than to the private imterestes”, which has limited the passion and motivation for the creation of the fortune. Thus the society should build a culture and value system that would adapt to the development of the market economy.The second factor exists in the currier policies and regulations. It mainly presents as: the policies and regulations for the private economy have never got one of the frame of “utilizing, limiting. There are not enough statutes to ensure the property right of the private enterprise. The legislation for the main bodies of the market is sill at the phase of Dual System. And the social services can not adapt to or satisfy the needs of the development of private enterprises. The efforts of the government are still needed to construct a environment with regulation treats everybody equally without discrimination and encourages fair competition.Thirdly, there are some factors in the macro-management system, including some obscurities and conflicts on the definition of the administrative rights of the private economy. Besides, the situation of multi-department supervision stillexist under the mode of planned economy, So we should strengthen the macro-management for the private economy and enhance the servicing function to the private economy according to the requirements of the market economy. Fourthly it talks the challenges to the private enterprises in our country after we enter the WTO. The private enterprises should build up a global horizon and be familiar with the game rules as soon as possible to foster and enhance the international competition ability. Chapter 8 investigates the reasons for and proposes some approaches to, the difficulties in financing of the private enterprise. It points out two reasons: the inner reasons and the eternal reasons. The eternal reasons are that it is hard for private enterprises to gain support from credit market and capital market since our country’s special ownership structure and economy system formed in the switching period. The development of the private financial enterprises was also confined for the since teen. Additionally, there used to be some “identity discrimination” to the private economy in people’s awareness which results in the difficulty in financing of the private enterprises.The inner reasons are that most of the private enterprises are small in scale, asymmetry in information, not good in credit condition and not wholesome in hypothecate system. These factors increase the difficulties of financing. To solve the problems of the financing of the private enterprises, we should firstly deepen the reform of the financing system, actively develop different kinds of nongovernmental business banks and other financing institutions, especially private banks. Meanwhile, we should build and perfect the service system for the middle and smallsized enterprises. Chapter 9 discusses the property right and organization system in the private enterprises. It mainly teats of three problems: firstly, it explains present conditions of the organization system in Chinese private enterprises from the view of the evolvement of organization form of the financing in the nation’s private enterprises, decision-making system and etc., which bring forward the conclusion that the main characteristics of the inner management in Chinese private enterprises is family-dominant model. Secondly, it analyzes the problems of the property right system and organization system in Chinese private enterprises, including the centralization of the property right . 3.Main opinions and new creations. This paper brings forward the following opinions based on the summarizing, and absorbing existed academic research: 1.When comes to the definition of the meaning of the “private enterprises”, it claims to abolish Temporary Regulations for private enterprises in People’s Republic of China as soon as possible, to cease the division criteria of “seven employees no and eight employees yes” in the registration of the private enterprises, and to point out that private economy is a different definition from nongovernment economy . 2.On the basis of analyzing the condition of renaissance, development history and status quo of Chinese private enterprises, the thesis points out that the growing of the Chinese private enterprises was in a retroverse direction, growing from outer-institution to the inter-institution, obscured development and some other characteristics. From the scale, technology and facility, the level of management and some other factors, the Chinese private enterprises are mostly in the elementary phase. 3.The productivity is not simply correlated to the ownership of the produce materials. There seems to be no logical relationship between the form of the ownership and the productivity. It is not reliable both in theory and practice to conclude that the theory of the existence and development of Chinese private enterprises is the same as the theory of the multi-hierarchy and imbalanced development of productivity. 4. Modern market economy is a specific mutually complementary and coexistence economy group formed between different ownerships and forms of different economic operation systems and economic organizations. It is an impersonal phenomena in the mixed ownership system that some economic constitutions is main, while some others are subsidiary and all of them are mutually complementary and coexistence. Social market economy is also a kind of eco-economy. It needs the competition from various main bodies. It requires the force of the market competition to decide and adjust the proportion of the public ownership and private ownership in order to construct a dynamic mixed ownership structure that are suitable for the requirement of the development of the productivity. 5.To eliminate the outer unharmonious factors that restrict the development of the private enterprises, we should erect the conception of storing fortune for the people and treat the rich well in our mind and get rid of the frame of “utilizing and limiting” in regulation and adopt the measures that treat everybody equally without discrimination and encourage fair competition and modify the constitution to improve the statutes that protect the private estate in order that the private fortune has the same constitutional protect as the public fortune. 6.The reasons for the difficulties of the financing of the private enterprises has transformed rapidly from the “personal identification” discrimination to system obstacles and a symmetry in greeting in foremen. To settle the embarrassment of financing of the private sectors, the key is to break the situation that state-owned financing organization monopolizes the credit market and state-owned enterprises monopolizes the capital market, and to actively support and develop the nongovementel financing organization, especially some private financing organization such as the private bank. 7.Presently, there are some problems with the private enterprises including: the concentration and the singularity of the property right, the prevalence of the management under the mode of family-experience dominant, obvious family and politic love knot of the property right main body, undetachment of the ownership right and operation right, and low culture making and management level of the enterprise owner and etc confronted with these problems, we should promote the transforming the Chinese private enterprises from of the family-dominant operation mode to the normative modern corporation mode from three latitude: the right of controlling, management station and corporation configuration. Key word: private economy, fair competition, encourage development.

Title: The sustainable research of theme parks
Abstract: The theme park is a kind of the new modernistic garden style that appeared in Euramerica in the beginning of 21 century. Theme parks in china emerged as the times require in 1980's. After a illustrious and overdeveloped period, nowadays theme parks in china, as a kind of carrier for civic recreational activities, have those two problems: 1. The macroscopical plan is not do its best, and lacks in surveying in base of the whole civic ecology. So that, economic movement and operation overweights attention to ecology,temporary behavior replaces long-term benefit, and individual will controls whole regulation.2. Planning designs have all their goods in the window superficialness, and lack in colligated designs from origin of the rules of the recreational planning. So that, profits as a basic exceeds human as a basic, business running weakens recreational experience, and assembled things blot out rude ideas.Above all, through the research of the development background and course of international theme parks, the present treatise is intended to make a brief illumination of the mainstream of the theme-park design by visual angle of the design mode. That means that cooperation, among subjects and interposition of leading technological ideas, has been changing the theme-park plan mode. Further, by visual angle of respectively tourism system, civic ecology, city planning & landscape ecology, and territorial economics, the article searches the theoretic basic of the sustainable research of theme parks. At the same time, it's pointed out that the increasingly social function of theme parks surely makes big theme parks as green living rooms in cities. As a result, the conclusions of the article are two design methods to realize the sustainable development of theme parks. Firstly, theme parks should take the improvement of civic ecologic environment as a prime function. Secondly, theme parks themselves should be also a sustainable organism. Otherwise, the suggestion about the corresponding programming, evaluation and management system is involved, too.

Title: Research on College System Management Mode in China
Abstract: College system is the most common and the most successful management mode among colleges and universities abroad. The universities and colleges in our country have been carrying out "University/College-Department" two-stage management mode. With the establishment of social market economy and the further reformation of university interior management mode, many universities and colleges have started to carry out college system since the reformation in 1978. College system reformation is still a newborn subject, a nonstandard college interior management mode, which right now is in the beginning stage both in theoretical research and in practical performance. College system reformation has been the key content in our university management mode reformation since the 1990s and it is also the key point and difficult point in the new round of university management mode reformation in the 21st century. It is rather necessary to learn experience from colleges abroad, to combine the reality of our universities, and to further our research. The significance of this study is to expose the reason of college system in theory and explain how the high schools could carry out the college system in practice. With the theory of modern education economy management as support and the implying of methods of documents analysis and social investigation, "Research on College System Management Mode of Chinese Universities" sums up the problems existing in the management mode reformation of Chinese universities, generalizes systematically the development of college system management mode, summarizes the reformation trend and analyzes the current problems in the present reformation. This passage studies the principles the reformation should follow and put forward the principles to establish the college management mode, which is suitable to Chines e present condition. The paper consists of five parts. Part One is Chapter One: " The Significance of Research on College System Management Mode of Chinese Universities ". This part puts forward the problems in Chinese College system. That is, with the further reformation of college management mode, with the enlargement of college scale, with the development of science and technology and the requisition of the change in college organization after joining WTO, some problems are urgent to be settled during the course of College System Management Mode Reformation. This chapter also sums up the research results of relevant scholars and raises the aim and meaning for this research.? Part Two consists of Chapter Two?"The Historical Development of College System Management Mode" and Chapter Three ? "Motivation Analysis of College System Reformation in China". This part studies the formation, types and reformation trend of college system abroad and sums up the content of college system reformation. This part points out that the college system reformation is dominated by the law of college education, driven by knowledge economy, market economy, popularization of the college education and the international environment. It is also the result of a series of conflict movement and administration impetus inside the college system. The reasons that cause the bad result of the reformation are the lack of the theoretical preparation, the incorrect understanding, the habitual in fluence, the barrier in culture, the adjustment in benefit, the question in management and the time delay in adaptation.? Part Three consists of Chapter Four ?"Resource Composition is the Base of the System Reformation " and Chapter Five--- "The Nature of College System Reformation is the Specialty of Collage Organization". This part mainly discusses the reason for college system. It also points out that under the condition of market economy, the manner of material allocation inside colleges should give play to the government's leading role and the role of market. But at the same time the manner should adapt the administrative rank system and should prevent the market system from playing fundamental function. College system is the best way of allocat ion. This part analyzes the characters of college academic organization, major organization and administrative organization, therefore, demands that universities/colleges should adapt college system management mode. Part Four consists of Chapter Six? "The Core of College System Reformation is the Integrity of Subjects" , Chapter Seven ? " the Critical Point of College System Reformation is the Allocation of Power ", Chapter Eight ---"the Core of College System Reformation is the Design of Organization Structure" and Chapter Nine "the aim of college system reformation is to raise the beneficial result of running a school." This part expounds the relation between subject integrity and college system reformation, the content of subject integrity. This part explains the allocation problem, allocation principle, and discusses in several levels the power running system in the college system. Uhis part also analyzes the types, design elements and principles of college organization, analyzes the function of matrix college system and deals with the scale benefit, structure benefit, investment benefit, arrangement efficiency, and the countermeasure in carrying out college system.? Part Five consists of Chapter Ten "Principles for Practicing College System". This part points out that the practice of the college system reformation is a very complex system engineering, which should be led under the principle of human-orientation, practicing target management, carrying out entity operation, giving prominence to feature site and adjusting measures accordingly

Title: On the systematic study of the development and changes of China's journalism education
Abstract: New trends in China's journalism education are inevitable. The changes and development must hence be rooted either on the basis of the succession, original reproduction and further development of the traditional education, or on the basis of the integration between humanities and science, of its mergence with the advanced model of the international journalism education. Set in a full-scoped research, the paper, using the theoretical studies (from two different approaches) as the starting points, carries out the detailed analysis on factors like process, characteristics, motivation and the like that promote and restrain development of the 80-year-old China's journalism education. The author then divides it into several phases like the budding and formation, the primary development, readjustment, crisis, recovery, popularity and prosperity. With its development and changes as the object, in the background of the condition of the current China's journalism, education and society, the author puts forward the reasons for the above division. There are also a detailed description of the scale, teaching and the department representatives of the journalism education at various stages on one side, and on the other, of the journalism thoughts of some famous journalist educators. The paper holds that the coming into being and the initial development of China's contemporary journalism offers a hotbed for the formation of China's journalism education, while the establishment of the system lays a strong foundation for the very formation. The author also points out that the New Culture Movement provides an incentive for the birth of China's journalism education, and that the setting up of the Journalism Society in Beijing University marks the very beginning of China's journalism education. The earlier journalism education focuses on the importance of newspaper education, the trainees of which are characterized as that of the practical, like craftsman, and the management model is also shaped by that of the American. Since the foundation of the new regime in 1949, China's journalism education has been greatly affected by the Soviet style for quite a considerable length of time before finding its own road for its development, which is clearly shown from the fact that there appeared a booming period for opening journalism schools. Disastrous to all, China's journalism education met its irrevocable destruction during the Cultural Revolution, yet it will be accepted if we take the premises that are destroyed into consideration. Its vitality is recovered with the opening-up. For the past 20 years, it has made remarkable progresses and breakthroughs owing to the guidance of the Party and the government, to the improved environment, especially to the hard work of thousands of press workers and teachers. As to China's journalism education itself, the involvement of political parties, groups and press media, individuals and the foreign journalist thoughts contributes a lot to its development. Its education demonstrates differently due to the patron organizations and the different historical stages. Yet, as far as the training model concerned, there is a transition from the comparative unitary model to the compound model to produce all-round talents on the basis of the integration between humanities and science. This transition from application orientation and knowledge and technique focuses to human-science basis and the academic, international competitiveness orientation marks the beginning of China's journalist talents' image in the world's journalist platform. Accordingly, it is essential for China's journalism education to take globalization path. This path is characterized as the reestablishment of training aims, reconstruction of the teaching material, building a qualified teaching staff of a higher academic level, taking a path prioritizing either on humanities or on science, expansion of international exchanges and cooperation. The development will be impossible without the support from the journalism studies, the improvement of the political, economic and humanity conditions, with specially the social and historical development offering its outcome. Only through a harmonious interaction and mutual support between journalism education and such factors, can it progresses with the time in its peculiar way in the internalization and globalization, so that in the context of China's accession to WTO, China's journalism education may work out wonderful talents for the world's press a nd furthermore to outpace the world's journalism education.

Title: Urban water industry reformate of china
Abstract: Abstract Rencent years,after communication, civil aviation and bank industry, reformation of water industry began to effect. Especially after Chinese entry to WTO, the market of water industry gave access to social and foreign capital. Although the WTO items do not involve the issue of admission, this market do not exit the period of protection. Now the enterprises in water industry inevitably confront the whole international market, so the market is free from the regional monopoly. At present, the reformation of water industry is speeding up, and the process is very critical. But at the same time, we can find that the theoretical research is still at its earlier stage, and we have not gotten an explicit cognition. Through the research and analysis of the present reformation mode, we referred to the history and experiences of developing water industry in developed countries, and summarized the thoughts and measures in the development of reformation and the prospect in the article. At first, we introduced the status quo of water industry and the domestic and foreign background of reformation. We indulged to make the readers acquaint with the malpractice in systems and industrial structures. Then we tried to make the readers realize the international competitive circumstances and make certain the imminent and essential characters of reformation. After that, we introduced the reformation mode of water industry and analyzed the characters of different modes. We also investigated the different practices and successful experiences and pointed out the existent and potential problems. As a result, we found out the thoughts and measures of reformation. Then, for the success of reformation and favorable movement, we initialized the selection of reformation modes. At last, according to the conclusion in the third part we summarized the prospect of reformation and potential trend and orientation. Key word: urban water industry, market- inclined reformation, franchise system

Title: An analysis of the feasibility of transferring the english early excellence centres (eec) programme to early childhood settings in greece
Abstract: Worldwide, accumulating evidence indicates an international movement within countries towards the development of integrated early childhood education and care services (OECD, 2001). Not only do demographic trends underscore such a demand, but also extensive research documents the cognitive, social and emotional developmental benefits of high quality integrated provision in early childhood while at the same time contributing to countries’ ability to compete in a global economy (Eming-Young, 2002). This thesis is concerned with an analysis of the feasibility of transferring the English Early Excellence Centres (EEC) Programme to early childhood settings in Greece. The EEC Programme was introduced by the English Government in 1997 to develop and promote models of high quality integrated education and care services for young children and families as an important part of Government’s broad based strategy for increasing opportunities, supporting families, reducing social exclusion, increasing the health of the nation and addressing child poverty. Case studies were constructed at three Early Excellence Centres (EECs) in England - and two key policy makers involved in the programme were also interviewed. The analysis of the interviews, questionnaires and documents collected during the research in England provided useful insights into the development of integrated services at practice and policy level, along with the successes and challenges encountered during the process of change. Further exploratory case study research took place in Greece to examine whether there is the potential and desire to move towards integration. The theory of a ‘tipping point’ (Gladwell, 2000) provided some profoundly suggestive arguments and insights to analyse the processes by which the English EEC Programme developed at policy level, and how it ‘crossed a threshold’, tipped and spread nationally and internationally. In addition, this theory offered a practical thinking tool for constructing a strategy towards integration in Greece. Analysis revealed that a change process towards integration is not easy to manage; is most productively seen as a social process that gradually unfolds over time; and which acknowledges the socio-economic, political and cultural context of each country. This research indicates that keeping our focus on the development of integration at ground level could be an effective starting point in Greece, -but the development and delivery of integrated services also needs local and central support. A strategy towards establishing integrated service provision in Greece needs to explore what already exists and start building on that; to support personal and professional development; to value the participation of parents; to promote research; and to influence policy. This thesis wishes to stimulate debate, to contribute to the limited Greek literature in the area of integrated early childhood services and to be of interest to policy makers and advocates who have the capacity to shape the direction of the early childhood system in Greece.

Title: A cross-cultural analysis of the spatial distribution of international tourists in China
Abstract: This research focuses on the cross-cultural study of the spatial distribution of tourists (SDT) or international tourists (SDIT) within China. It encompasses two broad areas of knowledge base - cross-cultural and SDT. Many of the issues in these wide ranging, but overlapping, domains have developed separately and have as yet to be conceptualised and researched in a holistic and rigorous manner. This makes the holistic and behavioural perspective, as well as the scientific approach of this study, all the more novel. The societal context of this study tourism in China, adds more practical and theoretical interest to this research. Its diversified tourism resources provide one of the best places to carry out a cross-cultural spatial research. The conceptual framework has strengthened and reinforced the literature in two respects. First, the notion of SDT has been clarified, and it is suggested that it consists of three features of tourist movement - pattern, direction and intensity. Secondly, a factual 'cultural distance' variable, formed from cultural constructs, has been used to underpin the cross-cultural comparative framework in addition to commonly applied cultural proxies such as nationality. The whole research methodology was developed based upon these two notions, and was greatly enhanced by the use of the discrete choice approach (logistic regression models) by which the operational challenges faced when incorporating the behavioural elements into cross-cultural and spatial research were successfully resolved. The research findings do not entirely support the empirical evidence quoted in the cross- cultural SDT literature. The key findings of this research are that tourists prefer linear instead of circular travel within China; their movements are either vertical and/or horizontal; international gateway positions of Beijing and Shanghai have been confirmed, but that of Guangzhou is questioned. All the cultural related variables are significant in the SDIT, but cultural distance is more sensitive at expressing the differences in the SDIT than cultural proxies. There is no evidence suggesting that geographical distance is a primary factor in the SDIT. Some trip attributes, such as travel groups, as well as social economic variables, such as income levels, are confirmed as significant, but demographic characteristics such as age and gender show no significance in the cross-cultural SDIT within a destination country.

Title: Artisans and the city:  a social history of Bristol's shoemakers and tailors, 1770-1800. (BL: DXN066961)
Abstract: This study looks at Bristol artisans in the late eighteenth century in considerable depth, compared to generic studies of English artisans conducted in the past.  The compunction to trace a nascent trade union movement that evolved into a mass movement of the latter nineteenth century, a common theme in previous studies, has been eschewed.  Such an approach fails to locate and explain the purpose of labour agitation within that society, a concept that should be to the fore of any study, as artisans were hardly concerned with what their organisations were to become in a hundred years time.  It is therefore vital to study workers within their own specific context of space and time, for while the national and even international context is useful, an over-reliance on uniform processes can obscure as much as it reveals.  A case study can therefore establish an exact context in which artisans went to work, related to their employers (and each other), engaged with other actions of the local populace, and so on.  This study therefore utilises a holistic approach, in order to provide a well-balanced socio-economic picture of the artisan experience in this period.  While this approach will balance the dispute-centred bias of previous studies, it will also provide a greater understanding of the social milieu from which disputes arose.  Bristol and its status as a regional metropolis in the eighteenth century offers the perfect opportunity to undertake an in-depth analysis of the two trades in question, as surprisingly little is known of eighteenth-century shoemakers and tailors beyond the confines of London.

Title: Alien by degrees: a philosophical and linguistic exploration of citizenship.
Abstract: Addressing the question of how to conceive of citizenship and migration in a globalising world takes an unconventional approach. A global, philosophical and linguistic perspective is required to avoid the well-trodden path that not only leads to always already familiar frameworks but also perpetulates dichotomous thinking. The thesis is structured in three parts to explore each of these perspectives in turn. This distinctive approach is adopted firstly to permit new connections to be made between citizenship and migration, the citizen and the migrant, secondly to demonstrate the heterogeneity that exists between the citizen and the alien, and thirdly to explain the condition of the citizen as alien: alien by degrees. Part one, in order to build a bridge between the concrete and the abstract, develops an explanation of migration that draws attention to multiple levels of displacements and migrants without moving. This takes some weight of the concept of citizenship. The central idea that the meaning of migration is not limited or confined to conventional definitions of physical movement and social settlement, and that citizenship too is a linguistic as well as spatial and temporal phenomenon, is investigated in parts two and three, which complement each other in their examinations of how words relate to words in general, and metaphor, migration and citizenship in particular. The philosophical and linguistic exploration of citizenship treats words as citizens and migrants, and highlights the place of alien words as much as words about aliens. This alternative approach presents both migration and metaphor as movements and processes of displacement. It reveals the differences in the status and agency of migrant citizens involved in different types of movement, real and imagined, and shows that it is not only people who migrate. This leads to an understanding of the asymmetry between and within familiar oppositions, the real constraints that too often foreclose self-definition in non-oppositional terms, classifications resonant of citizen and alien, and the power of unfamiliar juxta/oppositions which serve to unsettle them.
