Title: Design of Marketing Framework for China PUTIAN Corporation
Abstract: CHINA PUTIAN CORPORATION(hereinafter called "CHINA PUTIAN") is an IT products and service provider in telecommunication industry. The company was founded in 1980, originally called China Posts and Telecommunications Industry Corporation. It is a state key enterprise directly under the leadership of the State-owned Assets Supervision and Administration Commission of the State Council (SASAC). The company owns CHINA PUTIAN Co., Ltd., which consists of 7 companies: PUTIAN Capitel, PUTIAN Eastcom, Ningbo Electronics, Beijing Ericsson PUTIAN, Nanjing Ericsson Panda, PUTIAN Taili, PUTIAN Designing & Planning Institute for Engineering. Besides that, CHINA PUTIAN also owns over 40 companies directly invested by the headquarters, which include 5 listed companies- Shanghai P&T, Chengdu Cable and Nanjing PUTIAN are directly invested by headquarters; PUTIAN Eastcom and Ningbo Bird are indirectly invested by headquarters. CHINA PUTIAN is a leading one among top 100 enterprises in China's IT industry, and ranked excessively the No. 1 of Top 100 Chinese Electronic & Information Enterprises in 2001 and 2002. In 2003, CHINA PUTIAN ranks No. 1 among the overall listing of China's largest enterprise groups in the manufacture sector of electronic and communication equipments. It ranks No. 5 both in the listings of 500 largest import & export and 200 largest export enterprises issued by the Ministry of Commerce of China. CHINA PUTIAN's business scope covers both fixed and mobile communications. Its available communication equipments and terminal products include: mobile communication network equipments and handsets, optical transmission equipments and communication cables, PDF and connectors, power supplies, microwave communication equipments, telecommunication network Operation Support Systems (OSS), SPC switch, videophones and IC card payphones, PHS handsets, logistics information system and equipments for industries, ITS series products, office information equipments and etc, as well as project contracting home and abroad, international cooperation, technology transfer, products import and export and etc. Since it was born under the planned economy, China Putian gets many serious problem with its marketing framework, such as branches overlapped, overstaffed, half and unclear assignment, faulty merit system, lay much more emphasis upon sales than marketing. CHINA PUTIAN's marketing network includes two networks of market development and after-sales service, which has about 700 relative offices covering almost all the areas above county level in China. CHINA PUTIAN has established 8 representative offices in Beijing, Shenyang, Nanjing, Hangzhou, Wuhan, Guangzhou, Chengdu, and Xi'an. China Putian equips its framework with the marketing department, but the department puts its all force into market scheme and distribution. It’s vague and general, far from real market, unresponsive to the marketing information, lack of essential effort towards marketing. China Putian has a group of subsidiaries who do the market in their own way, and it is lack of management and development over the whole holding market. This seriously stunts China Putian’s growth. In the fast developing industry, China Putian must find a way suitable for itself and went along with the developing direction of the industry. Telecommunication industry will be the largest industry in the world of 21th century, it is the base of modern economy and leader of society development. At the same time, the industry needs knowledge and technique, and provides high percentage of social employment. It can be a continuously developing industry, with low input and high efficiency. But it also hides with high risk, high competition and high investment. In China, telecommunication industry has its own specific character. Considering both the practice of China Putian and the specialty of the industry, the thesis designs a whole framework of marketing for China Putian. It first expatiates the differences between sales and marketing, and the importance of marketing, also introduces the successful experiences of corporations in the industry to set out the importance and bright future for the marketing of China Putian. It has significant influence to set out a suitable marketing framework in a corporation. A corporation’s living base is marketing. So marketing should be given highest attention throughout the corporation, from investment planning, personnel training to the setting up of an effective marketing framework. Thus, China Putian will have an overall marketing structure. The thesis gives a design of marketing frame for China Putian, considering its own features. The marketing frame is formed of seven functional parts. They are government department, align department, partner department, sales communicating department, product developing department, international market developing department and promoting department. The thesis lists their organic system, ruling extension and duties. The departments set up due to different courses: Government department: as a state-owned corporation, China Putian’s products and services may be greatly influenced by government’s policies. It is very important to the corporation to remain good relationship with the government. Being the practicer and witness of the rapid growth of Chinese IT industry at all times, CHINA PUTIAN and its subsidiaries have attracted great attention from national Communist Party of China (CPC) and government leaders. Those leaders' sincere concern and support can be found in the development history of CHINA PUTIAN. Align department: its main assignment are to absorb right personnel, to supplement each other with resources in the industry, to gain a better and healthier environment for the development of the corporation, to promote the develop of the whole industry to gain the scale economy. Under the new market mechanism and the support of friends from all walks of life, CHINA PUTIAN will establish good cooperation relationships with all major telecommunication carriers in China by resorting to its own technical merit and industrial capacity. Partner department: it’s a channel cleaner between the corporation and final market, to make the channel expedite and healthy, to organize its affiliated enterprises to undertake important projects of constructing state public and private networks and to provide total solutions for manufacture, design, installation, test, etc. It is important to set up an information-sharing channel for innovators and potential partners working in academia or the business world, aiming to promote cooperation. Now our country is facing a strategic period and it's also a vital one for the development of IT industry. CHINA PUTIAN should cooperate with the partner in and out of the industry, to meet government's requirements, carry out reforms proactively, strengthen the integration of group resource, enhance competence and manage to create values for clients, so as to become better, stronger and more stable, and make greater contributions to China's IT industry. Product developing department: it is a vanguard of the corporation’s R&D towards the market demands, and finds new way of developing market, to widen the business of the corporation. CHINA PUTIAN promotes technical innovation and continually consolidats its R&D on telecom technologies and products with its independent intellectual property right. CHINA PUTIAN R&D System includes central research institute and its branches. In November 2001, CHINA PUTIAN set up its central research institute-CHINA PUTIAN Institute of Technology and later four branches in Capitel, Eastcom, Runway, and Smartcomm in succession. This central research institute is responsible for the comprehensive management and planning of over 80 PUTIAN's research institutions. In July 2003, CHINA PUTIAN Institute of Technology (Shanghai) was formally in operation. It will provide mobile phone chipset and RF module with own core technologies for PUTIAN Group and deepen terminal R&D in core level. Promotion department: modern marketing strategy aims much more on the reputation of the corporation by have promotion activities toward products related with the looks, characters, purchasing issues and benefits to the customers, etc. And of course all of these promotion should be based on the right products for the aimed customers, in all the aspects of meeting the needs of final customers, went along with the fashion, the trend of the social developing, and pricing attractively. To do the promotion, CHINA PUTIAN shall also contribute its efforts to commonweal affairs to maintain good reputation of the corporation among common people who are also the potential customers, and it has done so gradually. Its donation built a Wazijie Project Hope School in Huanglong County of Shaanxi Province. It donated mobile phones of its own brand to model workers from China's western area. It donated relieving fund to the "Care for the West, Share One Love" movement. It signed assistance agreements with 2 poverty-stricken counties-Dari and Gande, in Guoluo Prefecture of Qinghai Province. It donated money and material to Anti-SARS related organization. International marketing department: CHINA PUTIAN is keen on developing international markets. Through joint venture, cooperation, and compensation trade, CHINA PUTIAN has established over 90 joint venture companies with 47 companies including world-renowned telecommunication manufacturers from 19 countries and regions. CHINA PUTIAN enjoys long-term strategic partnership with world-renowned telecommunication manufacturers such as Ericsson, Nokia, Panasonic, Motorola, Alcatel, Toshiba, Sanyo, Lucent, NEC, Corning, Nortel, TI, Tellabs, etc. In 2003, the company's total import and export volume is US$ 4.63 billion. Its export volume is US$ 2.16 billion. Its products are sold in dozens of countries and regions such as the U.S., Japan, Finland, Sweden, the U.K., Turkey, United Arab Emirates, India, Nepal, Indonesia, South Africa, Nigeria, Cuba, Columbia and etc. So it is an important part for corporation’s development that to communicate and cooperate with the industry members global wide. PUTIAN should also pay greater attention and resources on cooperation with foreign companies. It is committed to expanding its business scope into promising new areas in communications solutions, products and services at home and aboard. Sales department: it is the final step of marketing, which is a point to verify the effects of the work of marketing. The thesis emphasizes on the functions, extension and merit system of these seven parts, and gives living cases to support the design. These cases illustrate different aspects of the marketing function. The functional departments are not working independently, but connecting a lot. In this way, China Putian’s developing strategy can be laid down to the detailed assignments of marketing. At the same time, the various problems and information can be fed back and solved in time, so that, the strategy itself can be supplemented and corrected. The thesis demonstrates the significance of after-sales services. The holding of customers largely relies on the quality of after-sales services, it’s also a course of gaining goodwill for the organization, so after-sales service is an important and complex function. The thesis also discusses the merit system of after-sales service function, and illustrates the merit system of customer-service department of China Putian Hexin Network Communication Technique Corporation to make it practical to China Putian. The thesis then emphasizes on what should be noticed during the setting up of the framework, like the problem of communication hindrances. The marketing framework will have large investment of the resources, and what’s more, may not get immediate effects. So the leading members of China Putian have to voluntarily demonstrate the importance of the framework, and push forward the work of setting up the framework. Marketing function is the most disputed one among all the functions in the corporation, and the decisions makers are rectify their attitudes towards marketing stage by stage. At first, marketing function is just like other functions of personnel, finance, manufacture, afterwards, going along with the development of the corporation, people gradually realize the importance of marketing, and think it should be more important than other functions, and even the core function of the corporation. No marketing, no corporation. Other people regard that customers are the core of the corporation’s living, marketing is the channel connecting the corporation and the customers. And the regards have been believed throughout the world. But in China’s corporations, there is no way to believe marketing as the core of living, include China Putian. China Putian pays much attention on the volume of sales, on the time of payback. Marketing is just so-so, no one is ready to think high of the marketing function. From the view of the ready marketing framework of China Putian, the subordinate functions are set up according to the assignments of the strategy, some of the assignments are rather duplicated, so it makes cooperation much important. But smooth cooperation is rather difficult to get, it needs a common interest among the subordinate functions. The thesis tries to exercise the marketing theories to analyze the sticking point in the marketing function of China Putian, and finally tries to find a way for it.

Title: Research on Chinese Culture Domain Development Solution
Abstract: Culture domain is the rising one in century 21. Not only the advance of culture industry can promote the culture development, but also make the fortune. It is now the important part and increasing point of our national economy. The nation has exploring abroad on the efforts of domain from 1979, as the principals of contract and be raised by culture itself. Through the advance of two or more decades, we now have some progress but in the period of weakness and have a large step after the economies with capitals and technology level, capability of marketing operation and marketing competition. This text analyses the problems in the area. Exterior- the management of culture of nation was born under the plan economy, it has have lots of disadvantage after several time reforms. Mainly on the aspects of the not very clear responsibilities and rights and benefits between the government and cultural marketing runners in culture control, thus, the runners are not the real one who in charge of the marketing and the corporation. Much interferences of state occur in management. The interconnected system of the funds is chartered and made during the investing of culture construction. The runners can not make any incomes individuals and not have the rights to use funds self-determined, who not have the activities and enthusiasms to make more funds and financing. Due to the united management of government, the administration of cultural and non-industrialization, now our culture projects has a lower efficiency of operation. Non-legalization is also the important characteristics of cultural system. The situation and function can not be confirmed by law. The operation of culture projects is not guaranteed by law indispensable and lacking law certification in cultural activities management. Culture projects development just depend on the focus degree of governors. In interior, the career has lower technologies, talents lacking, fund insufficient, irrationality of configuration, non-good systems of running. Because for a long time we think the culture belongs to sphere of social ideology, researching its development from the view of economy and how making the policies seldom. Furthermore, majority of the art troupes are running by the state, whose has the system of focusing on civilization lightening profits. So the development of our culture career badly disconnect with the demands of the marketing. This text indicates to promote our national culture career, we, first of all, should have a clear acknowledge of the development circumstances. One is the economy globality, the impersonal tendency, which can not only deeply influence the policies and activities of all nations in the world but also have the powers on the culture policies and movements and directions of development, and impact the reorganization of configurations of cultural power and the changes of international culture orders. The other is our policies obviously disaccord and has internal conflicts with the WTO trade freedom, clarity and marketing entry allowed rules. The third is culture worldwide expand, comes the cultural imperialism, which really threaten our national culture domain development. The security situation of national culture becomes worse and worse. And we must fact to the advantages and disadvantages. The nation has vast territory large population, sufficient demand of diversified culture, the biggest culture marketing compare with other nations. She has rich resources of culture- the irreplaceable one, long history culture. Disadvantages are small scales, non-competition abilities and not enough manage experience, can not follow the WTO. To advance, we must deal with the relationship between the career and cultural domain; distinguish strictly from the career with marketing sales measures and domain with thick commonwealth colorful, the relationship between culture system reform and culture domain. Processing culture system reforms mainly with the economy structure adjustments and guided by marketing. Economic benefits and social benefits, the latter is much concerned. The relation of opening and developing, strengthen the protection of folk culture as well heir and creation. And he order of development, lighten characteristics. First well done in certain areas, then radiates and stimulate the zones around advance together. Choose rational direction according to practice. We can adopt following ways to strengthen our culture domain: speed the reform of the system, change the management functions of government, separated from the government. To perfect the present manage and operation systems. The second, to carry out active domain advance policies, setup the system base on the Chinese culture status and demands of culture managing as well as suitable to WTO principles. Open wide the admission level, adjust and reorganize the relation of culture economy profits on the basis of marketing system. Speed up the update frequency of system to meet the modern enterprise principles. Bring the new foreign trade strategy for cultural foreign trade system. Establish the strategies for big pace development of culture domain. Thirdly, talents, we need lots of creative culture professionals. Fourth, expand the international market for rapid progresses. Fifth is the system of national intellective properties protection setup, through which firm the domestic and competitive in overseas. Sixth, build the national culture safety precaution system and enhance the culture safe legislation construction. And should have financing system of culture domain . Thus, the Chinese culture domain can advance good and sustainable, always successful in the competition with world culture industry.

Title: From Marx's Alienation to Georg Lukacs'Reification
Abstract: The problem of alienation is a basic problem that Marx considered in his whole life. Even since very early days, Marx had touched on the various phenomena of alienation and kept a conscious mind toward its seriousness and urgency. Marx had not formed the view of alienation during his writing of The Doctor's Thesis and his explanation of alienation had still been limited to Hegel's Philosophy. According to Hegelian theory, alienation primarily refers to the alienation on the spirit, i.e, the absolute idea can be alienated from or get out of nature in its own movement. Marx affirmed the very alienation theory of the essence of spiritual subject as Hegel did and regarded alienation of the spiritual substance (atom) as the natural way in its self-fulfillment, because alienation was exactly objectification and only through objectification could the concrete integrity of essence and existence be realized. During his writing/compiling of “Rheinische Zeitung”, Marx shifted his standpoint of alienation to a new one because of the serious conflict between the problem in practical life and Hegel's Philosophy as well as the great effect of Feuerbach' standpoint of alienation. The conclusion Marx drew from those theories was that reason was the innate character of the world and was expressed by the public opinion and the people's spirit and concentrated by the speech-free publications and the philosophy and then rose to the nation and the law. He asserted that the nation was not the incarnation of the public reason, nor a super-existence beyond the citizenry society, but the alienation of people's political lives. Marxian standpoint of alienation was transformed into humanism in his Criticism for Hegel's Law Philosophy and “About Jewry' Problem”. Marx came to the conclusion: on the one hand, the citizenry society determined the nation; on the other hand, the nation was the alienation of the human being’s nature. The human being would not only exterminate alienation in the thought, but also exterminate the alienation in the actuality, and the proletariat was the very incarnation of power. Marxian theory of alienation took its form as “alienated labor” in Manuscript of Economics and Philosophy in 1844. Marx investigated the properties and the displays of alienated labor from four aspects. First, there was a relation of alienation between a worker and his product. Second, there was a relation of alienation between a worker and his labor. Third, alienation happened in individuals and their human essence. Fourth, because of the relation of alienation between a worker and his product, between a worker and his activity of life, between the worker and his human essence, a direct result of these things is alienation between a man and the other man. Marx explained concretely all kinds of theoretical problems and actual problems. He claimed that human and nature were united, but human labor essence was alienated in the process of objectification, and the relation between human and nature was also the relation of alienation, because the nature was isolated from human being and was opposite to human, and the private possession was the product of alienated labor, and the history was the history of alienation of essence of human labor and the history of sublation of alienation, so communism was historical inevitableness. However, the premise of his theory of alienation was still humanism, because Marx used the species essence of human to stand opposed to the actual human existence, and the labor as the embodiment of human essential power to stand opposed to the alienated labor, therefore, whatever was the viewpoint of human or the viewpoint of human labor would both take the characteristic of the abstract metaphysics. In The Holy Family, Marx began objectively to evaluate alienation phenomenon from the viewpoint of history. Opposition between the proletariat and the bourgeois was made by the system of private ownership, both the proletariat and the bourgeois were objective, historical results of alienations. Only through the extermination of the system of private ownership could alienation phenomenon of capitalism be eradicated. German Ideology marked the birth of historical perspective of materialism and strode to scientific explanation of Marxian theory of alienation. Marx thought that alienation first was a historic phenomenon rather than a pure mental and moral phenomenon. That is to say, the history could be used to explain alienation, but not the vice versa. What pushed the human history forward were not alienation of human species essence and the sublation of alienation, but the development of productive power that led to the change of productive relations. Marx’s manuscripts and the book Capital demonstrated the achievement of scientific ideology of Marxian theory of alienation. Marx claimed that the essence of alienation was that the reified labor governed human beings. Once the sociality of producers’ activities was reified in the form of commutative value and the form of currency, it would become a social power that is opposite to the producers. In his manuscripts and the book, Marx not only revealed with the category of alienation the social oppositeness of capitalism in the profound and supplement way, he also disclosed the historical transition of capitalism and the historical value of the theory of alienation to mankind's emancipation from capitalism. What I interpret Marxian theory of alienation is based on both historical perspective of materialism and the theory of labour value. Mankind not only realizes its own reproduction but also creates and develops the material productive powers through the labour of production. Directly speaking, on the one hand, the human being changes the nature of himself and develops his own physical strength and intelligence as well as accumulates the productive experience and the labour skills; on the other hand, he also creates the new social combinative way of labour. The employment system of capitalism and the mode of realization of value not only obstruct the development of productive powers, but also lead to the alienation of social relation. There were great changes in both the economy and politics of the capitalist society during the end of 19th century and the early part of 20th century, and the problems caused by these changes were waiting for being solved by Marxists. The Second International leaders represented by Edward Bernstein abandoned Hegel's Philosophy which Marx had absorbed some rational factors with appraisal and regarded economy as the only decisive factor while ignoring the relative independent character and the important reaction to the economic basis provided by the superstructure which consisted of politics, ideology and philosophy. To counter the Second International leaders’ worship for the spontaneous theory and their neglect of the major function performed by revolution, George Lukács tendered his bitter attacks and published a book named History and Class Consciousness by compiling his eight papers finished in four years. In the book he deemed that the main cause for the failure of the revolutions in different European countries lied in the crisis in proletarian class consciousness. He proposed to restore the traditional connections between Marxism and Hegel's Philosophy and criticized acutely on the important role played by the proletarian class consciousness. His theory of reification was born in the above-mentioned background. George Lukács combined Max Weber’s theory of rationalization with Marx's analysis of the worship of commodity and advanced the theory of reification that maintained a man’s activity and his labor became the things objective and contradictory to himself in History and Class Consciousness. He claimed that both producer and the relation between producers were reified into the elements of merchandise producing in the employment system in capitalism and the thinking way of reification had already constituted the inside principle of the capitalist philosophy. And reification furthered its influence on ethics and became the unified ideological structure of the whole society. A bureaucrat was subjected to the bureaucratic mechanism and was proud of doing so while a journalist lost his righteousness and made a living by selling his belief and experience, and a capitalist and a worker were the slaves of capital by sacrifice themselves voluntarily to commodities. Lukács pointed out with the aid of analysis that there were two reasons for the formation of reification: the first reason was that in capitalist society the relations between merchandises created an independent world whose laws could be recognized by human beings but couldn’t be changed by them. The world was totally against human being and became the objective foundation of reification. The second one arose in the subjective aspect and was that labor became merchandise as Marxed revealed. Lukács thought that the German classic philosophy had been related to the consciousness of reification at the very beginning ever since Kantianism , which only admitted that the reason method was the unique method of controlling actuality. This philosophy reflected the consciousness construction of reification of capitalist society, which was a form of merchandise in the thought. At the same time, Lukács not only objected to Engels's dialectics of nature and Lenin's theory of reflection, but also criticized that the former expanded dialectics from the realm of reciprocal action of subject and object to the nature realm which contained none of dialectics factors and that the latter was actually simple realism and metaphysical materialism. In order to get rid of reification, Lukács emphasized the dynamic role and the revolutionary practice of proletarian class consciousness and pointed out that Marx's category of totality was the key to extricate the restraint of reification. He claimed that Marx's dialectics found out the uniformed subject and object, that is the proletariat. After attaining the self-conscious class-consciousness, the proletariat can fundamentally change the social reality. Lukács' theory of reification resisted Kantian understanding analysis by using Hegelian dialectical reasonableness and included two latitudes of both objective explanation and subjective criticism on capitalistic mode of production. However, He put generality above the economic basis and overstated the dynamic role played by the consciousness. This assertion not only resembled Hegel's distortion of Marxism but also reflected the trend of extreme “Left” deviation. On the other hand, Lukács did not distinguish between alienation, reification and objectification precisely and he used reification as the synonym of alienation. Therefore, it was impossible for him to enunciate the source of alienation and to find out the way to eliminate alienation. In Marx’s manuscripts and his book Capital, Marx made a clear distinction between alienation and reification. He assumed that there were two kinds of reification: one was the reification of the physical labor in its natural regulations, i.e, the specific kind of concrete physical labor would create certain use value and it was the objectification of physical labor. The other kind of reification was the reification of the physical labor in its social stipulations, i.e., under capitalist conditions, human beings’ physical labor as part of the whole social labor could create certain exchange value. So-called alienation labor occurred in the latter. In his manuscripts and the book, Marx not only revealed with the category of alienation the social oppositeness of capitalism in the profound and supplement way, he also disclosed the historical transition of capitalism and the historical value of the theory of alienation to mankind's emancipation from capitalism. He insisted that the capitalism pushed the alienation to an extreme end meanwhile it helped the history to discard the alienation. Capitalism played a role both in pushing the alienation to an extreme and preparing the mature conditions for the sublation of alienation. Therefore, unlike reification and objectification, which were eternal and inevitable, alienation was just temporary and inevitable. The sublation of alienation was the process in which the old social division would be eliminated on the base of a rapid development of the relation between human being and nature. But its realization depended mainly on the proletariat's conscious practice in reforming the capitalist system.

Title: A Statistical Analysis of the Stock Market's Response to Global Economic Events
Abstract: Event studies are among the most successful uses of econometrics in financial markets. By providing a simple process for measuring the impact of events on investor wealth, the method offers a fruitful means for evaluating the implications of significant economical or political events. This paper is an attempt to construct a new frame of event studies. It is, maybe, the first time to use those statistical tools to solve some problems. This paper concentrates on statistical analyses about global economical event from two points of view: on one hand, trying to find factors of the impact to stock return; on the other hand, making research about the interval of the effective impact. There are four chapters which unfold as follows: Chapter 1 describes the background of event studies. The efficient market theory (EMF) is introduced first, including the basic concept, analysis frame, its relation to kinds of statistical models and tests, and so on. Later, we show the primary matters of event study, emphasizing its relation to EMF. Some basic definitions are also provided in this chapter. Chapter 2 contributes descriptive statistical analysis of the data. Some necessary data adjustment is put on to make the following analysis more convincible. What’s more, some other basic definitions are provided here. Chapter 3 is one focus of the paper. In order to analyze the return under the effective impact, two kinds of models are applied. The first is transfer function models, which are used to investigate the joint dynamics of price changes and volume on the stock markets. To present the influence of effective impact, we just make some simple correction to these models. As most time series analysis of financial data, GARCH model is employed to correct the residuals. The second is ordinary leaner models, which are familiar with most readers. Some important conclusions are maintained in this chapter. n	The movement direction of the stock price can not be predicted by using the information of the history price and volume. n	The magnitude of the movement of the stock price can , to some extent, be predicted by using the information of the history price and volume. …… Chapter 4 focuses on another center of this paper, which is the interval of the effective impact. General count models and Survival models are widely used in social science areas, such as analysis of wars, strike, plague, insurrection and the life of equipment or humans. These give us some clues to carry on our research. However, some transforms are necessary, which includes: n	Division of the time series and the independence of the effective impact; n	Choice of the risk factor; n	Introduce of censoring conception. There are also some important conclusions abtained in this chapter. We find two useful explanatory variables contribute to the analysis of this chapter, which is the average magnitude of price change and the standard error of the volume on the past stage. In addition, the following statistical tools are used in this paper: transfer function model, ordinary regression model, survival model, GARCH model, dummy-variable method, residual analysis, ARCH test, survival distributions.

Title: Study on Regulation Reform of Water Supply Industry in China
Abstract: In the whole world, especially western developed country, the natural monopoly industry is going through a regulation reform. People realize more and more soberly that under the traditional regulation system, the operation of the natural monopoly industry is in charge of too widely and tightly, which have caused a lot of drawbacks hindered the sound development of the natural monopoly industry. So the countries all over the world have carried on the reform to the regulation of the natural monopoly industry in varying degrees. Regulation is reformed along two ways at the present time: Firstly, adopt the policy of the relaxed regulation, cancel the regulation clause in part or in whole, and introduce the competition mechanism of the market. For example, An open and important reform had been carried out to the regulation of the communication and transportation business in the U.S.A, through the issue of a series of bills successively from 1976 to 1982, such as “Law of Railway Rejuvenation and Railway Regulation Reform”, “Relaxed Regulation Law of Passenger Traffic of Aviation”, “Law of Automobile Transportation”, “railway law” etc. And in Britain, there are privatizing and relaxed regulation movements on a large scale to the telecommunication, coal gas, water supply, electricity and railway transportation in the beginning of the eighties of the 20th century. Other country like Germany, Australia, and Japan had also carried on the regulation reform one after the other. Secondly, improve the existing regulation and introduce the encouraging regulation to promote the operation of economic regulation more rationally and more effectively. According to the theory of new regulation economics, it’s the commission- agent relationship between the governor and regulated enterprises. Difficulties in regulation are the information asymmetry. Encouraging regulation is designed in the way of self-choose of the regulated enterprises in order to utilize privately owned information better and achieve the goal of raising the efficiency. The regulation organization can make the best weighing between efficiency and other social goals in the encouraging regulation. The western developed counties have made very good result to the regulation reform, which is carried on to the characteristic of the natural monopoly industry, the improvement of the business efficiency and service quality of the natural monopoly industry, great reduction of the cost and price and the increase of the social welfare. It has a very strong demonstration effect. And with the deepening of the market economic system reform with Chinese characteristics, drawbacks of natural monopoly industry developed under the traditional system expose day by day, such as the low management, poor service quality and serious investment insufficiency. So reform to it becomes more and more important and urgent. In recent years, our country has already begun in industry's relaxed regulation reform has already begun in China in some natural monopoly industries, such as telecommunication, electricity, aviation and railway, etc. and also have made the positive result. These domestic and international successful experiences have proved from practices that relaxed regulation and introduction of competition is of great importance to the development of natural monopoly in China. As a typical natural monopoly industry, the regulation reform of our water supply industry lags behind obviously compared with other natural monopoly industries, such as electricity, telecommunication and so on, so it is urgently to deepen the regulation reform of our water supply industry. Under this background, this paper will apply the governmental regulation theory on natural monopoly industries to analyze the reform practice of our water supply industry, so it has a very important practice meaning. This paper mainly uses the governmental regulation theory on natural monopoly industries to make a systematic research on the regulation reform of our water supply industry. In this paper, through the analysis of current situation and issues of some contents of our governmental regulation on water supply industry, such as the legal frame, the operating mechanism of current regulation system, the price regulation, the quality regulation, the market-enter regulation, the investment regulation, etc. Some policy recommendations will be put forward to deepen the regulation reform of our water supply industry further. Though the suggestions in this paper have been put in practice in the other natural monopoly industries, the suggestions are still important and meaningful for the water supply industry. In this paper I mainly learn from the experience of the regulation reform in British, which show the shortcoming of this paper. Though there are so many researches in the natural monopoly industries, I will be very delighted with my contribution to the regulation reform in water supply industry.

Title: A Study on Korean Administrative Reform of Kim Dae-Jumg Government
Abstract: The strong impact of the financial crisis in the latter half of 1997 left Republic of Korea in its biggest economic disaster ever since World War II: slump in the stock market, inflation of currency, shutdown of factories, roaring rate of unemployment, rapid decrease in foreign exchange, and the country was at the verge of a tumble down. At the height of the financial crisis, in February 1998, Mr. Kim Dae-jung vowed in as the 15th president of the Republic of Korea. Having strived all his life for political reform in South Korea, Mr. Kim Dae-jung assumed responsibility at a critical time. During his presidency, Kim adopted a series of comprehensive reforms in finance, enterprises, labor-capital structure, public sectors and so on, determined to end the trusteeship of International Monitory Fund (IMF) within one year and a half. The amazing thing was that the series of measures adopted by Kim Government took effect, successfully stopping the financial as well as social crisis and regained people’s confidence in the government. Korea thus became the first Eastern Asian nation to recover from the economic crisis. The outstanding achievements call for international attention on the reforms. The administrative reform is the object of this paper. Through research, the author attempts to answer the following questions: what is the background of the administrative reform of Kim Dae-jung Government (Chapter I)? What are the contents, progress and achievements of Korean Administrative reform (ChapterII-IV)? What are the factors concerning the results of the administrative reform (Chapter V)? And what are the lessons that can be learned from Korean experience for the theory and practice of administrative reform (Chapter VI)? The world’s past and present experiences have told us that there are always domestic or international backgrounds behind all administrative reforms. For Korea, the 1997 financial crisis served as the biggest and most direct external cause for administrative reform while domestically, the frequent change of power leads to the reform. In the December 1997 election, Kim Dae-jung was chosen as the 15th president, a first out-party president in the history of South Korea. History has it that when power switches from one side to another, administrative reform will definitely become part of the political promises because administrative reform is the political image of a politician. In addition, the 1997 financial crisis provided a good political reason for Kim Government’s administrative reform. In order to overcome the crisis, South Korean had to accept the trusteeship of International Monetary Fund. On receiving a 60 billion U.S. Dollar emergency loan, Korean had to accept rigorous conditions such as to slow down economic growth, increase tax rate and cut back government expenditures. The historical national crisis created a consensus among the Koreans to have an necessary administrative reform, which effectively reduced the barriers to the reform. On the other hand, the key internal cause for the reform would be the reconsideration on the weakness of the traditional government management model. Korean government oriented economic development model had dated back to the 1960`s. It was to accelerate the national economy and to implement the strategy and plan for a fast catch-up. Honesty speaking, such a development model was crucial for Korean economy to take off and grow from lack of resource and an extremely backward economic infrastructure. But its weak points are exposed with the change in international environment and development in domestic economy and society: the occurrence of plutocracy, a fragile financial system, collusion between government officials and business people and the spread of corruption brought about by the centralized political system. All these lead to a decrease in its international competitiveness and the outbreak of the financial crisis. Also since 1970’s, the new public management campaign beginning in some Western developed nations such as the U.S. and the U.K. had a “media effect” on Korea. The theory of new public management and the practice of reform measures adopted by Western nations in countering the malpractice of traditional bureaucracy have not only provided a solid foundation and abundant experiences for Korea to set guidelines, targets and methods for the reform but also become the external pressure for reform. Just like the Western developed nations, Korean administrative reform takes the idea of new public management as the guiding principle for the reform. But the reform was not simply for the crisis caused problems. To a greater extend, it was designed for the improvement of a market economy oriented system, for the enhancement of national power and for a basis of a sustained after-crisis development. For sake of this, Kim Dae-jung Government set the goal of establishing a “small and efficient, service oriented government”. Reforms in three areas are initiated to achieve this goal: restructuring of public sectors, reform in administrative operation system and the construction of a service oriented government. More concretely, in terms of public sector restructuring, the goal would be to establish “small government”. Reforms include institutional restructuring, redundancy, privatization of state owned enterprises, out-contracting of government projects, readjustment and management upgrading of government funded institutions and the accountability of the central and local governments. Indicators have shown a smooth progress of Kim Government’s restructuring, and the reforms live up to their expectations. Of all the reforms, the results of redundancy and the privatization of state owned enterprises are most outstanding: the number of government officials in 2002 dropped back to that of 10 years before; the privatization of 74 state-owned-enterprises reduced the range of public sector and increased fiscal income of the country, providing large capitals for a next step reform. Short-term goals have been achieved in coordinating the responsibilities of central and local governments, delegating more rights and duties to the local level. This laid an institutional foundation for the efficiency and responsiveness of governance. The three-step institutional readjustment played its positive role in strengthening the adjusting ability of the economy, and the role of social management. Additionally, as an auxiliary measure of the institutional readjustment, out-contracting of government projects, reform of government funded institutions have also become an important part of the “small government”. Admittedly, influenced by the political environment, some of the designed reform projects are abused and some demolished institutions resumed. In terms of the reform in the system of administrative operation, the Korean Government adopted such systems as the system of responsibility operation department, the system of liberalized employment and the system of performance-salary, and these consequently promoted the reform in personnel engagement and management. By the end of 2002, Kim Dae-jung Government has had a total of 23 responsibility operation departments and 119 employed officials for the open enlisting. Also, the performance-salary system has been applied in almost all departments of central government and majority of autonomous regions. The reform in personnel engagement and management is not limited within government administrative departments, but has extended to the retained state-owned enterprises and research institutions directly under the government. Tangible improvements have also been made in the reform of fiscal operation system: decisive adjustment has been made to cancel or merge some 35 foundations and supervision and control have been strengthened over all other foundations; at all levels of governments sectors, there is the system of reward for prudent budgets; the trial system of performance prediction has been going on in 39 institutions. But one important topic facing Korea is more adjustment and improvement on the reforms because institutional abuse and boycott of some government officials have occurred. The Korean Government has adopted many measures as well in improving its service function and constructing a service-oriented government. The measures are as follows: the legalization of administrative service has been adopted widely at the central and local level governments; results are apparent in rectifying quasi-taxations, relieving at least 300 billion Korean dollars of burden on the Koreans; with an extensive opinion poll and a thorough investigation, the government conducted reform in the most unsatisfying 15 sectors in the following 7 areas including: police, housing, transportation, education, environment, social security and employment, food and hospitals. This has contributed to improving the administrative service. Also, in terms of establishing e-governance and legal reform, the performance of the Korean Government has also been accredited internationally. The reforms have not only greatly improved the quality of service, raised and enhanced government competitiveness and performance, constructed information infrastructure, but also fought corruption, advocated for proper governance and increased operational transparency. Then, how to evaluate the administrative reform of Kim Government? The actual effect of administrative reform does not surface shortly afterwards, and the multi-significance reform means differently to varied values, standards etc. So this article prudently judges the Kim Reforms. The author analyzes the progress of the reform measures to see how the targets are reached. Because administrative reforms affect political images, the author has also taken as important rating standards the people’s recognition towards the reform concept and reform direction in the late Kim period. As for reference, the author has also considered the comments by OECD and other international organizations, the growth rate, foreign exchange reserve, average income, Korean sovereignty credit rating and its international competitiveness. The general rating by the author is that: progress has been made by the Kim Dae-jung Government in administrative reform, most reform targets have been achieved, the reforms contributed to surviving the financial crisis and has laid a good foundation for the country’s sustainable development. These results followed the strategic choices including: the rationality of the concepts (which are different from the traditional administrative models and improve the government’s competitiveness), the strongly willed president, and the extensive support, participation, understanding and compassion of all Koreans from top government leaders to ordinary people, the reform being an overall and scheduled one, institutions for ensuring the progress of the reforms, the rationality and transparency of the decision making process ensured by the government-people cooperation mechanism, and the insurance promoted and provided by legislation. But judging from the current results, defects still exist. Causes are many, but a selected few are included to analyze the theory of the institutions. After reviewing performance-salary system, liberalized employment system, responsibility operation departments system and regulation reform, analysis is given on the impact of informal institutions on the reform. The results show that it’s those informal institutions countering the reform concept that kept some reform measures down or even abused. With the above explanations, the author got the following conclusion concerning the theory and practice of Kim’s reform: the adaptability of new public management concept. Against the backdrop of globalization and informatization and with the urgent need to deal with the traditional bureaucracy, it is admittedly beneficial to learn from international experiences in new public management movement. But a nation’s political system as well as such informal institutions as culture, values and traditions and customs should be given full attention to while deciding the targets, contents and strategies of the reforms. An appropriate change in the system will save time and energy in realizing the basic goals for the nation’s development and construction. The second is the improvement and development of the theory and analysis framework of the system. Because administrative reform is a de facto man-made government rearrangement process which can be explained by new institutionalism. Meanwhile, it is necessary to improve and develop the definition, function, formation and alteration of the institution. With the constraints of time and space, it becomes the focus and difficulty to research on the dynamic relationship between the structures and behaviors of the institutions. The third questions concerns the uncertainty of administrative reform and the choice of reform strategies. Kim’s reforms have told us that some of the reform results can be predicted while others not, even with our limited rationality. In other words, it could be unavoidable to have “obsolete”, “unsuitable” or even “abused” reform measures. So it is an important method to choose gradual and democratic reform strategies to effectively solve this uncertainty.

Title: Rent-seeking Theory and Analysis of the Rent-seeking Activities in State Owned Commercial Bank in China
Abstract: Rent seeking theory appeared in 1960s. In spite of short history, this theory has developed very quickly. Further more, rent seeking theory break through the limited area of traditional economic theory. It has combined with politics, sociology and culture research. Rent seeking theory develops the research area of economics and enhanced the power of economics to explain reality. From broad sense, rent seeking refers to nonproductive profit-seeking activities, or the nonproductive activities to keep vested economic interest as well as to redistribute the vested interest. From the narrow sense, rent seeking refers to utilizing political and law instrument to block the free flow and competence of producing factors among different industry so as to keep vested interest. Of course, there are many disputes to the definition of rent seeking. Running down the developing history of rent seeking theory, we can find although classical economists (such as Say) has discussed this question, they didn’t establish the system info of rent seeking. In 1967 Tullock put forward the basic idea of rent seeking. In his paper ’The Welfare Costs of Tariff, Monopolies, and Theft’, Tullock analyzed monopoly’s influence on social welfare. According to him, monopoly’s social cost should include the resources wasted during competing for monopoly except ‘Harberger triangle’, which is called ‘Tullock rectangle’. ‘Tullock rectangle’ is the social cost of rent seeking. But in this paper, Tullock didn’t put forward the concept of “rent seeking’. At that time, rent seeking theory only had a small influence in theory circle. In 1974 Krueger set up the full frame of rent seeking theory in his paper ‘The Political Economy of the Rent-Seeking Society’. He used the concept of ‘rent seeking’ at the first time. From then on, rent-seeking theory has aroused wide recognition in economic theory circle. Just for this reason many economist consider that Krueger is the real inaugurator of rent seeking theory. Tullock and Krueger inaugurated two different creeds of rent seeking theory, which is public choice creed and international trade creed. Public choice creed is based on the rent seeking theory of public choice school (Tullock and Buchanan are the main spokesman of public choice school). While collective choice school (represented by Olson) and New Institutional economic School (represented by North) developed rent-seeking theory along the public choice creed. Bhagwati made great contribution to the development of international trade creed. He summarized the rent seeking theory heretofore and put forward the concept of Directly Unproductive Profit-seeking Activity. Then rent-seeking theory is used in more expansive area. Hereafter the international trade school of rent seeking theory uses DUP in most time, while the public choice school continues to use the word’ rent seeking’. The integrated analysis to rent seeking theory should include the following five aspects: the person factor analysis, the institution factor analysis, the process analysis, the consequence analysis, the theoretical contribution and utilizing value of rent seeking theory. The person factor analysis emphasized on analyzing the applicability of economic man hypothesis. The body analyzed by rent seeking theory should be limited rational economic man who is opportunistic. This hypothesis should be applied to bureaucracy, too. Rent seeking activity is the outcome of given institution environment. Government has natural extrusion trend to marketing, which is the institution root for rent seeking activities. As regards the process of rent seeking, there are two different routes for rent seeking activity: the first is that government officers seek for rent on their own initiative, they ask for rent to the potential rent seeking body by tempting or threatening. This is a game process between the government officer and the rent seeking body. Rent seeking activity has strong domino effect of self-copying and self-extending. Just for this reason, once rent-seeking activity appeared it would have the trend of expanding continuously. Rent seeking activities lead to great waste of social resources, reduce the productive efficiency and distort the social incentive mechanism. For developing countries, rent-seeking activities would also block the system reform. Rent seeking theory has great academic significance and application value. It has breakthrough the research area of traditional economic theory. Rent seeking theory divides the economic activity into two different classes: productive activity and unproductive activity. It also differentiates rent seeking activity and profit seeking activity. Rent seeking theory has been widely applied in many areas. Rent seeking theory especially is used to analyze the transition process of developing countries. The state owed commercial bank in our country plays an important role in the economic development. But for the speciality of these banks plenty of rent seeking activities appeared in the reform course. It is very important to master the movement law of rent seeking activities and give out the countermeasures. The rent seeking activities in state owed commercial bank in our country can be divided into two different types according to the participants. One is rent seeking activities implemented by commercial banks. As the main body of market, these banks carry out rent seeking activities by lobbying or bribing government administrator. It is mainly displayed in three aspects: rent seeking activities in the appointment of super administrators of commercial banks, rent seeking activities to the superior administration department in the operations of commercial banks business; rent seeking activities to evade the supervision from the supervision department. The other kind of rent seeking activity refers to the rent seeking activity performed by the economic body outside state owed commercial banks, which is also displayed in three aspects: rent seeking activities in loan examination and approval, rent seeking activities in the personnel employment of state owned commercial banks, rent seeking activities performed by local government. The existence of these rent-seeking activities can be attributed to the following reasons. First, the speciality of state owned commercial bank is the root reason of rent seeking activities in this region. State owned commercial banks, as independent interest body, would like to pursue rent from government; While administrator’s pursuing self interest maximization would lead to rent seeking activities to banks. Second, overmuch government control expanded the room for rent seeking activities; Third, the special relationship between state owned commercial bank and local government is also one important cause for rent seeking activities. The rent seeking activities in state owned commercial bank have caused great adverse influence to economy development of our country. We can find this clearly from the following aspects: first, plenty of non-performing loans are the direct social consequence of rent seeking activities in the state owned commercial banks. Second, the group with vested interest, which is formed in the course of rent seeking, has blocked the course of the reform of state owned commercial bank. Third, rent-seeking activities have led to low diathesis of bank stuff. Last, the low efficiency in capital collocating influenced the efficiency of economy greatly. Of course, some kind of rent seeking activity would push on the reform course of state owned commercial bank, which are favorable from final consequence. Ti is a long term to father the rent seeking activities in state owned commercial bank. We must nail down the economic man hypothesis firstly. We should take action from the following aspects to father the first kind of rent seeking activity: First, strengthen the administration system reform of state owned commercial bank, to set up canonical loan examination and approval system and stuff employment system so as to enhance the cost of rent seeking. Second, to set up reasonable incentive mechanism and wash out mechanism, so as to decrease the expect income of rent seeking. Third, strengthen the inner and outside supervision mechanism, so as to cut off the self-copy and self-swelling process of rent seeking activities. For the second kind of rent seeking activity, it is necessary to take stock system reform. With the introduction of non-state capital, the proprietor can function better. The administrator of bank should be appointed by the directorate of bank. Stock-option system should be taken for bank administrators. At the same time, government should reduce its control over the operation of state owned commercial bank so that banks could perform business innovation independently according to the market environment. Bank supervision department should change from government organization to guild, which would take action according to market mechanism.

Title: The transplantation of theatre-in-education from britain to taiwan
Abstract: The British-born Theatre-in-Education (TIE) is now an international phenomenon. Theatre and education practitioners worldwide have come to recognise TIE as an important resource for the reinforcement of institutional or orthodox education. In Taiwan, by way of cultural exchanges and in accordance with the practice of the well meant, but not so well planned education reforms, TIE has also been gradually adopted by drama specialists and professional theatre groups over the last decade to provide young students with alternative experiences of active learning. During this process of transplantation, the representation of TIE has become an issue that demands careful deliberation in the island. This dissertation surveys the development of Theatre-in-Education in Taiwan from a personal perspective, as well as demonstrating the interdisciplinary relationship between TIE and regional/community theatre through a case study on the encounter of the Greenwich and Lewisham Young People’s Theatre (GYPT) and the Tainan Jen Theatre Troupe. By making use of first-hand experience of TIE transplantation (from Britain to Taiwan) and of interviews with TIE practitioners, the author intends to contextualise the Taiwanese TIE movement by relating it to an international trend of audience-oriented theatre. Within this framework, the author argues that the localisation of British TIE in Taiwan is best embodied, and therefore can be expected to find strength in the association of TIE and those Taiwanese theatre groups of or with a community-friendly nature; in addition, the continuing social, cultural and educational reforms will create a better environment for the growth of Theatre-in-Education in the island.

Title: European nuclear disarmament: a study of transnational social movement strategy
Abstract: This thesis is a study of an attempt to help create a transnational movement against the nuclear arms race and the Cold War in the 1980s. The attempt began with the drafting and launch of the Appeal for European Nuclear Disarmament in early 1980. The thesis describes and analyses the work of the British group, European Nuclear Disarmament, or END, which was founded in order to further the aims outlined in the Appeal. The thesis examines END's work in three, overlapping, geographical areas: Britain, where END acted mainly as a pressure group on and/or ginger group within CND in an attempt to internationalize - END-ize - its work; in Western Europe (including Britain), where END (with other Western peace groups) was trying to create and sustain enduring ties amongst Western peace groups; and across the East-West divide, where END was one of a number of groups that engaged in dialogue with independent forces in the Soviet bloc - while maintaining relations with the regimes - with the aim of creating some kind of pan-European alliance that would bring together above all these forces and Western peace groups. The study is conducted in terms of an explanatory framework that emphasizes the pre-existing networks out of which END emerged; the distinctive END worldview or 'frame' and the ways in which END supporters campaigned in its terms, tried to persuade others to adopt it, and/or adapted it - above all in dialogue with independent groups in the Soviet bloc; the resources and structure that helped determine the work END activists could do; the way in which this campaigning was shaped by END's relationship with other peace groups, in Britain above all CND; and the political opportunities and constraints that END activists faced. To date there has been no full-length study of END nor one that analyses the various dimensions of its campaign and how they shaped each other. This thesis thus aims to be a contribution to our knowledge of the West European peace movements of the 1980s; it also hopes to add to our understanding of transnational social-movement campaigning.

Title: Women and the public sphere in the early meiji period
Abstract: Historians of Japanese studies have hitherto argued that during the 1870s and 1880s Japanese male intellectuals started forming the Japanese public sphere by setting up male associations, publishing newspapers and discussing political and social issues that had not been a matter of public debate before.  One such issue was the education of women, since for Japan to attain a more powerful position within international politics, Japanese intellectuals argued that women had to be educated to become good wives and mothers and help the progress of their nation. This thesis demonstrates that, far from being passive actors in the 'modernisation' of the country, women created alternative spaces from which to voice their views and their demands.  Thus, in order to understand the importance and potential of the 'public sphere' in relation to the early Meiji period, I have used as my theoretical background the works of those female scholars who have developed Jürgen Habermas' theories to define women' s entrance into, and formation of, the public sphere.  I looked at the new professions opened to Japanese women, such as teaching and medicine, at the new public spaces in which they could be found, such as girls' schools and women's groups, and at the ways in which they established links with Western women and learned more about their movements and struggles. My thesis shows how the early Meiji years can be described as the period in which feminism became thinkable.  Only a few women were able to formulate thoroughly feminist theories in their writings or take an active part in pursuing their demands.  Nevertheless, and for the first time in Japanese history, they could start voicing thoughts in public settings by asking for more public space and participation in society while supporting the nationalistic ideology of educated mothers and wives.

Title: Italian anarchists in london (1870-1914)
Abstract: This thesis is a study of the colony of Italian anarchists who found refuge in London in the years between the Paris Commune and the outbreak of the First World War. The first chapter is an introduction to the sources and to the main problems analysed. The second chapter reconstructs the settlement of the Italian anarchists in London and their relationship with the colony of Italian emigrants. Chapter three deals with the activities that the Italian anarchists organised in London, such as demonstrations, conferences, and meetings. It likewise examines the ideological differences that characterised the two main groups in which the anarchists were divided: organisationalists and anti-organisationalists. Italian authorities were extremely concerned about the danger represented by the anarchists. The fourth chapter of the thesis provides a detailed investigation of the surveillance of the anarchists that the Italian embassy and the Italian Minster of Interior organised in London by using spies and informers. At the same time, it describes the contradictory attitude held by British police forces toward political refugees. The following two chapters are dedicated to the analysis of the main instruments of propaganda used by the Italian anarchists: chapter five reviews the newspapers they published in those years, and chapter six reconstructs social and political activities that were organised in their clubs. Chapter seven examines the impact that the outbreak of First World Word had on the anarchist movement, particularly in dividing it between interventionists and anti-interventionists; a split that destroyed the network of international solidarity that had been hitherto the core of the experience of political exile. Chapter eight summarises the main arguments of the dissertation.

Title: A theology of mission for post-communist poland: towards an integrative approach
Abstract: What might a theology of mission for churches in post-communist Poland look like?  The answer requires a prior examination of distinctive features of the Polish traditional culture.  This culture includes the close identification of Catholicism with the national identity, and contradictions between professed ethical values and the moral impact of massive changes suffered by society during and after the commitment era.  Equally, there are striking contrasts between official myth and harsh socio-political reality. The fall of communism in Poland in 1989 initiated a process of total social transformation, resulting in tensions between positive developments, including civil liberties and the market economy, and the high social costs associated with these changes.  A deep crisis of identity, arising from consumer culture, social fragmentation, uncertainty about the future and the growing number of conflicts of interest, are some of the outcomes that deeply affect the Polish ethos.  The religious sphere of Polish life did not remain unchanged as new trends and religious awareness emerged that can be best described in terms of the shift from the ‘Folk-Church’ to the ‘Church of Choice’. The Polish Church emerged as completely unprepared to face the new reality.  Thus, learning from global shifts in mission in the light of restrictive elements of ‘theology of the second world’ concerns more than the issues of survival.  It is a mission call for change and theological renewal in Poland.  On the basis of the critical analysis of the context, informed by broader perspectives of the global mission movement, it becomes clear that what the Polish Church requires is not just a change of methodology in mission, but rather a much deeper change, namely, development of a new holistic approach to mission imbedded in community.  From this arise three aspects of such a missional community:  a Community of Love, a Community of Word and Life, and a Community of Transformation. These, when dynamically integrated, form a valid, contextually relevant and missionally transformation vision of Church-in-mission, capable of beginning to respond to some of the main challenges arising in the post-communist context.

Title: Narratives of place, culture and identity: second-generation Greek-Americans return 'home'. (BL: DXN067821)
Abstract: The thesis explores the phenomenon of 'return migration' in Greece through the settlement and identification processes of second-generation Greek-American returning migrants.  It examines the meanings attached to the experience of return migration as they relate to and impact on the returnees' sense of self and sense of place.  The concepts of 'home' and 'belonging' figure prominently in the return migratory project which entails relocation and displacement as well as adjustment and alienation of bodies and selves.  Furthermore, the thesis considers the multiple interactions (social, cultural, political) between the place of origin and the place of destination; network ties; historical and global forces in the shaping of return migrant behaviour; and expression of identity.  The human geography of return migration extends beyond geographic movement into a diasporic journey involving (re)constructions of homeness and belongingness in the ancestral homeland. Return migration as process of relocation of both bodies and selves involves a disruptive space in terms of how culture is articulated in the ancestral homeland, expressive of national time and place.  The disruption involves a reassessment of relationships to both 'home' and 'host' countries.  The politics of space and of identity construct encounters of rupture when dimensions of 'nostalgia' in the lives of migrants attempt to forge a connection between 'imagined' notions of the ancestral homeland and the current 'pragmatic' trends in modern Greece.  Ultimately, the documentation of the tribulations experienced during the return adjustment reflects a process of cultural adjustment and reveals insights into the dynamics of the understood self and the perceived other. Through the analysis of the ethnographic and other material, return migration in the second-generation emerges as a multi-faceted process that profoundly impacts on returnees' identities.  Return migration is a highly complex yet illuminating aspect of migrant subjectivities and its study should be contextualised within specific social, cultural and political references.  That is, life stories of return migrants are directly related to the modern history of the nation and therefore become and integral part of the history of the nation.

Title: Is there a new trade union internationalism?  The ICFTU and the campaign for core labour standards in the WTO.
Abstract: This thesis investigates the extent to which a 'new' trade union or labour internationalism (NLI) has emerged since the end of the Cold War.  Employing an historical case study approach using primary and secondary documents, participant observation, and interviews with trade union officials and NGO workers, the thesis compares and contrasts the 'old labour internationalism' (OLI) of the Cold War era, with the contemporary activities of the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions (ICFTU).  The study specifically focuses on how the ICFTU constructed and pursued its main campaign between 1996 and 2001 for the inclusion of core labour standards in the World Trade Organisation (WTO) - the social clause.  The thesis argues that since the end of the Cold War, the ICFTU has undergone a difficult process of political, financial and organisational retrenchment, reorganisation and modernisation.  Its priorities have moved away from geo-politics towards addressing the impact of neo-liberal globalisation on trade unions worldwide.  It had professionalised its campaigning and lobbying capabilities, entered into closer alliances with labour NGOs, and attempted to involve its mass membership in its activities for the first time.  It has also partially opened up its decision-making structures to greater internal scrutiny and democratic participation, and relates to other international trade union bodies in a less hierarchical and territorial way. However, this enforced modernisation does not equate with a transformation, tentative or radical, towards a NLI.  Its adoption of the social clause campaign was primarily for reasons of institutional self-interest, and as a strategy towards globalisation it repeated it classic re-regulation approach to the world economy.  Its new symbolic orientation to alliance building and membership mobilisation is a largely strategic manoeuvre - its methodological spine remains rooted in its traditional elite lobbying approach and hostility to non-labour NGOs and social movements.  The thesis concludes that the ICFTU's core ideology, methodology and structures are strongly embedded in the discredited OLI model of the Cold War, but that internal and external pressures are forcing it to try to capture the new discourses and symbolic practices of labour internationalism.  Put succinctly, the ICFTU is at critical turning point in its history, rooted in and constrained by its past, but increasingly challenged to adapt and change to the challenges of the present and future.
