Title: A DISCUSSION ON THE GENERATION OF MODERN CHINESE LITERARY CURRENT
Abstract: From the present study of the Chinese modern literary current, the arising of the literary movement is usually regarded as the generation of the literary current. For this reason, few researchers have paid due attention to the generation of modern literary current in China as they have neglected the fact that Chinese literary enlightenment has rather great influence and restraint in the modern literary current. In fact, if people acknowledge that the cultural nature of the Chinese enlightenment has been evolved from the study of Confucian classics to that of literature, the influence of thought of the Chinese literary enlightenment has triggered the emergence of modern literary current, which has facilitated the arising of modern literary movement. At the same time, it must be recognized that the demand of ideology reconstruction for the Chinese literary enlightenment has restricted the full arising of the literary movement with the medium of the modern literary current. This is why the arising of modern Chinese literary movement requires the theory precedes literary creation, but unavoidably causes the biased result of the literary movement. The present study of the literary enlightenment and the modern literary current has two characteristics: one is the study of literary enlightenment and currents by dividing the modern era into two periods; the other is the study of them by separating the traditional influence of native culture from the modern influence of foreign culture. The first characteristic has initiated the second characteristic, and the second characteristic has strengthened the first characteristic. Thus it results in a quite influential study paradigm which focuses on one period with traditional influence or that with modern influence. However, in terms of the research tendency, there are also two major characteristics: the first characteristic is the research for the mentioned in the long period of time in history, the second is the synthetic research for modern transformation above mentioned. The first characteristic has facilitated the second characteristic, and the second characteristic has promoted the first one. Therefore, the synthetic research based on the long period of time has become a more and more influential study method. And only in this way, can we expand our research and make a more in-depth discussion on the Chinese literary enlightenment and the generating of modern literary current so as to grasp the multiple relationships between them. The origin of the Chinese literary enlightenment can not be separated from the Chinese enlightenment. First, the Chinese enlightenment is a kind of cultural enlightenment with historicity and totality. It is both modern and traditional. It has caused the interaction and compatibility of the modern orientation and the tradition continuation in the cultural enlightenment. How to avoid the dual opposition of understanding the cultural nature of the Chinese enlightenment also needs to refer to the theoretic thinking about cultural nature of the European enlightenment. Next, from the enlightenment of the study of Confucian classics to the literature, we can see that the evolution of the enlightenment mode in the Chinese enlightenment was undoubtedly happened under the historical background of the Chinese cultural development. Whether it is individual interpretation of the study of Confucian classics or the individual writing of literature will have relevant change with the cultural development. Therefore, the thought enlightenment,which has changed the individual choice from the study of Confucian classics to literature writing,has also showed process of thought evolution in the cultural enlightenment.Finally, the literary enlightenment specifically presents the modern orientation led by literary renovation. With the revitalizing of the enlightenment of the study of Confucian classics during the end of Qing Dynasty, the enlightenment mode has evolved from the study of Confucian classics to that of literature. Not only the enlightening group has been expanding from the scholars to writers, and the enlightening object from gentlemen to people, but also the mission of saving the nation from subjugation has been developed from the domestic revolution to the international anti-imperialism. Thus it has finally formed to the cultural tradition of enlightenment as saving the nation from subjugation. The initiation of modern literary current cannot be separated from the Chinese modernization. First, early in 1933, some people started to discuss "the issue of the Chinese modernization", which revealed the basic question that we had to solve for the Chinese modernization: the relations between the modern and tradition. The literary enlightenment is a traditional continuation of native culture based on the renovation of the cultural consciousness so that it can be adapted to the modern orientation of the foreign culture.This cultural characteristic of the Chinese modernization displays not only in the literary enlightenment, but also in the literature modernization.Next,there is an intrinsic relation between the literary enlightenment in China and drastically political change in China. After 1900, the Qing government had carried out a series of system transplanting which was objectively helpful to the social modernization, especially the modernization of the man in China.It facilitated not only the formation of independent thought, but also the disintegration of the ideological despotism to a certain degree. The man has come into the actual process of modernization as human beings. In conclusion, the generating of modern literary current in China has at the beginning maintained the intrinsic consistency with the literary enlightenment. The real outspread of literary enlightenment is inseparable from the modern renovation of the literary current.The transformation of literary idea has become the modern beginning of the self-enlightenment for the Chinese literary current. The whole revolution of the Chinese literature and the phased development of the literary enlightenment supplement each other. First, the wholeness of literature has experienced the complete evolution of the essential literary factors such as theme, genre, style and language, etc. By the end of Qing Dynasty, various kinds of insufficiencies that appeared in the beginning of the literary revolution in various circles, has directly affected the whole evolution of literature and exhibited the same nature. Both the literary thought resources and the ways of literary expressing have been mostly taken from the native traditional literature.Meanwhile, the literary revolution of various circles by the end of Qing Dynasty also displays the non-uniformity. The thought enlightenment of poetry and prose is restricted within the social elites, but the thought enlightenment of novel opens to the social populace. From revolution in the novel circle to the literary revolution, there is literary continuity that occurs on the level of essential literary factors between them. It has indicated that there exists homogeneity of the modern development of literature between the revolution of the novel circle by the end of Qing Dynasty and the literary revolution at the beginning of the Republic of China.Finally, the relationship between language and literature is fundamentally a cultural relationship. This relationship exists in human's language use from the whole process of literature writing to accepting. Therefore, the literary revolution is a creating process in which man gives life to literature by renewing language. The use of the word revolution has undoubtedly proved that the word may impel the language revolution of literature, and move to the thought revolution of enlightenment subsequently. There would be no individual prescience in literary enlightenment without the modern transformation of Chinese education. Firstly, the renovation of the Chinese education system started in 1901, and cleaned the path for the widespread of modern thought from other cultures. It has facilitated individual to make an independent choice in the literary enlightenment, and brought up the prescience community and the national community of enlightenment object. Thus it has effectively guaranteed the literary enlightenment in China.Secondly, the modern thought dissemination with overseas students as the medium, has become the basic premise for the full development of literary enlightenment in the course of cultural exchange between China and the West. This indicates that the generation of modern Chinese literary current derives from the absorption of the west learning. Due to the dissemination of modern thought generation after generation of the overseas students, the Chinese literary revolution is influenced in every respect. Finally, the prescient people made literary retrospection with the characteristic of pure thinking in the literary revolution of various circles at the end of Qing Dynasty, while in the literary revolution at the beginning of the Republic of China, they faced the requirement of reality and engaged in individual pondering. Thus, they have confirmed aesthetic essence of literature and determined modern development of literature. They promoted thorough outspread of the literary enlightenment, and facilitated the generation of modern Chinese literary current at the same time. The "literature of human" which becomes the main literary current has accepted the dissemination and the influence from the humanism. First, the native culture towards the traditional view of human is embodied by the consciousness of citizenship as "the people are the foundation of the state". During the process of literary enlightenment, the prescience takes humanism of the taking men as the center. The Chinese humanist ideal starts its construction through the modern transformation of the cultural consciousness from the consciousness of the citizenship to that of humanism. Next, the influence of native culture holds a strong position in the literary revolution of various circles at the end of Qing Dynasty. The traditional influence of the consciousness of citizenship has strengthened the political utilitarian nature of literary enlightenment, which causes the literature of "renewing people" to take a dominant position through the political teaching in the literary current. Finally, with the influence of the external culture became strong, the "literature of human" which is deeply influenced with humanism has become the mainstream during the generation of the modern Chinese literary current. But in the literary revolution movement," the life art school" gradually occupied the dominant position of the literary current. The occurrence of literature utilization might cause literature tending to be a practical tool. Thus, from the generation of modern Chinese literary current, the main literary current has turned from the literature of "renewing people" to the "literature of human", as the literary revolution of various circles during the end of Qing turned to the literary revolution at the beginning of the Republic of China at the same time.Therefore, no matter it is the thought enlightenment in the literary enlightenment or the literary modernization in the literary vicissitude, either one has direct influence in the generation of the modern literary current. It has brought the Chinese phenomenon which the literary ideas evolution from old to new prior to the whole evolution of essential literary factors. This phenomenon not only indicates the consistent relationship between the evolution of literary ideas from old to new and the literary enlightenment, but also proves certain realistic inevitability that the individual thinking of literary theory takes precedence of the individual writing of literary creation during the generative process of the modern literary current. It is necessary as reasonable to the presciences in literary enlightenment. This can explain why the theory initiative has advanced in the movement of the literary revolution in China. So, the literary current may surge to facilitate the arising of literary movement. In this sense, the literary revolution in China is a literary war that is initiated by a number of people to subvert the tyrant's-like literary kingdom. Of course, we should not neglect the fact that it is the existence of the thought enlightenment of literary enlightenment in China that displays an constrained influence in the generation of the literary current, and triggers the self-enlightening of the prescience from culture to literature. Therefore, it is not a kind of historical inevitability to the literary vicissitude in China that the precedence of initiating literary theory over the writing of literary creation. It needs to study widely and deeply in future.

Title: A Comprehensive Study of the Development of the CPC's Democratic Thoughts
Abstract: Before the foundation of the Communist Party of China (hereinafter CPC) the Chinese democratic revolution has been occurred. The Chinese revolution has been continued for several decades before CPC has become the major revolution force in Chinese political arena. The Revolution under the leadership of CPC has been the continuation of the Chinese democratic revolution indeed. Therefore, the following characteristic background for the foundation of CPC goes as: firstly, its long period of living in isolation and its serious political corruption have caused the under development of Chinese economy and thus the level of the productive forces for the development of democracy in China is kept really low; secondly, the invasion of the Imperial Powers has robbed China of its sovereignty as well as the independence of the Chinese nation; thirdly, the 1911 Revolution (Xinhaigemin) has overthrew the rule of the Qing Dynasty and established the Republic of China, but the newly born Republic of China headed by Jiang Jieshi later has turned into the regime of big landlords and bourgeoisie. It has not paved the way for the development of Chinese National Capitalism, but threw itself into the lap of Imperial Powers to suppress the development of Chinese National Capitalism. The nature of its Class has determined itself to fail to set down the right policy for the classes and politics in China so as to complete an effective political conformity of the Chinese society. Therefore, after the establishment of the Republic of China, the whole country still remains disintegrated, and the Chinese people still live an extremely poor life, let alone their independence and democratic rights in China. In 1917, the October Revolution in Russia won its victory and then it has brought Marxism into China. With its revolutionary and scientific and practical features, the Marxism has been accepted by the progressive intellectuals in China, therefore, CPC has come into being which has been the product of the combination of Marxism and Chinese revolutionary practices. Since its foundation, CPC has been guided by the Marxist proletariat revolutionary thoughts and struggled for the ideal of Communism. CPC has worked out the proletariat revolutionary strategy, adopted the democratic principles of Marxism, established the Marxist Party and Army and led Chinese people to carry on the democratic revolution in China. During the Chinese revolution, with the combination of democratic thoughts of Marxism and the revolutionary practice in China led by CPC, the CPC democratic thoughts have come into being. Thereafter the CPC democratic thoughts have been developing. This dissertation aims at making a comprehensive study of the CPC democratic thoughts in six chapters. Chapter one has discussed the establishment of CPC democratic thoughts. The CPC democratic thoughts set the Marxist democratic thoughts as its core with the background of particular Chinese revolution and rich Chinese Civilization. Therefore, the establishment of CPC democratic thoughts have been influenced by the following three forces: Marxist democratic thoughts, capitalist democratic thoughts, and the Chinese traditional thoughts such as “human-oriented and rule of virtue”. Since the establishment of the CPC democratic thoughts have come into being in the course of democratic revolution, it has presented itself with two features: adopting to conditions of Chinese revolution and responding to the task of the time. During the 1920s and 1930s, China has remained as no independence to the outside and no sovereignty inside, its people has lived in extremely poverty. Just like the famous scholar in Peking University, Prof. Guan Haiting pointed out in his writing, The Review of History of 20th Century Chinese Political Development, as to the Chinese people living in such a poor life, democracy has become a real luxury in their life, the first thing to do for the Chinese people at that time should be conducting the revolution to save the nation in peril, therefore, the Chinese democratic movement often serves as the tool to save the nation in peril and it remains not as its aim at all. That is why we can say that the CPC democratic thoughts have the revolutionary feature from its very beginning. The CPC democratic thoughts has developed with the focus of conducting Chinese revolution and taking the regime for the revolution, and with its aim of capturing the victory of the revolution in China and establishing of the new democratic state. Therefore the CPC democratic thoughts have been embodied as the concrete revolutionary strategy and tactics, such as “the mass line” and “united front”. As to the periods of establishment and development of the CPC democratic thoughts, the period from the foundation of CPC to the victory of new democratic revolution is the most important period for the primary establishment of the CPC democratic thoughts. Chapter two has talked about the development of the CPC democratic thoughts. Before the foundation of the People’s Republic of China, what kind of state-ship and government should be established in China has become an urgent task for CPC. At that time, guided by Marxist thought of Proletariat dictatorship and based on the practical condition of China, the CPC has creatively brought forward the People’s democratic dictatorship which guided the new China to establish the state-ship of the People’s democratic dictatorship and its basic democratic system, and has pave the way for the socialist democratic system in the way of government guarantee. In addition, CPC has guided Chinese people to pass the first basic law, namely, the Constitution in China in 1954. The Constitution has stipulated the state system of the People’s democratic dictatorship in China, the system of government of people’s congress, the basic democratic system of multi –nationality, the system of multi-party co-operation and democratic supervision, and democracy at basic levels. It has also regulated people’s basic democratic rights which has embodied the CPC democracy and democratic legal system thoughts. At the same time, CPC has led people to conduct the economic building and set the first five-year plan and the target of industrial development which has lain a solid base for the establishment of the socialist democratic system and embodied the CPC thought that the productive forces is the base for development of democracy. After foundation of People’s Republic of China (PRC), the state system of People’s democratic dictatorship is of the new democracy. During that period, the public ownership as the dominated position in the national economy has not established, and there are also five kinds of economic forces in the country’s economy which are not of the socialism. Guided by the ideal of the socialist democracy, CPC has renewed national economy and put forward their transition towards the socialist economy. CPC has regulated this transition into the Constitution which is the embodiment of CPC’s building of socialist democracy in China. The transition towards the socialist economy, the CPC democratic thoughts has also developed into the socialist democratic thoughts. After “the Three Great Remould” movements, namely, movements of socialist transformation of agriculture, handicrafts and capitalist industry and commerce, China has established the socialist democracy system and pushed the development of the CPC democratic thoughts into that of the Socialist democracy thoughts. This period has been the period of establishing and developing of CPC socialist democracy and legal system thoughts with its focus of creation of people’s democratic dictatorship, transition towards the socialism, paving the way for building of socialism and making perfect the legal system. Chapter three has focused on the ups and downs of the CPC democratic thoughts. After the completion of “the Three Great Remould” movements, the new system of socialism has been established in China. The development of Chinese democracy and that of the CPC democratic thoughts both have been based on the socialism thereafter. Before and after “the 8th CPC National Congress”, the CPC has made a lot of exploration in the way of how to improve and develop the socialist democracy. The CPC has found more problems and studied more issues. For example,, Mr. Mao Zedong has discussed how to balance the relation between the central government and the local government in his On the Ten Major Relations and on its related discussions. In the field of scientific work, the CPC has adopted the guideline of “letting a hundred flowers blossom and a hundred schools of thought contend”, developed a policy of “long-term co-existence and mutual supervision” with other democratic parties, and formed the thought of “handling correctly the contradictions among the people” and so on. During September 15-27, 1956, the 8th CPC National Congress was held in Beijing which was held with the background of the victory of the socialism and the realization of its fundamental change of social conditions in China. The congress has reflected the status of the every social class and Chinese changes in their political, cultural and economic senses. The congress has summed up the experiences of the People’s democratic dictatorship as well as of constructing the newly socialist democracy. More importantly, the congress was held after the 20th National Congress of Communist Party of the Soviet Union and has discussed the malpractice of the Soviet Union Mode and stressed the issue of the development of democracy and brought forward many thoughts and strategies of constructing the socialist democracy. But due to the pressing economic development and the threat from the international capitalism, due to the unilateralism of developing the economy and due to the influence of the malpractice of the Soviet Union Mode, the “Left” mistakes have occurred in the CPC and the thoughts of the 8th National Congress has been given up in the practice of socialist construction. During the transformation to the socialist construction, the development of the CPC democratic thoughts has been misled and the “Left” thought in CPC has been spread unchecked and prevented the development of the socialist democracy and led to the happening of the tragedy of “Cultural Revolution”. Chapter four has stressed the recovery and the development of the CPC democratic thoughts. The opening of 3rd Plenary Session of the 11th National Congress of the CPC has indicated the ending of the “Left” errors in CPC. The 3rd Plenary Session of the 11th National Congress of the CPC has resumed the Marxist thought line of “seeking truth from the facts” and renewed the correct thought of how to develop the socialist democratic thoughts around the 8th National Congress of CPC. During the correction of the “Left” errors, CPC has set forth the Four Fundamental Principles (the socialist road, the People’s democratic dictatorship, Marxist-Leninism and Mao Zedong Thoughts and the leadership of the CPC) which guide the construction of the socialist democracy. Along the correct guideline of “seeking the truth from facts”, the CPC has set forth the thoughts of reforming system. As to the economic system, the CPC has brought forward the central task of the economic construction and come back to the road of Marxist idea that “the productive forces have been the base for the development of democracy. Constructing the socialist democracy must be needed to enhance the construction of the legal system and democratic system, and make the democratic system institutionalized and legalized so that to meet the requirement of extending democracy and of constructing the socialist modernization. The CPC has brought forth the thought of reforming the system of cadre leadership which starts to the prologue of reforming the political system. Chapter five has detailed the comprehensive development of the CPC democratic thoughts. On the 12th National Congress of CPC, the CPC has stated the importance of developing democracy from the overall situation of constructing the socialist modernization. The CPC headed By Mr. Deng Xiaoping has changed the modernization development strategy from its unilateralism of developing the economy into the comprehensive one, in other words, modernization in China means not only the modernization of economy, but also the modernization of politics and culture. The CPC has also set forth the task of building our great motherland into a strong, prosperous, democratic and culturally advanced modern socialist country. Thereafter the CPC democratic thoughts has finally shook off from its thinking of revolution and stepped into the suitable track of developing the socialist democracy in China, set out the strategy of comprehensive development of the society and has made the democracy as one of the developing target of the whole development of the society. The reforming of the political system has officially brought forward only after the primary success of the economic reforming. With the deepening economic system reform, the former political system has not met the development of economy. In order to liberate the productive forces and shake off the bondage of related superstructure, the 13th National Congress of CPC has stressed the thought of reforming the political system. On the 13th National Congress of CPC, the CPC has stated the thought of reforming the political system in a comprehensive way which is the further advance in developing the CPC democratic thoughts. With the further development of reforming and opening-up, the CPC has continued its exploration in developing the socialism and later the CPC has developed the theory that China was in the primary stage of socialism and the thought of the socialist commodity economy and further developed into forming the new theory of building socialism with Chinese characteristics. Among which building the socialist democratic thoughts with Chinese characteristics has become the advancement of the CPC democratic thoughts. With the guideline of building the socialist democratic thoughts with Chinese characteristics, the CPC has formed its reform thought of political system with the base of “adhering to and improving the socialist democracy system” in its practice of political reforms. With the advancement in legal system construction and publication of democracy, the CPC has developed into the thought of “ruling with law and constructing the socialist legal country”. After the successes in reforms in economic and political systems and with the start of building a well-off society in an all-round way, the CPC has pointed out the new thought of development of political civilization as its democratic thoughts. The development of political civilization has come into being with the development of the times and it is the requirement for the CPC to build a well-off society in an all-round way and it is also the advancement of CPC democratic thoughts. In terms of its contents, the development of the CPC democratic thoughts has been centered on how to reform and improve the basic system of the socialism, and the development stage is its mature period for the CPC democratic thoughts. Chapter six has summed up the path and characteristics of the CPC democratic thoughts. The development of the CPC democratic thoughts has been influenced by many factors, such as social conditions for the economy, people’s education level, people’s knowledge of law, and democratic practice. It is clear that the CPC democratic thoughts have been a combination of many factors. With the influence of these factors, the CPC democratic thoughts have gained their characteristics: people’s democratic dictatorship, socialism, adaptation to the revolution and construction, keeping on developing and so on. In general, the various stages of the CPC democratic thoughts have indicated a progressive course in which the latter stage has advanced with the base of the former. From the revolution period to the socialist construction period, the CPC democratic thoughts have adapted to the requirement of revolution first and then of socialist construction, and experienced the following stages: from the democratic thoughts of the revolutionary party to that of the party in power, from its stress on seizing the victory of the revolution and creating new system to stressing the socialist systematic construction and legal development, from its stressing that democracy should be submitted to the needs of revolution and economic construction to the idea that the democracy construction has become the important part of collective targets of socialist construction. In the part of conclusion, this dissertation has stressed again that the CPC democratic thoughts have been guided by the ideal of communism and developed with the direction of socialist democratic practice, in other words, the CPC democratic thoughts have developed with the direction of communist ideal and also with the direction of socialist practice which reflects that the basic law of Chinese Socialist democracy development led by the CPC, namely, from its ideal to its practice, and again from its practice to its ideal. Therefore, not only from the viewpoint of the CPC democratic thoughts, but also from the practice guided by the CPC democratic thoughts, the ideal is not far from us, our theory could give us strong motivation an push us forwards our ideal; as long as we strive for our ideal with heart and soul, we human beings could step into the glorious future of Communism.

Title: Research for auto consumer finance--With analysis and suggestion to auto consumer finance in China
Abstract: The huge demand for capital is recognized as main characteristics of auto industry for many reasons to sustain manufacture and sales. The utilization of finance to boost production and sales is the incentive for auto manufactures to chase for financial service. The earliest auto consumer finance --- auto consumer credit originated from United States in 1907. Following booming demand for automotives in America, Germany and Japan, the auto finance increasingly expanded. The main business of auto finance is identified as auto consumer credit and auto leasing, plus refunding and entrusting purchasing and so on. Auto consumer finance and auto industry are interacting on each other and you may find the most sophisticated service nowadays in United States, Germany and Japan. In those countries, the auto consumer finance features on easy process, innovative products, improved credit evaluating system, robust legislation and regulation and specialized finance agency etc. Along with the revolution, the auto financial services company invested by auto manufacturer plays major role counting on its exclusive advantage of industry-insider and massive volume. This paper illuminates in different scope of the functionality of domestic and especially foreign auto financial services company in a bid to further disclose the fast movement of auto financial services company and its growing tendency towards multipleness and industrialization.. On basis of wide experiences learnt from mature markets such as America, Japan and Germany, this paper is to stress on study of development and current status of Chinese auto consumer finance. In particular, it illustrates the characteristics of domestic economy and auto industry in different phases, and puts forward reasons constraining further development of auto consumer finance. Based on which the paper brings forward suggestions and conditions to boost auto consumer finance in China: bolster versatile auto finance services, encourage to develope auto financial services company, establish social credit system, and improve legislation and regulations. In brief, heavily looking at global auto consumer finance --- auto consumer credit and auto leaseing and other successful operational experiences in developed countries, this paper puts forward detailed suggestions to boost China auto consumer finance combining with analysis of domestic current status.

Title: Reason Analysis of The Rupture of Sino-Soviet Alliance
Abstract: In the 50th and 60th of the 20th century, the development of the Sino-Soviet relation may be said the path winds along mountain ridges, full of twists and turns or ups and downs. The Sino-Soviet relation has gone through forming an alliance and following honeymoon in the fifties, and develop into the breaking of the national relation and party relationship in the sixties. The development of the Sino-Soviet relation, especially the rupture of Sino-Soviet relation has caused inestimable losses to the international communist movement and the two countries at that time. The international communist movement is split greatly, and move towards the low ebb progressively. Two Sino-Soviet countries fall foul of each other, which have caused a series of questions such as the border and national conflict, etc. It causes the incomparable negative effect to both sides' politics, economic and foreign relations. Why did Sino-Soviet relation change so deeply within so transient time? Especially it is beyond belief that more and more prosperous Sino-Soviet relation on the surface " suddenly "reaches the situation that national relation is serious damaged, and party relationship totally breaks. In the initial stage when the Sino-Soviet relation breaks, Sino-Soviet both sides shirk responsibilities to the other side. Both sides at that time explain from one's own ideology, and attack the other side's ideology faith each other so as to prove itself is the Marxism-Leninism orthodox school. With the development of time and the open of the relevant files material, especially since latter half of 1990s, more and more scholars begin to care about the real reason of Sino-Soviet splitting, and put forward such national benefit say, ideology say, leader individual say, development path say etc. At the same time those who go through the Sino-Soviet splitting in those years have mentioned the Sino-Soviet reason by way of having an informal discussion and memoir from different angles. This text attempts to catch two threads that run through Sino-Soviet related to development tightly: National benefit close and conflict, unity and difference of ideology, finding the reason that relation breaks in concerning from national benefit and interdynamic of ideology. The full text divides into four chapters altogether: Chapter one sketch the course that the Sino-Soviet relation breaks, and the research results of the reason about breaking both at home and abroad in recent years mainly; Chapter two proceed with explanation of the national benefit, introduce the Sino-Soviet both sides' different explanation to each country's benefit. With forming an alliance relation for big background, it discusses the maintaining for prerequisite with alliance national foundation reason of benefit while being Sino-Soviet. Considering from geopolitics, national security strategy, national relation normal form, social economic development, etc. several respect probe into in form an alliance with honeymoon national unanimous and conflict of interests, both sides of stage, while being Sino-Soviet, And the sharp collision of the Sino-Soviet national benefit of latter half of the fifties of the 20th century; Chapter three attempt to probe into ideology and dispute, which has the malignant influence on the Sino-Soviet national relation from another aspect. Mainly from both sides heavy difference such as the Soviet Communist Party 20 heavy, Stalin issue, three peace route, development path headed by Soviet to explain the really essential of ideology difference, and to dispute the enormous destruction function on the relations of both ideology. Chapter four explain mainly the rupture of Sino-Soviet relation on the domestic influence to both sides, and how to think about the role of the national benefit and ideology correctly.

Title: Rational Thinking of Technological innovation Strategy and Choice of Pattern
Abstract: How to reflect the globality , independence , affinity to the people of technological innovation? The theory meaning studied lies in order to build and construct the theory system which knows new development in science and technology, offer the new analysis vision ; Practice meaning lies in submitting to the policymaker of our country while making the technological innovation strategy, should watch out for digital disparity , information is unjust , such new-type social contradictions as knowledge splits up ; Carry out the social goal of the affinity to the people of knowledge and policy system of the social development conscientiously, real representative's vastest people's basic benefit. Just the rational thinking of the strategic choice of technological innovation was launched in this text. This text divides three chapters altogether. Chapter one consists some of theoretical foundation of the strategic choice method of technological innovation. This chapter, to technological determinism, it criticize society theory, after construct there aren't doctrine and Marx materialist conception of history building by knowledge theory , society, clarifying different theories school will make the rational composition to the technological innovation strategy. Regard Marx's materialist conception of history as the basic program , the rational kernel with the main schools of thought complemented, refine and make three basic categories of technological innovation strategy: Globality , independence and affinity to the people. Chapter this to extend as clue with reason at first, through teach beginners reach rational hegemony modern reason, criticize from rational value neutrality to technological reason, to technological " morbid state society " and each criticism of aspect of " alienation of people " that reason bring, form by society already it last school line of demarcation not different of theory,not for instance alienation theory , Frank school not technological of Marx, behind modernism,etc. It is still western major ideology that technology rules the theory at present, its advance and independence of paying attention to technical development, as to developing economy fast, have certain reference function. The society criticizes the theory and emphasizes the humane care to people, have positive meanings to the globality of choosing globality development strategy of technological innovation. And then the modern knowledge theory is about the scientific diversified thought of culture , having meaning of building to the independence of technological innovation. Society is it construct theory emphasize productivity especially science and technology whether society of people is it construct to build to build, society build technological democracy to construct doctrine is it check development strategy of affinity to the people in technological innovation have realistic meanings inside rationally to wait. Chapter two explains the evolution of the technological innovation theory from theory aspect at first, technological innovation theory develop into from economics concept, bear of Peter society is it construct national innovative system of theory to build already. It construct from society theory think national innovative body have globality , independence and affinity to the people to build, regulate the function that the market does not work and the government does not work. Is it combine together in terms of the view to construct materialist conception of history and society , regard national innovative system as carriers to build secondly, analyse the contemporary forms of productivity and contradiction movement of relations of production in era of knowledge-driven economy, so as to announce the display form of the social basic contradiction of knowledge. Namely what knowledge natural instinct socialization and knowledge occupied is not the dialectical relation between socialization; Contemporary western development relies on the whole world of knowledge to spread the high concentration with knowledge power , cause " knowledge disparity " between the developed country and the third world. The disequilibrium of development of the world is shown as " digital divide " expanded outstandingly day by day, form new global gap between rich and poor in information age. We should choose the globality of technological innovation , the development strategies of the independence and affinity to the people , watch out for globalization and conceal knowledge monopolizing and knowledge hegemony which some developed countries follow , prevent from from " technology rely on " to the political trap where " sovereignty rely on ". Chapter three regards developed industrial country and newly industrializing country as the system of consulting , analyse one by one about its economic development and technological innovation strategy mode. The theory that the developed country has finished technical revolution of modern science without any confusion in 100 solid years is created and melted, research and development , new and high technology industrialization and globalization ,etc. develop the step, pay attention to the independence and globality of technological innovation on the technological innovation strategy, is it raise manpower capital competence through education to put emphasis on , realize economic catching up with and surpassing. It is an important means that the newly industrializing country catches up with and surpasses with technology, pursue the advance of technology. Developing countries generally adopt the depending on mode in economic development, lack independence on the technological innovation strategy. Though the former Soviet Union has scientific and technological advantages , has not handled the relation between the technology and affinity to the people well . China is walking while new and industrialized, is building and constructing the socialist harmonious society, must regard Deng Xiaoping Theory , important thought of 'Three Represents' and scientific development view as the guidelines , insist on the public and private unity of opposites of scientific and technical innovation, unity of opposites of the global and national characteristic, unity of opposites of technology import and autonomous innovation unity of opposites , economic growth and core technological ability unity of opposites , humane care and scientific and technological progress.

Title: The Vicissitudes Of Society In Nanxun Of China
Abstract: In this article,the author researches a town named Nanxun in Hangjiahu Plain in the northern part of Zhejiang province.Under the background of natural exploitation and human development of Taihu Basin,and the clue of rise and fall of silk industry since modern times,the paper describes the social changes of this special area during about a hundred years, analyzes the inside and outside factors of the silk industy's vicissitudes,as well as the ups and downs of businessmen' colony of Nanxun, and ulteriorly discusses the changes in the fields of social economy and culture in China. This thesis discusses the developing process of the silk industry and economy of the town in Nanxun.It divides the process into three stages,namely,before the Opium War,after the Opium War to late 19th century,from late 19th century to 1937. Before the Opium War,the development of chinese silk industry mainly relys on domestic demand.After that until late 19th century,export and domestic sales have half each.After late 19th century,export sales are a large proportion. Since late 19th century ,the economy in Nanxun has developed continually and reach a peak between in the 1920s and 1930s,especially in the 1920s.Traditional rural professional economy makes great progress under the situation of new international trade and brings an unprecedented prosperity for Nanxun.After traditional handicraft industry fails to compete with machine produce of modern China,all kinds of "new"cottage industries rise up and temporarily recuperate after traditional handicraft's losses. Because of a close contact with international trade,on one hand,the traditional handicraft can develop rapidly,consequently brings the prosperity of the town.On the other hand,it also falls into a decline because of the changes of international market. During this process, the author points out several outstanding essentials: First of all,the impetus to promote economic growth of Nanxun mostly comes from the international demands for raw silk.Since the opening of five treaty ports and the evolution of the Shanghai port,the demands act directly on this area and make it develop continually. Secondly,as interior power goes,the fateful improvement happens in the 1870s,that is to say,castle silk is weaved into silk so as to export.The improving course is passive,not active.With the rise of machine silk industry,Nanxun finally falls into a producing area of the materials -----pods. Thridly,we should notice the private mode of operation based on the family,which has continued for several thousand years.Not only the agricultural economy of the combination of plough and weaving in Pre-Modem,but also a variety of machining industries rising in rural areas,the mode of operation regarding the family as a basic unit has never changed. Thus it can be seen that the rural economy of towns always behaves to accommodate "passively" itself to the western civilization in the face of the western civilization that modern industry is a representative of it.It hardly happens to affiliate contemporary factors to the commodities and the mode of operation. Therefore,as a traditional town,Nanxun is a representative of Jiangnan towns because of its great rise and fall.Its prosperity relys on the traditional silk industry and the trade of "Huzhou silk"rising from the industry.The demands for castle silk of market abroad impulse its development.Further more,the opening of five treaty ports and the repid evolution of the Shanghai port give Nanxun the chance to improve.When facing the western civilization,the town hardly has a desire to take adventage of the new technology for itself.It even laughs at the machine silk industry,and is still immersed in reeling silk with indigenous method.Therefore,its decline is a inevitable result of the development of modern silk technology.It is just the modern silk industry which seizes the oversea market in the first instance and then domestic market.Finally it makes the traditional silk industry decline. The modern fate of Nanxun is just the same as the fate of the traditional silk industry of China to a certain extent. From the late 1950s to the late 1970s,in the rural economic policy,chinese govenment experiences to take a quantum leep and regress again.The course vividly shows that the family individualism possesses a stubborn vitality and a great adaptability.This kind of small-scale producing mode makes privite economy burst forth in the littoral province of China in the late 1970s.At the same time,countless markets of industrial products and agricultural products spring up,and propel the peerless urbanization process of rural towns,which is the continuation of the modern movement in Jiangnan towns during 1920s and 1930s.The private mode of operation in traditional society of small farmer has a stubborn vitality and follows to this day.

Title: CPC’s Theory on Religions and Its Policy Implications:1949 to Present
Abstract: Religions in Mainland China enjoy a great development in the 21st Century in general, and some religions develop especially quickly. Accordingly, the social effects of religions extend greatly, social contradictions caused by the interweaving of religious and ethnic issues are more severe than ever, and hostile forces outside infiltrate in the internal religious affairs further. All the matters above raise new problems in the management of religions, even its power wielding methods and founding for the Communist Party of China (CPC). Thus, we should sum up the CPC’s theory on religions and its policies as well, and its experiences and lessons. In my opinion, it is a significant theoretic and practical issue for the proper understanding and management of China’s religions, for the unification of the Nation as a whole, the stability of the society, and the development of the socialist modernization undertakings. The dissertation is composed of six parts, which would be summarized respectively in the following. The Introduction of the dissertation summarizes religions and its social effects in the Old China, and Marxist views on religions and its communication in China at that period and the CPC’s theories and policies concerned before the foundation of the People’s Republic of China. There are many religions in China, for example, Buddhism, Daoism, Islamism, Catholicism, Christianism, Orthodox Church and other religions of certain minorities, or local beliefs. In the Old China, almost every religions had been controlled and exploited by the ruling classes and accordingly had some negative effects. Since the October Revolution of the Russia, Marxism entered into China, and CPC members such as Chen Duxiu, Li Dazhao and Yun Daiying introduced Marxist views on the origins, the evolution and the social effects of religions. Before 1949, the main task of the CPC was to struggle for liberation and independence of Chinese people from the semi-colonial and semi-feudal society. The CPC must solidify all possible forces to make final success, how to unite people from religious cycle became a practical issue for the CPC. According to the needs of national liberation and the characteristics of the religions themselves, the CPC began to form patriotic and anti-imperial united front with the religious cycle, , and the CPC began to accept the principle of religious belief freedom and the views on how to manage religions. Chapter One of the dissertation studies the CPC’s theoretic views and policies on religions during the period of 1949 to 1956. It was the period of China’s socialist transition. Abided by the general line for the transition period, and by publicizing further the Marxist theory of religion, the CPC summed up the five characters of religion, that is, long-termed, mass-driven, ethnical, international and complicated characters. The cognition became the foundations of CPC’s policies towards religious affairs during the period. In the Constitution of the People’s Republic of China, the principle of religious belief freedom had been erected. As for the specific policies, the CPC made religious reform to apply to the New Society. At the very initial stage of the period, the imperial forces exploited Catholicism and Christianism in resistance against the New China, so the CPC led the autonomy, self-communication and self-supporting movement of the two religions, so as to break off all relations of the two religions with the imperialism. To get rid of the feudal vestiges in Buddhism and Daoism, the CPC first suppressed the anti-revolutionary remnant forces in the temples, and stressed the patriotic education of the Buddhists and Daoists; and then got rid of the feudal land property system and patriarchal management system, and carried out democratic management system; thirdly, organized the Buddhists and Daoists to participate in production activities and to earn their own livings. Islamism and Lamaism were two main religions in the minority regions of China. For the stability of the newly-established state power and the undeveloped consciousness of the ethnical mass, though the integration pf church and state of the two religions could not adapt to the needs of the New China, CPC adopted modest policy on the democratic reform of the two religions, accordingly, the reform of Islamism began in 1958, and that of the Lamaism began in 1959, and the reform succeeded by the end of 1960, and the feudal prerogatives and exploitation system had been got rid of, and all religious believers were liberalized from the oppress and exploitation of the religious feudalism, thus promoting the political, economic and cultural development and ethnical unity. In sum, the religious reform led by CPC at the beginning and the first stage of the PRC was surly a success, whose achievements should be affirmed. ……..

Title: The study of Chinatown as an urban artifice and its impact on the Chinese community in London
Abstract: Sociologists claim that the ethnic Chinese community in the United Kingdom cannot be spatially defined. The first reason is that the widely scattered Chinese catering businesses-still the main source of employment for incoming Chinese migrants - makes the Chinese community too dispersed to form residential enclaves. Secondly, the evasive nature of the ethnic Chinese population towards government assistance and strong sense of ethnic solidarity also makes them an "invisible community". The Confucian philosophy governing their way of life further reinforces patrilineal links oriented towards ancestral villages in China. Recent renewed interests in the future of London's Chinatown as the result of a recent development plan has prompted this report to investigate whether a spatial pattern of occupation by the Chinese community exists in Chinatown, or if it is simply an intelligent urban artifice exploited for touristic and commercial purposes. Unlike its historical East End predecessor which has never been exclusively Chinese, present day London Chinatown can be qualified as a "persistent enclave". Whilst it crucially accommodates co-ethnic businesses and facilities for the oriental population, it is not the sole centre for the Chinese community. At the outset, studies on the Chinese have been confounded by their lack of assimilation into host society, inconsistent methods of data representation from the population census and high levels of suspicion by the immigrant community when conducting fieldwork. By first understanding historical developments in London's two Chinatowns and concepts pertaining to Chinese ethnography, this helps substantiate the demographic data, changing land use and household occupation by the Chinese community in Limehouse around 1890 and Soho today. The global and local relationship for these two areas are also analysed syntactically through spatial maps derived from Booth's Map of Poverty of 1889 and a current axial map of London respectively. The spatially-oriented case study of Soho's Chinatown identifies through a public survey a collective mental representation of its neighbourhood area that differs from its administrative designation. Pedestrian movement studies suggest that there is a distinct spatial and temporal pattern of occupation amongst the ethnic Chinese which differs from non-Chinese tourists and locals which can be syntactically measured. The findings support the view that a complex social and spatial relationship exists between the two disparate groups that utilise Chinatown. Whilst its commercial success is crucial to maintaining Chinatown's public profile, it also allows it to continue to function as an important centre for the Chinese community.

Title: Trade unions, strategic pedagogy and globalisation: learning from the anti-privatisation struggles of sintraemcali
Abstract: The thesis explores trade union resistance to neo-liberal globalisation through a case-study of the strategic development of Sintraemcali (the trade union of the Municipal Enterprises of Cali) in Colombia. Sintraemcali, since the mid 1990's, has fought off a series of attempts by the Colombian government to privatise the public utilities of water, electricity and telecommunications. Drawing on Burawoy's (1998) Extended Case Method the research is based on 16 months of participatory ethnographic fieldwork and develops a critical theory approach to researching `globalisation from below' through drawing on the work of the Neo-Gramscian School and that of Boaventura de Sousa Santos. The thesis focuses on one particular episode of protest - the 36 day CAM Tower Occupation that began on December 25th, 2001 - in order to understand the conditions that enabled this event to come about. This episode of protest linked workers and local communities in mass protest and operated on a range of scales from the local to the global. The thesis explores how this multi-scalar strategy developed. The thesis traces the historical development of these strategies and explores Sintraemcali's transformation during the 1990's from a corporate trade union fighting for the particular interests of its affiliates to a social movement union defending the broader interests of the local community. The transformation of the trade union took place under the difficult conditions of Colombia where trade unions and human rights activists are regularly subject to assassination by state and para-state forces. Through a reconceptualisation of `trade union education' the thesis argues that Sintraemcali's transformation can be understood as a pedagogical process. The main argument put forward is that the emergence of a strategic pedagogy within the union facilitated the development of a broad multi-scalar strategy that included: (1) an alternative economic strategy for the management of Emcali; (2) a trade union/ community alliance within the city of Cali in defence of public services; (3) a mobilisation strategy which included a series of militant occupations of high profile buildings; and, (4) a human rights strategy that provided access to local, national and international legal and advocacy mechanisms that facilitated Sintraemcali's ability to globalise its struggle against privatisation. The research isolates two key pedagogical processes at work that serve to modify the context within which Sintraemcali operated: transborderisation and horiiontalisation. The first challenges the view that labour organisations can only operate at the local scale and highlights how, through a multi-scalar pedagogy, Sintraemcali members and allies developed new skills, knowledge and strategies that enabled them to operate on a range of scales from the local to the global. The second pedagogical process, horiiontalisation, highlights the rearticulation of trade union objectives towards an ethic of citizenship and human rights. This allowed for the development of a more reciprocal relationship between the trade union, social movements, and marginalised communities at a range of geographical scales.

Title: The look of Ireland: The representation of Ireland in Gael Linn's “Amharc Éireann” film series, 1956–1964
Abstract: Gael Linn's Amharc Éireann (literally translated as Look at Ireland ) film series began in 1956 as monthly short documentary films on topics of domestic interest and was transformed in 1959 to weekly newsreels. It was a cultural nationalist project sponsored by Gael Linn, a newly-formed Irish language protection organization whose mandate was the revitalisation of the Irish language through the use of modern media and technology, and produced by Colm Ó Laoghaire, a member of a well-known Irish literary and nationalist family (the Plunketts). Created during a period of rapid social, economic and political change, it reflects and records the dramatic transformation of Ireland from a rural, underdeveloped and relatively isolated nation into a modern member of the international economic and political community. As the first and longest-running Irish-language documentary and news-film series, Amharc Éireann represented the attempt on the part of a few committed Irish-language enthusiasts to present Ireland to the Irish in a way that would instill a sense of pride in the country, and to promote the language in a way that the public would accept. Irish-language productions and non-fiction film are both relatively under-researched areas of study. This dissertation analyzes the context, production, reception and content of the series, establishing its contemporary significance and its relation to the Irish language revival movement by critically dissecting the image of Ireland that Gael Linn and Ó Laoghaire constructed. As the first investigation of the Amharc Éireann series as an historical artefact, it broadens the field of Irish cultural history. By focusing on non-fiction film, it expands the popular conception of film studies. By looking at the promotion of the Irish language and culture through modern media, it examines the construction and reflection of Irish identity in the 20 th century.

Title: The political economy of crisis and global governance
Abstract: This thesis considers the significance of contemporary developments in global governance.  It argues that contemporary processes can be understood via Marx's depiction of the crisis ridden nature of historically developing social relations under capitalism and Gramsci's concept of hegemony, Poulantzas's notion of relative autonomy of political authority and Karl Polanyi's description of the 'double movement'.  Following several other critical scholars influenced by these concepts, the thesis develops a multi-dimensional analytical matrix for understanding patterns of change and persistence in the construction of capitalist hegemony, and different manifestations of it. The thesis argues that contemporary global governance is characteristic of the construction of a specifically neo-liberal hegemony but that this is characterised by two distinct phases.  While the first was disciplinary in nature and concerned to dismantle a previously embedded hegemonic world order, second-phase strategies aim to contain the crisis tendencies generated by first-phase reform, embedding capitalist hegemony over the long-term.  The deployment of these second-phase strategies by agencies bearing a degree of relative autonomy at domestic, macro-regional and global levels is considered in depth through three case study chapters.

Title: British expatriate belonging in dubai: foreignness, domesticity, intimacy
Abstract: This thesis analyses expatriate belonging through an ethnography of the British in Dubai. As an account of diasporic or transnational belonging, it is fully grounded in the complexity of everyday lives. This is achieved by exploring expatriate experiences of foreignness, domesticity and intimacy, three thematic strands that are attentive to contemporary theory in their recognition that belonging is embodied, material and emotional respectively. Each of the ethnographic chapters contributes to particular theoretical literatures. Focussing on the construction and enactment of foreignness in the daily lives of expatriates, the first chapter situates the British within Dubai's complex, racialised, social hierarchy and draws on theories of `whiteness' and an unsettling, bodily, experience of `culture shock', to complicate our understanding of expatriate racisms. In the second ethnographic chapter, the thesis explores domestic material culture in British expatriates' homes, analysing belongings and the homemaking practices in which they are involved, including display, remembering, shopping and cleaning. The third part of the thesis highlights the emotional geographies of expatriate intimacy as they are negotiated transnationally and within Dubai in (gendered) practices of relatedness, conjugality, conviviality, friendship and dating. Finally, a personal reflection on the ethnographic research experience also links my experience of ethnographic fieldwork closely into these themes. More generally then, by using this theoretical trinity combined with ethnographic research, the thesis illuminates the interdependence of the (trans)national and local, the material and imagined, as well as movement and attachment, in the everyday complexity of lived belonging. It is argued that British expatriate belonging is characterised by multiplicity, ambivalence and everyday negotiative effort.

Title: Struggling toward a new earth: the integration of faith and development practice within christian aid with particular reference to a brazilian partner, centro de estudos e ação social
Abstract: This thesis addresses the following question: what is the Christian contribution that a faith-based agency such as Christian Aid brings to development practice. It explores the integration of theological reflection with development work and advocacy in two faith-based organisations: Christian Aid (CA), a UK relief and development organisation and one of its overseas partners, Centro de Estudos e Ação Social (CEAS), a Brazilian Jesuit-based community development organisation. Such a question has been overlooked by many people working within development in the North but is often central to agencies in the South. Stemming from liberation theology, this thesis argues that the practice of these organisations is both developmental (economic, political, and cultural) and theological. It analyses two components arising out of the integration of faith and development. The first component is the methodology of action and reflection, the hermeneutic circle, that these organisations follow. The second is the content, the issues, emerging from the reflection. The first chapter analyses the method of the hermeneutic circle. This circle critically reflects in community on reality and spirituality, each in the light of the other. This thesis followed a similar method in its formation. The practice and reflection of CA and CEAS were considered through participant observation in both organisations with subsequent theological reflection. The following chapters explore the movement through the hermeneutic circle. First is the analysis of reality. CA’s acceptance of the development paradigm and globalisation is explored through its current focus: a campaign for fairer international trade. CEAS, in contrast, rejects economic development and globalisation. It focuses on the political realm encouraging the poorest communities to struggle with the local government, building their capacity as citizens. CA supporters also consider alternatives to development and globalisation, focusing on the local rather than the global and on the political as well as the economic realm.

Title: Professional health promoters?  Re-conceptualising urban women's organising in Peru.
Abstract: Whilst the Peruvian grassroots women's organisations of the 1980s became seen internationally as emblematic success stories of community self-help, there has been little more recent research which examines the current situation of urban, grassroots women, following 20 years of neoliberal development policies. This thesis aims to address this gap by examining how the situation of popular women activists has changed in the light of two decades of grassroots struggle. It focuses on the case of the long-established Centro de Servicios Integrados, a women's health project run by grassroots health promoters in a popular settlement in Lima, and supported by the feminist NGO, Mureres Trabajando Juntas. Drawing primarily on life histories narrated by the health promoters, this thesis focuses on the promoters' pathways to professionalisation; tensions and polarisation between the NGO and the grassroots organisation; changing leadership paradigms at the grassroots; and the interaction of local grassroots women activists in wider national and transnational networks. The thesis questions how individual health promoters have progressed socially and professionally over the 15-20 years that they have been involved in the Centro de Servicios Integrados, focusing on the extent to which, despite the 'voluntary' nature of the work, the women health promoters have become local experts. However, the research suggests that their knowledge and skills are rarely scaled up beyond the local level. Possibilities for further progress are limited by wider neoliberal processes of institutionalisation evidenced in the polarisation of the NGO-grassroots relationship, as the NGO itself has been required to professionalize and formalise its network relationships in line with good governance funding requirements. The thesis is original in several aspects - in the new ways it combines literatures on professionalisation, neoliberal managerially, transnational networks, women's grassroots organising, NGOs and development; in re-visiting popular urban women's organising in Peru, which has become seen as an exemplar of community self-help; and in its engagement with women's grassroots organising around reproductive health, which has received little attention. The thesis raises questions about the future for grassroots activists, who are left in limbo - lacking the skills required to function independently of the NGO, yet no longer fitting the NGO's wider agenda, despite the core role that representations of grassroots actors play in securing international funding. The research suggests a need to re-examine more closely the role of grassroots actors in development, with a particular emphasis on exploring the lessons to be learnt from long term social movement activists.

Title: Encircling the dance: social mobility through the transformation of performance in urban Senegal.
Abstract: This thesis looks at the social significance of dance in Dakar, Senegal, both as an everyday practice and as a performing art.  The boundaries commonly drawn between stage and mundane performance are shown to be irrelevant, as people circulate between performance spaces and dance forms.  The dance itself is described as an elusive way of constructing identity.  Most importantly, this thesis introduces dance as a vehicle of social mobility in its multiple dimensions, as an instrument in the politics of ethnicity, and as a site of negotiations of gender relations.  The complex interplay between the agency of local dancers and global performing circuits is also examined.  Transformations in the social status of performers are traced through time, space and across three genres of performance: the sabar , central in what I call "women's dances", folkloric performance and recent choreographic experiments, often misleadingly labelled "contemporary dance". The sabar and women's dance events are examined both as the local movement style that informs part of the choreographic work displayed on stage, and as a space in which alternative gender relations are experimented with.  I suggest that urban dance events have become increasingly dominated by women, for whom the dance is a convenient way of excluding men from their sociality.  Women are thus able to retain the control of important aspects of social life (including the socialization of young girls, marriage negotiations, exchanging secrets on how to "tie" a husband), engage in trade and coach each other into small-scale business.  Alongside the celebration of female solidarity, dance events are also moments of intense female competition.  This is achieved through fashion, sexually explicit dancing and elaborate manipulation of the body.  I argue that in a depressed economic climate which as turned to the disadvantage of many men, women are discreetly using their favourite form of sociality - dance events - to make advances into the socio-economic domain.

Title: The politics of pressure: group campaigning for and against European integration in Britain, 1997-2003
Abstract: In recent decades, European integration has made significant advances such as Economic and Monetary Union and the creation of a draft Constitution.  However, public backing for the European project has diminished drastically, with several No votes in referenda on European integration issues and a rise in voter support for Eurosceptic political parties, and the EU institutions have been much-criticised for their alleged 'democratic deficit'.  This thesis considers whether campaign groups have played any part in widening or narrowing the gap between public and elite support for European integration in Britain over the period 1997-2003.  While pro-European and Eurosceptic campaign groups have emerged in several EU member states, their existence has been largely overlooked by social scientists research European integration in favour of a focus on government and political parties.  We explore these groups' significance and function by undertaking a sociological analysis of the emergence, activities and impact of groups campaigning over European integration in Britain, which addresses two questions: first, whether groups have created new spaces for political participation among citizens, and secondly, whether groups have formed new channels for communication among citizens and between citizens and political elites. The thesis tests whether theories developed in social movement research can profitably be extended to study this sector of campaign groups that act primarily within institutionalised politics, aiming to contribute to the growing body of literature examining European integration from a sociological perspective.  A multi-method approach is used, combining quantitative (social network analysis, media content analysing, frame analysis, survey data) and qualitative (semi-structured interviewing) techniques.  We examine the political opportunities that shaped group mobilisation, the national and transnational networks of alliance, opposition and influence groups established, the campaign strategies they employed and how they framed European integration. Finally, we present a framework for evaluating group impact, and examine what success groups had in influencing the course of European integration in Britain.

Title: Students and the struggle for democracy in sub-saharan africa 1995-2005: with a focus on senegal and zimbabwe
Abstract: This thesis examines students as agents of political change in sub-Saharan Africa.  It explores the extent to which students exercise political agency, and the ways in which opportunities for agency are shaped by historical and geographical circumstances.  It is argued that in post-colonial Africa students are, in many respects, politically privileged actors.  This is attributable to a host of factors including the relative weaknesses of other social groups; the cultural status of education; the small numbers who make it to university; their shared identity with political leadership; the need of the state for graduates and the nature of campus life.  However, structural factors intervene, shaping a wider political and economic context and the way students exercise agency.  These processes are today associated with globalisation and related to the neo-liberal agenda of international financial institutions (IFIs); World Bank pressures on education systems and the role of non-governmental organisations (NGOs). Within these wider structural changes students do, however, exercise political agency to a varied extent. The two case studies in the thesis are based on interviews with leading student activists and archival research and focus on similar moments of political activism.  In the late 1990s both Zimbabwe and Senegal under went important 'transitions'.  In Zimbabwe it resulted in the formation of a mass party, the Movement for Democratic Change (MDC), in 1999 after a period of widespread social protests.  As the regime regained momentum after the formation of the MDC the 'transition' became increasingly frustrated.  Student activists were involved in each stage of this political ferment.  Although Senegal did not see mass mobilisation, the country experienced an important 'electoral transition'.

Title: The mystical theology of Jessie Penn-Lewis (1861-1927).
Abstract: This thesis examines the life and mystical theology of Jessie Penn-Lewis (1861 -1927), It undertakes an analysis of the mystical theology of Jessie Penn-Lewis whereby I demonstrate that Penn­-Lewis was part of the classical mystical tradition, over and against the Quietism operative within the Keswick Conventions of her day.  Following a brief summary of her life, international ministry, and mystical writings, I show that Penn-Lewis's mystical path engaged suffering in the soul's ascent to union with the Divine and this separated her from the Quietists who insisted upon the one-act of passivity in reaching the highest mystical states.  I trace the Quietism within the early Keswick Conventions to a mishandling of the Prayer of Simple Regard by Quietists such as Madame Guyon and Thomas Upham .   Upham's reshaping of Guyon's Quietism was readily assimilated by leaders within the early Keswick Conventions, excluding Mrs.  Jessie Penn-Lewis who could not tolerate the passivity and absorption of the will demanded by Quietism.  Penn­-Lewis's mystical theology, also called Cross Theology, was nurtured by the Romantic mood of the day, and was thus rooted in personal religious experiences, including the experience of suffering.  In this way Cross Theology combines the apophatic tradition of Bonaventure with an experience of suffering, in the soul's ascent, such that Cross Theology opposes the shallow mysticism of Keswiek's Quietists who rejected effort and suffering in the path toward the unitive state.  Penn-Lewis's mysticism also advances an egalitarian theology that challenged leaders within the Keswick Movement to consider the social ramifications of women's union with Christ.  According to Penn-Lewis, women who are united with Christ bear the fruits and responsibilities of the highest mystical state, just as men.  Cross Theology therefore had social consequences manifest in women's equal service beside men in Christian work.  Penn-Lewis's mysticism was central to her ministry, her interpretation of scripture and her activism on behalf of women.  Thus Penn-Lewis was a Protestant mystic whose mysticism gave shape to an egalitarian agenda that challenged the gender bias of the Church at the turn of the century.
